DOC.HEAD: Barry Turns Over Duties to Aide After Cocaine Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf: ``Barry, the,'' to note differing account that coat comking on, not shirt coming off, when arrest made
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry turned over ``the duties and functions'' of his office to an aide Friday after being formally charged with drug possession in an FBI sting that officials said included a videotape of Barry smoking crack cocaine. Barry did not give up his office, which he has held for 11 years, and retained authority to sign and veto legislation and approve contracts. The drug charge added to the turbulence of the political situation in the nation's capital, where Barry had already been under fire and the list of challengers for next November's election had been growing. Jesse Jackson, the leader in early polls though he has said he would not run against Barry, said Friday he felt only sorrow about the new development and would not talk politics. Federal prosecutors said Barry tested positive for cocaine in blood and urine tests after he was taken into custody Thursday night at a Washington hotel. His lawyer said Friday he would plead innocent to the charge. The FBI used a woman to get Barry to the hotel room, said a law enforcement source who spoke on condition of anonymity. The woman was identified by sources familiar with the case as Rasheeda Moore. One source said Ms. Moore agreed to cooperate with the FBI's investigation of Barry after she got into trouble with state authorities in California. The Washington Times said in an extra edition Friday afternoon that Ms. Moore, according to one law enforcement source, agreed to cooperate with the FBI because she believed Barry ``needed help because he had been addicted before and had been showing signs of being addicted again.'' According to the newspaper's account, she invited Barry to a party at the hotel. But three of the party-goers were FBI agents. Barry, the newspaper said, was taking off his shirt when arrested. But a narrative of the same events described by The Washington Post in Saturday morning editions said Barry ``had just started'' to put on his coat as if to leave when agents burst in to announce, ``You are under arrest. Remain still.'' Sources for the two accounts were not named. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens denied that the mayor had been unlawfully entrapped by the operation, saying prosecutors had found evidence of Barry's predisposition to commit drug-related crimes. ``Wherever there is predisposition there is not entrapment,'' said Stephens. ``It was scrupulously fair to the subject of the investigation, Mr. Barry.'' After Friday's brief court hearing, in even briefer remarks to reporters swarming around the Federal Courthouse, Barry said, ``I'm going to leave here and go about the business of government.'' But the mayor's office issued a statement later which said he was temporarily giving up his day-to-day mayor's chores because of a ``need for time to handle his legal matters, his concern for his family, and because it is in the best interests of the citizens of Washington, D.C.'' He has been plagued in recent years by accusations of drug use as well as the corruption convictions of several top city officials. He has repeatedly denied ever using or buying drugs. Barry had indicated he would seek a fourth term this November, though opposing candidates have proliferated as his troubles have mounted. A formal Barry candidacy announcement, scheduled for Sunday, was postponed indefinitely. Former Democratic presidential candidate Jackson, who has campaigned against drugs across the country, fueled speculation he would run for mayor when he moved to Washington last year. But Jackson also has said he would not directly challenge Barry, a former civil rights colleague. Jackson said Friday in Chicago that the Barry matter should be ``handled in a courtroom, not a newsroom'' and that he was ``in no mood'' to deal with questions about politics. In the statement released by his office, Barry said, ``I want to assure my friends, colleagues, supporters, fellow citizens, the business community and the nation that this government will continue to operate at maximum performance. I know I have a team of competent professionals who will continue to run the affairs of government while I devote some time to my legal case.'' The statement, which said he was turning over day-to-day mayor's duties to city administrator Carol Thompson, was released after he huddled with cabinet members and political advisers. Sources commenting on condition they not be named said several cabinet members threatened to resign if Barry did not step aside from most city affairs. If convicted, the mayor could face penalties of up to one year in jail and a $100,000 fine, said U.S. Attorney Stephens. Barry was arrested at an FBI-rented hotel room that was being watched through a surveillance camera. He gave ``a quantity of currency'' to a cooperating witness in return for the crack, according to court papers filed by federal prosecutors. ``Mr. Barry put some of the crack cocaine in a smoking apparatus, lit the crack cocaine and smoked it,'' FBI agent Ronald Stern said in an affidavit. ``I observed Mr. Barry ... inhale on the lit smoking apparatus.'' Federal agents then entered the hotel room and arrested the mayor, who officials said later tested positive for cocaine when blood and urine tests were given under a warrant. He was taken to FBI headquarters and released on his own recognizance. Officers also took samples of the mayor's hair, which law enforcement authorities say can be used to determine drug use. Stephens said that Barry went to the Vista Hotel ``in his limousine, accompanied by security guards. He entered on his own volition. He went to the seventh floor on his own free will. He put himself in that situation.'' The prosecutor said the mayor's arrest was part of a continuing investigation of a ``broad range of allegations'' against Barry. He later specified that the probe deals with fraud and city contracts as well as narcotics. U.S. Magistrate Deborah Robinson allowed the mayor to remain free but ordered him to undergo drug tests every Monday. He also must make weekly phone calls to a pretrial services agency and will face another court appearance Feb. 5. Barry's court appearance came less than two hours before the sentencing of Charles Lewis, a former friend of the mayor and now a cooperating government witness against Barry, for conspiracy to distribute cocaine. When Lewis pleaded guilty to the charge last year, he told the judge he had given cocaine to the mayor. Lewis was sentenced to 15 months in prison, but was given credit for time served and is to be released in May.

DOC.HEAD: New Official Opposed by AIDS Activists
DOC.TEXT: Indiana state Health Commissioner Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. was named New York City's top health official Friday despite opposition to his AIDS policies by gay rights activists and a prominent AIDS researcher. Mayor David N. Dinkins announced the appointment of Myers as city health commissioner just one day after several supporters on a search committee withdrew their backing. Among those who stopped supporting Myers was Dr. Mathilde Krim, co-founder of the American Foundation on AIDS Research. Myers supports Indiana laws to keep government lists of those infected with the AIDS virus and to quarantine people who knowingly infect others. The Indiana official has said he wouldn't impose such policies in New York and would support the policies of Dinkins, who opposes quarantines and government lists. Despite the controversial AIDS policies in Indiana, Myers has a national reputation as an AIDS expert. He is credited with encouraging Indiana doctors to treat AIDS patients and was instrumental in arranging schooling for Ryan White, a teen-age AIDS-afflicted hemopheliac who received national attention when a local school board refused to enroll him. Myers also made headlines by resigning from his post as vice chairman of the President's Commission on HIV under Ronald Reagan to protest what he said were inadequacies with the group. HIV, or the human immunodeficiency virus, causes AIDS. On Thursday, Krim and several other members of the search committee withdrew support from him. Krim cited ``profound differences'' between Myers' views and ``desirable public health policies.'' ``I'm not the insensitive, brutish fiend that some people have tried to make me out to be,'' Myers said this week. Myers on Friday underscored that, saying ``quarantine is not an effective health strategy.'' Myers, 35, will earn $110,000 a year as commissioner and also get an annual $22,000 supplement as an assistant professor of medicine at the Cornell University Medical School. In outlining the challenges facing the appointee, Dinkins referred to a recent study that found a man in Bangladesh has a better chance of living past age 40 than a man in Harlem. ``The causes of this shocking finding will set the agenda for the new health commissioner: drug and alcohol abuse, cirrhosis, violence and the spread of disease, including the AIDS epidemic,'' Dinkins said. There have been 23,000 AIDS cases in New York and 12,000 have died. At least 200,000 New Yorkers, and perhaps nearly twice that many, have been infected with the virus. Protests continued Friday afternoon, with about 75 members of the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power picketing in front of City Hall, chanting, ``No testing. No quarantine. No Myers. No way.'' There were no arrests. Indiana law requires the reporting by name of any person who tests positive for the human immunodeficiency virus. The names of infected people are collected and stored in confidential files at the state Board of Health. The information is used to contact sex partners deemed at risk and to target state prevention efforts.

DOC.HEAD: South Florida Beaches Covered With Oil, Jellyfish
DOC.TEXT: Sticky gobs of oil and grotesque Portuguese men-of-war, blown ashore by an east wind, have made the footing treacherous on some beaches in south Florida. The Coast Guard hadn't determined the source of the tar-like glop washed by strong winds and surf onto beaches around Fort Lauderdale. ``It's wet and clinging to everything that's floating,'' said area resident Pauline Gerweck. ``Tourists are coming out covered head to toe. ... This is scandalous.'' The jellyfish-like men-of-war, whose sting can be dangerous to the allergic, are flopping ashore from the Keys to Jupiter in Palm Beach County, about a 200-mile stretch. But few stings have been reported because bathers are staying out of the water, which has been stirred by rainshowers and rough seas. ``I think with all the warnings, people are staying out of the water,'' Bonnetta Kaplan, a lifeguard in Pompano Beach, said Wednesday. ``When something like this happens, we load the beach with signs.'' Two weeks ago, hundreds of swimmers were stung in south Florida when swarms of the jellyfish washed up on the beaches. ``That coincided with some real nice sunny weather,'' said Capt. Bill Pallowick of the Fort Lauderdale Beach Patrol. ``There are probably 10 times more of them out there today, but the weather is not good.'' It was harder for beach-going tourists to avoid the tar spots. Jim Haskell, a tourist from Newburyport, Mass., said the soles of his feet were black with oil after he strolled near Anglin's Pier in Lauderdale-by-the-Sea. ``There were some little kids in the surf and they were just covered with it,'' Haskell said. Coast Guard officer Pete Thiel, in Fort Lauderdale, said the Coast Guard twice inspected tankers anchored off the city's coast on Wednesday but found no evidence of leaks. Huge oil tankers enter and leave Port Everglades daily and frequently anchor off Fort Lauderdale. Thiel said tankers sometimes pump oily bilge water into the ocean in violation of federal law.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agent Killed in Shoot-Out with Robbery Suspect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to correct category code.
DOC.TEXT: An FBI agent and a bank robbery suspect were killed, and two FBI agents were wounded in a shootout at a home Friday night, authorities said. The agents, who were members of a SWAT team, were executing a search warrant about 7:15 p.m. in south St. Louis County when the suspect opened fire with a shotgun, FBI spokesman David Binney said. The names of the agents weren't immediately available. The agent who was killed was pronounced dead at 9 p.m. at St. Anthony's Hospital, Binney said. Wounds to the other two agents weren't believed to be serious. One of the agents was shot in the arm and the other was shot in the leg. Both were taken to St. Anthony's Hospital, Binney said. The suspect was identified as James Price, 45. The agents were looking for money taken in a Jan. 3 robbery of Community Savings & Loan near Price's home, Binney said. ``We used a SWAT team because we had information that the man was armed and dangerous,'' Binney said. ``The SWAT team penetrated the door and shooting occurred.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Rose From Sharecropper's Son
With AM-DC Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry Jr. was a sharecropper's son who used the streetwise bravado he learned as a civil rights activist to become a savvy political insider who served more than a decade as mayor of the nation's capital. Always claiming he could move as easily among royalty as among the city's poor, Barry shrugged off scandals involving top aides and allegations of drug abuse to win election three times to the city's top position. During his tenure, Barry made the most of the limited power of the city's home rule charter to make himself the undisputed leader of the city government. But Barry was also under federal investigation during much of the period between 1984 and 1990 for his ties to drug suspects. Several of his friends have gone to jail and recent news reports suggested the wall of silence that prosecutors had tried to penetrate was crumbling as some former associates testified before a grand jury. Barry has always called himself a survivor, pointing to the gunshot wound he suffered in the city hall building in 1977 as an example of how he could never be counted out. ``He is not going to go out quietly,'' said Max Berry, a former key political adviser, after the arrest. Berry, who turned against Barry after the mayor's troubles last year, added: ``If he has not been telling the truth to the people, he's going to face the possibility of resigning, but he has always been a strong campaigner and a proud person. What kind of effect this will have on his ego, I don't know.'' Indeed, Barry's most recent boasts of political power were earlier this month. A Los Angeles Times profile got him into political hot water when he was quoted as boasting that he would cut his opponents ``off at the kneecaps'' and that Jesse Jackson, whom Barry had supported, ``don't wanna run nothing but his mouth.'' Barry and his third wife, Effi, have one son, Christopher, who is 10. Barry was born on March 6, 1936 to Marion and Mattie Barry, in the small Mississippi delta town of Itta Bena, and was raised in Memphis after the death of his father, a sharecropper. ``My background is one of survival,'' Barry told The Washington Post a month before his first election as mayor in 1978. ``I mean I was lucky, you know. I used to run around with guys who went to prison or are dead. I was lucky. I was the one who didn't get caught by the police when we were out shooting dice or something.'' Barry did graduate work in chemistry at Fisk University in Nashville, but was sidetracked on his way to a doctorate by the growing civil rights movement and left school with a master's degree. He was the first national chairman of the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee, which sent young people into the South to register black voters. It was SNCC that brought him to Washington, where he became immersed in local issues, joining boycotts of the bus system. With his second wife, Mary Treadwell, he helped found a black self-help group, Pride, Inc. Treadwell was convicted in 1983 of misusing funds in connection with a real estate spinoff of Pride. It was Barry's high profile as an anti-establishment activist that propelled him into local politics, first as a member of the Board of Education and then in 1974 as a member of the first elected City Council organized under the home rule legislation. He suffered his first personal crisis in 1977 when he was wounded by a shotgun blast in the Hanafi Muslim takeover of the District Building, the district's city hall. A young reporter was killed. In 1978, he defeated incumbent Mayor Walter Washington in the city's Democratic mayoral primary and went on to easily win the general election, taking over a government he had railed against only a decade before. ``I want to take the boards off of houses and put people in them, I want to provide minimal care for all people, regardless of their financial situation and I want to live out (Dr. Martin Luther) King's legacy of peace, brotherhood and survival,'' he said shortly after being sworn in. His tenure has been noted for extensive downtown office and hotel development, a soaring murder rate among young drug users and, critics charge, deterioration of services like housing despite the largest city bureaucracy in the country on a per-capita basis. His troubles began shortly after his first re-election in 1982, with the first of federal investigations he termed attempts to ``lynch black people another way.'' In 1984, Karen Johnson, a convicted cocaine dealer with whom Barry admitted having a ``personal'' relationship, served 11 months in jail on contempt of court charges rather than tell investigators whether she used drugs with or sold them to the mayor. The current round of investigation was touched off in December 1988, when Barry repeatedly visited the hotel room of a suspected drug dealer. That man, Charles Lewis, was later convicted of cocaine charges in the Virgin Islands and has pleaded guilty to a drug conspiracy count in Washington. There have been recent news reports that Lewis had told prosecutors he had provided drugs to the mayor.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Say Government Secrecy Thwarts Defense
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs with UPDATE with accusations that government tried to intimidate witnesses. Picks up 5th graf pvs, ```There is...'
DOC.TEXT: The government tried Thursday to intimidate witnesses who testified for one of Manuel Noriega's co-defendents by threatening them with immigration agents who questioned their legal status, a defense attorney charged. The agents demanded that three witnesses who testified for Luis del Cid on Tuesday turn over all their immigration papers and give information about how they obtained passports into the United States, said Samuel Burstyn, del Cid's attorney. Burstyn filed a motion late Thursday asking U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler to order the government to refrain from contacting defense witnesses without their permission. Burstyn told the Associated Press that he hoped to hear Friday morning when Hoeveler would grant a hearing on his emergency motion. The U.S. Attorney's office had no immediate comment. Earlier Thursday, defense attorneys accused the government of balking at court orders to turn over both secret and non-secret documents to aid the defense in the case against Noriega and his co-defendants. And a lawyer for convicted drug kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas strongly denied his client will cooperate with the government to convict the deposed Panamanian leader, despite a taped interview the imprisoned trafficker gave implicating Noriega. On Wednesday, Hoeveler announced a March 5 trial date for Noriega and the other defendants after Burstyn demanded his client's right to a speedy trial. Burstyn said he hoped the date _ far earlier than the nine months to two years most attorneys had anticipated _ would force the government to cease dragging its feet on documents. ``There is a desire to stonewall information,'' Burstyn said. ``It's an effort to hermetically seal off the guts and gore of the early investigation.'' He emphasized he has not yet requested CIA or other sensitive records, only routine matters such as the prior criminal record of Floyd Carlton Carceres, the former Noriega pilot whose testimony helped bring about the February 1988 drug-trafficking indictment. U.S. attorney's office spokeswoman Diane Cossin refused to comment, beyond saying defense attorneys ``should do as instructed and not try this case in the media.'' One attorney who has unsuccessfully sought secret material is Michael O'Kane, lawyer for accused drug pilot Daniel Miranda. When he requested information from a National Security Agency listening post in Panama City, prosecutors threatened to try him just for revealing its existence. ``I tend to think that a lot of this case is going to go away, because I don't think that a lot of the intelligence agencies want to reveal things,'' O'Kane said. He said Noriega was a CIA asset since at least the 1960s, and noted the case of CIA agent Joe Fernandez, whose indictment in the Iran-Contra affair was eventually dropped because the government feared the trial would reveal too many secrets. ``Joe Fernandez's case had to be dismissed, and Joe Fernandez was a pipsqueak compared to Noriega,'' O'Kane said. The lawyer said that from the reaction of the U.S. attorney's office to requests for information, he suspected the prosecturs were not receiving cooperation from Washington agencies. ``I don't think anyone is telling them just what the situation is,'' he said. Speculation that the government may have the help of testimony from convicted Medellin cartel trafficker Lehder was dismissed by Lehder's attorney, Jose Quinon. In a prison interview with the West German magazine Stern, recorded in November and broadcast Wednesday on NBC News, Lehder said he had paid Noriega several million dollars for protection. Lehder also said Noriega confiscated drugs and processing equipment, then sold it to drug dealers in Colombia, Panama and the United States. Quinon said Thursday that the interview was Lehder's idea, and was no indication he planned to cooperate with prosecutors trying Noriega. ``He will be no witness against Noriega, there is no deal, there's no cooperation with the government,'' Quinon said. The U.S. attorney's office spokeswoman, Ms. Cossin, said she could not reveal the names of witnesses.

DOC.HEAD: Best-Selling Single Becoming History Lesson Tool
DOC.TEXT: Welcome to sophomore history, a look at post-World War II global events. Now put on your headphones and pump up the volume, dude. It's the classroom of the '90s, where Billy Joel's No. 1 single ``We Didn't Start the Fire'' will soon have teachers turning to their turntables to help students learn about history from Harry Truman to Tiananmen Square. A special cassette version of the rapid-fire single, including a 10-minute talk by Joel, will be provided to 40,000 junior and senior high school students nationwide, according to the singer's label, CBS Records. ``A lot of people tend to think history is just this drab series of boring names and dates that you just have to connect to pass the test,'' Joel says on the tape. ``Really, history is a living thing. We are where we are today, and we are who we are today, because of our history.'' Joel says he's received letters from both teachers and students about the song, his highest-charting single since ``Uptown Girl'' in November 1983. The Grammy-winning singer-songwriter also reveals on the tape that he once considered a career as a history teacher. The cassette will be distributed in conjunction with Scholastic magazine; teachers will receive a poster-sized copy of the lyrics and a lesson plan to aid them. The tapes will be sent out with the Jan. 26 issue of Junior Scholastic magazine, for junior high school students, and Update magazine, for high schoolers, said Scholastic public relations manager Stephanie Feuer. ``We're trying to create a bridge between the classroom and what's going on in the outside world,'' said Ms. Feuer. ``We're bringing their world into the classroom.'' Joel packs enough images into the song to fill a few volumes of the World Book: He begins with Harry Truman, touches on the Korean War, ``trouble in the Suez,'' ``Belgians in the Congo,'' the JFK assassination, then wraps it up with a string of current events climaxing with ``rock and roller cola wars.'' Each year from 1949 through 1963 gets a verse; USA Today described it as ``musical Cliff Notes.'' Joel, in an interview with Rolling Stone, said teachers have told him the song is ``the greatest teaching tool to come down the pike since Sesame Street, which means a lot to me.'' A fifth-grade class at the Banta Elementary School in Menasha, Wis., used the song lyrics last year to select topics for history reports. The single is from Joel's ``Storm Front'' album; its success has not been limited to the United States. ``We Didn't Start the Fire'' has gone Top Five in Canada, Australia, Japan and Germany, while hitting the Top 10 in England, Holland, Norway and New Zealand. Joel's interests weren't strictly educational _ there is a record to be sold, as Ms. Feuer noted. ``These kids are part of the record-buying public, and he hasn't had a No. 1 record in six, seven years,'' she said. ``The record company wanted to do something a little different.''

DOC.HEAD: McMartin Child Abuse Case Changed Social, Legal Landscape
DOC.TEXT: It began as the nation's largest child abuse case and ended as the nation's longest trial. In the six years between, the McMartin Pre-School case helped incite a revolution in the way society treats its youngest victims. It was August 1983 when a woman named Judy Johnson called the police in Manhattan Beach, Calif., to say that her son had a red bottom and was talking about a man named Ray. Ray worked at the McMartin Pre-School. What followed was a nightmare _ a legal case that became too long, too cumbersome, too expensive and too traumatic. It ended Thursday with the jury acquitting the defendants of 52 charges and declaring themselves hopelessly deadlocked on the remaining 13. Regardless of the outcome, experts say the case has led to fundamental changes in the way society looks at child abuse. ``McMartin made it evident to everyone working with kids and the legal system that there had to be some changes,'' said Nancy Peterson, a spokeswoman for the Chicago-based National Committee for Prevention of Child Abuse. ``I think that it's safe to say that it has influenced a great deal of reform on behalf of kids.'' Some of those reforms have been in the regulation of child care. Many states now require background checks, including fingerprints, for all child care workers. There also is a growing emphasis on training, so that teachers and child care workers, as well as parents and children, know how to recognize the signs of sexual abuse. The unfortunate legacy of McMartin may be the suspicion it cast on an overwhelmingly innocent group of people _ the adults who care for children in day-care centers and nursery schools. A study by the American Association for Protecting Children showed that about 65 percent of child abuse cases involved an older relative of the child, and only about 5 percent involved baby sitters or child care workers. Other studies have shown the percentage of sexual abuse cases involving child care workers to be as low as half of 1 percent. It's hard to say just how many of the changes in child care legislation can be traced to the McMartin case. Interest in child care had been rising as more women entered the workplace. And there have been other notorious child abuse cases. In one of the most recent, seven people in Edenton, N.C., were charged with sexually abusing at least 70 children at a day-care center. So the argument can be made that McMartin was only one of many influences, and that change would have occurred anyway. ``The McMartin case was the first one to gain national notoriety. I'm not sure still, though, that it had that much of an impact,'' said Katie Bond of the Denver-based American Association for Protecting Children. Others say its influence has been profound. ``First and foremost, there has been an enormous increase in awareness of abuse of children under the age of 6. ... That is a whole domain that didn't exist prior to McMartin, really,'' said David Finklehor, co-director of the Family Research Laboratory at the University of New Hampshire. ``Secondly, there's been quite a revolution in the investigation and handling of sexual abuse cases in the criminal justice system, and that can be traced to McMartin.'' For instance, investigators, prosecutors and judges are now frequently trained to deal with the victims of child abuse, and some prosecutors employ counselors and other specialists to assist them. In the McMartin case, hundreds of children initially told investigators that they had been sexually abused, but many of their accounts were later disregarded as false responses to leading questions. Prosecutors were forced to whittle down their case from hundreds of charges against seven defendants to 65 charges against two defendants. Investigators since have been taught ``to be less leading, more objective, and to avoid even the appearance of rewarding the children for being forthcoming,'' Finklehor said. Courtroom procedures in some places have been tailored to the very young, so they aren't intimidated by formality or legalese. In some cases, children are allowed to sit on a parent's lap while testifying. Some changes have been controversial. The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in 1988 that an Iowa man was improperly convicted of sexual assault because he wasn't allowed to face his 13-year-old accusers _ they testified with a screen blocking their view of the defendant. This week, the court agreed to review two more sexual abuse cases. In one, four children in Maryland were allowed to testify with only a prosecutor and a defense lawyer present. In the other, in Idaho, a pediatrician was allowed to describe what a 2-year-old girl told him _ testimony that in adult cases would be considered hearsay.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Crime Down After Crackdown on Nightspots
DOC.TEXT: South Korea's crime rate has declined by about a third since the government ordered nightspots to close before midnight starting this year, police said today. Police reported 7,859 crimes nationally in the first half of this month, down 29 percent from the same period in December. Except for those at tourist hotels, terminals and railway stations, nightspots were ordered to shut down before midnight this year in an effort to halt a sudden increase in crime. Police and government officials have raided beer halls, discos, bars, cabarets and nightclubs and punished owners who violate the new regulations.

DOC.HEAD: `Life After AIDS' Improving, Two Studies Indicate
DOC.TEXT: Life expectancies are improving for AIDS patients diagnosed with a certain type of pneumonia, raising hope that the once uniformly fatal disease is becoming a ``chronic, manageable'' one, researchers say. Two studies published in today's Journal of the American Medical Association indicate adults initially diagnosed with AIDS and with a pneumonia known as PCP are surviving significantly longer than they did in the early 1980s. PCP, or pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, is the most common AIDS-related infection and has been considered one of the most quickly fatal diseases that can overwhelm the damaged immune systems of people with AIDS. ``The data in these reports appear to confirm what clinicians, investigators, and patients have known for several years: Life after AIDS is improving and death is no longer as swift and as certain as in the early years of the epidemic,'' said an editorial accompanying the studies. But the dramatic improvement in two-year AIDS survival hasn't been matched by a corresponding improvement in five-year survival, which remains low, said the editorial by Dr. Richard E. Chaisson of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore. New antibiotics to prevent PCP in AIDS patients, and the highly successful anti-AIDS drug zidovudine, formerly called AZT, have produced hope that AIDS has become a ```chronic, manageable disease,''' Chaisson wrote. His editorial accompanied a San Francisco study of 4,323 AIDS patients that found those who were diagnosed in 1982 and who initially had PCP survived a median of 10.3 months. Five years later, that figure had risen to 17.9 months, researchers said. But survival worsened over the same period among AIDS patients initially diagnosed with a type of skin cancer called Kaposi's sarcoma, a common sign of AIDS. Survival declined from a median of 33.9 months to a median of 18 months, the researchers said. The finding may have resulted from a declining proportion of AIDS patients with KS _ patients who are relatively healthy compared with pneumonia patients _ reflecting a shift toward more aggressive forms of AIDS, the researchers said. Among patients diagnosed with other opportunistic infections or malignancies, survival remained the same, the researchers said. For 644 patients treated with zidovudine in the San Francisco study, the drug was a ``significant predictor of survival,'' said the researchers, led by George H. Lemp of the city's Department of Public Health. Zidovudine was released for widespread use in 1986. Overall, in the seven years of the San Francisco study, the median survival of AIDS patients was 12.5 months, and five-year survival was 3.4 percent, said the authors. The other study published in today's Journal looked at adults nationwide who were diagnosed with acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the years 1984 through 1987 and in whom PCP was an early sign of the disease. In patients diagnosed in 1984 and 1985, just 42.7 percent survived a year, the researchers said. By 1986 and 1987, the one-year survival rate had risen to 54.5 percent. ``The gain in survival was observed in homosexual men and intravenous drug users of both sexes, in all age and racial groups, in all geographic regions, and in patients with or without'' other diseases at the time, said the study's author, Dr. Jeffrey E. Harris of Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. ``Better diagnosis and treatment, particularly the introduction of zidovudine, may have contributed to the decline in mortality,'' he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Party animals along fraternity row at the University of Mississippi have new neighbors _ Methodists carrying a code of behavior. The university's Wesley Foundation, a United Methodist group, started moving into the former Beta Theta Pi house last week. The white Beta Theta Pi fraternity was dissolved by Chancellor Gerald Turner after two members were dumped nude Sept. 18 at black Rust College in Holly Springs. Racial slurs had been scrawled on their bodies. ``We're glad something positive has come out of something so negative and unfortunate,'' said Kerby Bowling II, Beta Theta Phi House Corporation president at the university. The Methodist group had been looking for a place to set up a student center when Beta Theta Pi inquired in October, said Wade Holland, the foundation's adviser and associate pastor of Oxford University United Methodist Church. After two months of negotiations, Beta Theta Pi agreed to lease the house to the foundation until May 1991, when the fraternity will be eligible to reapply to organize at Ole Miss. Sixteen male students will live in the house. No alcohol will be allowed. Visitation times for women will be set, too. Each resident will be responsible for cleaning a section of the house. ``I made sure they understood this is not a fraternity,'' Holland said. ``It's a Christian environment. They must agree to the standards before they can live in this place.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed at 146.33 yen on the Tokyo Foreign Exchange Market on Friday, up 0.67 yen from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Women Without Symptoms can Spread Genital Herpes
DOC.TEXT: Most of the 30 million Americans who have genital herpes probably will never know they are infected, researchers believe, and a new study indicates that women without symptoms can easily spread the disease. In the study, 27 women with genital herpes simplex virus infections that produced recurrent sores underwent daily home tests to detect whether they were giving off the virus even when they didn't have sores. Though such viral ``shedding'' in the absence of symptoms has been detected in previous studies of women with genital herpes, never before has a study tried to determine how often it occurs, authors of the study said. Subjects self-tested themselves at home at least three times a week for three weeks, and the tests revealed that seven were giving off virus, the researchers said. The ``shedding'' occurred during 1 percent of the total days on which home tests were performed, the researchers reported. ``These data suggest that all women with recurrent genital herpes simplex virus infection should be instructed about the possible risk, albeit infrequent, of asymptomatically shedding virus from the genital tract,'' the authors said in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. Men also can spread the virus in the absence of sores, previous studies have shown. All women who underwent the home test on more than 100 days were found to be shedding virus on at least one occasion, and the same was true of 80 percent of women who underwent tests on more than 50 days, the researchers said. The researchers said if tested frequently, ``probably all women'' with recurrent genital HSV infection would shed the virus even if they didn't have sores. Shedding was not related to age, contraceptive practices or frequency of recurrence of genital sores, the researchers said. Nor did it occur more often in any one location on the genitals, said the researchers, led by Brigit V. Brock and Dr. Lawrence Corey of the University of Washington at Seattle. ``What's new is that they (the researchers) looked at the sites of shedding in women,'' said Dr. Stephen Straus, head of medical virology at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md. ``And they looked a little better than those (who) had done so previously in terms of how long you have to test a person before you find it,'' he said in a telephone interview Thursday. Genital herpes, an incurable and lifelong infection that is spread through sexual contact, lies dormant most of the time but can erupt in painful sores or blisters. ``Existing data suggest that about two-thirds of people who have been infected never know it,'' Straus said. ``When they transmit it, that is of course asymptomatic.'' Genital herpes is usually mild in adults, but each year 250 to 500 U.S. babies are born with severe herpes simplex 2 infections they inherit from a parent, Straus said. Some of the babies have severe developmental problems, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Mayor Arrested on Drug Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 16th graf, ``Barry was xxx'' to update with Barry returning to his house.''
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, his last years in office tarnished by accusations of drug use, was arrested on a narcotics charge Thursday night in what federal authorities described as ``an ongoing public corruption probe.'' A federal law enforcement source said authorities had a videotape of Barry smoking cocaine. Barry's arrest at a downtown hotel came just three days before the mayor planned to formally announce that he would seek re-election to a fourth term and a day before long-time Barry associate Charles Lewis was scheduled for sentencing on drug charges. Lewis testified in federal court that he provided cocaine for the mayor, but it was not clear whether Thursday night's arrest was connected to the Lewis investigation. Barry has steadfastly denied that he used drugs. The law enforcement source, who spoke on condition he not be identified, said the probe was designed to catch Barry with an illegal drug, and that authorities had Barry on film. The source said cocaine was seized from the hotel room but that specific charges would not be lodged until the substance could be analyzed. He said enough cocaine was seized to charge the mayor with possession for personal use. The U.S. attorney's office said Barry would appear before a federal magistrate for arraignment on drug charges Friday. A second federal law enforcement source said the arrest was the result of as ``sting'' operation in which FBI agents observed a prearranged meeting between the mayor and an unidentified friend in a downtown hotel, the Vista International, about six blocks from the White House. The undercover operation, which had been in place for several weeks, involved setting up film equipment to photograph and record the mayor in the hotel room, sources said. Barry, 53, was arrested at the hotel shortly after 8 p.m. as a result of an undercover operation conducted jointly by the city police department's internal affairs division and the FBI, according to a statement by U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens and Thomas DuHadway, special agent in charge of the FBI's Washington office. There was no word of additional arrests. City police officers barred access to upper floors of the hotel to all but guests. A dozen or so teen-agers mixed with reporters, discussing the arrest, outside. A city official who asked not to be identified said Barry had no events on his schedule at the hotel Thursday night. First word of the arrest was broadcast shortly after 10 p.m. by television station WRC, which said the mayor attempted to buy cocaine on the seventh floor. The mayor, the city's second under home rule, was led away by undercover police officers and FBI agents, the station said, and his driver and bodyguard were led away separately. Barry was taken to the FBI's national headquarters, said federal sources who asked not to be identified. He returned to his home in the Southeast section of the city after midnight, accompanied by FBI agents and Herbert O. Reid, a long-time adviser and the city's attorney, Barry, who has repeatedly won re-election with large majorities, has lost support over the past four years because of allegations of drug use and corruption convictions against several members of his administration. Jesse Jackson fueled speculation that he would challenge Barry when he moved to Washington last year. However, Jackson has said repeatedly that he would not challenge Barry. Jackson said through a spokesman he would have no comment on the arrest. Drug use among the city's young men is blamed for a sharply rising murder rate _ a record 438 homicides were committed last year against 369 the year before. Top city officials were meeting late Thursday night to assess the arrest. City Council Chairman David Clarke, who is running for mayor, called the arrest ``a tragic moment in our city's history.'' Councilwoman Charlene Jarvis, another mayoral candidate, said the arrest ``changes the political landscape of the city.'' Although rumors about Barry and drugs had surfaced throughout the last half of his tenure as mayor, no charges had been brought before Thursday. The accusations became even more widespread after the arrest of Lewis. Barry was visiting Lewis' hotel room in December 1988 when city police were sent to investigate a report that Lewis was selling drugs. When the officers found out Barry was present, they abandoned their mission in an episode not yet fully explained. Lewis pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to distribute cocaine in Washington, and was scheduled to be sentenced on that charge Friday. Lewis also has been convicted of selling drugs in the Virgin Islands. In November, WUSA-TV said a local physician had reported to police that Barry had been treated for a drug overdose in 1983. The then-police chief later reported that investigators were unable to confirm that report. Karen Johnson, a former city worker with whom Barry eventually admitted a romance, was convicted on various drug charges in 1984. She served several months in prison for refusing to testify about Barry.

DOC.HEAD: Author Shrugs Off Controversy Over US-Japan Book
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese legislator who wrote a book sharply critical of American attitudes toward Japan shrugs off the controversy it is stirring up in the United States. Americans may be unhappy, Shintaro Ishihara says, but the controversy has been great for sales in Japan. Already, 500,000 copies of ``A Japan That Can Say `No''' have been snatched up and he predicted sales will hit 1 million by spring. In an interview Thursday during a trip to Washington to try to calm outraged U.S. policymakers, Ishihara rejected a suggestion that his nationalistic views were out of the mainstream of Japanese public opinion. ``I have many letters from my readers,'' he said. ``Many of them are saying, `How come Americans get mad at those things that are so ordinary that I read in your book?''' While no authorized version of Ishihara's book exists in the United States, copying machines on Capitol Hill have been working overtime to reproduce translations done by U.S. intelligence and defense agencies. Portions of the book have even found their way into the Congressional Record as congressional critics of Japan's trade policies rushed to publicize what they say is a prime example of Japan's arrogance in economic matters. In the book, Ishihara argues that Japan needs to be more assertive in standing up to America. He brags about Japan's technological superiority and calls America's military shield for Japan an illusion. He complains that ``Americans behave more like mad dogs than watch dogs,'' and he dismisses American criticism of Japan as being racially motivated. In the part of the book that attracted the Pentagon's attention, he warns that unless America reforms its policies toward Japan, Tokyo might stop supplying the microchips needed to accurately target U.S. nuclear missiles. Ishihara writes that Japan could sell the chips to the Soviets instead in an action which ``would instantly change the balance of military power.'' In an interview with The Associated Press, Ishihara did not recant any of his comments, but he maintained that the ``pirated'' version now in circulation in Washington leaves out certain clarifying comments. He said he was working to bring out an authorized English-language version of the book by April, although it will lack the contributions of his Japanese coauthor, Sony Corp. Chairman Akio Morita. Morita, who wrote several less inflammatory chapters of the Japanese book, now says he regrets his involvement with the project. Ishihara said he intended for the book to stimulate an honest dialogue between U.S. and Japanese policymakers at a time when relationships between the two countries are in transition. ``We have come to a new era where a redefinition of the U.S.-Japan relationship is called for,'' he said. He said he hoped to arrange a series of debates between members of the Japanese parliament and the U.S. Congress after the upcoming parliamentary elections in February. With Japan accounting for almost half of America's $111 billion annual trade deficit, efforts to stem the flow of Japanese imports and boost U.S. export sales are a prime topic in Congress with various lawmakers urging retaliation against Japanese imports unless the country buys more American products. Ishihara, a member of the conservative Liberal-Democratic Party, was considered one of the frontrunners last year for the prime minister's job which eventually went to Toshiki Kaifu. Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich., met with Ishihara and said afterward he was not optimistic there will be any quick resolution to the trade problems separating the two countries. He called Ishihara's views ``a minority point of view'' but one which American policymakers ``need to take seriously and respond to it.''

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Says U.S. Should Guard Own Borders in Drug Fight
DOC.TEXT: U.S. warships off the coasts of Colombia are unwanted and unneeded in the fight against drugs, says the ambassador from that country. ``I don't think that the sending of vessels or troops to our waters is necessary,'' Colombian Ambassador Victor Mosquera Chaux said Thursday. ``I think U.S. naval forces could begin by trying to control the entry of narcotics within their own waters.'' ``I don't understand why there's so much insistence on military operations when the Colombian military and police forces have shown their capabilities,'' he said at a press conference. Ambassador Cesar Atala Nazal of Peru also said his country would not accept U.S. troops for drug fighting within the country or U.S. vessels in waters offshore ``because they are not necessary at all.'' But Atala dd not rule out limited use of U.S. ships and planes for radar surveillance and aerial tracking. ``What we object to is unilateral decisions made by the United States affecting the internal affairs of our country,'' he said. ``We would like to see what the points are, what the arguments are, what the benefits would be, and you can be sure that the Peruvian government will be absolutely understanding of the arguments presented by the United States government and eventually reach an agreement,'' he said. Defense Department sources said last week that the aircraft carrier USS John F. Kennedy has been chosen to lead an interdiction effort off the Caribbean coast of Colombia but that no final decision had been made on deployment. Word of the proposed deployment touched off rumors that the United States might try to blockade Colombia and there was outrage from Latin American nations that were still angry over the U.S. invasion of Panama. Atala, Mosquera and Bolivian Ambassador Jorge Crespo Velasco appeared at the news conference after testifying before a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate Caucus on International Narcotics. Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., has proposed to offer South American countries debt relief in exchange for concrete activity against the drug trade. Biden said he hoped the idea would appear on the agenda when the leaders of the three countries and the United States hold their drug summit in Colombia Feb. 15. Peruvian President Alan Garcia has said he will not attend the meeting unless all the U.S. invasion forces are out of Panama. Biden expressed interest in a proposal by Peru's Atala and endorsed by Bolivia's Crespo for the U.S. to help purchase the coca leaf crop for a few years while farmers turn to other crops. Atala said Peruvian farmers ``would dream to be on the side of the law'' even if it meant earning slightly less from other crops. Payments to the farmers _ about $234 million for one year's worth of crops _ would find their way into the economy as well, Atala said at the hearing, noting that last year's drug-fighting aid totaled $254 million. ``I am absolutely convinced that the farmers themselves would profit by getting this money but working within the law rather than continue being the victims of traffickers, the terrorists and the Peruvian police,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Many Soviet Emigres Will Have to Wait for Permission to Enter US
DOC.TEXT: Up to 400,000 Soviets may be asking to enter the United States as refugees in the coming years, but at most only 10,000 will be allowed in this fiscal year, an immigration official says. The rest will have to wait, despite some signs they may be in danger of intimidation by Soviet authorities, the nation's top immigration official said Thursday. Under an agreement between the administration and Congress, 50,000 Soviet refugees will be allowed into the United States in the 1990 fiscal year that began Oct. 1. But 40,000 to 45,000 of those slots will be used up by a backlog of Soviets waiting since last year in transit in Italy, said Gene McNary, commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The Rome channel was shut off by the Bush administration last Oct. 1 under a new system that only allows Soviets to apply in Moscow. But Attorney General Dick Thornburgh pledged to clear up the backlog in Rome before closing down the transit facility. As many as 100,000 other applicants, most of them Jews, are waiting in Moscow. McNary told reporters the INS has provided 300,000 additional application forms. Based on talks and impressions from a trip to Moscow last week, McNary said it was difficult to determine whether applicants were in danger of intimidation by Soviet authorities. ``By and large'' people are free to come to the U.S. Embassy and present their applications, as evidenced by the long lines outside the building, McNary said. ``But there are situations which would indicate a well-founded fear of persecution.'' The estimated 2.5 million Jews in the Soviet Union were for many years subject to officially sanctioned anti-Semitism, banned from practicing their religion and studying their language and history. The liberalized Soviet administration of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has banned anti-Semitism and lifted most restrictions on the emigration of Jews and Evangelical Christians and Armenians. But a State Department report several months ago found that anti-Semitism among newly emerging nationalist groups has risen. After years of demanding that the Kremlin allow more Soviets to leave, the United States now faces severe budget limits and more Soviets seeking to enter the country than it can take in. More than 71,000 Jews left the Soviet Union last year, the highest annual rate ever, and 36,147 of them came to the United States as refugees. Refugee status means the federal government pays for their travel and resettlement here, and recipients are eligible to become citizens. McNary said he expects a possible increase in the number of Armenians seeking refugee or asylum status in the United States as a result of the violence against them in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. Dozens of Armenians have been killed in the fighting, which has escalated in recent days to civil war proportions. As many as 2,000 Armenians could be allowed into the United States each month under a category known as humanitarian parole, which entitles them to some federal assistance but not to automatic citizenship. About 12,000 Armenians came here last year. McNary said the INS has increased its staff in Moscow to 24, and has begun operating an office in suburban Washington to help in processing the Soviet applications. McNary also said the INS had received 3,720 applications from Chinese studying or working in the United States seeking permission to stay here in light of the repression against the pro-democracy movement in China. Most of the applications have been approved, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say Asbestos Risks May be Overstated
DOC.TEXT: Concern about asbestos in schools and public buildings may be overstated, suggests a group of researchers who say there is little data showing that asbestos levels in such buildings are a health hazard. The report by a group of scientists, as reported in Science magazine, said that although most of the health concerns from asbestos stem from studies involving occupational exposure, there is no data to show similar risks to the general public exposed to airborne asbestos. ``Surveys of asbestos in schools and public buildings show that the mean airborne concentrations are several thousand times lower'' than in workplace environments that existed before asbestos was strictly regulated, said the study. Asbestos, once widely used for insulation and other purposes, has been shown to cause lung cancer; asbestosis, a scarring of the lung; and mesothelioma, a cancer of the chest and abdomen. The federal government has directed that schools inspect for asbestos and develop plans to have it removed or enclosed so occupants will not be exposed to airborne particles. The researchers _ three from the United States, one from Scotland and one from France _ argue that most of the studies on asbestos have involved asbestos miners and other workers routinely exposed to the cancer-causing materal in the workplace. ``An important issue is whether these diseases are also hazards to the general population exposed to airborne levels of asbestos in schools and other buildings,'' said the researchers. The findings noted there are different forms of asbestos and that each poses different health risks. ``The available data,'' said the report, ``do not indicate that asbestos-associated malignancies or functional impairment will occur as a result of exposure to most airborne concentrations of asbestos in buildings.'' The scientists said that even when asbestos-containing materials in buildings are damaged, the levels of airborne asbestos normally found ``are magnitudes lower than concentrations in the unregulated workplace in the past.'' Airborne asbestos levels found in schools and buildings normally are no more than 1 percent of levels considered today to be permissible in the workplace by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the scientists said. Furthermore, said the scientists, ``with few exceptions the type of asbestos fiber found predominantly in buildings is chrysotile. Accumulating evidence indicates that this asbestos type is probably not associated with the occurrence of mesotheliomas at low levels of exposure.'' The scientists said the rate of deaths from mesothelioma over the past 10 to 20 years has been increasing among males over 65 years of age that have a past occupational history of exposure to asbestos, but similar rates among females of all ages have declined or remained constant. ``These results support the concept that asbestos in buildings is not an important risk factor as one would expect increased mesotheliomas in both males and females,'' said the study. The findings were authored by B.T. Mossman, of the University of Vermont College of Medicine; J. Bignon a leading French medical researcher; M. Corn, of Johns Hopkins University; A. Seaton, director of the Institute of Occupational Medicine in Edinburgh, Scotland; and J.B.L. Gee, of Yale University School of Medicine.

DOC.HEAD: Documents Detail Noriega's Rise from Traffic Section to Dictator
DOC.TEXT: U.S. intelligence officials have long known Manuel Antonio Noriega was once relieved of his duties for mistreating prisoners and was restricted to quarters as a junior officer for drunk and disorderly conduct, documents show. The documents, released by the Defense Intelligence Agency in response to a Freedom of Information Act request, provide details of Noriega's rise through the Panamanian military, starting with his education in Peru and Venezuela before 1962. But many details in the biographical reports were blacked out to prevent public scrutiny. Noriega, who previously had helped U.S. intelligence agencies, was ousted as Panama's dictator in the invasion by U.S. troops last month. He is jailed in Miami on charges of drug trafficking. The DIA documents show Noriega was in trouble with the Panamanian National Guard less than a year after he entered the service on May 26, 1962. ``Thirty days restriction to quarters for drunk and disorderly conduct, Jan. 1963,'' reads one item written when Noriega was a second lieutenant assigned to Colon. After a stint in the traffic section in the town of David, Noriega was put in charge of a detachment in the Bocas del Toro Province on March 11, 1964. Less than a month later he encountered another problem. ``Temporarily relieved of duties for mistreatment of prisoners, 4-13 Apr 1964,'' the documents say. But Noriega returned to David to head the traffic section in April 1964, and his association with the United States apparently started the next year. In 1965, Noriega was selected to attend the jungle operations course at the U.S. Army School of the Americas at Fort Gulick in the Canal Zone. The school, now at Fort Benning, Ga., is considered a prestigious assignment for up-and-coming Latin American military officers, according to Maj. Jack Rail, a spokesman. Foreign nations select the people they want to attend, he said. Rail said the school's records also show Noriega attending the school in 1967. Before he was promoted to major, Noriega worked briefly as a public relations officer. He then moved into intelligence work, serving as a member of the counterintelligence and counterespionage organization in 1969-1970. He also served as a member of an arms purchasing commission that visited France, Israel and possibly England in July 1970. From 1970 until 1981, Noriega was the assistant chief of G-2, the intelligence unit. He was made a brigadier general on Aug. 1, 1983. Other DIA documents reveal that U.S. officials kept superiors apprised of current information Noriega. Quoting the weekly newspaper, Quiubo, a DIA report said Noriega was said to have received death threats from Colombian drug lords because he was cooperating with U.S. drug enforcement agents. Noriega reportedly moved his headquarters to a ```super' protected bunker with extremely limited access'' on the small island of Naos alongside a causeway, the DIA report said in April 1986. The documents provide only a few personal details, such as Noriega's birthday on Feb. 11, 1936. The report notes ``Noriega is a non-practicing Roman Catholic, and is possibly a follower of the Rosicrucians and has studied Buddhism.'' Rosicrucians are followers of a group of 18th century philosophers who claimed to have been deeply versed in the secrets of nature. When Noriega's quarters were raided by U.S. troops in December, American officials said they found items of voodoo apparatus.

DOC.HEAD: Child Care Group: Anti-Abortion Lawmakers Have Chance to Recoup Favor
DOC.TEXT: Anti-abortion members of Congress can regain some of the favor they've lost with pro-choice voters by supporting a $1.75 billion child care package, according to a child welfare group. ``Here is an opportunity for candidates, including those moderate Republicans who may be anti-choice, to be pro-women, to be pro-family,'' Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, said Thursday. ``Parents overwhelmingly say they need it. ... In an election year, it's going to be hard for any candidate to vote against it,'' said Mrs. Edelman. The Senate approved child care legislation last year by a 63-37 margin despite fierce opposition from the Bush administration and the Senate GOP leadership. But the package was derailed in the House after Democratic leaders failed to resolve a dispute among members of their own party over spending levels. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., has pledged to make the legislation a priority when Congress returns next week. Public opinion polls indicate a large majority of Americans favor federal aid for child care. The Children's Defense Fund supports a compromise worked out last fall between Sens. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., and Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, and Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif. The compromise would authorize an increase of $1.1 billion to states for child care services, much of it in reimbursements to low- and moderate-income families. It would also provide about $215 million for Head Start pre-school programs and $435 million for public schools so half-day child care programs could be expanded into all-day centers. The measure would be funded through the annual appropriations process. Congress last year included $1.2 billion for the new program, but it was stripped from the budget when lawmakers failed to complete action on the authorization bill. A competing version by Democratic Reps. Tom Downey of New York and George Miller of California offers an initial $200 million through an expansion of block grant entitlements to states, with the level increasing to $400 million in later years. Because those are entitlements, Congress would not have to approve the funds each year. A key difference in the plans is an increase in tax credits for working families that's included in the Downey-Miller version, though supporters of the other plan have indicated they are willing to include similar provisions. The projected tax credit for 1991, adjusted for inflation, is expected to be about $1,000. The credit would be increased under the Downey-Miller plan to $1,220 for families with one child; $1,500 for families with two children; and $1,790 for three or more children. It would also create a supplemental tax credit for families with children under age 6. That credit would be about $430 in 1991. The tax credits would provide about $13.5 billion over five years, according to the House Ways and Means staff.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Wants $1.8 Billion Boost in Foreign Spending, Sources Say
DOC.TEXT: President Bush wants to add $1.8 billion next year to the government's international affairs spending, enough to retain current aid to Israel and boost assistance for Eastern Europe, congressional sources say. Bush will propose increasing this year's $16.6 billion in outlays for foreign aid and other international operations to about $18.4 billion for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. The proposal will be included in the 1991 budget the president submits to Congress on Jan. 29, the sources said. Spending on international affairs includes foreign aid, the budgets of the State Department and U.S. Information Agency, and participation in international organizations such as the United Nations. It is a part of the budget that was frequently cut during the Reagan administration years. It remains highly unpopular with many members of Congress, who prefer to spend federal money on domestic programs, and the increase could be difficult to win from lawmakers. ``It will be tough,'' said John Sewell, president of the Overseas Development Council, a private think tank in Washington. ``But we're reaching the point where there are two options: start cutting those items that are already in there, or start putting some new resources in.'' According to the sources, the increase would allow Israel and Egypt, the two largest recipients of U.S. foreign aid, to avoid any cuts in their assistance. Israel gets $3 billion annually from the United States, while Egypt receives $2.1 billion. On Thursday, Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin told reporters he has been assured that foreign aid to his country will not be cut next year. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., this week proposed cutting assistance to all countries _ including Israel and Egypt _ so it could be redistributed to countries in Eastern Europe and Central America. Dole proposed a 5 percent cut in aid to each country, which he said would free $400 million for ``emerging democracies.'' When Dole discussed his plan with reporters, he said Bush had been informed of his idea and that the president ``must've agreed with it.'' The boost would permit new assistance to Eastern European and Central American countries, the sources said. They said it also would allow the United States to pay the $700 million it owes the United Nations for membership and peace-keeping expenses, and to begin rebuilding a new embassy in Moscow. U.S. officials believe the newly constructed embassy there is riddled with Soviet listening devices. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they were uncertain what assistance would be provided to the new U.S.-installed government of Panama under the Bush plan. The administration is expected to seek aid for Panama this fiscal year, which runs through Sept. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Social Worker Defends Child Interviews in McMartin Case
With PM-Preschool Molest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A therapist defended her interviews of alleged victims in the McMartin Pre-School molestation trial, despite criticism by several jurors who said leading questions undermined the prosecution's case. The jury on Thursday acquitted Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, of 52 child molestation counts and deadlocked on 13 other counts. Therapist Kee McFarlane later defended her work with hundreds of McMartin students, and suggested that the goals of therapy are at odds with the legal standards required for a successful criminal prosecution. ``What is in the interest of children is not always in the interest of the legal system,'' she said. Evidence introduced by prosecutors in what became the longest and most expensive criminal trial in U.S. history included videotaped interviews of the alleged victims. Many of the interviews were conducted at an early stage of the sexual abuse investigation by MacFarlane, a social worker and director of the Child Sexual Abuse Center at Children's Institute International. MacFarlane said Thursday she still believes children from the school had been molested and that they had not fabricated their accounts of abuse. ``This agency would never have gone all the way through what we have if we did not believe these children,'' she said. At least seven jurors who attended a news conference agreed the evidence showed children had been molested. But the jurors were sharply critical of the interviewers' technique at the institute. ``The children were never allowed to say in their own words what happened to them,'' said juror John Breese. ``All the questions were leading.'' ``If the CII tapes had not been entered into evidence and I had not seen them, I could have believed the children a little more,'' juror Brenda Williams said. But MacFarlane said that the interviewing techniques were sound, noting that small children must be interviewed differently than adults. ``I didn't put words into their mouths,'' she said. ``I tried to enable them to get over their fears.'' MacFarlane acknowledged that some procedures could have been done differently, including conducting more interviews over a longer period of time. She called the outcome of the case a ``tragic consequence of an attempt to prevent trauma to these children.'' But the institute's executive director, Mary M. Emmons, said some good may come out of the case. ``It has greatly increased the awareness about the issue of child sexual abuse and about the problems of prosecuting these cases,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Top Democrats Seek to Tailor Their Media Message
DOC.TEXT: Amid high popularity ratings for President Bush and the Republicans, House Democratic leaders will hold a secretive weekend retreat to ponder how to squeeze maximum media advantage out of the congressional session that begins Tuesday. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., will convene his top lieutenants and about a dozen or so rank-and-file ``activist'' House Democrats on Saturday and Sunday at the Aspen Institute, a conference center on Maryland's Eastern Shore, according to party sources. Participants were reluctant to talk about the event or its agenda Thursday, and Gephardt spokesman David Dreyer, who organized the retreat, declined to discuss it. ``I just don't regard it as press business,'' Dreyer said. ``There are some things he (Gephardt) doesn't care to advertise.'' Sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said the meeting will not involve legislative business or an agenda for the 1990 session of Congress. Those matters will be left to a retreat for all House Democrats scheduled for Feb. 1-2 in Columbia, Md. Rather, the sessions will focus on how the party can be sold to American voters. They will feature discussions by pollsters, media consultants and outside analysts on topics such as, ``Effective Message Making,'' ``Making the News and Deciding What's News,'' and ``Who is Our Audience?'' There will be a discussion on ``GOP Message Strategy,'' and a wrapup session, ``Democratic Themes for 1990 and Beyond.'' The polls operated by the three major television networks in cooperation with major newspapers on Wednesday and Thursday reported Bush's job approval rating anywhere from 71 percent to 79 percent, topping even the peaks of his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. The Washington Post-ABC News poll of 1,518 adults also showed half of them most trust the Republican Party to cope with America's problems, compared with 38 percent who believe the Democrats can do a better job. All the polls had error margins of about 3 percentage points either way. Most of those attending the weekend meeting near Queenstown, Md., are Democrats who attend morning meetings in Gephardt's office when Congress is in session, seeking to tailor a daily party line for press consumption. The list of speakers and panelists includes some political operatives who were with Gephardt's unsuccessful 1988 presidential campaign, including pollster Ed Reilly and political consultants David Doak and Bob Shrum. Also among speakers scheduled to appear are pollsters Harrison Hickman, Tubby Harrison, Mark Mellman, Geoff Garin, Celinda Lake and Stanley Greenberg; Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee, and Mike McCurry, the DNC press spokesman; and analysts Norman Ornstein and William Schneider of the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington think tank. The list also includes Sidney Blumenthal, a Washington Post reporter; Ken Bode, the former chief political correspondent for NBC News and now a journalism educator; and political consultants Bob Squier and Jim Carville.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Says Women Not Strong Enough for Combat
DOC.TEXT: First lady Barbara Bush is softening the ``qualified yes'' she gave when asked if military women should be allowed to serve in combat. She said in a radio interview with Mutual Broadcasting on Thursday that women are not ``physically strong enough'' to go into combat and their presence would cause morale and other problems. That differed from what she told news agency reporters Tuesday _ ``a qualified yes'' _ when she said: ``If I thought a woman physically could pick up someone who was wounded and carry them to safety, if I thought they could throw a hand grenade as far a man, then I would say fine, because I think certainly emotionally and mentally they are more than able to compete with a man.'' ``I'm sure they can shoot as well, they can fly as well,'' she said in the earlier interview. ``The only problem I would have would be if it risked somebody else's life because they couldn't throw a hand grenade as far, or carry.'' That answer put her at odds with Pentagon policy, which excludes women from combat roles. However, in the U.S. invasion of Panama, some women unexpectedly found themselves getting shot at and shooting back. Mrs. Bush said Thursday, ``I wasn't clear'' in the earlier interview. ``What I said was I don't think women are physically strong enough. But it's much more complicated than that. There's a morale problem, other problems.'' ``I do not think a woman is as strong as a man. If you endanger the lives of your buddies, then that just automatically rules it out, forgetting morale problems and other problems that are very important to the military.''

DOC.HEAD: National Education Goals Take Final Shape
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's State of the Union address will call for guaranteed pre-school programs for disadvantaged children and requiring states to cut dropout rates in half by the end of the decade, according to draft documents. Bush, who has said he wants to be the ``education president,'' and the nation's governors agreed in September at an education summit to establish specific guidelines, with timetables, to improve learning in the nation's schools. They have been hurriedly working on a consensus in preparation for Bush's State of the Union on Jan. 31 and the National Governors' Association meeting in February. In a memo obtained Thursday by The Associated Press, Bush's domestic policy adviser, Roger Porter, said specific objectives backing up the goals will be announced and approved during the Feb. 25-27 NGA convention. ``I believe that we have satisfied the criteria we set for ourselves of producing goals that are limited in number, memorable, measurable, ambitious, and yet realistic,'' Porter told Govs. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Carroll Campbell of South Carolina in his memo. ``These goals are ambitious, yet they can and must be achieved,'' said the draft memo. ``However, they cannot be achieved by our education system as presently constituted. Substantial, even radical changes will have to be made.'' According to the documents, the national goals will focus on six key areas, all targeting measurable progress to the year 2000. The areas are: school readiness, student achievement, international performance, high school completion, adult literacy and lifelong learning, and safe, disciplined and drug-free schools. Specifics goals include: _Making sure all disadvantaged 4-year-olds have access to pre-school programs that help prepare them for school and that they have the nutrition and health care needed to arrive at school healthy. _Requiring each state to reduce its dropout rate by at least half, on average, and making sure that 75 percent of those students who drop out of school will successfully complete a high school degree or its equivalent. _Cutting by at least half the gap in high school graduation rates between American students from minority backgrounds and their non-minority counterparts. _Tripling the percentage of high school students who complete a rigorous curriculum including proficiency in English, mathematics, science, history, geography, foreign languages, and computer sciences. _Increasing the number of qualified teachers in mathematics and science. Also to be recommended will be a National Panel on Education Performance, which will report annually on progress toward the goals, overseeing development of new measures and revising goals and objectives if justified, the document said. The governors also are working with the administration and Congress to develop more regulatory flexibility. The final phase of the government's program _ accountability by the federal government, the states and all in the education system _ will be developed over the next few months in time for the NGA's annual meeting in July.

DOC.HEAD: Burglar Caught by Lure of Nintendo
DOC.TEXT: A convicted burglar who told police he left his house-arrest program out of boredom landed back in jail after a woman caught him inside her home, playing Nintendo on the television, authorities said. Police also charged Kelly Lee Hardyman, 19, with breaking into another house earlier Thursday, and said he played a Nintendo game there, too. Police said he took small amounts of money in each break-in. Susan Kirkland said she stopped in her home on the lunch hour and came face to face with the burglar. ``I yelled at him and said, `Just get out of here,''' said Ms. Kirkland, 38. The suspect ran out the front door, with Ms. Kirkland after him. Neighbors and passersby joined the chase, and Hardyman was caught, police said. Hardyman has a history of burglary convictions, but not of violence, police said. He has been serving a house-arrest sentence, and he told officers he committed burglaries partly because he was bored, said Cpl. Joe Steins of the Gainesville Police Department.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Single-Engine Crash
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine aircraft crashed shortly after takeoff from the Burbank Airport late Thursday, killing all four people aboard, a Federal Aviation Administration official said. The aircraft caught fire after impact, said Jerry Acosta, an FAA regional duty officer. The plane lifted off at 8:13 p.m. and was headed for Santa Barbara, he said. ``The pilot then radioed back to the control tower that it needed to land immediately,'' Acosta said.
