The aircraft apparently had turned and was headed for the airport when it crashed in one of the airport's remote parking lots at 8:15 p.m., said an airport operations official who declined to be identified. Eyewitnesses said the plane narrowly avoided a Lockheed Aircraft Corp. building. The plane was from the Burbank Airport Flying Club, KNBC Channel 4 reported. The names of the pilot and passengers was not released by authorities, and further details were unavailable from airport operations officials.

DOC.HEAD: ATF Will Review Petition to Ban Assault Pistols
DOC.TEXT: A federal firearms official says the administration will consider whether to ban imports of semiautomatic assault-style pistols, but says there aren't that many coming into the country. Handgun Control Inc. petitioned for a ban on pistol imports as semiautomatic assault-style rifle imports were barred last July, contending the pistols are being imported in ``significant numbers.'' The Washington Post also reported the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms approved a permit last fall for Heckler & Koch of West Germany to send 10,000 of its SP-89 semiautomatic pistols into the United States. ``I don't know where these numbers are coming from,'' ATF spokesman Jack Killorin said Thursday. ``The actual number of imports are not anywhere near the numbers being mentioned.'' The ATF cannot release specific import figures for the previous 12 months because they are considered proprietary information, said Killorin. But he provided general information on all the styles of semiautomatic assault-style pistols. ``There's a total of several thousand that have been actually imported over a three-year period,'' he said. ``Without identifying it, one of the firearms mentioned appears not to have been imported since 1987. The total quantity reported to have been imported into the United States is 50.'' Killorin said the ATF studied the pistols last year when it reviewed imports of semiautomatic assault-style rifles, including the popular AK-47 model used by drifter Patrick Purdy to kill five children and wound 29 others and a teacher at a Stockton, Calif., elementary school Jan. 17, 1989. The ATF in July banned imports of 43 types of semiautomatic assault-style rifles, but decided to let the handgun imports continue, he said. ``We looked at them in line with the law and we approved the guns,'' he said. Killorin said the agency would examine the issues raised by the Handgun Control petition filed Wednesday. He said he could not predict when the study would be completed. The petition names five models _ the Heckler & Koch and Uzi pistols similar to rifles already banned, the Australian Automatic Arms SAP pistol, the F.I.E. Spectre P pistol and the Sterling Mark 7 pistol. ``All of the factors which ATF considered persuasive in banning the importation of semiautomatic assault rifles are present and applicable to semiautomatic assault pistols,'' the petition said. But Killorin said banning the pistol imports would be much more difficult than banning the rifle imports, although all firearms imports must meet the test that they be suitable for sporting purposes. The handguns passed all the regulations in place since the Gun Control Act of 1968, which focused on keeping out cheap Saturday Night Specials, he said. The rifles represented a relatively new technology not covered by extensive legislative history that centered on handguns, and therefore the ATF had more leeway to ban them, he said. ``The object of what we do is to fairly and reasonably enforce the law and to reasonably interpret what the law means through regulation,'' Killorin said. ``What we cannot do is we cannot, through regulation, rewrite the law,'' he said. ``The writing and passing of laws is the business of elected officials, the president and Congress.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Big Investors Would Gain Most in Tax Cut
DOC.TEXT: A new congressional study estimates less than 10 percent of President Bush's proposed capital gains tax cut would go to occasional investors, including those who once in a lifetime sell a family farm or business. More than 81 percent of the benefit would be reaped by those who are likely to report capital gains in three or more of every five years, according to an analysis by the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation. Rep. Byron L. Dorgan, D-N.D., a House Ways and Means Committee member who opposes a capital gains cut, said the report ``explodes the myth perpetrated by President Bush that his proposal is a tax cut for middle-income families and designed to help those who sell a farm or business they've held for 20 years.'' Mark Bloomfield, executive director of the American Council for Capital Formation, a business group that supports a capital gains cut, said the study does not refute arguments for a reduction. ``Our point is that there are middle-class people who periodically do realize capital gains and the tax system considers them rich every year by the way it taxes them,'' Bloomfield said. ``That is not right.'' The new analysis of Internal Revenue Service data found 58.9 percent of capital gains recorded in a five-year period were reported by people who had gains every year. More than 81 percent of the profits were reported by taxpayers who had gains in at least three of the five years. By contrast, 9.8 percent of the gains were collected by those who reported gains in only one of the five years, including those whose only capital gains were profits from the sale of a home, farm or business. ``Among taxpayers who realized gains in the period 1979 through 1983, a substantial number of taxpayers (43.7 percent) realized one-time, or non-recurring, gains,'' the committee staff concluded. ``However, in dollar value, the bulk of realizations were undertaken by taxpayers who were repeatedly in the market.'' The analysis seeks to answer the question of who would actually benefit from cutting the tax on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of stock and other investments. Democrats cite estimates that 80 percent of the benefit would go to those with total incomes more than $100,000 a year. Republicans say it is misleading to list someone as having an over-$100,000 income when a person, for instance, earns $30,000 a year but sells a family business for a $100,000 profit. Bush, who will renew his call for a capital gains reduction in the budget he sends to Congress Jan. 29, criticized opponents of the cut in a speech earlier this month. ``I am sick and tired of the demagogues who call this a tax cut for the rich. It means jobs, it means savings and it is good for all Americans,'' he said. The congressional study found people with non-capital gains income under $20,000 filed 28 percent of the returns on which gains were reported but had only 20 percent of the dollar value of the gains. Even the 20 percent figure was distorted, the report stated, because it included people whose taxable incomes were less than zero due to a business or farm loss or a tax shelter. Since enactment of the 1986 landmark tax overhaul, capital gains have been fully taxed at the same rates that apply to other income. Bush wants to exclude as much as 30 percent of capital gains from taxation, which would mean such profits would be taxed at lower rates than apply to wages. The House, over objections of Democratic leaders, approved a reduction last year in the capital gains tax. Democratic leaders blocked a cut in the Senate, although a majority of senators favored it.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Group Finds Abortion Issue Will Work for Women
With PM-Republicans-Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Democratic women's political organization says its survey shows 1990 should be a strong year for women who run for public office and take a liberal position on abortion. The survey released Thursday by EMILY's List shows pro-choice candidates would be generally favored over anti-abortion candidates, if all other circumstances in the elections were equal. The survey showed the biggest advantage for those favoring liberal stances on abortion would be in when a hypothetical pro-choice Democratic married woman is matched against a ``pro-life'' Republican married man. The findings showed a 12-point advantage for the woman in such a contest, the widest spread of any of the combinations used in the poll. EMILY's List president Ellen Malcolm called the results ``a key to electing more Democratic women, which is not an easy task.'' The poll said that when marital status and sex were not specified, ``pro-choice'' Democrats would have a 10-point advantage over ``pro-life'' Republicans. EMILY's List said it used the terms ``pro-choice'' and ``pro-life'' in the survey because of the strong images they present and because of the likelihood that candidates would use one of the terms to describe themselves. The survey was designed to single out the impact of the abortion issue on elections and so the only information given to respondents about hypothetical candidates was their position on abortion, party affiliation, sex and marital status. EMILY's List is a political network, founded in 1985, that raises money and identifies political opportunities for Democratic women. Its name is an acronym for ``early money is like yeast'' _ that is, it makes the dough rise. Release of the group's survey coincided with a meeting of the National Republican Committee. The GOP debate over the abortion issue was highlighted Thursday when a member who tried to introduce a resolution reaffirming the party stand against abortion was told he was out of order. Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater was expected to dedicate a good portion of his speech at today's session to how candidates should handle the issue. Democratic candidates who took strong pro-choice stands won statewide races in Virginia and New Jersey in 1989 and Republican leaders said they would try to recapture disaffected voters by saying the GOP was ``a big tent'' with room for both views. But that stance has alienated some conservatives, who applauded the party's strong platform position and President Bush's vetoes last year of bills over abortion provisions. The EMILY's List poll showed the GOP's division on the issue hurt pro-choice Republicans. They fared ``less well overall'' than hypothetical pro-choice Democrats because they lost the Republican conservative base. But pro-choice Republicans did well when paired in the poll against anti-abortion Democrats. ``Republican candidates who are pro-choice have a 5-point advantage over Democratic candidates who are `pro-life,''' said Celinda Lake of Greenberg-Lake The Analysis Group Inc., which conducted the poll. The telephone survey was conducted from Dec. 12-16, 1989, among 810 randomly selected registered voters. Each state was represented in proportion to its share of the nation's population. The margin of error for the poll was plus or minus 3.5 percentage points, said Lake. A sample of 200 Hispanic voters surveyed for EMILY's List found 37 percent supported keeping abortion legal under all circumstances and 51 percent under certain circumstances. Twelve percent were against legalized abortion. She said that 68 percent of those questioned in the overall survey believe parental consent should be given before minors can get an abortion and 27 percent oppose such a requirement.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Foreign Aid is Being Debated Again _ With a Twist
DOC.TEXT: Foreign aid keeps growing. So do the complaints. About $371 billion has been dispersed since the end of World War II _ a lot of money, by any yardstick. So is the $14.6 billion in economic and military assistance Uncle Sam is delivering this year. That amounts to about $60 per American. Compare foreign aid spending to the $300 billion the Pentagon gets this year for its weapons programs and other operations. It's about 4.7 percent. Or compare foreign aid to the total U.S. budget of more than $1.2 trillion. It amounts to 1.2 percent. Almost every year Congress calls for cuts in foreign aid. The twist this time is a proposal by Senate Republican Leader Robert Dole of Kansas to redirect $400 million to Eastern Europe and Panama at the expense of some current recipients. That has made Israel very nervous as it tries to keep pace with arms shipments to Arab enemies while settling an extraordinary influx of Soviet Jews that could total 500,000 over the next three years. Israel is the largest recipient of U.S. aid _ $1.8 billion in military help and $1.2 billion in economic assistance. Some of the other favored nations, Egypt, Turkey, Pakistan and the Philippines, are quieter about Dole's proposal, but probably anxious as well. Dole appeared to have support from the Bush administration. The State Department was quick to endorse the concept of ``flexibility'' in providing aid, although officials stressed that Israel and other favored nations were not being targeted. But on Thursday word spread on Capitol Hill that President Bush actually would ask Congress to boost spending on foreign aid and other international operations by about $1.8 billion next year. And Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin left town after talks with Bush administration officials saying he had ``reason to believe'' U.S. assistance to his country would hold steady at $3 billion through 1991. It is not clear what the White House is up to by seeming to encourage Dole while developing its own plan to increase foreign aid. Still, the problems Dole touched on _ budget strictures and a desire to help Eastern Europeans as they make a painful adjustment to capitalist economies _ are real. Prodded by Congress, the president last year agreed to allocate $553 million in aid this year to Poland and Hungary, the first breakaway countries. Czechoslovakia, Romania, East Germany and Bulgaria are following in their footsteps. ``To me,'' Dole said Tuesday, ``it boils down to this: Are big gains for freedom worth a small cut in a few huge aid programs? I say yes.'' But there is another view: Find the money someplace else, such as at the Pentagon where billions are spent on weapons that quickly become obsolete. Some are faulty from the start. And Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to reduce tensions in Europe may be making others wasteful. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, attacking Dole's plan, said that rather than cutting funds to close allies ``let's find more money for democracy in costly, unnecessary weapons programs like SDI (the space-based Strategic Defense Initiative), the B-2 bomber and the mobile MX missile.'' Traditionally, American presidents embrace foreign aid and dutifully take on congressional skeptics. Back in 1974, for instance, Richard M. Nixon said the $4.1 billion he proposed to spend on economic aid would be useful ``building sound foundations for a durable peace.'' Three years later, Gerald R. Ford asked Congress for $4.7 billion in military and economic aid so the United States could ``take the lead in creating conditions which will insure justice, international cooperation and enduring peace.'' When Congress comes back next week, however, some of the members are bound to express a contrary view. And the battle over foreign aid will be on.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Thanks Campaign Workers as First Anniversary Nears
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, invoking memories of the 1988 campaign, has his biggest thanks for campaign loyalists ``for one thing you did not ask me to do.'' ``You never asked me to make a video riding in a tank,'' Bush told a boisterous crowd of 2,000 at a Bush-Quayle campaign reunion Thursday night. The joke, a reference to a much ridiculed Michael Dukakis pose in a tank, set the tone for the GOP partisans who cheered Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle, Republican Party chairman Lee Atwater and the brain trust of the 1988 Bush victory drive. ``I'm sorry if I'm late,'' Bush quipped. ``The 18-wheeler got a flat. Then I got tangled up in the flag and the metal detector got set off by a silver foot. Doesn't it all come back to you now?'' Bush took to driving a tractor-trailer in New England to smite his patrician image after he got clobbered in the Iowa caucuses. He made the flag a theme of his campaign, and Texan Ann Richards poked fun at him at the Democratic convention by saying he was born with ``a silver foot in his mouth.'' ``The toughest part for me was the debates. Some time has passed so I want to recognize my opponent,'' Bush said. ``He was strong, tough, tenacious and a real fighter, and I gained a newfound respect for Dan Rather.'' Bush squared off with Rather in a contentious interview early in the campaign when the CBS anchorman sought to pin the then-vice president down on his knowledge of the Iran-Contra affair. The reunion brought together the principals of the Bush campaign, with the exception of Secretary of State James A. Baker III, its chairman. Atwater said Baker isn't doing political events these days. Two Cabinet members, Nicholas Brady of Treasury and Robert Mosbacher of Commerce, were on hand. Saturday is the first anniversary of Bush's inauguration. Of his running mate, Quayle, Bush said, ``Nobody took more heat and did a better job for our ticket and our election than you.'' The vice president, for his part, joked, ``It's hard to believe that it's been over a year since George Bush rode to victory on my coattails.'' Turning to Ailes, the campaign media strategist, Bush cracked, ``Some say it was Roger Ailes who gave me a personality. He made me seem more decisive. I'm not sure about that. Maybe I am, maybe I'm not.'' Earlier Thursday, in a more sober-sided appearance at Constitution Hall, Bush told his Cabinet and 2,000 top appointees that ``all America has triumphed'' in his first year in office.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-DC Mayor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events of the political career of District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry: 1974: Barry, a former black militant, is elected to the D.C. City Council. 1976: Barry is re-elected to the council. March 9, 1977: Hanafi Muslims shoot Barry in the chest during their seizure of the District Building. The bullet barely misses Barry's heart, but he's back at work a week later. Jan. 21, 1978: Barry announces his intention to run for mayor of the nation's capital. Sept. 12, 1978: Barry, after receiving a last-minute endorsement from The Washington Post, wins the Democratic primary with 35 percent of the vote over two opponents, incumbent Mayor Walter Washington and City Council President Sterling Tucker. Nov. 7, 1978: Barry is elected mayor. Jan. 2, 1979: Barry is inaugurated; pledges that ``here in Washington D.C., we will be our brother's keeper.'' During his first term, the city deficit mushrooms, forcing Barry to cut jobs and services and press for more federal aid. He weathers a major snowstorm and a drawn-out teacher's strike. 1982: Barry is re-elected. His second term sees improved fiscal health, renewal of the downtown area, a decline in unemployment and crime and growing crowding of the city's jails and prisons. Scandals begin to take their toll as 10 top city officials are convicted of various financial crimes. Sept. 25, 1983: Barry is stricken with chest pains while attending a meeting in a downtown hotel; hospital officials blamed the episode on a hiatal hernia. A physician not involved in his treatment tells police the mayor suffered a drug overdose, a report not revealed for six years. Police then say they could find no evidence for the physician's statement. Nov. 4, 1986: Despite his mounting troubles, Barry is re-elected to an unprecedented third term, taking 61 percent of the vote. Jan. 2, 1987: Barry is inaugurated. Jan. 26, 1987: Vacationing in California, Barry is hospitalized briefly after suffering chest pains, later explained as a flare-up of the hiatal hernia. Jan. 30, 1987: The mayor is still on the West Coast when back-to-back snowstorms hit Washington, paralyzing the city. He decides to attend the Super Bowl rather than return to direct the cleanup effort. Apr. 16, 1987: Barry defends the city ambulance system after eight people die in six months following the slow arrival of ambulances. May 22, 1987: U.S. Attorney Joseph diGenova announces federal probe into allegations of fraud in city government. June 18, 1987: Barry denies a local television station's report that he used cocaine with a former city employee. Dec. 22, 1988: Police officers planning to attempt a drug buy from Charles Lewis, a former Virgin Islands official and acquaintance of Barry's, are called back when it's discovered that the mayor is in Lewis's hotel room. Traces of cocaine are found in the room. Dec. 29, 1988: U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens announces plans to investigate Lewis episode. Dec. 31, 1988: Barry apologizes for ``bad judgment'' in the incident. Jan. 5, 1989: A grand jury investigating Barry's alleged interference into police drug probe has subpoenaed the mayor's telephone logs. Jan. 6, 1989: Lewis denies ever using drugs with mayor. Jan. 11, 1989: City Council member Betty Ann Kane calls for council investigation into a joint personnel project involving the Virgin Islands government on which Lewis worked as a consultant to the city. Jan. 12, 1989: The FBI joins the probe into the Lewis episode. Jan. 19, 1989: Barry appears under subpoena before the grand jury and testifies for three hours. He tells reporters he has done nothing wrong. April 24, 1989: Lewis is convicted in the Virgin Islands on four counts of possession of cocaine. May 15, 1989: Lewis is indicted in Washington on 16 cocaine and perjury charges. Sept. 17: Barry responds to hecklers at an outdoor festival by making an obscene hand gesture. Nov. 6: Lewis pleads guilty in a plea bargain to two counts of conspiring to distribute cocaine and names Barry as a person for whom he bought crack cocaine while staying at the hotel where Barry visited him in 1988. Nov. 27, 1989: A local television station reports that the 1983 hernia episode was reported to police as a drug overdose; police say they investigated at the time but found no substantiation. Dec. 12: Published report says FBI report includes evidence the agency believes could support allegations that Barry used drugs. Jan. 7: Los Angeles Times publishes interview in which Barry ridicules potential mayoral challenger Jesse Jackson. Jan. 18, 1990: Barry is arrested on a drug charge in a downtown hotel.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Reports Surge in Azerbaijanis Crossing Iran-Soviet Border
With PM-Soviet-Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Soviet Moslems crossed the border between Iran and the troubled Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, the largest number to cross in one day since protests and ethnic violence broke out along the frontier this month. The official Islamic Republic News Agency said 430 Soviet Azerbaijanis returned from visits to Iran Thursday after scores of their Iranian relatives staged a four-hour farewell ceremony. IRNA also said dozens of Azerbaijanis crossed into Iran. The Soviet Union has dispatched thousands of troops to try to quell the fighting between the Shiite Moslem Azerbaijanis and the Christian Armenian minority. The Soviets boarded two boats for the trip across the Araks river that forms the border. They spent two days in Iran, IRNA said, returning with copies of the Koran, prayer books, pictures of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and other souvenirs. ``Both hosts and guests vociferously cried `Allahu Akbar!' _ `God is great!,''' IRNA said. Tehran Radio said dozens of arriving Azerbaijanis chanted Islamic slogans as they crossed into Iran to visit their ethnic brethren. They share a common language, culture and religion. The number arriving in Iran Thursday was not specified. The report said Soviet and Iranian border guards who watched the crossing took no action to stop the Azerbaijanis. The radio did not specify how the Azerbaijanis crossed into Iran, but it has reported daily on Soviet Moslems swimming across the Araks river this month for short visits. The ethnic clashes were preceded by the Dec. 31 demonstrations, when hundreds of Soviet Moslems gathered on the bank of the Araks demanding an open border and free trade with their Iranian brethren. There have been almost daily protests along the border, but IRNA said the state of emergency apparently prevented the gathering Thursday. Iran has said it welcomes any Soviet Moslems who wish to visit. The violence in the Caucasus is rooted in a historical animosity between the Soviet Azerbaijanis and Armenians over who should control the mostly Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh. The region has been part of the Azerbaijani republic since 1923. While many countries have backed Moscow's decision to send in troops to put down the violence, an Iranian newspaper deplored such action, IRNA reported. It quoted the Farsi-language daily Abrar as saying that ``the deployment of Soviet forces in Azerbaijan is a development capable of gradually changing the situation there into a tinder box ready to explode in the future.'' The daily warned that ``any indiscreet handling of the situation by the Soviet government may very well rouse 1 billion sympathetic Moslems throughout the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Politician Convicted in Lockheed Scandal Dies
DOC.TEXT: Political veteran Tomisaburo Hashimoto, a powerful figure in Japan's governing party who was convicted in the Lockheed bribery scandal, died today, a hospital official said. He was 88. The official at Tokyo hospital said Hashimoto died of pneumonia. During the 1964-1972 administration of late Prime Minister Eisaku Sato, Hashimoto served in such key posts as secretary-general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, construction minister and transport minister. In 1976, while transport minister, he was arrested on charges of accepting $34,000 for promoting sales of aircraft by Lockheed Corp. of the United States to a Japanese airline. The Tokyo District Court later sentenced him to a 2{-year jail term. Hashimoto, who denied the bribery charges, took his case to the Supreme Court, but the court has not yet issued a ruling. The Lockheed scandal erupted in 1976 when the U.S. aircraft maker acknowledged it had bribed Japanese officials to influence their decisions on plane purchases. The scandal was the worst up to that time in Japan's postwar history and caused a split in the Liberal Democrats that took several years to repair. Hashimoto, a native of Ibaraki prefecture northeast of Tokyo, joined the Asahi Shimbun, a major Japanese newspaper, in 1927 after graduating from the Department of Politics and Economics at Waseda University. He quit the newspaper company after World War II and won his first election to the nation's lower house of Parliament in 1949. Hashimoto returned to the House of Representatives 12 times before he lost in general elections in 1980. He served as construction minister from July to December 1960 in the late Hayato Ikeda's Cabinet. Hashimoto also acted as secretary-general in the Cabinet of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, who governed from July 1972 to December 1974. Tanaka, who was also implicated in the Lockheed scandal, is still appealing his case to the Supreme Court. There was no immediate word on survivors or funeral arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Grandson Searches for Gold Cache That Cost a Life
DOC.TEXT: According to the legends it was the riches produced by Spanish miners, or the war loot of an Apache chief. Some say the government spirited it away before the area was cleared for bombing practice. Few have seen the gold cache said to be beneath Victorio Peak _ but one man has died over it. The grandson of that man has marshaled a team of engineers and geologists, and convinced a wealthy Californian to invest $2 million, in a renewed search for an American ``el dorado'' said to be worth $3 billion. Terry Delonas, 41, is the grandson of Milton E. ``Doc'' Noss, who claimed he found the gold stacked in an underground cavern in 1937 while hunting with his wife, Ova. Noss said it was sealed in the cave when he tried to blast a wider entrance with dynamite. Three official searches since then have come up empty-handed, but Delonas, who took a group of journalists on a tour of the area Thursday, said he plans to begin searching again in April. He is determined to save his dead grandfather's honor, Delonas said, for there are those who say Noss was a con-man. He died in 1949, shot to death by Charlie Ryan in an argument over money Ryan had invested in the search for the cache. Ryan was acquitted on grounds of self-defense. Aaron Kin, a 26-year-old Beverly Hills, Calif., real estate developer who is bankrolling the dig, seems relaxed about the venture. For one thing, he believes he could recoup the investment without even finding the gold. ``We've got other directions to go as far as a movie to the story. There's other avenues besides the gold outlet,'' he said. Besides, Kin said, ``The amount of work that was put into this project tells me that these people wouldn't be doing this unless it was true.'' Letha Guthrie, the 74-year-old daughter of Ova Noss, claims to have handled several gold ingots and artifacts that Noss brought from the cavern and hid in the desert. The Army has denied rumors that the federal government found and removed the gold years ago. Delonas said three previous excavations were not as well financed, were too short, and lacked cooperation from the Army. Ground radar used in the latest, 1977 search, showed a large cavern under the peak, he said. Delonas' group has a 365-day contract with the Army to search in the southcentral New Mexico preserve. An amendment to the 1989 Defense Authorization Act allows the Noss family heirs to dig for the treasure. The area has been closed to the public since 1955. The excavators must leave the peak during target practice and missile firings, White Sands spokesman Jim Eckels said. Any cost to the Army, such as military police escorts, will have to be paid by the Noss family. Delonas said he is conducting the treasure hunt in memory of his grandmother, who died in 1979 telling her grandson to carry on. But he admitted wanting a little more than family honor. ``Certainly with the money and effort we've put into it, we'd like to have some monetary reward,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Portrait of Robert E. Lee to be Unveiled
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Restores dropped word `he' in last graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Frustrated by Ulysses S. Grant's refusal to pose for a portrait, a Swiss artist commissioned to glorify the Union triumph in the Civil War decided instead to paint Grant's old nemesis, Robert E. Lee, in a daring gesture of spite. The long-forgotten oil painting by flamboyant artist Frank Buchser spent the next 120 years gathering dust in a museum in his native Switzerland _ until it was found by Swiss Ambassador Edouard Brunner and brought back to the United States last year. Tonight, on the 184th anniversary of Lee's birth, Brunner will unveil the newly restored portrait of the Confederate general at an embassy reception attended by alumni of Washington and Lee University in Lexington, Va. Lee was president of Washington College in Lexington for five years after his April 9, 1865, surrender to Grant at Appomattox ended the Civil War. The institution was renamed in Lee's honor after his death in 1870. Brunner obtained the portrait on permanent loan from the Swiss National Museum in Bern to the embassy in Washington. It is the last portrait of Lee to be painted from life, and one of only three for which Lee ever posed. Lee, who rarely consented to pose even for photographers, relented to the charming Buchser's entreaties. He sat for the painter for three weeks in the fall of 1869, about a year before he died. Lee refused to wear his old Confederate commander-in-chief's uniform, saying ``I am a soldier no longer,'' and posed instead in the black broadcloth suit he had worn at his son's wedding. Buchser, however, persuaded Lee to sit next to a table where the artist had arranged the former general's hat, binoculars, and the sword, belt, sash and uniform coat that Lee had worn at Appomattox. Buchser had been commissioned by a group of Swiss liberals who admired the Union cause in the Civil War and wanted portraits of Northern heroes, including Grant, to hang in the Swiss parliament in Bern. When Grant repeatedly refused to pose, Buchser painted Lee's portrait in the hope he could persuade Grant to change his mind. Grant never consented, but the Lee painting _ though unpopular with Buchser's patrons who refused to pay for it _ came to be regarded as Buchser's finest portrait and went on permanent display at the Bern museum. A known brawler and womanizer who sported a 12-inch waxed mustache, Buchser arrived in Lexington unannounced, but quickly won Lee's confidence and captivated his wife and daughters with his hand-kissing European manners and his lively performances on the guitar and piano. Buchser soon embraced Lee as a father figure. ``What a gentle, noble soul, how kind and charming the old white-haired warrior is,'' the artist wrote in his diary. When he returned to Europe, Buchser declared that Lee was ``the ideal of American democracy.'' The artist even grew a beard and trimmed his mustache to look like Lee. During their hours together, Lee shared his private thoughts with Buchser in a way he rarely did with others. According to the artist's diary, Lee praised former Confederate president Jefferson Davis for his character but called him ``one of the extremest politicians.'' Lee also made unflattering comments about Grant's skills as a military tactician. One of the two other life portraits of Lee was painted by an obscure artist in 1833 when Lee was a young, mutton-chopped lieutenant with the U.S. Army engineers. It hangs in the crypt of Lee Chapel on the W&L campus where Lee is buried. The other portrait, painted in 1853 by another little-known artist, shows Lee as superintendent of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, N.Y. That painting hangs in the home of Lee's granddaughter, Mrs. William Hunter de Butts, in Upperville, Va. Brunner said he brought the Lee portrait to Washington to join another Buchser portrait of Union Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman at the ambassador's residence here. Both belong to the Swiss government, he said, and will remain at the embassy.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Yen Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen today, and share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded moderately after three consecutive days of decline. The dollar closed at 146.33 yen, up 0.67 yen from Thursday's close of 145.66 yen. After opening at 146.20 yen, it ranged between 146.15 yen and 146.70 yen. A currency dealer with the Bank of Tokyo said market sentiment for the dollar ``remains bullish'' following its overnight rise on the New York market. The dollar's strength followed statements by two officials from the U.S. Federal Reserve Board that it would not cut interest rates any time soon. Manuel Johnson, a vice chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, and Wayne Angell, a governor of the board, were quoted in Thursday's Wall Street Journal as saying they would not support easier short-term U.S. interest rates unless economic conditions changed. Higher interest rates tend to support a country's currency. Traders said the Bank of Japan probably sold between $300 million and $600 million during the Tokyo trading day, although few participants could verify the intervention. ``The Bank of Japan sold a lot of dollars when it rose to 146.60 yen. It was pretty effective because there was a lot of profit-taking on long-dollar positions at that level,'' said Robert Mckeon, a trader with Manufacturers Hanover in Tokyo. Mckeon said that rumors in the market that the central bank could raise the official discount rate in the near future, partly to counter the dollar's strength and high money supply growth, gave support to the yen against both the dollar and the mark. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which slipped 91.68 yen on Thursday, rebounded 107.08 points, or 0.29 percent, to close at 36,836.54. The benchmark index fell in morning trading as investors were concerned about the yen's decline against the dollar and falling interest rates on Japanese bond futures. But share prices rebounded in a last-minute round of futures-linked buying in afternoon trading. Securities dealers said the market seems to have hit bottom after falling more than 2,000 points since the beginning of the year, but there was not enough strength for a decisive rally. The afternoon rebound of Japanese government bond prices helped the stock prices to recover, they said. Volume traded on the first section of the exchange, where most major shares are listed, was estimated at 500 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Blame Plentiful in Preschool Molestation Case
With PM-Preschool Molest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: There was plenty of blame to go around at the end of the lengthy and traumatic McMartin Pre-School molestation trial, but no one was willing to accept it. In the nation's longest and costliest trial, Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were acquitted Thursday on 52 child molestation charges. The jury deadlocked on 13 other charges. Afterward, the district attorney who filed the case criticized the current district attorney. The current district attorney blamed his predecessor and defense attorneys. And some of the parents of children who attended the school blamed everybody. ``The system is not going to protect children,'' said Jackie McGauley, a parent who believes her child had been molested but didn't testify in the case. ``Life is not fair,'' said Robert Curry, whose son attended the McMartin school. ``I tell my children all the time ... there is no such thing as fair.'' The district attorney who originally pursued the case said he would not have done anything differently. Robert Philibosian, now in private practice, angrily dismissed accusations that he played up the McMartin case in 1984 _ with the news media acting as eager accomplices _ to boost his public profile as he ran for district attorney. ``I was a professional prosecutor for 16 years before this case was brought,'' he said. ``To have people who know very little about professional or prosecutorial ethics, to criticize me personally that I have some political motive is totally unjustified.'' Philibosian instead pointed the finger at the man who defeated him, current District Attorney Ira Reiner. Philibosian said Reiner hurt prosecutor's chances by dismissing charges against five of the original seven defendants and criticizing the case in a 1986 ``60 Minutes'' interview. But Reiner, calling his dismissal of charges for lack of evidence ``the decision we're proud of,'' said the trial took so long because of the state's ponderous criminal justice system, delay tactics by defense attorneys and a mess left behind by Philibosian. ``This is a case I inherited,'' Reiner said. In interviews, many jurors said they believed some of the children were molested, but the prosecution never established that the defendants were responsible. ``Even if you accept that the children were molested, it didn't necessarily mean they were molested at the McMartin Pre-School,'' said juror Brenda Williams.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Top Palestinian Activist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with report of expected charges; adds details, quotes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Jerusalem police today arrested pro-PLO Palestinian activist Faisal Husseini, who has been considered a potential negotiator in proposed Israeli-Palestinian talks. Police spokesman Uzi Sandori said Husseini was brought in for questioning and would be taken to court, where police would request an extension of his detention. On Thursday, Husseini was named as an unindicted co-conspirator in a military court trial of five Jerusalem Palestinians. The five were accused of forming a PLO-supported ``popular army'' unit to carry out the orders of the underground leadership of the anti-Israeli uprising. According to court documents, Husseini allegedly gave the men money and agreed to consult with them about their activities. Husseini, 49, denied those allegations before his arrest. ``There is no truth to that story,'' he said in a telephone interview Thursday. Family members today confirmed that police took Husseini from his home in Arab east Jerusalem at about 7:30 a.m. They had no details of the charges. However, Israel radio said Husseini is expected to be held on incitement charges because of statements he made about the killing of Palestinians suspected of collaborating with Israel. It said he also may be investigated in connection with the military court case against the five Palestinians. At a news conference in September sponsored by the Foreign Press Association, Husseini accused Israel of organizing groups of armed collaborators. ``The reaction from the people (Palestinians) was that they had to get rid of these collaborators,'' Husseini said. ``The responsibility (for the killings) ... is with the occupiers.'' He said attacks on collaborators occurred under any occupation. ``We don't like to see any Palestinian killed,'' Husseini said. ``At the same time, we don't like to see collaborators among us.'' Sari Nusseibeh, another leading Palestinian activist who was named as an unindicted co-conspirator in a similar case last year, said Husseini's arrest would have ``a negative impact on the peace process.'' He added: ``It confirms people's growing belief that the Israeli government is not at all serious about the peace process and tries everything it can to wriggle out of it.'' The arrest came as Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin was winding up talks with U.S. leaders in Washington. Rabin has been discussing ways to break the current stalemate in efforts to convene Palestinian-Israeli talks in Cairo. The efforts are deadlocked in part over the composition of a 10-member Palestinian delegation. Husseini's name has been raised repeatedly as a possible negotiator, but right-wing Israeli politicians contend he has been a key figure in the 25-month uprising and have called for his arrest. Husseini heads the now-closed Arab Studies Society in east Jerusalem. He spent 18 months in Israeli prisons at the start of the uprising but was never charged or tried. In recent weeks, Israel has issued two orders banning Husseini from traveling to the occupied lands and from going abroad. The order banning travel abroad also affected six other Palestinians and drew a strong protest from the United States. In another development Thursday, the army filed charges in a special military court against Col. Yehuda Meir, the highest-ranking officer to face trial for brutality during the uprising. Meir, who served as military commander of Nablus in the West Bank, was charged with eight offenses for ordering soldiers to beat and break the limbs of 20 Arabs from the Beita and Hawara villages in January 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Man Receives Death Sentence for Setting Up Brothel in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: A Beijing man was sentenced to death for turning a hospital clinic where he worked as a night duty officer into a brothel, an official daily said today. The Beijing Daily said He Shuchi also was found guilty of raping five women at the Longtan Hospital, which he used more than 20 times in 1988 to set up nighttime liaisons between prostitutes and their customers. He was sentenced by the Beijing Intermediate Court. The report said He, who had a history of arrests for stealing, gambling and hooliganism, was given the death sentence because ``he had not changed his pernicious habits'' and ``his crimes were abominable to the extreme.'' Prostitution has become increasingly prevalent in China in recent years. It is one of ``six vices'' that are target of a nationwide anti-crime campaign. The others are gambling, drugs, pornography, the kidnapping of women and children, and profiteering through superstition. There have been several cases in recent months of death sentences for similar crimes. The report did not say if the execution, usually by a bullet to the back of the head, had been carried out.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Preventable Chronic Diseases Kill Many, But Get Few Dollars
DOC.TEXT: Nine chronic diseases responsible for more than half the deaths in the United States are getting only 2 percent of the states' public health dollars, according to new federal health research. The national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that the chronic diseases _ diseases with long periods of onset or suffering _ accounted for 1.1 million deaths in 1986, 52 percent of the deaths nationwide. The diseases are stroke, heart disease, diabetes, obstructive lung disease, lung cancer, breast cancer, cervical cancer, colorectal cancer and cirrhosis of the liver. Cigarette smoking, overweight, high blood pressure, drinking and lack of exercise contribute to some or all of the diseases. ``They're all largely preventable _ or preventable to some extent,'' said Dr. Robert Hahn, a CDC epidemiologist. ``We know what the risk factors are,'' Hahn said. ``We know less about how you get people to act on them.'' The survey of 45 states and the District of Columbia found that less than 2 percent of state public health expenditures were allocated to prevent and control chronic disease. The average state expenditure was just 66 cents per person per year, Hahn said. Comparable figures on federal public health spending for chronic disease were not available, Hahn said. Most of the health money from state governments in the United States is tied up in Medicaid _ especially with the mounting federal deficit in the 1980s, said Dr. Robert Blendon, chairman of the Department of Health Policy and Management at the Harvard School of Public Health. Most public health activities at the state level were paid for by federal grants, but those grants are now fewer and states are left scrambling just to fund Medicaid care for their sickest citizens, Blendon said. ``Prevention of chronic disease became the residual that disappeared,'' he said. `It's very frustrating; we just don't have the early warning prevention systems, the minimal stuff that anybody who looks sensibly at this would want to do,'' Blendon said. The 1986 death toll from the CDC's list of nine chronic diseases included 593,000 deaths from heart disease, 149,000 from stroke, 125,000 from lung cancer, 71,000 from obstructive lung disease (such as emphysema) and 55,000 from colorectal cancer. There were 40,000 breast cancer deaths; 37,000 from diabetes, 26,000 from cirrhosis; and 4,500 cervical cancer deaths. The CDC said death rates from the nine preventable chronic diseases were generally lower in the West. The highest 1986 death rate was in Michigan, 518 such deaths per 100,000 people; lowest was in Hawaii, 327 per 100,000.

DOC.HEAD: Embattled Senator's Organization Closes Door
DOC.TEXT: Board members of a non-profit organization torn by allegations that Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., used it for political purposes say the establishment has run out of money and will shut down today. The executive director of Americans for Generational Equity _ AGE _ resigned Tuesday and the group's three-person office will close its doors today, an aide to Rep. Tim Penny, D-Minn., the organization's acting chairman, said Thursday. Durenberger and a former congressional aide, Paul Hewitt, founded the organization in 1984 to represent working Americans on such issues as Social Security and housing. However, AGE has been unable to raise money because of a pending ethics investigation of Durenberger and allegations by Hewitt that the senator steered the organization to assist his 1988 re-election campaign, said Steve Kingsley, Penny's chief of staff. Durenberger and other board members, including Penny, have denied the allegations. The 15-member board will meet Jan. 30 to determine the future of the organization, she said. The Senate Ethics Committee is investigating allegations that Durenberger laundered speaking fees through a book contract and used special interest groups to pay for personal trips. The committee has since widened the investigation to include real estate transactions involving his Minneapolis condominium.
DOC.HEAD: Navy: Trident 2 Missile Problems Solved
DOC.TEXT: The Navy says problems that caused submarine-launched Trident 2 missiles to spin out of control have been cured and the missile program is ``on track'' for a March deployment. ``My confidence is fully restored that we've solved the problem beyond a shadow of a doubt,'' Rear Adm. Kenneth Malley told reporters at a Pentagon briefing Thursday. Two of the first three submarine tests of the 44-foot, $26.5 million missile, formally known as the D-5, failed when the missiles self-destructed. Following two successful undersea launches earlier this week, Malley predicted the missiles will be deployed aboard the submarine Tennessee on schedule. The Navy has touted the Trident submarines and their new missiles as the ``most effective strategic platform in the world today.'' ``The Trident 2 program is now on track. ... It still looks like it's very solid for the end of March,'' the admiral said of plans to have the submarine armed and ready for patrols. The USS Tennessee will be the first of 24 subs to go to sea, each carrying 24 of the weapons. The Trident 2 is capable of hurling as many as 12 nuclear warheads to individual targets more than 4,600 miles away.
DOC.HEAD: NRC Says It Will Decide On Seabrook License Within Three Weeks
DOC.TEXT: The Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant could be generating power for a million New England homes by May under a licensing schedule laid out by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The commission said Thursday that it would make a decision within three weeks on whether to issue a full-power license to the long-embattled plant. The announcement by NRC Chairman Kenneth Carr came after the commission listened for three hours as plant operators and the NRC staff reported that Seabrook is ready to begin producing electricity at full power. In a victory for plant opponents, the NRC agreed to rule on several contested issues, including emergency evacuation plans, before deciding on the license. ``There is reasonable assurance that the plant can and will be operated without endangering the health and safety of the public,'' the NRC staff concluded in its report to the commission. ``The staff recommends commission approval to issue a full-power license.'' Thomas Murley, the NRC's Director of Nuclear Reactor Regulation, told the commission that ``emergency preparedness at Seabrook is adequate to support full-power operations.'' Seabrook, conceived more than two decades ago and built near a salt marsh two miles north of the Massachusetts border, cost $6.4 billion, and the price tag is still rising. It has generated mass protests by environmentalists, lawsuits by Massachusetts officials and bankruptcy protection for its beleaguered principal owner, Public Service Company of New Hampshire. Only three of the five-member NRC board will decide Seabrook's fate. Two others said they would abstain from the deliberations because of past involvement at lower levels in the Seabrook licensing process.

DOC.HEAD: Morris Says Error Caused Worm to go Berserk
DOC.TEXT: A graduate student told a jury he became frightened when he realized the worm program he introduced into a federal computer network was replicating out of control. Robert T. Morris, speaking publicly for the first time about the Nov. 2, 1988, attack that disabled an estimated 6,000 computers nationwide, testified Thursday that the worm was an experiment that turned into a ``dismal failure'' because of a programming error he made. ``Are you proud of yourself?'' his attorney, Thomas Guidoboni, asked. ``No, I'm not,'' said Morris, 25, who has been suspended by Cornell University and faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine if convicted of a felony computer-tampering charge. ``I was scared. It seemed like the worm was getting out of control,'' Morris said. ``My purpose was to see if I could write a program that would spread as widely as possible. My intention was that it should not grow. The worm spread on the network far faster than I expected.'' Morris' testimony was the last in the federal trial. Closing statements are scheduled for Monday. Questioned by prosecutor Mark Rasch, Morris freely admitted designing the worm to break into the Internet network, which links computers at major universities, NASA and several military facilities. Morris said he gathered passwords from various universities and, without permission, decoded them to make sure the worm would spread widely. He said he also took steps to make it difficult to detect. During questioning by Guidoboni, Morris told the jury he included mechanisms to limit the worm's growth and left out any commands that would have caused it to permanently damage existing files in the computers it attacked. He said he wanted to avoid overloading the network, so he decided on a method to let the worm re-enter computers it already had infected just once in every seven tries. Morris thought the worm would duplicate a few times a day or every few hours, but the programming error caused the worm to continually re-enter each computer. Morris said he unleashed the worm into the Internet network through computers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass., at about 8 p.m. on Nov. 2, 1988. He said he then went out for dinner, and when he returned about three hours later, he noticed Cornell's own computer was slow to respond to commands. Morris said that when he found copies of the worm in the Cornell system, he knew it was spreading and realized it wasn't working right. Initially, Morris said he considered sending out a second worm designed to track down and destroy the first worm. But Morris said he decided against that after seeing the unpredictable nature of the first worm. Instead, he said he called Andrew Sudduth, a friend at Harvard University, and asked him to send a message on an electronic bulletin board read mainly by Internet users. Morris said he wanted to apologize for unleashing the worm and tell users how to eliminate it. Sudduth testified Wednesday that it took two days for the message to reach the bulletin board because the route he picked was backed up.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Co-defendant Pleads Innocent
DOC.TEXT: A Panamanian businessman realized he couldn't live on the run and turned himself in to face charges of plotting with Manuel Noriega to smuggle 1.4 million pounds of marijuana into the United States, his attorney said. Enrique A. Pretelt, who surrendered to U.S. forces in Panama on Wednesday, pleaded innocent in federal court Thursday and was ordered held at an undisclosed location until a detention hearing Monday. ``He's a legitimate, successful businessman. People like that can't live on the run,'' said defense attorney George Tragos. ``He's got one thing to clear up in his life to get on with his life and that's this indictment.'' Trial was set tentatively for April before U.S. District Judge George C. Carr. Pretelt, 47, was charged along with the fallen Panamanian leader with conspiracy and trying to smuggle the marijuana from Colombia in 1983-84. He is accused of taking bribes from Tampa-based smugglers to help ferry millions of dollars worth of the marijuana safely through Panama. Prosecutors also said Noriega and Pretelt took payoffs and laundered drug profits through banks and businesses in Panama. The Tampa indictment was returned Feb. 4, 1988, the same day Noriega was charged in a complex cocaine racketeering indictment in Miami. That trial is set for March 5. ``It's our great hope that he is tried separate and apart from Mr. Noriega,'' said Tragos after the brief arraignment. ``We're hoping that this trial here will go before the other trial concludes so that we can ensure being tried alone.'' Tragos refused to comment on whether a plea agreement might be in the works. If convicted, Pretelt faces a maximum penalty of 35 years in prison and fines totaling $265,000. According to the Tampa indictment, more than $1 million was paid to Noriega, Pretelt and Cesar Rodriguez-Contreras for Noriega's authorization and approval of drug smuggling and money laundering activities in Panama. Rodriguez has since been assassinated in Medellin, Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: Two Bank Robbery Suspects Killed
DOC.TEXT: Police and FBI agents who had trailed two gunmen to a bank fatally shot them after they robbed it and tried to flee with a bag of cash. The men, unaware they were being followed, ran into the Hamilton Federal Savings Bank in the borough of Brooklyn on Thursday morning, wearing stocking masks and ski caps. The men carried a sawed-off shotgun and a revolver, authorities said. About 30 heavily armed FBI agents and police sealed off the block. The robbers jumped in their car and tried to drive away, attempting to run down two officials in the process. Neither was injured. Officers fired into the car, killing both men, said Assistant Chief Joseph Calzerano. Witnesses said at least 20 shots were fired at the car. The two men had been linked to a crime ring responsible for a dozen area bank robberies during the past 18 months that netted more than $250,000, said William Y. Doran, head of the FBI's criminal division in the city.

DOC.HEAD: Snowstorm Buries Plains; Cooler, Dry in Northeast, Upper Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell early today across the Texas Panhandle leaving drifts of up to four feet, and the threat of fog in Southern California blocked the space shuttle Columbia's landing until Saturday. Four to 6 inches of snow was forecast for much of the Plains, with up to a foot expected in a 100-mile-wide corridor in northwestern Texas and southern Kansas. In Washington state on Thursday, President Bush declared flood-ravaged Lewis County a disaster area, clearing the way for assistance centers. High winds and flooding during the past week killed three people and caused millions of dollars in damage. Snow continued early today in the Lake Superior snowbelt. The Upper Midwest and Northeast looked for cooler, dry weather under sunny skies. The Southeast braced for cooler air and thunderstorms today. Cold rain was due in the Tennessee and Ohio valleys tonight. Thunderstorms and a few tornadoes, spawned by strong jet-stream winds, were predicted today for northeastern Texas and western Arkansas. The National Weather Service said 3.5 inches of rain fell at Longview, Texas, on Thursday. Winds in western Texas and New Mexico gusted to 68 mph at Guadalupe Pass. A storm dumped a foot of snow on Pagosa Springs, Colo., and a storm warning was posted today for southern Colorado, the southern foothills and the Sangre de Cristo mountains and for New Mexico's high altitudes. Snow advisories were called today in elevations above 3,000 feet in central and northern Arizona. A winter storm watch was in effect for southern Nebraska and much of Iowa tonight through Saturday. Six or more inches of snow were expected _ welcome news for farmers worried about the virtually snowless winter. A winter storm watch also was in effect Saturday for southern Wisconsin. The Eastern states enjoyed sunny weather Thursday. Record highs included Boston, 63; Philadelphia, 64; Wilmington, Del., 65; Newark, N.J., 66; Greenville-Spartanburg, S.C., 68; Washington, D.C., 69; Baltimore, 70, and Tampa, Fla., 84. Thursday's high temperature for the nation was 88 degrees at McAllen, Texas. Marie 14 snow; San Antonio 69. _WEST: Albuquerque 28 partly cloudy; Anchorage 37 windy; Boise 23 fair; Casper 13 fair; Fairbanks 6 snow; Great Falls 22 fair; Honolulu 71 showers; Las Vegas 38 fair; Los Angeles 46 fair; Medford 27 fair; Pendleton 28 foggy; Phoenix 41 partly cloudy; Portland, Ore. 38 fair; Reno 19 fair; Salt Lake City 23 fair; San Diego 49 fair; San Francisco 44 fair; Seattle 30 fair; Spokane 26 foggy. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 12 fair; Montreal 18 windy; Ottawa 18 windy; Regina 14 fair; Toronto 25 fair; Winnipeg 18 fair; San Juan 77.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Perestroika is a bone in their throat, but they can't oppose it directly, so they clutch at tension on an ethnic basis.'' _ Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Soviet leader, blaming violence between Azerbaijanis and Armenians on extremists fanning ethnic hatred to hurt his reforms.

``I think everybody was a victim. I don't think anybody came out of this case a winner.'' _ Julie Peters, juror in the nation's longest and costliest criminal trial, after the former operators of a California preschool were acquitted of child-molestation charges.

``Now they are not going to get paid for unwanted treatment, and that is going to carry a lot more weight with the facility than abstract patients' rights.'' _ Rose Gasner, attorney for the Right-To-Die Society, after a court ruled in favor of a Long Island, N.Y., man who refused to pay a $105,000 nursing home bill for keeping his comatose wife alive against family wishes.

DOC.HEAD: `I'd Like to Have No Memories of This'
With PM-Preschool Molest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``Ray Will Die'' is scrawled in big black letters on the faded green paint of the McMartin Pre-School, testimony to the rage inflamed by the notorious child-molesting case. Former McMartin teachers Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were acquitted Thursday of 52 charges of molesting students. Jurors were deadlocked on 13 other counts. Whatever happens on those charges, few in this upper-middle-class Los Angeles suburb would disagree with the judge in the trial, William Pounders, who once said, ``The case has poisoned everyone who had contact with it.'' Sue Brown, a receptionist at a medical office across the street from the school, said she had two friends who were involved in the case and had been convinced of the Buckeys' guilt. ``I think they got off scot-free,'' Brown said. ``I'm really sick about it.'' Alan Lagunoff, whose son, now 10, testified against the Buckeys, stood in front of the run-down, long-closed nursery school and talked about his disappointment. ``The defense did everything to prolong the case and the prosecution did not do enough research to prosecute the case properly,'' he said. A cold wind blasted leaves across the schoolyard as Lagunoff leaned on the rusted chain-link fence surrounding the dilapidated L-shaped building. ``I'd like to see the school become a center for abused children,'' he said. ``It should be put to some good use rather than tear it down.'' But another longtime Manhattan Beach resident disagreed. ``I'd like to see it torn down,'' said Brenda Platt. ``I'd like to have no memories of this.'' Platt, who has two children aged 1 and 3, said she has serious doubts about placing them in a day-care center because of the McMartin trial. ``I think (the McMartin case) is a disgrace to Manhattan Beach and society. It's totally upsetting,'' Platt said. Linda Geisert, another resident of the beach city, was also upset. ``I'm greatly disappointed in the legal system and quite frankly in the jurors,'' Geisert said. For all his disappointment, Lagunoff said he did not feel the prosecutors should retry the remaining 13 counts. ``It would be just more of the same circus,'' he said. ``We put so much faith and hope in our courts,'' said Robert Canter, 74. ``And this is what we get _ frustration.''

DOC.HEAD: UC Berkeley Chancellor Opposes Free Speech Monument
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to establish a monument to the Free Speech Movement are meeting resistance from the same quarters on the University of California that opposed the movement to begin with. A coalition of faculty members has suggested a commemorative piece of artwork in Sproul Plaza, the location of many rallies by the student movement that helped kick off years of protest around the country. The initial 1964 protest concerned administration rules limiting political activity on campus. Chancellor Ira Michael Heyman said in a letter to faculty Thursday that he opposes the monument. ``I am troubled,'' Heyman said, ``in our establishing a monument in celebration of a movement which is viewed by many in the community with negative or mixed emotions.'' A group of faculty members conducted a nationwide design competition that attracted more than 1,000 entries. ``I think once we come up with a brilliant piece of art, there's no reason to believe it will not be passed,'' said professor Peter Seltz, former director of the UC Art Museum and chair of the Berkeley Art Project.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Firms, Gold Sags
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose in European trading this morning as market sentiment continued to run toward the U.S. currency. Gold was lower in slack trading. Analysts said the dollar is rising on expectations that U.S. interest rates are not likely to ease in the near future. Tensions in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe also made traders more favorable to the dollar, analysts said. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 146.33 yen, up 0.67 yen from Thursday's close of 145.66 yen. After opening at 146.20 yen, it ranged between 146.15 yen and 146.70 yen. Later in London, the dollar sold for 146.28 yen. Traders said the Bank of Japan probably sold between $300 million and $600 million during the Tokyo trading day, although few participants could verify the intervention. ``The Bank of Japan sold a lot of dollars when it rose to 146.60 yen. It was pretty effective because there was a lot of profit-taking on long-dollar positions at that level,'' said Robert Mckeon, a trader with Manufacturers Hanover in Tokyo. Dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday: _1.7145 West German marks, up from 1.7095 _1.5235 Swiss francs, up from 1.5185 _5.8295 French francs, up from 5.8090 _1.9332 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9130 _1,276.00 Italian lire, up from 1,272.00 _1.1745 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1713 The British pound traded for $1.6425, down from $1.6445 late Thursday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommend price of $410.60 an ounce at midmorning, down from $413.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal traded at $410.50, from $413 bid late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped the equivalent of $2.69 an ounce today to close at $409.46. Silver bullion in London traded at $5.25 a troy ounce, from $5.26 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Governor Won't Seek Full Term
Retransmitting to fix category code.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Rose Mofford said she was lying in a hospital bed when she first started thinking about not seeking a full term in the office. On Thursday, her first day back at work since undergoing surgery a month ago to remove her gallbladder, she announced she would not seek election this fall and retire after nearly half a century in state government. Mofford became governor two years ago with the impeachment of then-Gov. Evan Mecham. She had been secretary of state. ``There are so many things I want to do that I don't think there will be enough time left in my life to do them all,'' the 67-year-old Democrat said. ``I feel this one I have to call for Rosie.'' She has been plagued by medical problems, including a concussion, cataracts and headaches. But she denied she was bowing out of politics because of her health. ``I'm not tired,'' she said. ``I wish I had 50 years to go.'' She underwent gallbladder surgery Dec. 18, and before Thursday returned to the Capitol only to deliver an abbreviated State of the State address Jan. 8. Mrs. Mofford also had political troubles. Throughout her term she was criticized for her hands-off style of government. Particularly damaging was her commutation of the prison sentences of two convicted murderers last year, which she later rescinded, saying she didn't realize that families of the victims had not been notified. Mrs. Mofford's decision not to run opens the door for other Democrats, who had stayed out of the contest. Mecham and several other Republicans have already announced their intention to run for governor. Mrs. Mofford went to work in 1941 as a secretary in the state treasurer's office and never left state government. She was appointed assistant secretary of state in 1955 and 22 years later, she succeeded her boss, Wesley Bolin, who became governor. She went on to win election to the office in 1978, 1982 and 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Protest Threat To Free Speech
DOC.TEXT: Citizens of Nagasaki protested what they called a threat to free speech today as police questioned a right-wing extremist accused of trying to kill Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima. The 67-year-old mayor was reported in stable condition a day after he was shot in the back as he left City Hall. The mayor had received death threats for over a year after he said the late Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II. About 300 city hall workers rallied today in a parking lot beside their building to denounce the attack and demand that police crack down on anti-extremists. The attack, an unusual event in a country where handguns are outlawed, was said to be the first shooting of an important politician in Japan since World War II. Police were questioning an avowed right-wing terrorist, Kazumi Tajiri, 40, of Tokyo, and searching offices of his group, called the Sane Thinkers' School, a Nagasaki state police spokesman said. Tajiri admitted to shooting Motoshima and was being held on suspicion of attempted murder, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Police said they found a .22-caliber pistol in the hotel room where Tajiri was arrested, with one spent shell and four live bullets. The National Police Agency urged local authorities to increase their vigilance over the nation's 820 right-wing groups and recommended tighter security for public figures, said an agency spokesman in Tokyo. At the Nagasaki rally, Yukiyoshi Sato, secretary-general of the City Hall Workers' Union, said the mayor ``risked his own life in fighting to protect freedom of speech and democracy.'' ``We declare our resolve to resolutely uphold these principles in the wake of this attempt to suppress them with a pistol.'' The Nagasaki city council said in a declaration: ``This incident is not only a challenge to freedom of speech but a threat to the very existence of a democratic society, and is unpardonable.'' ``It's a real shock,'' said city hall worker Mikako Umehara. ``In Japan, it's so rare for anyone to have a gun _ just police and gangsters. For this to happen right in front of our eyes is, I think, a much bigger shock than for Americans or Europeans.'' ``This act should never be condoned, in light of democracy and freedom,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said today. The government, he said, ``must take all possible measures to prevent such incidents.'' He did not elaborate. Tajiri's group, which has a record of violence, was active in the rightist intimidation campaign against Motoshima. It began after the mayor said in December 1988 that the late emperor ``shares responsibility for the war, as well as all of us who lived in that period.'' Motoshima said the emperor could have ended the war sooner and spared Nagasaki from its atomic-bomb attack. Nagasaki was struck on Aug. 9, 1945, three days after Hiroshima. Japan surrendered on Aug. 15. The mayor's comments, made as Hirohito lay dying of cancer, outraged the rightists, who revere the imperial family. Hirohito died Jan. 7, 1988 at the age of 87. The mayor's opinion is shared by many Japanese, as evidenced by the 286,000 people who signed petitions backing his statement. But rightist groups have circled Nagasaki City Hall many times with sound trucks blaring ``Death to Motoshima!'' In 1987, Tajiri appeared in an interview at TV Asahi, where he was asked if he was willing to kill somebody he hated. ``Yes, because after all, right-wingers are terrorists,'' replied Tajiri. People who answered the phone or the door intercom at his group's offices refused to speak to reporters. Free speech is guaranteed in Japan's postwar constitution. But in the past, newspapers and others who exercise it have sometimes been the target of rightist violence. An attack blamed on rightists at an office of Asahi Shimbun, a leading newspaper, killed one reporter and wounded another in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Former Prime Minister Files Libel Suit Against Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone filed a libel suit against a leading national newspaper today, claiming it had falsely accused him of involvement in a stock deal, his aide said. In the lawsuit filed with the Tokyo District Court, Nakasone demanded that the newspaper, Asahi Shimbun, publish an apology, said Yoshihiko Kamiwada, Nakasone's secretary. ``The article was filled with malice and inaccuracies,'' he said. ``Nakasone had no part in the stock deal.'' Asahi, which has an estimated daily circulation of 8 million, reported in a front-page story Jan. 1 that Nakasone was involved in a behind-the-scenes stock deal in 1987 while still in office. It reported that one of his aides earned profits of $85,700 from what it described as questionable share transactions in Kokusai Kogyo, a Tokyo-based aerial surveying contractor. Kamiwada said the Asahi article led readers to believe Nakasone was personally involved in the deal, though he said there was no evidence to support such allegations. ``We have said repeatedly that the stock deal was done by his secretary independently,'' he said. ``It is clear that Asahi was trying to hurt Nakasone's image and damage him in the coming election.'' Asahi spokesman Takemi Akiba said in a statement that the article was ``objectively reported.'' ``We have conducted more than sufficient investigations and have gotten testimony of parties involved,'' he said. ``And we have full confidence.'' Nakasone has been shadowed for more than a year by allegations he was involved in the separate Recruit influence-peddling scandal. Nakasone was never charged in that scandal, but opposition parties forced him to testify at a parliamentary hearing in May. He resigned on May 29 after the hearing to take responsibility for the Recruit scandal. Since then, Nakasone has been fighting an uphill battle to maintain his influence. Analysts say he needs an overwhelming win in the upcoming election of Parliament's lower house, scheduled for Feb. 18, to return to the governing party.

DOC.HEAD: Three Coal Strikes End, Negotiations Continue At Other Mines
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of miners who struck for higher pay returned to work today at three southern mines, and negotiations were under way to end two other walkouts, the official news agency PAP said. The strikes, which began Tuesday, were the first significant labor protest since the Jan. 1 start of radical reforms aimed at transforming Poland's economy to capitalism. Strikes ended this morning at the Thorez, Walbrzych and Victoria mines in Walbrzych, a city 12 miles from the Czechoslovak border, PAP said. The resolution followed negotiations between miners' representatives and the Industry Ministry in Warsaw, but no details were reported. Negotiations also were reported under way to resolve strikes by about 6,000 workers at the Czerwone Zaglebie mine and another 40 at the Niwka Modrzejow mine, both in the city of Sosnowiec just outside Katowice, an industrial center about 185 miles south of Warsaw. The miners at the Czerwone Zaglebie mine have been demanding a $26 supplement to their wages for December. The miners in Walbrzych had similar demands, PAP said. All the striking miners are calling for retention of special shopping privileges for miners, a reduction in administrative workers in offices and no repercussions against strikers. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa said strikes were an inappropriate response at this point to the nation's difficult economic situation. ``If everybody strikes ... anarchy, a lack of understanding will deepen,'' he said during a news conference Thursday in Gdansk. Under the economic plan, the government has sharply raised prices but halted wage increases while trying to create a market-oriented economy and curb inflation. None of the mines involved in the current protests partcipated in the August 1988 strikes that pushed Poland's then-Communist government to begin political reform talks with the Solidarity-led opposition. Those talks led to parliamentary elections in June and the formation in August of the East bloc's first non-Communist government.

DOC.HEAD: Fog Forecast Blocks Columbia's Return Until Saturday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with fog materializing as forecast, quote from flight director, DELETES outdated material. Picks up 10th graf, `Columbia carries...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: A threat of fog that proved real blocked Columbia's return to Earth until Saturday, making for the longest space shuttle mission yet. The shuttle had planned a pre-dawn landing today at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., but Mission Control decided to keep Columbia in orbit because conditions were favorable for a fog bank to move in suddenly. The new landing time of 12:01 a.m. PST extends the flight to nearly 11 days, surpassing the old record by 11 hours, 38 minutes. That was set by Columbia in 1983. Capsule communicator Mike Baker early today initially directed the five astronauts to lengthen the flight by one orbit, or 95 minutes, in case the fog forecast improved. When it didn't, he said, ``We've decided not to come home today. The weather looks a lot better Saturday.'' ``OK. Sounds like the best plan,'' Columbia commander Dan Brandenstein responded. Earlier he said, ``This is not a good vehicle to fly into fog.'' The forecasters proved right. Dense patches of fog formed and were in the area at the planned landing time. Flight rules dictate visibility of seven miles for landing. ``Our concerns were valid and we did the proper thing today,'' said Flight Director Lee Briscoe. The initial directive to hold off was relayed to the astronauts just three hours before they were to have fired their re-entry engines, wrapping up a flight that deployed one satellite and rescued another. The shuttle will have four chances Saturday to land at the Mojave Desert base. Columbia carries enough fuel and other supplies to stay in orbit until at least Monday, officials said. Other U.S. landing sites at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida and at White Sands Missile Base, N.M., also had unacceptable weather conditions today. The space travelers planned a day of exercising, photography and other light activity. Their day began at 9:35 p.m. EST Thursday with Mission Control blaring the Steppenwolf song, ``Born to Be Wild'' as the wakeup music. ``Good morning Columbia, I hope you're ready to rock and roll,'' said the control center. ``We're ready to rock and roll,'' replied shuttle pilot Jim Wetherbee. The 11-ton scientific satellite stowed in the spaceship's cargo bay had been in orbit for nearly six years before being snared by the astronauts a week ago. The satellite, called the Long Duration Exposure Facility, was deployed by a shuttle crew in April 1984 and was supposed to remain in orbit for less than a year, but its retrieval was delayed because of scheduling changes and the 1986 Challenger accident. Scientists want to know how the various experimental materials stored in 57 trays outside the LDEF withstood being pounded by micrometeoroids, blasted by cosmic rays and corroded by highly reactive atomic oxygen. ``We believe LDEF is a real treasure that's going to help very much in designing future space satellites, shuttles and space stations,'' Brandenstein said Thursday as the crew spoke by radio-telephone with President Bush at the White House.
