Bush called the rescue ``a very exciting grab.'' If the astronauts had failed to catch it, the satellite was expected to be destroyed in March in a fiery dive through Earth's atmosphere. Brandenstein, Wetherbee and mission specialists Bonnie Dunbar, David Low and Marsha Ivins devoted most of the time in space to medical and science experiments and Earth photography. The mission is the 33rd shuttle flight and is a steppingstone toward months-long trips aboard the space station starting in the mid-1990s.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Has Prided Self on Survivability
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead and edits throughout
DOC.TEXT: A streetwise veteran of the civil rights movement, Marion Barry has always prided himself on being a survivor. ``My background is one of survival,'' Barry told The Washington Post a month before his first election as mayor in 1978. ``I mean I was lucky, you know,'' he said. ``I used to run around with guys who went to prison or are dead. I was lucky. I was the one who didn't get caught by the police when we were out shooting dice or something.'' Now, after more than a decade as mayor of the nation's capital, Barry's survival skills were facing their severest test after his arrest on a narcotics charge Thursday night at a downtown hotel. A federal law enforcement source said authorities had a videotape of Barry smoking cocaine. The son of Mississippi sharecroppers, Barry claimed he could move as easily among royalty as among the city's poor, boasting, ``I'm the mayor of all the people'' even as he was found in compromising positions that put investigators on his path. Barry has been under federal investigation during much of the time since 1984 for his ties to drug suspects. Two deputy mayors went to jail for crimes in office and recent news reports suggested the wall of silence created by Barry's friends was crumbling as some former associates testified before a grand jury. Barry has always liked to point to the gunshot wound he suffered in the City Hall building in 1977 as an example of how he could never be counted out. ``He is not going to go out quietly,'' said Max Berry, a former key political adviser, after the mayor's arrest. Berry, who turned against Barry after the mayor's troubles grew last year, added: ``If he has not been telling the truth to the people, he's going to face the possibility of resigning, but he has always been a strong campaigner and a proud person. What kind of effect this will have on his ego, I don't know.'' Earlier this month, a Los Angeles Times profile got him into political hot water when he was quoted as boasting he would cut his opponents ``off at the kneecaps'' and that Jesse Jackson, a potential mayoral opponent whom Barry once supported, ``don't wanna run nothing but his mouth.'' Barry scoffed at federal investigators, always denying he ever used drugs. Barry and his third wife, Effi, have one son, Christopher, 10. He was born on March 6, 1936, to Marion and Mattie Barry, in the small Mississippi delta town of Itta Bena, and was raised in Memphis after the death of his father, a sharecropper. Barry did graduate work in chemistry at Fisk University in Nashville, but was sidetracked on his way to a doctorate by the growing civil rights movement and left school with a master's degree. He was the first national chairman of the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee, which sent young people into the South to register black voters. SNCC brought him to Washington, where he became immersed in local issues, joining boycotts of the bus system and leading protests clad in traditional African garb. With his second wife, Mary Treadwell, he helped found a black self-help group, Pride, Inc. Treadwell was convicted in 1983 of misusing funds in connection with a real estate spinoff of Pride. Barry's high profile as an anti-establishment activist propelled him into local politics, first as a member of the Board of Education and then in 1974 as a member of the first elected City Council organized under home rule law. In 1977 he was wounded by a shotgun blast in the Hanafi Muslim takeover of the District Building, the district's city hall. A reporter was killed. In 1978, only a decade after marching against the city establishment, he defeated incumbent Mayor Walter Washington in the city's Democratic mayoral primary and went on to easily win the general election. His tenure has been noted for extensive downtown office and hotel development, a soaring murder rate among young drug users and, critics charge, deterioration of services like housing despite the largest city bureaucracy in the country on a per capita basis. Just this week, Barry boasted that the city was winning its war against violent crime. He made that claim the same day President Bush called January the ``month of murder'' in Washington. His legal troubles began shortly after his first re-election in 1982, with the first of federal investigations he termed attempts to ``lynch black people another way.'' In 1984 Karen Johnson, a convicted cocaine dealer with whom Barry admitted having a ``personal'' relationship, served 11 months in jail on contempt of court charges rather than tell investigators whether she used drugs with Barry or sold them to him. The current round of investigation was touched off in December 1988, when Barry repeatedly visited the hotel room of a suspected drug dealer, Charles Lewis. City police were sent there to investigate a report that Lewis was selling drugs, but the mission was called off when officers found out Barry was present. Lewis later was convicted of cocaine charges in the Virgin Islands and has pleaded guilty to a drug conspiracy count in Washington. There have been recent news reports that Lewis told prosecutors he provided drugs to the mayor.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BEIRUT
Israel Raids PLO Station, Fundamentalist Bases in Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with air raid on Palestinian radio station, more casualties; Adds byline. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes blasted a PLO radio station and bases of pro-Iranian Moslem fundamentalists in raids today in south Lebanon, killing at least five people and wounding 12, police said. Two people were reported missing. Four Israeli jets fired on outposts of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, in a pre-dawn raid, police said. Several hours later, six warplanes raided the radio station of the Mieh Mieh refugee camp near the port of Sidon, they said. That 77-minute raid destroyed a radio station that the Palestine Liberation Organization planned to use to transmit programs to the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, a police spokesman said. The Israeli army said the station ``was intended to broadcast orders to guerrillas in Lebanon and hostile groups in the territories.'' It said all its jets returned safely to base. Six Phantom F-4 fighter-bombers fired 34 rockets in seven runs, wrecking the two transmission aerials of the station called Radio al-Quds, or Radio Jerusalem, according to police. The station was testing to begin programming Feb. 1, said the police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing rules. He said at least three people were killed and eight wounded in Mieh Mieh and that two people were missing. Guerrillas fired ground-to-air missiles that were deflected by scarlet heat balloons released by the pilots of the raiding jets, police said. Smoke billowed afterward from several parts of the stricken shantytown on the southeastern fringe of Sidon, which is about 25 miles south of Beirut. The spokesman said several delayed-fuse rockets were fired to blow up the underground structure of the station, but no word on the damage was immediately available. Police said four Israeli jets carried out two rocketing sorties on outposts of Hezbollah in the villages of Ein Bouswar, Lwaize, Mlikh and Jabal Safi in the region of Iqlim al-Tuffah. A police spokesman in Sidon, six miles west of Iqlim al-Tuffah, said the jets fired six rockets on the Hezbollah bases, killing at least two guerrillas and wounding four. Hezbollah sources in Beirut said the warplanes dropped ``devastating rockets on our bases'' but refused to discuss damage or casualties. The raids followed a rocket attack on an Israeli border area Thursday. The army said several Soviet-designed rockets fired from south Lebanon fell but caused no damage or injuries. The rockets landed in Israel's self-proclaimed security zone, a strip six to 10 miles deep in south Lebanon designed as a buffer against guerrilla attacks. By police count, at least 28 people were killed and 137 wounded in 18 Israeli air raids in Lebanon last year. This was the first raid this year.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Police Break Up Sports Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1 graf for 4th pvs to UPDATE with 10 arrests; Subs 2 grafs for 11 pvs, `The arrival...' to UPDATE with report of bomb threat, comments from team captain. Pickup 12th pvs, `The English...'
DOC.TEXT: Riot police with attack dogs today beat and dispersed scores of anti-apartheid protesters who demonstrated against an English cricket team defying a ban on sports ties with South Africa. Dozens of police, wielding batons and spraying tear gas, charged into about 100 mostly black protesters who tried to enter the international terminal at Jan Smuts Airport to protest the arrival of the English team. Snarling police dogs lunged at protesters, biting people and knocking them over. Dozens of protesters fell on each other and were trapped as they scrambled to escape the dogs. Police officers beat protesters with long batons as they lay on the ground, trying to ward off the blows. Several protesters were led away with blood pouring from head cuts and other wounds, but no injury toll was released. Police said 10 protesters were arrested. Demonstrators in six buses arrived at the airport to protest the arrival of a so-called ``rebel'' team of top English players on a six-week professional tour. The players face five-year bans from international competition for competing in South Africa. Most nations, including Britain, ban official sports contacts with South Africa because of its policies of discrimination against the black majority. ``Ban racist tours,'' said placards carried by protesters along with the green, black and yellow flag of the outlawed African National Congress, the main black political organization. Police initially kept the protesters on the buses, but about 100 were allowed to march to the terminal and gather there, peacefully singing and dancing. Riot police tore into the crowd after the protesters were ordered to disperse. The protesters were chased back to their buses by the police officers and dogs. Police then ordered the buses to leave. A senior police officer said the demonstration was illegal because the protesters failed to obtain a magistrate's permit. He said the violence used by police was not excessive. The team arrived about three hours after police dispersed protesters. The South African Press Association reported the South African Airways plane was delayed three hours in London after a bomb threat from an anonymous caller. Team captain Mike Gatting told an airport press conference said people should be allowed to protest peacefully. ``We're unhappy that if it was a peaceful demonstration, that it was disrupted,'' he said. The English players reportedly are receiving $160,000 each, with Gatting getting $320,000, for their appearance. Winnie Mandela, wife of jailed black leader Nelson Mandela, and several black leaders at the airport complained of the police tactics. Mrs. Mandela said the police tactics undermined President F. W. de Klerk's claim that he wants to dismantle apartheid. ``We saw unlimited violence unleashed towards our people here,'' she said. Officials of the South African Cricket Union say the tour, which they are financing, is costing $1.6 million.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Region of India Placed Under Federal Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 6th pvs, ``At least...'' to UPDATE with threat from militant group. Pickup 7th pvs, ``In New...'' One name cq. for new governor.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government today brought Jammu-Kashmir state under tighter federal control in an effort to combat escalating violence by Moslem separatists. The new state governor, Jagmohan, told reporters the state legislature has been suspended and the region would now be administered through his office. ``My top priority will now be to solve the Kashmir problem, but my approach will be that of love for an ailing patient as (shown by) a nursing orderly,'' said Jagmohan, who has a reputation as a tough, no-nonsense administrator. He said he would visit Srinagar, the state's summer capital and the stronghold of Kashmiri militants, on Saturday to ``assess the situation.'' Militants in the Kashmir region of the state are fighting to set up an independent Moslem state or join neighboring Pakistan, an Islamic nation. At least 26 people have been killed in Jammu-Kashmir since the beginning of the year, and Moslem agitators have repeatedly attacked government buildings and police patrols. In Islamabad, Pakistan, the leader of a Moslem militant group today promised to make India pay for the appointment. ``It clearly means the government is going to have a go at crushing our freedom fighters,'' said Amanullah Khan, the leader of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front. ``But they are going to find it will cost them far, far more than they can imagine.'' In New Delhi, Home Ministry spokesman Krishna Rao said Jammu-Kashmir had been placed under governor's rule, which is akin to federal rule. Under the Indian Constitution, a governor is appointed by the federal government and is subject to the decisions of the state government, which is headed by a locally elected chief minister. But Chief Minister Farooq Abdullah resigned Thursday night in protest of Jagmohan's appointment as governor, claiming he had not been consulted. When a chief minister resigns, the governor can assume wide executive and legislative powers. Singh's government named Jagmohan, who uses one name, to the governor's post Thursday morning after procuring his predecessor's resignation. The new governor took his oath of office today. Jagmohan, speaking at his official residence that was once a palace of the former king of Jammu-Kashmir state, said he has accepted the resignation of Abdullah and his Cabinet. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. Moslems form about 12 percent of predominantly Hindu India's 880 million people and about 64 percent of Jammu-kashmir's 5 million people. Abdullah's National Conference, a predominantly Moslem party, is closely aligned with the Congress Party of ex-Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and has differed with Singh's National Front government. The militants also have rejected the National Conference's authority to govern the state, claiming it came to power through rigged elections. Jagmohan, a Hindu who served as Jammu-Kashmir's governor from 1982 to 1988, has been credited by newspapers with curbing the spread of Moslem agitation during his previous tenure.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Favors Multiparty Democracy, Religious Freedom
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party advocates a multiparty system, parliamentary democracy, and religious freedom in draft documents to be adopted at a party congress this month. The party statement, outlined late Thursday and due to be voted on when the congress convenes Jan. 30, also called for eliminating the Communists' ``Marxist-Leninist'' label. The changes are in line with the Communists' efforts to shed the Stalinist image left over from the 34-year rule of hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov. Zhivkov, who was forced to step down Nov. 10, is now under house arrest and charged with abuse of power and fomenting ethnic unrest while in office. ``The Bulgarian Communist Party must be de-Stalinized and established as a new type of contemporary Marxist party,'' said a draft declaration reported by the official BTA news agency. The report did not say when the drafts were formulated or by whom. Usually such draft documents are done by senior party members. ``The political system of democratic socialism implies a multiparty system, parliamentary democracy ... separation of legislative, executive and judiciary powers ... guaranteed freedoms, (and) autonomy of science and education,'' the document said. According to the declaration, the Communist Party is willing to recognize religious and some ethnic rights of the 1.5 million minority Turks and other Bulgarian Moslems known as Pomaks. Zhivkov's often-violent, forced assimilation policy banned Moslem religious practices and required ethnic Turks and Moslems to forsake their own names and take Bulgarian ones. Bulgaria's ``society of national unity and agreement'' should unite ``all citizens ... to provide freedom of rites and the use of the language preferred in the everyday life, while guaranteeing (Bulgaria's) territorial entity and sovereignty and the Bulgarian language as an official one,'' the draft declaration said. The statement promised to provide guarantees against a ``relapse to authoritarian methods and style of leadership,'' but it did not say what these guarantees would involve. Parliament on Jan. 15 abolished the Communists' guaranteed monopoly on power, but talks with the opposition on power-sharing and democratization broke down Thursday after the leadership refused to provide media access to the talks _ a key opposition demand. The draft provides for all party offices to be elective and for ballots to be secret. All party office-holders, apparently also including the party chief, should only serve for two terms, BTA quoted the draft statute as saying. It provided for the congress, the supreme body of the Communist Party, to be convened every two years, instead of at five-year intervals as is the case now. The document also urged a radical restructuring of the party, which would include a Supreme Party Council to replace the existing policy-setting Central Committee. Within the Supreme Party Council, committees and working groups would be established to ``work on major problems of party activity,'' BTA said. The declaration proposed that the Supreme Party Council should elect a chairman, two deputy chairmen and a secretary of the party. Together with the chairmen of the standing committees, they would form the chairmanship of the party _ the apparent successor to the ruling Politburo.

DOC.HEAD: Roses, Cognac Left On Poe's Grave To Celebrate Birthday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs final graf to CORRECT that `The Raven' is a poem.
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious man dressed in black left a half bottle of cognac and three roses on Edgar Allan Poe's grave early today in a ritual that for 41 years has marked the horror writer's birthday. ``Tonight at 3 a.m., six of us inside Westminster Hall spotted a man dressed in black with a white scarf walk into the grave yard and place the cognac and roses on the grave,'' said Jeff Jerome, curator of the Edgar Allan Poe House. ``Some saw a man with white hair and others didn't.'' The gifts first were left on Poe's grave at Westminster Hall in 1949, the 100th anniversary of his death, said Jerome, 40. There is some argument as to whether the same man has been responsible for leaving the gift for the entire 41 years, or whether there has been a succession of grave decorators. Stopping the man to find out would be out of the question, Jerome said. ``First of all, that would be an invasion of privacy,'' he said. ``It's none of our business .. if we interfered, it would ruin it.'' The man in black leaves a rose for each grave; the bodies of Poe's wife, Virginia, who died at 25 of tuberculosis, and his aunt, Maria Poe Clemm, are buried beside the writer. Among Poe's most well-known stories are ``The Pit and the Pendulum,'' and ``The Fall of the House of Usher,'' as well as the poem ``The Raven.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Blames Extremists, Gov't Warns Of `National Catastrophe'
LaserPhoto NY4,5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev alleging secession effort by Moslems in Azerbaijan, ADDS chess champion's comments. Moves up explanation for clashes. Pickup 11th pvs, `The government...' Delete graf 19, `Nagorno-Karabakh...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today blamed violence between Azerbaijanis and Armenians on extremists fanning ethnic hatred to hurt his reforms, and the government warned the turmoil could escalate into a ``national catastrophe.'' Gorbachev told a conference in Moscow that despite the Kremlin's efforts _ about 29,000 troops and police cadets are trying to maintain order in the southern republics _ the situation is not improving. He said the six-day spasm of fighting, in which at least 72 people have died and more than 220 have been wounded, served the interests of ``a group of extremists, irresponsible adventurists and representatives of the shadow economy.'' The shadow economy refers to the billions of rubles in illegal trade conducted outside the state-run economy. ``Perestroika is a bone in their throat, but they can't oppose it directly, so they clutch at tension on an ethnic basis,'' Gorbachev told a conference convened to discuss perestroika, or restructuring. Gorbachev also blamed some Azerbaijani extremists who he said are ``calling for the republic to secede from the U.S.S.R., for an Islamic Azerbaijan,'' the Tass news agency said. But, he said, ``among the people they are not receiving support.'' Most Azerbaijanis are Moslems, and most Armenians are Christians. The two republics have been involved in a decades-old dispute over a region known as Nagorno-Karabakh, which is inside Azerbaijan but populated mainly by Armenians. The current violence is the worst since the dispute erupted anew two years ago. ``Today's tragedy, if it is not stopped, tomorrow could turn into a national catastrophe,'' said a statement carried by Tass and broadcast on radio and television. The statement, signed by the Communist Party Central Committee, the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet and the Council of Ministers, accused extremists of advocating ``blind hatred and craziness.'' The fighting broke out Saturday when Azerbaijani mobs attacked Armenians in the Azerbaijan capital, Baku. Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov called up the reserves Thursday to help cope with the fighting, which he described as ``a great disaster.'' At least 10,500 Armenians reportedly have been evacuated from Baku. World chess champion Garri Kasparov said he and his family fled the city Wednesday by boarding a plane for Moscow. Kasparov, 26, whose mother is Armenian, told the Spanish newspaper El Pais in an interview published today that he was ``stunned by the atrocities'' he had seen. The government appeal today appeared to conflict with statements earlier by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who said the violence was decreasing. Ryzhkov spoke on ABC-TV's ``Prime Time Live,'' broadcast in the United States Thursday night. Tass said today that ``the situation in Azerbaijan and Armenia has aggravated in the past 24 hours.'' Virtually all of Baku, an oil center of 1.8 million people, was on strike to press demands that Soviet troops be pulled out of the city and local authorities refrain from imposing martial law or a curfew, said Savili Peretz, deputy director of Azerinform, the Azerbaijani news agency. Extremists blockaded the Communist Party leadership's headquarters, refusing to allow its staff to enter, Peretz said in a telephone interview from Baku. He said extremists also blocked all the major roads in and around Baku. Tass reported rioting on the Azerbaijani border with Iran, and Peretz said some 31 miles of the border fences had been torn down Thursday by Azerbaijanis who wanted to be united with relatives in Iran. Today, guards are in control, he said. A journalist with Armenia's official news agency, Armenpress, said four people were killed and 10 wounded early today in an Azerbaijani attack on the village of Yeraskh, in the Armenian republic on the border with the Azerbaijani enclave of Nakhichevan. The journalist, who asked to remain anonymous, said this was the first time Azerbaijanis had attacked a village in Armenia proper rather than around the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. It was not clear whether the Yeraskh casualties were included in the latest official death and injury tolls. In Moscow Thursday, officials announced that reserve troops had been called up and that some military units had been put on a wartime footing in the embattled region. Gorbachev revealed today that the call-up concerned mainly reservists in the northern Caucasus region, and admitted it had evoked complaints from the population there. Defense Minister Yazov said the reinforcements were needed, in addition to the 29,000 already there, to maintain order and possibly enforce a curfew. He did not say how many reserve soldiers were called up. Authorities in Azerbaijan have refused up to now to impose a curfew, despite reports of vicious attacks by Azerbaijani extremists on Armenian residents. It was not clear whether the Kremlin intended to impose the curfew in Baku and other parts of Azerbaijan, or whether Yazov expected the Azerbaijani authorities to do it. Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin said extremists had obtained ground-to-ground missiles, tanks, helicopters and other heavy weaponry. Foreign reporters have been barred from travel to the republics since the latest violence began, making it impossible to verify the reports on the fighting. Troops already in Azerbaijan and the republic of Armenia were told Wednesday they could shoot if necessary to stop the bitter fighting in the hills around Nagorno-Karabakh. Tass said officials in Nagorno-Karabakh expanded an existing curfew by two hours Thursday and the military commandant there ordered unregistered organizations dissolved. However, the Azerbaijani People's Front, which is blamed for inciting demonstrations and ignoring calls for restoration of order, is far more active in other areas of Azerbaijan. Yerevan, the Armenian capital, has been running out of fuel because of the Azerbaijani blockade. Armenians have countered by blockading Nakhichevan, an Azerbaijani enclave inside Armenia, reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Boat People Attempt Suicide at U.N. Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with government comment, another protest, MOVES UP their rejection by immigration officials. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two young Vietnamese refugees facing forced repatriation entered the United Nations office at their detention camp today and attempted suicide, a U.N. official said. They entered the office carrying some kind of sharp objects, apparently knives, and stabbed themselves in the stomach, the official said. The two men, aged 20 and 25, were rushed to a hospital with abdomen injuries, a government spokeswoman said. One man was discharged and the other was in satisfactory condition, said the spokeswoman on condition of anonymity. ``They just walked into the office, said they were going to do it, and did it,'' said Anne Dawson-Shepherd, deputy chief of mission for the U.N. agency in this British colony. ``I think this all happened extremely quickly.'' The two boat people had been classified by immigration officers as illegal immigrants seeking a better standard of living, instead of political refugees, and their appeal to remain in Hong Kong was denied, Ms. Dawson-Shepherd said. A U.N. field assistant and an interpreter were in the office during today's incident. It occurred at the Whitehead detention center, one of several camps housing a total of 44,000 boat people who face repatriation against their will unless they can prove they fled persecution in their homeland. Also today, 100 boat people at the Sham Shui Po detention center in Kowloon protested being moved to Whitehead. Whitehead and the other cramped, squalid detention centers have been particularly tense since Dec. 12, when 51 boat people were whisked onto an airplane by security forces and forcibly repatriated to Vietnam. Thousands of Vietnamese in Hong Kong detention centers have peacefully protested the forced repatriation policy, although rioting broke out in one camp when security forces attempted a check for homemade weapons. The governor, Sir David Wilson, today said Hong Kong cannot allow boat people to ``fashion lethal weapons'' that threaten those inside the camps. ``We cannot allow violence to become a way of life in the camps,'' he said.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Plane Crash Rdp, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0503,0324
DOC.HEAD: Small-Plane Crashes Leave 8 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT to western sted eastern Ohio.
DOC.TEXT: Crashes of small airplanes in California, Massachusetts and Ohio killed eight people and injured four others. The FBI sent agents to investigate a Learjet crash that killed two men Thursday north of Greenville, in western Ohio, because widely scattered debris suggested the plane exploded in flight, said Ed Boldt, an agent in the bureau's Cincinnati office. The rented executive jet was flying empty from Ypsilanti, Mich., its base, to Louisville, Ky., suggesting the men intended to pick up cargo, said Mort Edelstein, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, one of several agencies investigating the crash. Wilbur Baker, who saw the crash about a half-mile from his home, said, ``It was a streak of fire going through the air.'' In Burbank, Calif., a single-engine plane crashed shortly after takeoff from the Burbank Airport late Thursday, killing all four people aboard, FAA regional duty officer Jerry Acosta said. Shortly after taking off for Santa Barbara, ``The pilot then radioed back to the control tower that it needed to land immediately,'' Acosta said. The aircraft apparently had turned and was headed for the airport when it crashed in one of the airport's remote parking lots, said an airport operations official who declined to be identified. In Great Barrington, Mass., two people were killed and four injured when a single-engine plane carrying a group on a ski trip in the Berkshire Hills crashed in the front yard of a home, officials said. One of the injured was in critical condition. The plane, a Piper Lance, was taking off from Great Barrington Airport on Thursday evening when it apparently veered away from the runway, clipped the tops off of several trees and crashed into a yard about 500 yards from a home, said police Officer Paul Montgomery.

DOC.HEAD: INS Releasing Illegal Immigrants from Detention in South Texas
DOC.TEXT: Immigration officials say an increase of Central Americans crossing the border into south Texas is straining detention centers and has forced the release of hundreds of detainees this month. Immigration attorneys and others had speculated that detainees were being released because the government expected an influx of refugees from war-torn El Salvador and Nicaragua. But Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner Gene McNary said Thursday in Washington that ``there is no connection between anyone who is released and any anticipation of a need for space because of the possible influx of Central Americans.'' However, he added, ``We would like to have the space to meet such an influx if it happens. ``We are not going to go over capacity,'' at the detention facilities, he said during a news conference. ``We are going to live within our budget.'' Illegal immigrants have been detained in south Texas while the government processes their requests for political asylum. INS spokesman Verne Jervis in Washington said more than 500 Central Americans were apprehended in south Texas in the first two weeks of January, compared to about 500 for all of December. Seasonal factors, such as people returning from family visits over Christmas, may account for some of the increase, Jervis said. Hundreds of detainees were authorized to leave south Texas over the past two weeks if they can provide a U.S. address where they have family, and agree to present themselves to the INS office nearest their destination. Allowing such travel is a departure from the policy instituted last Feb. 21 after thousands arrived in Texas primarily from Nicaragua and El Salvador. Immigrants were prohibited from leaving the area because most never reported to immigration officials in other cities. Instead, the immigrants were sent to detention camps while their applications for asylum were processed. At one point, more than 2,400 people were in detention last year, either awaiting an asylum ruling, appealing a ruling or awaiting an appearance before an immigration judge. The law says those without immigration documents may stay if they can prove they fled their homelands for political and not economic reasons. There were 1,046 detainees, primarily Central Americans, at the immigration detention center near Bayview on Thursday. Another 697 people were detained Thursday in five other facilities in the lower Rio Grande Valley. INS Harlingen District Director Jerry Sewell said he was unable to elaborate on whether the agency had changed the policy prohibiting asylum-seekers from leaving south Texas unless given asylum. ``Detention space is a problem and we're trying to develop ways to solve it,'' Sewell said.

DOC.HEAD: High School Senior Arrested in Lafayette Park Convicted on Drug Charges
DOC.TEXT: A high school senior arrested near the White House allegedly selling cocaine that President Bush later used as a prop in a speech has been convicted of three counts of drug distribution. A U.S. District Court jury declared itself deadlocked Thursday on a charge against Keith Jackson based on an alleged drug sale Sept. 1 to undercover Drug Enforcement Administration agents in Lafayette Square. But it convicted him of three counts of distributing drugs in other locations. The president held up the plastic bag seized in the Lafayette Park incident during his televised Sept. 5 antidrug speech, saying it had been seized in an arrest in the park just across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House. The government's first attempt to convict Jackson ended in a mistrial earlier this month when another jury declared itself deadlocked on all the charges. A DEA agent testified that he was asked to set up a drug deal near the White House. Jackson, 18, will face at least 12 years in federal prison without parole, said U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens. The incidents for which Jackson was convicted occurred at locations in Washington that were several miles from the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Effort to Suspend Governor Tied to Coup Blocked by Supporters
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of a provincial governor linked to last month's coup attempt sealed off a northern capitol building today and prevented the government from enforcing a suspension order against him. Also today, intelligence agents arrested two renegade military officers involved in the coup attempt in separate raids in the Manila area, the military said. In all, three coup leaders have been arrested since Wednesday. President Corazon Aquino has been struggling to consolidate her power following the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt, and arresting and prosecuting those responsible, especially in the military, is considered crucial to that effort. The coup attempt, which was put down with tactical support from U.S. warplanes, killed at least 113 people and injured more than 500. Elsewhere in the nation, unidentified youths today ambushed two cars carrying Red Cross workers in the southern Philippines, killing a Swiss and a Filipino volunteer, a spokesman for the relief organization said. In Tuguegarao, 200 miles north of Manila, scores of youthful suppporters of Gov. Rodolfo Aguinaldo prevented troops from entering the capitol building of Cagayan province to enforce a 60-day suspension order. Aguinaldo denied a claim by Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos that he had agreed to accept a suspension while he is investigated in connection with the coup attempt. He refused to step aside and turn over his office to Vice Gov. Melvin Vargas. The government says Aguinaldo threatened to send troops and tanks to Manila to support the December bid to oust Mrs. Aquino. In the Manila area, intelligence agents arrested two cashiered military captains, Pacifico Avenido and Rogelio Seradoy, officials said. Avenido was arrested without incident in a suburban parking lot, a Philippine Constabulary spokesman, Lt. Col. Criscencio Maralit, said. Avenido was dismissed from the service for involvement in a previous coup attempt and has been in hiding since. Hours earlier, agents arrested renegade Capt. Rogelio Seradoy in a soldier's housing area at Villamor air base, the camp commander, Col. Manuel Oxales, said. Oxales said Seradoy was driving a jeep with a female civilian when arrested. Oxales did not say whether the companion was arrested. Seradoy was under arrest in connection with the Aug. 28 coup attempt when he escaped last month. Robert Gates, President Bush's deputy national security adviser, conferred today with Ramos and afterward repeated that the Philippines government enjoys full American support. Gates told reporters he conveyed ``the strong personal commitment of President Bush to democracy in the Philippines and the constitutioanl process.'' On southern Mindanao island, four youths ambushed a car and killed Walter Berweger, the head of the Red Cross on the island, and his driver, Juanito Patong, said Paul Fruh, information delegate of Red Cross. Another Filipino volunteer was seriously wounded, he said. Fruh said the incident took place outside the town of Buldon, 550 miles southeast of Manila. Moslem separatists and Communist guerrillas are waging separate rebellions in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Antonio Cipollone, Awarded First Anti-Tobacco Damages, Dies at 66
DOC.TEXT: Antonio Cipollone died five days after his unprecedented jury award against the tobacco industry for the death of his first wife was overturned by an appeals court. He was 66. ``He knew about it in the hospital,'' said his second wife, Dorothy. ``It didn't seem to concern him in the least. He never got up-tight about anything.'' Cipollone, a retired Italian immigrant cable splicer, was pushed onto front pages and television screens nationwide during the highly publicized trial. He was admitted to Community Memorial Hospital in Toms River on Jan. 4, a day before the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned the $400,000 judgment awarded by a federal jury here in June 1988. His wife said Cipollone died Jan. 10 of pneumonia and heart failure. He had a quadruple bypass operation in 1986. The appeals court ordered a new trial, opening the door for new issues, and vacated the money damages assessed to Liggett Group Inc., the first time relatives or victims of smoking-related diseases recovered from a cigarette concern. Cipollone had carried on the suit brought by him and his first wife, Rose, who died at 58 of lung cancer in 1984. The suit named Liggett, Lorillard Inc. and Philip Morris Inc., which made the cigarettes Rose Cipollone smoked. ``He was happy that he had gone through with whatever his wife Rose had started. He never had regrets,'' said Dorothy Cipollone. In addition to his wife, Cipollone's survivors include a son and two daughters from his marriage to Rose. Born Aug. 31, 1923 in a small village in Italy between Rome and Naples, Cipollone immigrated to this country at age 15. He and Rose met at an outdoor opera, soon moved to the Bronx borough in New York City. Cipollone, who was buried Saturday, is also survived by a son and two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Student Bride, Catholic School Compromise on Expulsion
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager expelled from a Roman Catholic high school for getting married will be allowed to graduate, but she will have to do it by mail. ``Elizabeth Valeri will become an extension student of Maria High School, which provides credit for high school correspondence courses,'' said a statement released Thursday by the 17-year-old and the school. ``Courses completed in this manner will enable Elizabeth to satisfy all requirements for her Catholic high school scholastic record,'' the statement added. Elizabeth was kicked out of Maria when she and her husband, Xavier, 20, were pictured in a local newspaper as the first couple to marry in Cook County in 1990. The school said earlier that Elizabeth's marriage outside the church and before graduation, ``while not illegal, does not constitute an appropriate example for other students.'' The school's principal, Sister Grace Ann, said Elizabeth knew when she wed that she defied a school policy barring married students from attending classes. She would be living a different lifestyle from her classmates, the principal said after Elizabeth was ordered not to attend classes but to receive separate tutoring for mid-term exams. Elizabeth contended her lifestyle had not changed. She said she and her husband, who were married in a civil ceremony, would live with their respective parents until their vows were sanctified by the church. The bride's attorney, Robert Shindler, said earlier this month that the policy represented ``discrimination on the basis of marital status.'' He threatened a lawsuit unless his client received a written apology, was allowed to graduate and was readmitted to classes. ``We're glad we could reach this settlement and that it's over and she can go on enjoying her family and her friends and her 17-year-old's life,'' Shindler said by telephone. The statement said neither side would make any further public comments on the matter. A spokesman for the school didn't return a phone call Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: James Brown Still in Jail as Officials Sort Out Singer's Release Status
DOC.TEXT: Imprisoned soul singer James Brown technically is eligible for a work release program today, but he won't be released because South Carolina authorities have questions about his Georgia sentence. ``Back in January he was sentenced in Georgia to a total of six years and three months, which was to run concurrently with his South Carolina sentence of six years and six months,'' Department of Corrections spokesman Francis X. Archibald said Thursday. ``When it comes to work release, our laws are different, and we have asked his attorney to get his Georgia status clear. We haven't heard back,'' he said. Brown, 56, was jailed a year ago today for aggravated assault and failing to stop for police. He already was on probation for a guilty plea involving carrying an unlawful pistol, resisting arrest and pleading no contest for possession of the hallucinogenic drug phencyclidine, or PCP. ``At this point, I really don't have enough information to discuss what will happen,'' said Brown's lawyer, Buddy Dallas of Thomson, Ga. ``It's just bureaucracy. The only way to complicate this any more is to get a third state involved in it. ``Mr. Brown is in the hands of South Carolina officials. His fate and his future is in the hands of the South Carolina Department of Corrections. Whatever the appropriate officials there decide is appropriate will be appropriate and nothing has been decided yet _ not even whether he will get into a work release program.'' Unofficially, prison officials say they understand that Brown will not be eligible for parole in Georgia until 1992. If that is the case, he would not be eligible for work release in South Carolina until March. If Brown does leave prison on work release, it will be for daytime hours only for work in South Carolina. He has been offered numerous jobs, including one with a Columbia trolley company that wants to use Brown to bring people to concerts at Williams-Brice Stadium.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Factions Demand Party's Breakup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to UPDATE with protests, call for opposition support in government; picks up 19th pvs, ``Modrow appealed...''
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
East German Communist Party factions today demanded the party's dissolution, and the interim president said the pro-democracy opposition should help run the caretaker government until elections in May. Several thousand people demonstrated today in the cities of Leipzig, Suhl and Frankfurt an der Oder to press for demands that included better education and higher wages, the official news agency ADN said. The actions came as the Bonn government, increasingly disturbed by the flow of East Germans resettling in the West, blamed the Communists for the country's woes and insisted on eventual German unity as the solution. The developments indicate how difficult East Germany's road to reform has been since a pro-democracy revolution ousted hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18, opened the Berlin Wall, and set up a coalition government that is trying to lead the country until democratic elections are held in May. Interim President Manfred Gerlach, a non-Communist, said the opposition could take over some of the 16 Cabinet seats held by the Communists or the three Christian Democratic seats. The Christian Democrats have threatened to pull out of the shaky, 27-member coalition goverment of Communists and parties that have traditionally allied with them. In a statement released today in East Berlin, several Communist Party movements demanded the party's ``uncompromising dissolution under public control.'' The party, whose membership has plunged from 2.3 million to 1.4 million in six months, is wracked by internal squabbles. ``The delegates to the extraordinary party congress (held in December) should again be summoned to agree to the dissolution,'' said the statement, carried by ADN. It did not say how many party members supported it, but it listed seven Communist factions. More than 1,800 East Germans continue to resettle in West Germany each day, threatening the Bonn government's ability to feed, house and give jobs to the newcomers. Reflecting concern over the instability in East Germany, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's chief of staff on Thursday demanded a clear commitment to German unity from the East Berlin leadership. The official, Rudolf Seiters, said the Communists were ``guilty'' of a ``lack of willingness to introduce fundamental political and economic reforms.'' ``With every day that passes, the chances of a lasting recovery of the economy in the GDR (East Germany) worsen,'' Seiters said. ``This is due to the fact that the highly qualified manpower which has left is urgently needed within its own country. The last thing which the GDR can now afford is further bloodletting.'' The more than 340,000 East Germans who have resettled in West Germany are mostly young, skilled workers. Strikes and demonstrations have kept up the pressure on the Communist Premier Hans Modrow's government, while boosting the leverage of opposition forces. In order to join a caretaker government, the opposition has demanded participation in overseeing a dismantling of the dreaded secret police, and a right to speak in Parliament. Negotiators quickly approved resolutions backing both demands.
Modrow appealed to his coalition partners to hold the government together until the nation's first free elections set for May, spokesman Wolfgang Meyer said. In Bonn, Seiters spelled out West Germany's vision of the next steps toward a united Germany. He told lawmakers that shortly after the May elections, Bonn will seek a treaty arrangement with East Berlin. ``The treaty arrangement is the first step toward confederative structures which are to lead to a federal structure in Germany,'' Seiters said, emphasizing that Kohl intends to keep pushing for German unity. ``This view (of unity) must be made very clear in the treaty that is to be worked out,'' Seiters said. ``We hope that a freely elected Parliament in the German Democratic Republic will strengthen such a view for the solution of the German question and thus the goal of German national unity.'' Modrow himself first called for closer treaty ties, although the Communist premier said he was insisting on an independent East German state. The East German Social Democrats, considered the most likely to head the government after the May elections, have said they favor German unity and want to start talks on the issue as soon as possible following the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Developments in Eastern Europe at a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with latest developments in Romania, East Germany.
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the latest developments in East bloc.
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION:
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today blamed violence between Azerbaijanis and Armenians on extremists fanning ethnic hatred to hurt his reforms. The government warned the turmoil could escalate into a ``national catastrophe.'' Gorbachev said 29,000 troops and police cadets are trying to maintain order in the Caucasus but that the situation was not improving. The six-day outbreak of ethnic fighting has killed more than 70 people and wounded more than 220.
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA:
DOC.TEXT: The prosecutor-general said today that virtually the entire Communist Party leadership is under arrest, including the highest-ranking cronies of ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Also today, about 200 students walked out of classes at Bucharest University's college of architecture, demanding that 26 of the school's 82 professors be fired as incompetents who gained their positions though political connections during Ceausescu's brutal 24-year rule.
DOC.HEAD: POLAND:
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of miners who struck for higher pay returned to work today at three southern mines, and negotiations were under way to end two other walkouts, the official news agency PAP said. The strikes, which began Tuesday, were the first significant labor protest since the Jan. 1 start of radical reforms aimed at transforming Poland's economy to capitalism.
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY:
DOC.TEXT: East German Communist Party factions today demanded the party's dissolution, and the interim president said the pro-democracy opposition should help run the caretaker government until elections in May. Demonstrations today in three cities demanded better education and higher wages. West Germany said it remains disturbed by the flow of East Germans resettling in the West and that the tide will not stop until the Communists speed democratic reforms and make it clear they will eventually lead to German reunification.
DOC.HEAD: BULGARIA:
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party has called for a multiparty system, parliamentary democracy, and religious freedom in Bulgaria. The proposals are contained in a party statement that will be voted on at a party congress beginning Jan. 30. It also calls for eliminating the Communists' ``Marxist-Leninist'' label. The changes are in line with the Communists' efforts to shed the Stalinist image left over from the 34-year rule of hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Matsunaga Undering Treatment for Prostate Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Spark M. Matsunaga, D-Hawaii, disclosed today that he is undergoing treatment for prostate cancer. ``I can't conclude at this juncture that this condition is debilitating to the extent that I should step down,'' Matsunaga, 73, said in a statement. But ``if it appears that my attendance in the second session of the 101st Congress does not show marked improvement over the record of the first session, I will reassess my present intention of fulfilling my term of office,'' he said. Matsunaga, whose third term expires in 1994, had a ``string of illnesses'' last year that caused him to miss roll call votes, said spokesman Ed Greaney. Among those problems were shingles, a broken leg and, most recently, a broken right arm. Matsunaga disclosed the illness to his staff after his release Thursday from Walter Reed Army Medical Center, where he had spent 10 days because of the broken arm he suffered in a household accident. The statement did not say when Matsunaga learned of the prostate cancer or how it was being treated. Before his election to the Senate, Matsunaga served 14 years in the House.

DOC.HEAD: Sister of Hostage: Americans Care
DOC.TEXT: The sister of one of the hostages being held in Lebanon says government officials tell her Americans don't care about the captives' fate, but she disagrees. ``Two words I have come to hate are `political expediency,''' Peggy Say, the sister of hostage Terry Anderson, told newspaper editors at a meeting of The North Carolina Associated Press Thursday. ``I have been told numerous times that people just don't care, but I am convinced that the only ones who don't care are the ones who don't know about them,'' she said. Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. He was last seen in a videotaped message to his family in October 1988. ``I have no reason to believe since a year ago last October that Terry Anderson is alive, but I'm counting on him to be,'' she said. ``You can't live without hope ... and a little bit of faith in my government, that they are trying to bring these hostages out.'' Mrs. Say, who has made several trips to the Middle East seeking the release of her brother, said families of the hostages want the government to use ``positive pressure'' to work for the release of the eight Americans still held in Lebanon. Although the government has a policy against negotiating with terrorists, Mrs. Say said that did not stop negotiations for the release of hijacked airline passengers and the Achille Lauro cruise ship. The hostages' location may be a secret, she added, but there is little mystery about who is holding them and that Iran is behind those terrorists. ``I know who Terry Anderson's guards are _ what their names are and where they live,'' she said. She said released hostages have told her that guards hold guns to the heads of the captives every time there is a knock on the door. A rescue attempt would lead to the hostages' deaths, she feels. ``Terry told one of the hostages later released that he hadn't gone through all this to die in a rescue attempt,'' Mrs. Say said. ``What it's going to take is government-to-government discussions.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Criticizes Social Security Tax Cut Proposal
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs following 5th graf pvs, bgng, Moreover, it ..., to UPDATE with Mitchell comment.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is trying to blunt the momentum of a politically appealing plan to cut Social Security taxes, arguing it would force either an increase in other taxes or a reduction in retirement benefits. Bush called the proposal a ``charade'' Thursday. Vice President Dan Quayle said it was ``a political trap'' and ``a subterfuge for a general tax increase.'' The target of the White House attack was a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to roll back the Social Security payroll tax increase that began Jan. 1. Moynihan's plan has put Bush on the spot because it has won support across the political spectrum, even from traditional allies of the president such as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and conservative groups. Moreover, it has exposed Bush to criticism that he is espousing a tax cut for the rich with a proposed cut in capital gains taxes, while spurning a break for middle- and low-income Americans with a reduction in Social Security taxes. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said today that he believes Moynihan's proposal dramatized ``inequities and regressiveness in the American tax system,'' but he stopped short of endorsing it. The Maine Democrat said he has asked staff aides to study the budgetary impact of rolling back the Social Security payroll tax and said he would not make a decision on whether to support the bill until he has seen the results of the studies and has discussed the issue with Moynihan. Bush, in his first comments on the proposal, said, ``This is an effort to get me to try to raise taxes on the American people by the charade of cutting them, or cut benefits. ``And I am not going to do it to the older people in this country,'' Bush pledged. On the heels of Moynihan's measure, Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., proposed a 5 percent value-added tax _ a national sales levy _ to replace revenues lost by the Social Security tax cut and Bush's own proposal to lower the tax on capital gains. Hollings' plan would raise $53 billion in 1991. Quayle said Hollings' proposal was proof that a tax increase would be the result of reducing Social Security taxes. ``The cat's a little bit out of the bag right now,'' the vice president said in an interview with The Associated Press. However, Moynihan was quoted in today's editions of The New York Times as saying, ``It is not fair to say I want to raise taxes to offset the Social Security tax cut.'' He said the Social Security system ``edges on the sacred, and to see its revenues debauched this way is an independent question that stands apart from the budget deficit, a tax increase or any other question.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, lumping the Moynihan and Hollings proposals together, said: ``First we had the tax cut and now we have the tax increase. Can cuts in benefits be far behind?'' Moynihan's proposal would save workers $7 billion in Social Security taxes this year and $55 billion in fiscal 1991. The payroll tax, paid by both employers and employees, rose to 7.65 percent Jan. 1 from 7.51 percent, and it is levied on wages up to $51,300 instead of $48,000. That means a wage-earner could pay as much as $3,924 in Social Security taxes this year, an increase of about $319 from 1989. Moynihan argues that the payroll tax should be reduced because mounting surpluses in the Social Security trust funds are being used to help offset large budget deficits instead of being put away for future retirement benefits. The surpluses are the result of a 1983 agreement between the Reagan administration and Congress in which taxes were raised to build up a pool of hundreds of billions of dollars to pay for baby boomers' retirement costs in the next century. Moynihan's administrative assistant, Paul Browne, said Bush was engaging in ``a scare tactic.'' ``The notion that (a payroll tax cut) in any way hurts recipients is nonsense. That's just flat wrong,'' Browne said. Quayle said Moynihan's proposal gives Republicans their first opportunity to appear as the protector of Social Security. ``Let me tell you something, cut these taxes the way that Moynihan is talking about, you have to cut benefits at some time, and the president and the Republican Party now have an opportunity to show the American people, once and for all, that the Republicans are as committed to the integrity of this Social Security trust fund as anybody,'' Quayle said.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Tells GOP to Tell It Straight on Abortion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with Atwater speech, editing
DOC.TEXT: Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater advised GOP candidates today to face the abortion issue squarely, without ``vacillation, waffling or doubletalk,'' saying voters will accept differences but not ducking. ``In 1990, no candidate can run for office without squarely facing the abortion issue,'' Atwater told the winter meeting of the Republican National Committee. President Bush, the party platform and Atwater all are firm opponents of abortion, but the GOP chairman said that doesn't mean all Republican candidates have to agree. ``There is no litmus test on any issue which would be grounds for repudiating a Republican who believes in our overall philosophy ...,'' Atwater said. The issue figured in Republican defeats for two governorships in 1989, and ever since, Atwater has been telling his party that its candidates must stake out their own positions clearly and early. Otherwise, he said, Democrats will define the issue in their terms. ``What no voter likes is vacillation, waffling or doubletalk,'' Atwater said today. ``And they don't like the appearance of vacillation, waffling or doubletalk.'' He said the Republican Party ``is big enough to accommodate different views,'' saying that is one of the growing pains involved in becoming a majority. Atwater and other Republican leaders have been recommending that handling of the abortion issue ever since the defeats of 1989. Vice President Dan Quayle said Thursday that people on all sides of the abortion issue can be comfortable in the Republican Party, but there was a distinct level of discomfort at the national committee meeting. Idaho Republican chairman Randy Ayre was swiftly rebuffed Thursday when he tried to get the party to adopt a resolution reaffirming the 1988 GOP platform stance in opposition to abortion. Republicans are trying to cope with a turnaround in the impact of the issue after a decade in which the anti-abortion stance was ascendant and candidates espousing pro-choice views were on the defensive. But pro-choice activists were energized by a Supreme Court ruling last summer that opened the way for states to enact restrictions on access to abortions. In an interview in his White House office, Quayle reaffirmed his support for the 1988 platform but then added that Republicans ``are a party of inclusion ... the tent is big enough to include pro-life as well as pro-choice.'' ``The president has already campaigned for a number of pro-choice Senate candidates. He will continue to support the Republican candidate no matter whether pro-life or pro-choice,'' Quayle said. Despite the 1989 election results, President Bush has maintained a strong anti-abortion position, vetoing two bills that would have allowed the use of federal funds for abortions in cases of rape and incest. Quayle said that on abortion the GOP was ``becoming more like the traditional Democratic Party, that is that we are inclusive rather than exclusive. I have a hunch the Democratic Party really runs the risk of being more single-issue than the Republican Party.'' The vice president added that ``pro-choice Republicans don't feel uncomfortable in our party _ if they do, they shouldn't.'' When Ayre offered his resolution, he was told that his request would not be considered because he had not submitted a formal resolution in advance of the gathering, and that perhaps the issue would be discussed at the next RNC meeting in June. ``But we have elections coming up,'' he told the RNC's resolutions committee. After the session, Ayre said that while he personally opposes abortion and believes the party should too, he did not believe the GOP should not use a candidate's position on abortion as a litmus test for party support. ``I just feel that we should reaffirm the party's longstanding position on the issue,'' he said. But one RNC member, speaking on condition of anonymity, said party officials were reluctant to stir new interest in an issue that could hurt many GOP candidates in the 1990 elections. ``Those who are pro-life can point to the 1988 platform and those pro-choice can point to the president's remarks about inclusion,'' he said. ``It does us no good to stir this thing up.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Child Actor Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to CORRECT age to 42, sted 43, UPDATE with detective's comments on suicide, no foul play suspected, ADD Hamer worked for his brother and other jobs. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Rusty Hamer, the child actor in the television series ``Make Room for Daddy'' in the 1950s and '60s, has died at age 42 of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound, his brother said. Hamer was found dead in his home Thursday. ``He was a very unhappy, very confused young man,'' John Hamer said. ``No one does something like that if they aren't confused. I've heard of a lot of child actors who have become unhappy with their lives after they've left the industry.'' Rusty Hamer apparently shot himself in the head with a .357-caliber Magnum revolver, said the sheriff office's Chief Detective Robert McCullough. ``There was no indication of any foul play,'' McCullough said. On the TV series, Rusty Hamer played the part of Rusty, and Danny Thomas played his father, a nightclub singer and comedian. Hamer had his first movie role at the age of 5, and appeared in several Abbott and Costello films, John Hamer said. The Danny Thomas show was one of television's most durable and popular situation comedies. Most of the cast, including Hamer, returned in 1970-71 with a sequel, ``Make Room For Granddaddy,'' in which Rusty was a married medical student. John Hamer, who also was a child actor, said his brother was in debilitating physical and emotional pain for years but refused to see a doctor. Rusty Hamer worked for a Los Angeles messenger service when he left Hollywood at the age of 20, bitter and depressed, said John Hamer. After moving to this southwest Louisiana town, his jobs included delivering a newspaper, working offshore for Exxon, and occasional work at his brother's restaurant. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Arson Suspected in Fire Aboard Aircraft Carrier
DOC.TEXT: The Navy says arson is suspected in a fire aboard the aircraft carrier USS Forrestal that injured 11 sailors and caused an estimated $2.5 million in damage, a newspaper reported today. ``Most logically, the fire was intentionally set,'' said the report, which was obtained by The Florida Times-Union in a Freedom of Information Act request. But Navy investigators have not determined who set the fire, which occurred Oct. 9 while the ship was docked at Mayport Naval Station, northeast of Jacksonville. They said they found no evidence that it started accidentally. Investigators also said materials used to clean up a fuel spill from the carrier four days earlier were improperly stored on the ship. No arrests have been made and the Navy investigation is continuing. The fire broke out three days before the Forrestal was to leave on a six-month deployment to the Mediterranean. Repairs delayed the start of the deployment until Nov. 3. A Navy spokesman in Washington, Lt. Frank Thorp, said he could not speculate on whether the fire could have been set in an attempt to delay the ship's departure. The fire started in an air intake in the ship's No. 1 main machinery room on the second deck. Fueled by the oil-cleanup material, the fire spread through electrical cable to an aircraft elevator machinery room, then ignited a fire off one of the carrier's hangar bays. Smoke spread through the carrier, forcing the evacuation of 1,000 sailors. The fire affected some navigation, aircraft elevator control and weapons systems components and left some parts of the ship without electricity for several days.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Rebuts Report on Human Rights
DOC.TEXT: The government today dismissed as untruthful an Amnesty International report that accused South Korean authorities of torturing prisoners and committing other human rights violations. In a statement, the government said the London-based human rights organization has ``naively taken at face value one-sided and often malicious assertions.'' Amnesty International's report on human rights violations last year in South Korea contained ``serious factual errors, unrealistic assertions and suggestions which disregard the nation's legal system,'' it said. The statement called the allegations ``untruthful.'' In its report, Amnesty International said torture and other violations under the government of President Roh Tae-woo last year had reversed a two-year trend of human rights improvements in South Korea. The human rights group also said 800 political and labor activists have been arrested in a crackdown on political opposition by Roh's government and thousands more briefly detained for particiaption in demonstrations and industrial strikes. Hundreds of prisoners were believed being held for political reasons at the end of 1989, and another 200 political prisoners have been held for between one and 39 years, Amnesty said. The government maintained South Korea has no prisoners of conscience and ``only those who threatened the rule of law and national survival by willfully violating the established law'' have been imprisoned. ``Amnesty International's arbitrary definition of them as prisoners of conscience who must be released can only be deemed to be based on an ignorance or misunderstanding of the facts,'' it said. Roh has introduced broad reforms since he took office, but last year his government began taking firm action against radical students and dissidents. Public support for the radicals has waned because of their ideological extremism and violent tactics.

DOC.HEAD: Way Out Of Panama Is Safe, But Leave Plenty of Time
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 9th graf, `Among the...' to correct lamb to lam. Pickup 10th graf, `The capital...
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The main exit from Panama is not the swiftest. Nearly a month after U.S. troops invaded the country, security at Panama's airport befits more a prison than a way station for international flights. The Omar Torrijos International Airport is, for all practical purposes, closed to the public. It belongs to U.S. troops, armored cars, tanks, German shepherds and other bomb-sniffing creatures. The obstacle course includes more than the usual metal detectors and document checks. For one passenger, it included getting by an incontinent dog. The planes do take off, but passengers are advised to check in at least five hours before departure. If not, too bad, you may miss your flight. Most top aides and officers to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, toppled after the Dec. 20 invasion, are believed to have surrendered or sought asylum in various foreign embassies in Panama City. But some Noriega cronies are still on the loose, and U.S. forces aren't taking any chances that they'll slip out of the country carrying a boarding pass. ``We've gotten most of the Defense Forces, but not all,'' said Army Col. James Swank, spokesman for the U.S. Southern Command. Among the top members of Noriega's Defense Forces still on the lam is Lt. Col. Luis Cordoba, the former police intelligence head linked to the grisly 1985 murder of Noriega opponent Hugo Spadafora, whose headless body was found in Costa Rica. The capital is rife with rumors that Cordoba has taken to the mountains to wage a guerrilla war against U.S. troops and the new government of President Guillermo Endara. Cordoba might also be in hiding. But if he's waiting for an airplane, he's out of luck. An airline passenger can't just drive to the airport, park the car and check in at the counter. At least five hours before the plane takes off, travelers are told to be at the huge pink Atlapa Convention Center, 15 miles from the airport, where tickets, passports and visas are checked. If all the information fits with rosters and computer lists, the travelers get a boarding card and a luggage ticket stub. Then they're told to wait for a bus that will drive them to airport, at a cost of $5. The airport's entrance is sealed off with sandbags, barbed wire and tanks. Before the bus is allowed in, a soldier hops on and inspects passports and tickets. If there are no suspicious characters, the bus can go in. ``Don't get off the bus yet. Stay inside until we tell you to,'' a Panamanian woman admonishes impatient travelers. The luggage is taken off and lined up neatly next to a door. Then and only then, passengers can step down. One by one, they pick out their suitcases. Not more than two are allowed per passenger, and there are no porters. Step 1: Passenger and suitcase go through metal detector and X-ray. Step 2: Suitcases are lined in a row and opened. Passengers sit down and watch. Step 3: Dog No. 1 sniffs each suitcase and purse. Step 4: Dog No. 2 sniffs the same suitcases, again. Step 5: Panamanian security guard goes through each suitcase with hands. Step 6: Passengers try to close suitcase back up. The procedure is not always smooth. One dog decides to do more than sniff and urinates on a suitcase full of photography chemicals. The U.S. K-9 officer merely yanks the dog's chain and sets it to sniffing again. Amid raucous laughter, the dog, male, starts paying more attention to a fellow security dog, female. ``I'm never coming back to Panama as long as I live,'' says a Honduran woman looking on. The luggage then goes on the plane. But not the passenger. First a $15 airport tax must be paid, then exit visas are checked. At another glass booth, visas, passports, ticket and boarding pass are rechecked. The worst is over. One more X-ray. One more metal detector. Soldiers with machine guns and dogs on leashes mingle with passengers until the plane can be boarded. But even after everyone is on board, the checks go on. Outside, an official-looking man talks with the crew and boards the plane. A passenger is told: ``Come with me, please.'' Before the plane can take off, his luggage must be removed from the cargo bay. That takes 45 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Employees Didn't Prove Wiretap Allegations, Bell Lawyer Says
DOC.TEXT: Two former Cincinnati Bell Telephone Co. installers have failed to support their accusations that the company engaged in illegal wiretapping, Cincinnati Bell's attorney argued today. Lawyer Arnold Morelli said Leonard Gates and Robert Draise had changed their stories, forgotten key dates and ``bumped into facts'' during their testimony alleging two company supervisors and police directed them to install wiretaps. ``No corroboration _ nobody supports their stories,'' Morelli told the jury in closing arguments. ``It is all a figment of their imaginations.'' Morelli also noted that the former employees declined to take ``lie detector'' tests, while the company supervisors _ Peter Gabor and James West _ voluntarily submitted to the examinations. Gates and Draise say the company is trying to cover up that they were ordered to perform 1,200 wiretaps between 1972 and 1984, at first for Cincinnati police and later by Cincinnati Bell supervisors. The company denies any involvement with illegal wiretaps, and filed a defamation lawsuit against Gates and Draise. Hamilton County Common Pleas Judge Fred J. Cartolano planned to instruct the jury on the law after Gates and Draise completed their closing arguments today. Closing arguments in the eight-week trial began Thursday. As he did throughout the trial, Morelli on Thursday emphasized the employees' inconsistencies and discrepancies. Morelli said Gates has changed his story three times about which supervisor supposedly ordered him to tap the phone of President Ford during a 1975 visit to Cincinnati. ``A liar has to have a terrific memory,'' Morelli said. ``To attempt to establish lies takes a lot of time and a lot of work. They have been inconsistent, and they have contradicted themselves.'' Gates and Draise are defending themselves in the defamation trial. Draise told jurors in closing arguments Thursday that they must find in the employees' favor to prevent companies from retaliating against whistleblowers. ``You have the ability to send Bell and other companies a message: we're not going to stand for it,'' Draise said. Gates admitted Thursday that his memory about the years of supposed wiretaps is hazy, but he said anyone would have trouble remembering such details many years later. He also said Cincinnati Bell had only complimentary things to say about him in his work appraisals before he went public with the wiretap allegations. ``Look through my appraisals,'' Gates told the jurors. ``In 23 years, Cincinnati Bell has never called me a liar.'' Cincinnati Bell contends that Gates and Draise lied to get revenge against the company because Gates was fired in 1986 and Draise in 1979. Cincinnati Bell, its parent, Cincinnati Bell Inc., and two of the phone company's managers, James West and Peter Gabor, sued to challenge the wiretapping claims. Gates and Draise countersued, saying they were injured because Cincinnati Bell officials called them liars. Cartolano on Wednesday dismissed the defamation lawsuit that Gates and Draise filed against Cincinnati Bell. The jury now must decide only the original lawsuit the company filed against the two former installers.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Anticipates Cutting Work Force By 5,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The announcement...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Martin Marietta job cuts.
Eds: Version moving on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. plans to reduce its Seattle-area work force by 5,000 people this year although the company has record orders for commercial jets with deliveries stretching into the next century. Better East-West relations have cast doubt on the future of Boeing's defense business and fewer production workers are needed on the company's 747-400 jumbo jets, Boeing officials said Thursday. Boeing wants to build a new widebody jet, the 777, but no orders have been announced and production startup is at least two years away. The aerospace giant said it hopes to accomplish half the cuts through retirement and resignations. The Martin Marietta Astronautics Group also announced plans Thursday to cut about 200 jobs by the end of February, but will transfer many workers to other posts within the aerospace giant, a company spokeswoman said in Denver. Positions that cannot be directly tied to a contract will be affected, and will be eliminated possibly through a combination of full-time and part-time jobs, said spokeswoman Judy Stowell. A review of business propects for 1990 showed the company needed to cut overhead labor costs, Stowell said. The company employes about 11,500 workers in Colorado, and other Martin divisions employ 3,600 workers. Boeing's announcement came about two months after the company and union workers settled a 48-day strike, which was mainly over wages and mandatory overtime. About 43,000 Seattle area union workers were affected by the strike. Boeing said it will give layoff notices today to about 1,900 employees who might be among some 1,700 workers who will lose jobs starting March 20. The balance of the workers are to be laid off later in the year. Boeing has a backlog of more than 1,700 commercial jets worth about $85 billion. Last year, it added 10,000 employees in the Puget Sound area and was so strapped for production workers on its 747-400 that it borrowed 600 machinists from Lockheed. That startup and certification work has been completed and the extra workers are no longer needed, Boeing said. Delays and uncertainties on other projects, especially defense work, mean the lost jobs cannot be absorbed elsewhere in the company, it said. About 1,400 of the 1,700 hourly employees to be laid off are at the company's Everett plant north of Seattle, where widebody 747s and 767s are built. Most of the others probably will be defense workers, Boeing spokesman Paul Binder said. Thursday's announcement didn't mention possible job losses at Boeing plants outside the Puget Sound region. The company has a large military and commercial plant at Wichita, Kan., a helicopter division at Philadelphia, a space center at Huntsville, Ala., and smaller operations scattered throughout the country. At year end, Boeing had just under 106,700 employees in Washington state. Nationwide, its employment had grown to 145,200, up 10,800 from the beginning of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Rajneesh, Indian Guru Expelled from United States, Dead at 58
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, ``Osho left...' to UPDATE with cremation. Subs 12th graf, `The crowd...' to fix typo. Pickup 13th, `Rajneesh pleaded...' Deletes last graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: The Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the guru who drew thousands of followers to central Oregon by preaching a blend of Eastern religion, pop psychology and free love, died today of heart failure, his spokesman said. He was 58.
