Rajneesh, known as Osho Rajneesh in recent years, died at his commune in the southern city of Poona, where he settled after being deported from the United States in 1985. ``Osho left his body at 5:30 p.m. The doctors say it's heart failure,'' spokesman Swami Chaitanya Kirti said in a telephone interview. Disciples carried Rajneesh's body on their shoulders to a funeral pyre built on a nearby riverbank, and it was cremated, Kirti said. ``I don't think I ever wish anybody dead, but I wished many times that he would go back where he belongs,'' said Jean Opray, former mayor of the town of Antelope, Ore., which was taken over for a time by Rajneesh's followers. Kirti said the guru had greeted followers Wednesday in the Buddha Hall, his Indian commune's main prayer center, but did not appear Thursday because of ``pain on the left side of his chest.'' About 10,000 followers, mostly Westerners, were at the Poona commune when Rajneesh died, Kirti said. Another of Rajneesh's followers, Swami Prabhod, said the devotees burst into songs and chants to celebrate Rajneesh's departure from his earthly body. ``Everybody is singing and celebrating,'' Prabhod said. Music could be heard in the background as he spoke over the telphone from Poona, 750 miles southwest of New Delhi. As ``the Bhagwan,'' a Hindi word for ``god,'' Rajneesh presided over a 64,000-acre commune 120 miles east of Portland, Ore., from 1981 until 1985, when he pled guilty to violating federal immigration laws. In its heyday, the commune known as Rajneeshpuram was home to 4,000 red-clad followers, who toiled 12 hours a day and showered Rajneesh with jewels and Rolls-Royces that he used for daily drives past lines of singing, clapping fans. In ``The Orange Book,'' which contains the guru's teachings, Rajneesh advocated ``dynamic mediation.'' ``Explode! Go totally mad ... Jump up and down shouting the mantra `Hoo! Hoo! Hoo! ... Each time you land, on the flats of your feet, let the sound hammer deep into the sex center,'' he wrote. The crowd at the commune swelled to 15,000 during summer festivals, and residents of nearby communities resented the intrusion. Rajneesh's top aide was eventually convicted in an elaborate scheme designed to gain political control of the county. Rajneesh pleaded guilty in November 1985 to two counts of violating immigration laws by arranging sham marriages to help his foreign disciples remain in the United States illegally. Under a plea agreement, 33 other counts were dropped. Rajneesh received a suspended 10-year sentence, paid a $400,000 fine, and agreed not to return to the United States for five years without the written permission of the U.S. attorney general. He took his throne with him when he left. Rajneesh returned to India but left after a month when the government deported 10 of his aides. For six months he roamed the world in search of a home but was turned away by 21 countries. In July 1986, he returned to Indian and set up a commune. His headquarters in Poona were far humbler than the sprawling ranch in the sage-brush dotted hills of central Oregon's high desert. In Poona, Rajneesh was reduced to a six-acre commune. In December 1988, Rajneesh traded the Hindu honorific of Bhagwan for Osho, a Buddhist term that means ``on whom the heavens shower flowers.'' Rajneesh had reversed his free love preaching in recent years because of the danger of AIDS. He had been in failing health since leaving the United States and often claimed that U.S. officials poisoned him while he was in jail. The lavish Oregon commune, which included orchards, a vineyard, a 65-acre vegetable farm, two lakes stocked with fish, and an airport with a 4,500-foot paved runway, is now deserted. An insurance company foreclosed on the property but never found a buyer. Bernard Smith, district attorney of Oregon's Wasco County, said today that Rajneesh's death marks ``the end of what was a pretty unpleasant experience for most of us here.'' Rajneeshpuram was incorporated as a city on part of the commune in 1982. Disciples also moved into Antelope, a nearby town of 40 people, eventually holding all its elected offices and chaning its name to City of Rajneesh. The Antelope name was restored in 1985 at Rajneesh's suggestion in an effort to make peace with Oregonians. Rajneesh's utopia began to unravel in September 1985, when the guru's personal secretary, Ma Anand Sheela, abruptly left. In October of that year, Rajneesh and Sheela were arrested. The guru was taken into custody when two jets taking him to Bermuda were surrounded at the Charlotte, N.C., airport. Sheela fled to West Germany and was brought back to the United States. She pleaded guilty to a variety of charges, including attempting to murder the guru's personal physician with a poison-filled syringe. She also admitted orchestrating a food poisoning outbreak at restaurants in The Dalles, the county seat, as part of a plot aimed at gaining political control of the county. Sheela was sentenced to 4{ years in prison and ordered to be deported when her sentence was served. Rajneesh's body, attired in the guru's customary flowing robes and diamond-studded cap, was taken to the Buddha Hall three hours after death and was heaped with roses, Rajneesh's favorite flowers, Kirti said. ``There was no incense fixed because he hated its smell,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Cartel Releases Another Hostage, Tells Bush It Gives Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with White House rejecting drug traffickers' plea; picks up 4th pvs, `The cocaine...'
DOC.TEXT: The Medellin cartel released a hostage with a message for President Bush pledging to end the drug trade, but the White House today said the message would not persuade it to deal with drug lords. ``Our position is still the same,'' said White House secretary Marlin Fitzwater in Washington. ``We have traditionally been opposed to deals with the cartel ... Essentially it's a matter for Colombia to deal with.'' The cartel released the hostage Thursday and two other hostages on Wednesday, and in a communique it acknowledged defeat to the government. It offered to stop its activities in exchange for an amnesty. The cocaine lords have made such promises before, and major newspapers and the government called for the war against drugs to continue. In their message to Bush on Thursday, the Extraditables, a group representing the Medellin cartel, said: ``We are going to release all of our hostages.'' The group's name refers to drug suspects the United States wants extradited to face charges. The Extraditables have kidnapped 85 people in the last 45 days. Authorities estimate at least 18 remain in the hands of the cartel. The message was repeated from memory by Roberto Toro Gonzalez, who was kidnapped on Dec. 14. Toro Gonzalez, 23, son of a wealthy family that owns a chain of stores, said in a radio interview his captors made him memorize the message before chaining him to the window grating of a house in Medellin. Journalists from Colombia's two major radio networks, Caracol and RCN, were tipped off by anonymous phone callers and arrived at the scene shortly after Toro Gonzalez's captors drove off. In their message, the Extraditables asked Bush to take them at their word. ``If President Bush and the men of the ... (U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration) do not believe the word of drug traffickers, why do they negotiate with them and why do they let them testify against other suspects?'' the message asked. The cartel apparently was referring to plea-bargaining agreements often made between drug suspects and U.S. authorities. On Wednesday, the cartel freed Patricia Echavarria, the sister of President Virgilio Barco's son-in-law, and her daughter. The two, kidnapped in Medellin Dec. 16, carried the communique from the traffickers conceding defeat. Leading politicians said the struggle was almost over. Two Liberal Party presidential candidates, Ernesto Samper and William Jaramillo, said in declarations published Thursday in the daily El Tiempo that the offensive had pushed traffickers into an ``unconditional surrender.'' Their optimism was shared by Medellin Mayor Juan Gomez, who has repeatedly called for negotiations with the Medellin cartel. El Tiempo quoted Gomez as saying the traffickers' concession of defeat was ``an important step toward peace.'' But in its lead editorial, El Tiempo said the drug war had not ended, although the government offensive was working. Since Barco ordered his crackdown in mid-August, authorities have extradited 13 drug suspects to the United States. The traffickers responded with a terror campaign that killed 209 people, including 107 who died when a bombed jet crashed outside Bogota in November. Authorities also killed a leader of the Medellin cartel, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, in a gunfight. After the traffickers conceded defeat Wednesday, Interior Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds said the government would not be tricked into ending its anti-drug offensive. He also said that under no circumstances would the government negotiate with traffickers or drop the policy of extraditing suspects to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Valentino Becomes Fund-Raiser But Abandons Rome Runway
DOC.TEXT: Valentino, king of Italian couture, has turned mentor and benefactor. Beginning this spring, his Accademia Valentino _ a former school of theology off the Spanish Steps in downtown Rome _ will have art exhibits, concerts and other cultural activities. All proceeds from these events, which will also include private fashion shows, will go to charity, mainly AIDS research and care of AIDS victims. To inaugurate this philanthropic phase, Valentino invited actress Elizabeth Taylor, chairman of the American Foundation for AIDS Research, to be guest of honor at a cocktail party for 1,000 of Rome high society friends. At the soiree, he gave a preview of his spring-summer 1990 high fashion collection that will be presented in Paris later this month. Apparently tired from the day's activities, which included a visit to a home for AIDS victims, Ms. Taylor, wearing an aubergine blue evening gown adorned with a diamond brooch, stayed at the party just long enough Thursday evening to be photographed with the designer, and then disappeared. The disappointed guests who were hoping for a closer look at the actress were left with a glimpse at the new collection, as well as his first art exhibit: 30 paintings and sculptures of the 20th century ``scuola Romana'' that will travel to Moscow later this year. If Valentino's debut in American-style fund-raising is the good news, the bad news is that the golden boy of Italian couture is abandoning the Roman runway, and moving to Paris. Already a year ago, Valentino rocked the couture crowd by showing his new collection not only in Rome, but also in Paris. He repeated this double feature fashion show in the summer. Citing dwindling international interest in the Rome couture scene, indifference of Roman authorities to support the fashion world _ the French Chambre Syndicale supports Parisian fashion both morally and financially _ and the general state of confusion of Rome as it prepares to host the World Cup Soccer championships this summer, Valentino said it was not worth his while to show in Rome. He promises, however, to keep Rome as his headquarters and does not rule out a return on the runway the future. He has been showing his ready-to-wear collection exclusively in Paris for over a decade. What little Romans did see of the collection was beautiful. Harking back to his famous ``white collection'' in Florence that marked the beginning of his success story almost 30 years ago, Valentino presented 19 white silk gowns and suits adorned with tiny pleats, ruffles and a myriad of large mother of pearl and gold buttons. The models stood in static positions, as if at a party, in one of the reception rooms of the palazzo as the crowd filed past. Valentino is not alone in questioning the validity of the Rome fashion week that used to draw the international press and jet set twice a year when such names as Biki, Sorelle Fontana, Fabiani and Capucci dictated Italian fashion mores. Several years ago, Rome fashion got a boost when Milanese designer Gianfranco Ferre chose the capital to present his couture collection. But last summer Ferre was lured to Paris to become designer for the famed house of Dior. Other top names such as Balestra and Barocco have also threatened to abandon ship if Rome authorities do not give them a good reason to stay. In general the new look for spring-summer 1990 shown in Rome this week is demure and romantic. Colors are springtime pastels, and faded floral prints. The favorite fabric is silk chiffon and ruffles and pleats abound. Models wear delicate makeup and long wavy hairstyles. Most successful at this new look, and so far loyal to the Roman runway, was Mila Schoen with a series of garden party silk gowns in floral chiffon prints, with broad brimmed straw hats adorned with matching silk flowers. In response to the cries for help from the Rome fashion crowd, new Mayor Franco Carraro has promised to meet with leaders of the Italian chamber of fashion to see what can be done to boost Italian couture and keep the made-in-Italy label firmly rooted in the Eternal City.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Signs Regulations on Foreign Journalists
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng on Friday signed new regulations governing foreign journalists in China, the official Xinhua News Agency said, but it did not disclose their contents. Foreign journalists were under tight restrictions in Beijing during nearly eight months of martial law that ended Jan. 11. The new regulations are expected to reimpose at least some of those restrictions. The State Council, China's Cabinet, approved them on the same day that martial law ended. Xinhua said the regulations were necessary to ``supervise the activities of foreign journalists and resident foreign news organizations.'' The Foreign Ministry has refused to divulge their contents, and Xinhua did not say if they take effect with Li's signing. Under martial law, foreign journalists were banned from conducting interviews without army approval. All interview requests had to be submitted to the city government, and weeks often passed before a response was made, usually negative. The government expelled two foreign reporters based in Beijing following its June 3-4 army crackdown on pro-democracy protesters, and half a dozen visiting journalists. Police surveillance of journalists, including audible telephone bugs, increased sharply during the summer but appears to have relaxed recently. Information continues to be hard to get, however, because many Chinese officials consider it politically risky to grant interviews. The Beijing city government, meanwhile, approved a regulation forbidding books, magazines and audio or videotapes that ``violate the fundamental principles of the constitution, are pornographic, superstititious or contain other evils.'' It reiterated that all book, magazine, newspaper and tape sellers must be officially licensed, a requirement that has been widely ignored in the past. Authorities nationwide have conducted an intensive campaign since June against pornographic and politically suspect materials. They have raided book stalls, burned tens of thousands of books and magazines and shut down many book distributors and several publishing companies.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Jet Rips Top Off Turboprop, Killing One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with NTSB comment, delete one of two first references to Braden; picks up 8th graf, `Roger Myers....'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX1; LaserColor AX2
DOC.TEXT: A landing Eastern Airlines jet tore the top off a twin-engine plane that touched down just before it, killing one person aboard the smaller aircraft, officials said. None of the 149 people on the jet was injured in the accident on a runway at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport at 7:15 p.m. Thursday, an Eastern spokesman said. The spokesman said a wing was damaged on the jet, a Boeing 727. The collision involved Eastern Flight 111, which originated in Montreal and stopped in New York, and a twin-engine Beechcraft King Air 100 flying from a suburban airport. A second person aboard the Beechcraft was injured. Both planes had been cleared to land, Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Jack Barker said. Asked if that indicated a problem in the control tower, he replied, ``That's under investigation.'' ``Obviously something went wrong for two airplanes to hit each other on the runway,'' Barker said. ``Everything involving the movement of those two aircraft will be considered'' by federal investigators. National Transportation Safety Board investigators from Washington arrived today. Spokeswoman Drucella Andersen said they would question witnesses, including the Eastern crew and the smaller plane's injured co-pilot, and would examine air traffic control tapes and Eastern's operating procedures. Under aircraft approach rules, ``the arriving aircraft cannot be cleared to land until the preceding aircraft has left the runway,'' Ms. Andersen said. ``We won't speculate as to what this might mean. I can't tell you what the cause is.'' Roger Myers, another FAA spokesman, said the Eastern plane was completing its landing as the Beechcraft still was taxiing on the runway. ``The Eastern airliner landed behind him, and they collided on the runway,'' Myers said. ``He (The Eastern pilot) was on his landing roll,'' meaning the jet was still rolling to a stop. Barker said officials did not know how much time lapsed between the two plane landings, although ``It was very close between the two.'' It isn't unusual for planes to land within two minutes of each other at Hartsfield, which was the world's busiest airport in 1987 and ranked third last year, according to FAA figures. The airport averaged 75 landings an hour on two runways in 1987, an airport spokesman said then. It was the first pilot death at Hartsfield since three Delta Air Lines crew members were killed in a 1958 accident, said Hartsfield spokeswoman Rhonda Copenny. She said the huge airport has never had a passenger fatality. Gene Griffin, an Eastern passenger from New York, said, ``The plane veered to the left and hit something. I thought maybe it was a pothole. No one was really sure what was going on, but no one was really hurt or shaken up.'' Those who witnessed the collision described it much differently. ``I seen this debris flying everywhere, terrible, just like it flipped over and it was way up in the air _ terrible,'' said Rodney Johnson, an airport ground worker. Airport spokesman John Braden said the jet coasted 2,000 feet before stopping. The runway where the crash occurred was closed until National Transportation Safety Board investigators would let airport workers move the wreckage, probably sometime today, Braden said. Operations continued normally on the other runways. There was a little rain and fog at the time of the collision, but ``it was not bad weather,'' Braden said. He said he had not talked to controllers in the tower about what might have happened. The Beechcraft was owned by Epps Air Service and based at DeKalb Peachtree Airport on the edge of Atlanta. The two men aboard the plane were Epps employees, Braden said. ``The top half of the plane was pretty well sheared off. ... The engines are intact,'' Braden said. The tail section also was missing. Killed was Eric Thomas, 30, of Acworth, Ga., and injured was Daniel Olthoff, 26, of Norcross, Ga., said officials at the hospital where both were taken. Olthoff was described as ``conscious, alert and talking.'' ``Passengers on the Eastern flight are OK. No injuries,'' said Eastern spokesman Robin Matell in Miami. Matell said the flight was carrying 141 passengers and a crew of eight; Atlanta was its final destination. Matell said the Eastern plane's captain, whose name was not released, had 23 years' experience with the company.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Wants a Bigger Boat _ And He's Getting One
DOC.TEXT: What does the man who has everything give himself? A new, custom-built yacht that's bigger than a football field and fitted with a Roman bath and amphitheater. Billionaire Donald Trump plans to treat himself to just that with his custom-made 420-foot ``Trump Princess,'' which he expects to unveil in 1992 after selling off the current, cramped 282-foot version, said Trump spokesman Jeff Walker. The new boat is necessary because the present ``Trump Princess'' _ recognized in the Guinness Book of World Records as the longest private yacht in the world _ has become too small for the Trumps to entertain guests, Walker said. Trump is looking for a buyer for the 282-foot boat. Trump paid $30 million for it; his asking price is $115 million.

DOC.HEAD: Yoko Unveils Participation Art Piece
DOC.TEXT: Yoko Ono, resurrecting one of the interactive art works she displayed at the London show where she met John Lennon, unveiled ``Painting to Hammer a Nail In 1961-1990'' at a church on Friday. ``For me, this piece has worked as a kind of atonement, to start a new decade with a clearer vision, and to replace my reverence for the abstract with that of life,'' Ono said in a statement. ``I dedicate this piece to all martyrs in the history of the earth.'' The artwork, on display for the next year at the Judson Memorial Church in Manhattan, allows visitors to pound a nail into a cross-shaped piece of wood. One of its earlier incarnations was on display at the 1966 show where she and Lennon met. The display is part of the 100th anniversary of the church. The church's senior minister, Howard Moody, said the church was ``proud to host this work of art which is a symbol of resistance to every from of artistic tyranny by church and state.'' Lennon and Ono were married for 11 years until he was murdered outside their Manhattan apartment in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Actress: I Don't Date Actors Anymore
DOC.TEXT: After spending three years with Matthew Broderick and nine months as Johnny Depp's fiancee, actress Jennifer Grey has decided she won't be dating any actors any time soon. ``In the words of my people, 'Never again,''' Grey tells US magazine in its Feb. 5 issue. ``I'm an equal opportunity dater. I think everybody should have a shot.'' The actress, best known for her role in ``Dirty Dancing,'' describes Broderick and Depp as ``lovely boys, both of them.'' And she says her naive character in the smash film with Patrick Swayze was really an acting reach for her. ``Sometimes I think I did too good a job because people think that's who I am,'' she said. ``I was never that innocent in my whole life. Ever. Ever!''

DOC.HEAD: Barry's Arrest Could Kill Re-Election Bid, Observers Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 13 grafs new with announcement plans postponed, more reaction. Picks up 11th graf pvs, Even before.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, arrested on a charge of possessing crack cocaine, postponed indefinitely today announcement of his candidacy for a fourth term, City Hall sources said. Elected officials and politicians were describing the mayor's arrest as a crippling blow to his re-election bid, already facing several challengers and the formidable shadow of Jesse Jackson. Word of the postponement of Barry's announcement, which had been scheduled for Sunday, came from top city officials, who spoke only on condition they not be identified. Jackson was in Chicago. His only comment on the arrest was to say he was ``stunned.'' The two-time presidential candidate established residence in the nation's capital last year and has held a wide lead in opinion polls over all other potential mayoral candidates. But Jackson had said he would not challenge Barry, an old friend from thir days in the civil rights movement. In recent weeks, sources close to Jackson had described him as backing away from a mayoral bid. Barry, 53, was arrested on a narcotics charge Thursday night in what federal authorities described as ``an ongoing public corruption probe.'' He was charged with one count of cocaine possession, a misdemeanor. A federal law enforcement source said authorities had a videotape of Barry smoking crack cocaine at a downtown hotel. Barry has long denied rumors that he uses drugs. ``Politically, I think he is finished,'' said Julius Hobson, formerly the city's chief lobbyist on Capitol Hill and now an aide to Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va. ``This charge, apparently with audio and video evidence ... (is) political evidence that you cannot overcome.'' Hobson added, ``This may well be the opening that many of us have speculated Jesse was looking for. He has said he would never run against Marion, and now that problem may have been solved for him.'' Walter Fauntroy, Washington's elected non-voting member of Congress, said he was in shock _ ``the shock that comes to any family member who has been told repeatedly by somebody he cares about that he is not using drugs, and finds out that's not the case.'' Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., ranking Republican on the House Committee on the District of Columbia, said Barry should temporarily turn over his mayoral duties to another city official while the case is pending. Ron Brown, the national chairman of the Democratic Party, called the arrest ``troubling news.'' Brown said in a statement issued by his office that Barry ``is entitled to his day in court and I believe that a discussion of the political options for the District of Columbia should not interfere with the legal process.'' Brown's counterpart, Republican Chairman Lee Atwater, declined comment when asked about Barry's arrest, as did William Bennett, President Bush's federal drug policy coordinator. Even before Thursday night's arrest, Barry's chances of winning re-election appeared shaky as the drug use accusations mounted, the city's homicide rate continued breaking records and Barry battled claims of fiscal mismanagement. In 1986, he faced only token Democratic opposition in his re-election bid; this time around, four Democrats so far said they would run against him. Barry, elected in 1978 as the city's second mayor under home rule, said as recently as Friday that he has been the victim of ``character assassination.'' The arrest ``certainly is going to put a damper on his campaign, if indeed there is a campaign,'' said attorney Max Berry, who directed Barry's 1986 re-election effort but has since soured on the mayor. ``If there is any good to come from this, maybe we will look inside ourselves, find better candidates for office and demand more of them.'' Gregory E. Mize, general counsel to the D.C. Council, said that by law, the mayor can keep his office even though he has been arrested. However, Mize said that if Barry were convicted and incarcerated, he probably would not still qualify as a voter and therefore could lose his office. Elected officials said they were stunned by the news of Barry's arrest, and many predicted he now will have a difficult time gaining support for a fourth term. ``I just think this is going to be a terrible shock to the young people of our city,'' said City Councilman John Ray, one of those challenging Barry for the Democratic mayoral nomination. Others spoke of the irony of the city's top elected official facing drug charges as drug-related murders continued to plague the city. ``Obviously, anybody who has to depend on public support in a time where there is drug pushing and a lot of killing will be negatively affected politically,'' said Councilman Frank Smith. ``This is a difficult thing to deal with.'' But nearly all observers said the mayor's arrest is the latest indignity for a city burdened over the past two years with an increasingly negative image around the country. ``As a native Washingtonian, it's embarrassing,'' Hobson said. ``It is also a truly sad time for ... local Washington.''

DOC.HEAD: Antarctica Expedition Reaches Last Stop Before Final Leg of Journey
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Mirnyy' in 5th graf cq.
DOC.TEXT: A ski and sled dog team trying to make the first unmechanized crossing of Antarctica has arrived at the Soviet scientific base of Vostok, the last major stop before the journey's final leg. Thursday's arrival of the Trans-Antarctica Expedition, led by Will Steger of Ely and Jean-Louis Etienne of France, was confirmed when Etienne called a Paris science museum via satellite telephone, according to a statement from the expedition's headquarters in St. Paul. The six-person team's 750-mile trek from the South Pole to Vostok was the first foot crossing of the inhospitable Area of Inaccessibility. They planned to rest several days at the base in eastern Antarctica before heading the difficult final 850 miles of its 4,000-mile journey to Mirnyy, which they hope to reach in early March. After leaving Vostok, which is at 11,500 feet, the team will encounter deep snow and many crevasses as they travel to Mirnyy, a Soviet science station on the continent's Indian Ocean shore. As the Antarctic winter approaches, the team expects temperatures to drop daily from the current 30 degrees below to as low as 80 below. ``Our team can handle the weather,'' Steger said in a recorded message sent to the expedition's headquarters. ``It is the lack of visibility that will be a major problem. If we can't see the trail we will have to sit in our tents and wait. We cannot travel when we cannot see because the terrain will be full of crevasses.'' The team includes members from Great Britain, Japan, the Soviet Union and China.

DOC.HEAD: College Temporarily Covers Three Nude Drawings after Protests
DOC.TEXT: Truckee Meadows Community College administrators have covered three nude drawings hung in a hallway school art gallery until after spring registration, drawing protests from the artist. Donna Moore, 38, an art instructor at Truckee Meadows and at the University of Nevada, Reno, said Thursday she was shocked by the decision to cover her charcoal artwork. The female nudes are an artistic tradition and ``the perfect creation of God,'' she said. But student Loretta Abbott, 24, disagreed. ``I try to follow Jesus Christ,'' she said. ``I sin enough on my own. I don't need to pass by this every day.'' The decision to cover the nudes was made because of Abbott's complaints and because children often accompany parents to the college during registration, which ends Wednesday, said Jim Claybrook, a college grants administrator.

DOC.HEAD: Met to Help Romanians Restore Damaged Art, Museum
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art will help one of Europe's least-known art museums, the Romanian National, restore a collection damaged by revolution and four decades of Communist rule. Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, met with senior cultural officials Thursday to assess the damage, and he said afterward he will try to raise corporate support to give the Romanians basic materials and equipment. One way to help may be to exhibit at the Met six to eight of the best works from the Romanian collection, which features El Grecos, Van Eycks and French impressionists, de Montebello said. The Romanian collection and its museum were severely damaged in the revolution that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu on Dec. 22. It also had suffered for years beforehand from lack of funds and political manipulation, the Romanian and American museum officials say. ``The problems are much greater than the damage caused by the revolution,'' said Everett Fahy, the Met's chief curator who accompanied de Montebello. ``Due to decades of neglect ... their heritage is disintegrating.'' Dorana Cosoveanu, an art critic who has spent 25 years at the Romanian National Gallery, confirmed that as she guided a visitor around the burned-out, bullet- and mortar-scarred galleries of what used to be an art museum. In 1977, Ceausescu appointed Alexander Cebuc, a historian specializing in Communist Party lore, to head the art gallery, she said. Part of the Ceausescu personality cult were the exhibits the dictator and his wife, Elena, constantly imposed on the museum, forcing it to turn over its ground floor galleries to giant paintings glorifying the ruling couple, she said. Now, as workers begin the enormous task of repairing the gallery and dozens of canvases ripped by bullets, there is just one painting _ a torn portrait of the Ceausescus _ left hanging. Part of a vast canvas showing the rulers surrounded by Romanian children in folk costume, it has been vandalized by the workers to depict Ceausescu as a latter-day Adolf Hitler complete with Nazi swastika medal and ``SS'' on his lapels, and shows his wife as a she-devil with giant red ears. The gallery's real exhibits are in storage, some of them bandaged as primitively as injured victims of the revolution in the museum workers' attempts to carry out what Cosoveanu termed ``first aid'' on the damaged paintings. De Montebello said the museum needs everything from rice paper and canvas, to photocopying machines. He also said its workers need to gain modern expertise by interning at the Met. What some of the museum's employees lacked in that knowledge they made up in devotion as the gallery came under heavy fire in the battle against Ceausescu. The gallery was heavily attacked because it was housed in one wing of Ceausescu's official presidential palace, the former palace of Romania's kings, in central Bucharest. An attic common to the presidential quarters and the gallery apparently enabled the ``terrorists'' _ as Romanians call the Ceausescu loyalists _ to sneak down a now-blackened staircase in the museum to battle the army outside. Not one museum window survived the onslaught of gunfire and mortars in the battle between soldiers loyal to the revolt and elite Ceausescu guards opposing it. Cosoveanu first realized the museum's collection could be in danger hours before the dictator's overthrow, when angry crowds swarmed into the Palace square early on Dec. 22. She feared they did not know that one wing of the palace was an art collection. Leaping from the ground floor window of a now burned-out office, she ran to the crowds to urge them against attack, assuring them this was a museum, not a Ceausescu haunt. Museum workers, meanwhile, scrambled to remove to storage the paintings and artifacts small enough for them to carry, she said. Young people, and even Cebuc and other party officials, helped as fierce fighting erupted toward evening, trapping her and other loyal workers in the museum. Eventually, soldiers arrived. They were too late to save 16 destroyed canvases or to prevent severe damage to at least 20 others. Under the guidance of Cosoveanu and other museum officials who braved heavy gunfire to return to the gallery, however, they moved a giant El Greco ``Adoration'' and several other valuable works to safety. A tour of the museum made evident it will take years to repair the damage done to Romania's finest art collection, but the revolution has restored to the museum some hope it can once again become a national pride. ``We'll have the whole building,'' Cosoveanu said. ``When I was a student, the museum was in all the palace. So we'll go back to older times in this respect _ I hope.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Bob Dylan leads a cast of groups including British bands Tears for Fears and The Eurythmics, Scotland's Marillion, Bon Jovi of the United States, and pop artist Terence Trent D'Arby for a six-day, two-city rock festival. An estimated 90,000 Brazilians turned out Thursday out for opening night of Hollywood Rock, which moves next week to Rio de Janeiro. Dylan, who wore a black leather jacket and jeans despite the near 100-degree summer heat, drew his loudest applause with his 1960s folk hits. Though the 48-year-old singer was billed as the star of opening night, most of the teen-age fans who gathered Wednesday to see the groups arrive said they were waiting for a glimpse of the New Jersey band Bon Jovi.

Allen Collins, who lost fellow members of his rock group Lynyrd Skynyrd in a 1977 plane crash and was paralyzed by a 1986 drunken driving accident, is critically ill, according to friends. Collins, 37, has been hospitalized for 4{ months at Memorial Medical Center of Jacksonville. His family has asked that that no further information be released on his illness or condition, a hospital spokesman said. They also asked that no one call or visit. Two friends, Barry Harwood and Rick Reichard, said they had been told the former guitarist was suffering from pneumonia and other respiratory infections. Collins began his rise to success as the lightning-fingered guitarist for Lynyrd Skynyrd, formed in 1966 by a group of Lee High School students. The band enjoyed national fame in the 1970s with such hits as ``Free Bird,'' ``Saturday Night Special,'' ``Gimme Three Steps,'' and ``Sweet Home Alabama.''

A judge says former heavyweight boxing champion Joe Frazier didn't have much of a defense when he argued against a speeding ticket he received on the Pennsylvania Turnpike last summer. Frazier, who attended his hearing without an attorney Thursday, told district Justice Erika McVicker he wasn't feeling well and was in a hurry to get home when state police radar clocked his car at 74 mph on Aug. 23. He lost the case and paid $143.50 in fines and costs, Ms. McVicker said. Despite his loss, ``He signed autographs and posed for pictures after the hearing,'' she said. Frazier was World Boxing Association heavyweight champion from 1970 to 1973. He lost his last fight to Muhammed Ali in 1975 and now operates Smokin' Joe and Son gymnasium in Philadelphia.

The identical twins of the late U.S. Rep. Mickey Leland, killed in a plane crash in Africa, will be named Cameron George and Austin Mickey Leland, their mother says. Alison Leland, who gave birth to the twin boys 10 weeks prematuraly Sunday in Atlanta, said Thursday the children will be named after their father. ``George is Mickey's real name, Mickey is actually a nickname,'' she said. ``What I was thinking is that my oldest son Jarrett has the gift of having memories of the father. The others have his names.'' Mrs. Leland was in Atlanta for observances of the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday at which her late husband was honored. Leland was killed in August while on a hunger relief mission.

Country music singer Hank Snow, celebrating his 40th anniversary on the Grand Ole Opry, remembers having butterflies during his debut on the show. ``I remember it very, very well,'' he said in an interview Thursday about his first Opry performance in 1950. ``I was nervous, not to the point of passing out, but I was nervous.'' Snow, 75, will observe his anniversary on the long-running show Saturday night. The event will be broadcast live on The Nashville Network on cable television. Snow is best known for his 1950 hit record ``I'm Movin' On.'' He was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1979.

Imprisoned soul singer James Brown was eligible for a work release program Friday, but he stayed in jail because South Carolina authorities aren't sure about his Georgia sentence. Brown, 56, was jailed a year ago for aggravated assault and failing to stop for police. He already was on probation for a guilty plea involving carrying an unlawful pistol, resisting arrest and pleading no contest for possession of the hallucinogenic drug phencyclidine, or PCP. He was sentenced in South Carolina to six years six months, and in Georgia to six years and three months, with the two sentences running concurrently. ``When it comes to work release, our laws are different, and we have asked his attorney to get his Georgia status clear. We haven't heard back,'' Department of Corrections spokesman Francis X. Archibald said Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Police Drive Protesters Out of Lebanese Embassy
With AM-Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Police on Friday ended a week-long occupation of the Lebanese Embassy, driving out about 30 protesters loyal to Christian military leader Gen. Michel Aoun. No arrests were reported and the demonstrators left the grounds peacefully after officers entered the chancellory, police said. The Foreign Ministry said the evacuation was requested by Ambassador Fouad Turk, who spent the last week negotiating with the occupants to leave. Dozens of protesters took over the chancellory Jan. 11 to protest the plans of Lebanese Prime Minister Salim Hoss to transfer several diplomats in the United States and Europe. They controlled the embassy switchboard and prevented staff from entering. Several hundred demonstrators turned out to support them Sunday, walking through the chancellory and chanting pro-Aoun slogans. Aoun, a Maronite Christian who controls remnants of Lebanon's army, is opposed to Hoss and President Elias Hrawi, whom he views as appointees of Syria. Syria maintains about 40,000 troops in the Middle Eastern country and supports Moslem militias opposed to Aoun.

DOC.HEAD: Pop Singer Mel Appleby Dead at 22
DOC.TEXT: Mel Appleby of the pop music duo Mel and Kim has died after a two-year battle with cancer. She was 22. Ms. Appleby was hospitalized earlier this week with pneumonia and died Thursday. She and her sister, Kim, began their recording career in 1986 and their disco song ``Showing Out,'' reached No. 2 in the British singles charts.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Four Salvadoran Officers, Five Soldiers Charged With Jesuits' Murders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Expands 5th graf, `The ruling...' to ADD that case now enters a lengthy investigation phase. Pickup 6th, `Col. Guillermo...'
DOC.TEXT: An army colonel, three lieutenants and five enlisted men were charged with murder today in the November slayings of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her teen-age daughter. Judge Ricardo Zamora of the 4th Penal Court ordered the eight defendants in custody held for trial on charges of murder with ``premeditation and perfidy,'' which carries a maximum sentence of 30 years, according to court secretary Nicolas Hernandez. The ninth suspect deserted from the army in December and is a fugitive. Zamora issued his ruling at the end of a 72-hour deadline that began Tuesday when the prisoners, who have been under arrest since early January, were put at the disposition of the court. The ruling means there is enough evidence to make a case against the defendants. The ruling begins a 120-day period during which the case is prepared for trial, but this investigation phase can be delayed by motions. Col. Guillermo Benavides, director of the Military College, is the highest ranking armed forces officer to be accused of a crime involving a human rights abuse in the 10-year-old civil war against leftist guerrillas. The slain Jesuits were educators at the Jose Simeon Canas Central American University, one of the region's top colleges. The killings shocked El Salvador and the world and prompted calls in the Congress for reappraisal of the $1.5 million daily that Washington supplies in U.S. economic and military aid to this small Central American nation. No military officer has been convicted before of a crime linked to human rights abuses, even though rightist death squads sponsored or tolerated by the armed forces killed thousands of suspected leftists in the early 1980s. The Jesuits and the two women were slain in their campus home Nov. 16, five days after the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front guerrillas launched their biggest offensive of the war. The far right had long accused the Jesuits of being subversive ideologues because of they publicly argued that the civil war was the result of gross social injustice rather than a communist attempt to seize power.

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Chapter Criticizes Austin School Board for Holiday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Monday's federal...' with one graf to CORRECT by showing difference in King and Confederate holidays.
DOC.TEXT: The school board has insulted blacks by giving students a day off on Confederate Heroes Day but not on Martin Luther King Jr. Day, a local NAACP official said. ``Houston, Dallas, San Antonio and Fort Worth schools closed to recognize Martin Luther King Jr. Day,'' Victor Goode said Thursday at a news conference in front of a statue honoring Texans who fought for the Confederacy during the Civil War. ``Why Austin refuses and, whether wittingly or unwittingly, encourages the celebration of Confederate Heroes Day is insulting,'' said Goode, a member of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Confederate Heroes Day, celebrated today, honors Robert E. Lee, the general who led Confederate forces, and Jefferson Davis, the president of the Confederacy. Monday's federal holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader and the holiday honoring the Confederate leaders are optional state holidays. But there is a difference. Workers taking off the King holiday must make up that time by working one of several state holidays. But state employees taking off Confederate Heroes Day do not have to make up the time and those that do work get compensatory time off. Austin Independent School District officials said they gave students Thursday and today off because it's the end of the semester. Teachers use the time to compile grades and prepare for the spring semester. School trustee Bernice Hart, the only black on the seven-member board, said the two days off at the end of the semester are given to students each year. ``I had no idea it was Confederate Heroes Day,'' Ms. Hart said. ``It's simply on the calendar as the end of the semester.''

DOC.HEAD: Femininity Keynote of Summer Couture
DOC.TEXT: Soft and alluringly sexy are the way couturiers see women and their clothes for next summer in early sneak previews of haute couture shows. Designers are frantically stitching up hems _ very short _ for the shows that get under way this weekend. Luxury clothes are more feminine than ever: softer shoulders, deeper decolletes, flounces and embroideries. The shows will be more Italian than ever, with Gianfranco Ferre now haute couturier for Dior, and Angelo Tarlazzi designing for Guy Laroche's couture house, following Laroche's death last winter. Gianni Versace also is giving a show of his ``Atelier'' styles and a gala dinner at the Hotel Ritz on Saturday night. ``Paris is the best showcase,'' said Versace, who displayed his furred and fussy clothes on mannequins at a museum last season but considers this show with live models his real Paris couture debut. But Italians won't be grabbing all the headlines. Fashion-watchers are looking forward to the Lanvin show with French designer Claude Montana at the design helm. Will the avant-garde creator produce the kind of opulent elegance usually seen at this venerable house? They'll find out on Tuesday with the Lanvin show near the Ecole Militaire. As the first French couturier to breech the Iron Curtain, Pierre Cardin has manufactured and sold clothes in the Soviet Union for several years. He was instrumental in helping set up a French model agency, ``Glamour,'' there last fall, and he encouraged the Soviet government to accord professional status to models. Besides higher hemlines, the upcoming 25 couture shows include billowy organzas by Ferre for Dior, and sexy, draped and structured shapes in silk at Givenchy. Hanae Mori, celebrating her 35th year in fashion, is kicking up her heels with some shorter, knee-revealing styles, which is new for this usually conservative Japanese designer. Louis Feraud plans to show off garden-party girls in fluid dresses with appliqued leaves, but also revealed a bit of bare midriff in a little silk suit with graphic striped bows in a preview photo session. Jean-Louis Scherrer is apprently still inspired by his all-time favorite theme of the rich Raj looks from India: turbans, silk braid and all. Colors will be hot and spicy, starting with a shocking pink suit by Erik Mortensen at Balmain. Karl Lagerfeld is going for some warm corals in his collection of abbreviated styles for Chanel. Ungaro previewed an intriguing silk suit of pink and lavender piped in fanciful swirls of tangerine around the asymmetric decollete jacket. Philippe Venet uses mandarin orange and plum to advantage in a short raw silk suit with trapeze jacket. After his Sunday couture show, Christian Lacroix's big moment will be the Sunday night launch of his first perfume with a musical show at the Opera Comique. Named ``C'est la Vie,'' the scent will be presented in an elaborate bottle sculpted with a handprint and a little coral branch _ a Lacroix signature.

DOC.HEAD: Alabama Can Fly Confederate Flag, Court Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf at end with judges' names.
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court conceded that the Confederate battle flag that flies atop the Alabama Capitol is offensive to many people, but declined to get involved in the dispute. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in a ruling made public Thursday, said the flying of the Rebel banner on public buildings does not violate the Constitution, as alleged by the NAACP and 14 black state lawmakers. The Atlanta-based appeals court upheld a district court decision in favor of the state, rejecting claims that the flag display violates the First, 13th and 14th amendments. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, along with the 14 legislators, sued the state to remove the Confederate flag, which flies on top of the Capitol dome with the American and state flags. One of the legislators, Rep. Alvin Holmes, said no decision had been made on an appeal, but he hopes the case is taken to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``The issue of the Confederate flag is not going to go away. We are going to continue our efforts to remove it because it represents slavery and oppression toward black people. It's hurting the image of the state and hurting industry coming into the state,'' Holmes said. The appeals court suggested that those who oppose the display go through the Legislature to get it taken down. ``It is unfortunate that the state of Alabama chooses to utilize its property in a manner that offends a large portion of its population, but that is a political matter,'' the court said. The NAACP said the flying of the flag amounted to use of state property for racially discriminatory purposes; violatated the 13th Amendment ban on slavery as it was viewed by many blacks as a symbol of slavery; and violated free speech because salutation of the American flag was inhibited by those who oppose the Confederate flag. The 11th Circuit rejected all three arguments. The 3-0 decision came from a panel composed of U.S. Circuit Judges Frank Johnson Jr. and Larry Edmondson, and Robert F. Peckham, a senior U.S. district judge from California. Johnson wrote the court's opinion.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sets Dates of Ceremonies to Enthrone Emperor Akihito
With AM-Japan-Mayor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito will be formally enthroned in November in two ceremonies costing $55.6 million, a government committee decided Friday. The decision was made official during a Cabinet meeting after the committee, chaired by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, discussed and approved the ceremony dates, an official at the Prime Minister's Office said. The coronation will be held as a state affair at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo on Nov. 12, while the ``Daijosai,'' or ``Great Food Offering Ritual,'' will be conducted according to customs of the Shinto religion on the evening of Nov. 22 and will last into the following day. Akihito, 56, assumed the Chrysanthemum Throne when his father, Hirohito, died of cancer at age 87 on Jan. 7, 1989. But he and other imperial family members avoided holding important ceremonies and observed a year-long mourning period, thus delaying the coronation. The government has earmarked $55.6 million as expenses for the two ceremonies in next fiscal year's budget, which starts April 1. In the coronation, Akihito will announce his accession to about 2,500 invited dignitaries at the palace. Akihito and Empress Michiko will then lead a parade through Tokyo to announce the coronation and receive blessings from the people. Four days of banquets are to be held from that evening, with a total guest list of 3,400. In the controversial Daijosai, the new emperor offers freshly harvested rice to the gods of Shinto, then joins the gods in a communion and sleeps with the spirit of the sun goddess, according to the Shinto religion. Shinto is an indigenous faith based on nature worship, shamanism and elaborate rites. The Cabinet has said the Daijosai is ``a public ceremony in nature,'' but that it will not conduct the rite as a state affair because that might violate the constitutional separation of state and religion. Some opposition parties, including the Socialists and Communists, have denounced state funding. Under the Constitution, the emperor is a symbolic figurehead.

DOC.HEAD: High Stakes in Play in Britain's Ambulance Strike
DOC.TEXT: The army ambulances screaming through London traffic look like a throwback to World War II, but they symbolize a modern-day battle between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and the nation's ambulance drivers. Army and police ambulances have been thrown into the fray while the government and the drivers vie for public opinion in a pay dispute that is nearly 5 months old and ranks among the classic confrontations with organized labor that have marked Mrs. Thatcher's decade in power. Routine services have ceased almost throughout the country, forcing state health authorities to hire taxis and relatives to use their own cars to bring non-emergency cases to hospitals. Emergency calls are diverted to the police, army or Red Cross. Meanwhile, some crews suspended for joining the dispute are operating an unofficial service. They accept emergency calls direct from hospitals or members of the public, but not from the ambulance control rooms, which are their management. Each side accuses the other of being callous and risking lives in the increasingly bizarre and acrimonious dispute. There are no official figures on strike-related deaths, but doctors in Birmingham, central England, say they know of three patients who died because help arrived too late. The protests began Sept. 7 when Britain's 22,500 ambulance drivers started refusing to work overtime. In October, emergency crews stopped using their radios or, in many cases, answering calls routed through control rooms. Their employer, the state-funded National Health Service, responded by suspending the drivers without pay. With the crisis deepening, the Conservative Party government ordered in police and army ambulances on Nov. 8. It was the first time they had been used for civilian ambulance work since 1978-79, when public service strikes hit a Labor Party government. As frustration mounts, crews at half a dozen stations in London and south England recently defied union orders and voted to strike. Union leaders fear this will alienate the public. The public, which in the past has backed Mrs. Thatcher against the once-powerful unions, has so far supported the ambulance crews. They have become national heroes during an 18-month string of national disasters, including the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. The latest Gallup opinion poll says they are backed by 85 percent of Britons. Four million people signed a petition of support, and 30,000 turned out to cheer the crews as they marched through central London. Health Secretary Kenneth Clarke, the government's front-line fighter in the dispute, rejects the crews' claim to be treated like police and firefighters, arguing that only 10 percent of ambulance work involves real emergencies. But he has blundered in his choice of words _ saying most ambulance crews run a ``taxi service for old ladies,'' and that they are little more than ``professional drivers, a worthwhile job but not an exceptional one.'' Such imagery goes down poorly with a public that is used to seeing ambulance crews cutting survivors out of train wrecks or wading into burning subway stations. ``We are sick to death of this government ... attending every disaster that occurs, saying how wonderful the emergency services are and then refusing to pay them a decent wage,'' says Labor lawmaker Dawn Primarolo. Ambulance crews, who earn $16,630 a year, want 11.4 percent more, plus the automatic inflation-linked raises given to firefighters and policemen. The government has offered 6.5 percent, and bonuses for staff who have paramedical skills. The drivers reject that as ``elitist and divisive.'' The confrontation encapsulates the problems Mrs. Thatcher faces amid signs that Britain is slipping back into old habits of pricing itself out of the market with inflation-fueling wage hikes. Latest figures show production costs in Britain rising three times faster than in the United States and more than six times faster than in Japan. The ambulance crews' demands could be met for a paltry $16 million. But inflation is near 8 percent, and the government fears a surrender would encourage demands for double-digit raises by the rest of the one million staff in the health service, Europe's biggest employer. ``To the government it doesn't matter who dies, they are just hellbent on defeating us,'' said Chris Cosham, a 28-year-old suspended ambulanceman. ``It looks very desperate for us now. But we'll give them a bloody fight.''

DOC.HEAD: Auditor Cites Weak Financial Controls on Drought-relief Haylifts
DOC.TEXT: A drought-relief program for farmers in 1988 and 1989 suffered from poor financial controls that resulted in large uncollectable debts and sometimes involved poor-quality hay, according to an audit. ``Because controls over the program were weak, the (Minnesota Agriculture Department) and the state have lost money on the program,'' according to a legislative auditor's report released Thursday. The haylifts were implemented in an effort to get low-cost hay to drought-stricken farmers. The state bought the hay at below-market prices and sold it to farmers for the same price. The state bought $258,000 worth of drought-relief hay in 1988 and by late last year had collected only $129,325 from farmers, the audit says. The Agriculture Department said the 1988 haylift delivered hay to 432 farmers, 407 of whom paid for it. In the 1989 haylift, the state bought $176,000 worth of hay, delivered to 114 farmers, and had collected $81,600 from only 78 farmers by late last year. The auditor reported that some of the hay was so waterlogged or spoiled that it had to be buried. In addition, the audit said the state hadn't tried to collect on about $30,000 worth of spoiled hay from the 1988 haylift. On one occasion, the audit reported, the state paid people who had volunteered to work on the haylift program for nothing.

DOC.HEAD: Court Overturns Murder Convictions in Job-Related Death
DOC.TEXT: A state appellate court today overturned the murder convictions of three former executives in the work-related death of an employee exposed to cyanide on the job. The 1985 Cook County Circuit Court verdict against executives of Elk Grove Village-based Film Recovery Systems Inc. was believed to be the first in which corporate officials were convicted of murder charges in a job-related death. The appellate court ruled the convictions on charges of murder and on charges of involuntary manslaughter and reckless conduct were ``irreconcileable'' because of the different mental states required for such findings, said defense attorney Elliot Samuels. ``The court has opened the door for a new prosecution,'' Samuels said. Stefan Golab, 61, a Polish immigrant who worked at the plant where cyanide was used to recover silver from used X-ray film, collapsed at work after complaining of dizziness and nausea in 1983. His death was attributed to cyanide poisoning from inhaling fumes on the job. The appellate court sent the case back to the lower court, where Cook County State's Attorney Cecil Partee may pursue it if he decides to, said spokesman Ed McManus. Partee was out of the office and not immediately available for comment, McManus said. The state's attorney's office under the direction of Richard M. Daley, now mayor of Chicago, successfully prosecuted the case in 1985. The appeals court overturned convictions on charges of murder, reckless conduct and involuntary manlaughter against the defunct company's former president, Steven J. O'Neil, plant manager Charles Kirschbaum and foreman Daniel Rodriquez. The men were found guilty at a bench trial before Circuit Judge Ronald J.P. Banks. Elliot, who represent Kirschbaum and Rodriquez in the appeal, said that a murder conviction required a determination of a deliberate state of mind, while a finding of reckless conduct required a finding ``somewhere between negligence and indifference ... conscious disregard of serious risk.'' ``We argued that (contradiction) at the trial level and at the appeal,'' he said. Five people originally were charged. Gerald Pett, a vice president and manager was acquitted. A fifth defendant, Utah businessman and former Film Recovery vice president Michael McKay, has been the subject of three unsuccessful extradition requests by Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson. Utah officials said they questioned whether he could receive a fair trial.

DOC.HEAD: Gubernatorial Candidate Defends Use of Fists
DOC.TEXT: Texas gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams is defending two fist fights during his adult life, asking, ``Do you want a patsy for governor or somebody who'll fight for the things Texas needs?'' Some of his election opponents have criticized the fights, but the oilman, rancher and Republican front-runner says in each case it was the proper thing to do. ``I have had two fights in 33 years,'' Williams, 58, said Thursday. ``That's not too bad. I will defend myself.'' The fights occurred in Williams' hometown of Midland, Texas, about five years ago. Williams, shown leading the seven-candidate Republican primary field in recent opinion polls, was criticized this week by opponents Kent Hance and Tom Luce. ``This is not like the old days in Texas where you take the law into your own hands,'' said Luce's campaign manager, Jim Oberwetter. ``It's going to be up to the voters to decide if Clayton Williams' propensity for fighting is going to be an issue,'' said Hance press secretary Mark Sanders. But Williams and his staff defended both encounters. Bill Kenyon, the candidate's press secretary, said the fights involved people who once were friends of Williams. ``One who had severely betrayed his trust and the other who was just an outright bully, a physical bully, to Clayton's employees,'' he said. Williams said he had no regrets. ``The one fight in question, a guy became an alcholic. He was a close friend of mine and I was not dealing with him but with the disease of alcoholism,'' Williams said. He said the man had ``harassed all my little people'' for several years after Williams fired him in 1978. ``He came in the building one day raising Cain. It was my idea that this was man-to-man. It wasn't time to call a policeman or a lawyer. It was he and I, and I decked him. And I'd do it again.'' Williams also defended the outcome. ``Are we interested in results? The man never, ever bothered any of my people again.'' As the issue has gained publicity around the state, Williams and his staff appear to be enjoying the attention. ``I don't now how Tom Luce would handle a bully, but I think most Texans would appreciate a man who would stand up to a bully ... What's he going to do, call a lawyer?'' responded Kenyon when told of Luce's criticism.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Limousine Breaks Down on Highway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to CORRECT that breakdown was on way to speech sted airport.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: A limousine carrying President Bush broke down today, briefly delaying Bush as he was being ferried to downtown Atlanta to make a speech, the Secret Service said. Bush's car developed an oil pressure problem, causing it to stop on Interstate 75 in northwest Atlanta, Dwight Ellison, agent in charge of the Secret Service office in Atlanta, said. ``We switched him to a spare limo,'' Ellison said. After the brief stop, the Bush motorcade continued to the Omni arena, where the president spoke to the National Homebuilders Association. The disabled limousine was left at the side of the road with a police guard, police spokesman Michael Powell said. Bush later went by motorcade to Dobbins Air Force Base, where he boarded Air Force One for a visit to Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Low-Income Elderly Needlessly Buying `Medigap' Insurance
DOC.TEXT: Roughly half of the 3.5 million low-income older Americans covered by Medicaid needlessly spend hundreds of dollars for private medical insurance, according to a private study released Friday. Between 1.5 million and 2 million people 65 and older are projected to have private insurance such as ``medigap'' policies even though Medicaid covers their medical expenses, the report said. The study was commissioned and released by the American Association of Retired Persons and prepared by Market Facts Inc. based on interviews with a random sample of 1,500 older people contacted by telephone in January and February 1989. ``These findings clearly demonstrate that much more needs to be done to prevent the sale of medigap policies to the Medicaid-eligible population,'' said AAR Executive Director Horace Deets. Medigap policies are designed to cover certain hospital and other medical costs not covered by Medicare. Other health insurance policies bought by older Americans include hospital indemnity plans and policies covering specific diseases. The survey found more than 3 million older Americans who do not qualify for Medicaid say they cannot afford to supplement their Medicare coverage by buying medigap or other private health policies. That number is expected to grow as medigap premiums rise, pushed up in part by the repeal of Medicare's coverage of catastrophic health care expenses, AARP said. The government's General Accounting Office surveyed 20 major medigap insurers late last year and found that 1990 premiums were expected to rise by an average of 19.5 percent over 1989 levels, with increases ranging from 5 percent to 52 percent. The companies attributed more than half of the price rise to increased benefits and administrative costs created by the repeal of the catastrophic package. The AARP study found that people paid an average of $705 a year in premiums for their medigap policies. ``Now that many benefits provided under the catastrophic act have been removed, medigap insurance is all the more necessary,'' Deets said. ``The real tragedy is that due to its increasing costs, this coverage may be out of reach for more older persons.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Rally to Protest Shooting of Mayor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``Police arrested ...'' to make it The Sane Thinkers School.
DOC.TEXT: Japanese expressed outrage Friday over the attempted assassination of Nagasaki's mayor by an ultranationalist who said he ``couldn't condone'' the mayor's comments about the late Emperor Hirohito. About 300 city employees rallied outside City Hall, one day after Hitoshi Motoshima was shot there by a right-wing extremist. Motoshima had received death threats since he said in December 1988 that he felt Hirohito, at the time dying of cancer, bore some responsibility for World War II. ``The mayor was shot, but he was not the only target. Democracy is being threatened,'' said Yukiyoshi Sato, secretary-general of the Nagasaki City Hall Workers Union. ``They've caught the assailant, but that's just the tip of the rightists. They'll just keep coming back,'' Sato said as he sat at the wheel of a van carrying a large banner reading, ``Bullets cannot kill democracy.'' Police arrested Kazumi Tajiri, an avoved right-wing terrorist from Tokyo, and searched offices of The Sane Thinkers School, the rightist group to which he belonged, a police official said on condition of anonymity. Tajiri, 40, admitted shooting Motoshima and said he ``couldn't condone'' Motoshima's remarks, police told reporters. The 67-year-old mayor also said at the time that Hirohito could have prevented the atomic bombing of Nagasaki on Aug. 9, 1945, and of Hiroshima three days earlier. The nuclear attack on Nagasaki left at least 70,000 people dead. The comments infuriated Japan's small but radical right-wing fringe, who revere the imperial family and descended on City Hall in sound trucks demanding ``Death to Motoshima.'' Police protection was provided until Motoshima asked that it be discontinued last month. Following the shooting, the National Police Agency urged local authorities to increase their vigilance over the nation's 820 right-wing groups and recommended tighter security for public figures. At the City Hall rally, Sato said the mayor ``risked his own life in fighting to protect freedom of speech and democracy. We declare our resolve to resolutely uphold these principles in the wake of this attempt to suppress them with a pistol.'' Motoshima was shot once in the back, with the bullet slightly damaging his left lung. Doctors said he would recover and could leave the hospital in a month. Government officials were quick to condemn the attack. ``It cannot be tolerated in the context of freedom and democracy,'' said Chief Cabinet Secretary Mayumi Moriyama, the top government spokeswoman. In an editorial, the daily Asahi Shimbun said such violence ``will lead to fascism.'' ``It's a real shock. In Japan it's so rare for anyone to have a gun _ just police and gangsters,'' said Mikako Umehara, a City Hall employee. ``For this to happen right in front of our eyes is, I think, a much bigger shock than for Americans or Europeans.'' Possession of handguns is illegal in Japan, and only police, the military and strictly licensed hunters are allowed firearms. The Nagasaki City Council on Friday condemned the attack, which it called ``not only a challenge to freedom of speech but a threat to the very existence of a democratic society.'' Hirohito died Jan. 7, 1988 at the age of 87, and formal enthronement ceremonies will take place Nov. 12 for Emperor Akihito, his son. Hirohito renounced his divinity after the war. Many historians agree he was a figurehead wartime leader, but some critics say he played a more active role. Motoshima received several visitors Friday, said city spokesman Masayuki Chita. Several police guarded the hospital. Chita said get-well wishes came from more than 500 people, including some in Nagasaki's sister cities, St. Paul, Minn., and Fuzhou, China.

DOC.HEAD: Virtually Entire Communist Party Leadership in Custody
DOC.TEXT: Nearly all major figures in Nicolae Ceausescu's government, including all but one of the 19 surviving members of his Politburo, are in custody and will face trial, the prosecutor-general said Friday. Also on Friday, state media reported that the leader of the Romanian Orthodox Church stepped down after criticism that he was an apologist for the ousted Communist dictator. About 200 students walked out of classes at Bucharest University's college of architecture, demanding that 26 of the school's 82 professors be fired as incompetents who gained their positions though political connections during Ceausescu's brutal 24-year rule. Prosecuting Ceausescu loyalists is a key test of the National Salvation Front, the provisional government that is struggling to gain the support of the people and lead the country to free elections later this year. Prosecutor-General Gheorghe Robu said in an interview in the newspaper Adevarul that 18 members of the former 21-member Politburo were in custody. Two others, Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were convicted of ``grave crimes'' and executed Dec. 25, three days after they were ousted in a popular uprising. The only Politburo member not under arrest was Paul Niculescu, a more liberal official who is said to have offered his services to the new government. Robu said that 31 former high-ranking officials have been arrested in all, including one of Ceausescu's sons, Nicu, the former party chief in the western city of Sibiu. Robu said most of the jailed Ceausescu figures were cooperating with investigators. Those expected to be tried first are former Communist Party Secretary Emil Bobu, No. 3 in the government behind the Ceausescus and former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu, who headed the despised Securitate secret police. Also among those to be tried are Politburo members Manea Manescu and Ion Dinca. Their trials were expected to begin next week before a military tribunal. Robu said one of Ceausescu's daughters, Zoia-Elena, and another son, Valentin, were in jail but were not leading figures in the ousted regime. The prosecutor said Zoia-Elena had gone on a brief hunger strike in her first days in jail, refusing anything but coffee and smoking her own supply of American cigarettes. ``We told to her that she's living in exactly the same conditions that the Romanian people were subjected to, and she's adopted reasonable behavior,'' the newspaper quoted Robu as saying. Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru wrote in the newspaper that the flow of electricity might be cut to some large industries, saying the country's energy supply was endangered by factories routinely using more than their allotted share. ``Enterprises that draw too much power and do not obey the regulations will have their electricity shut down,'' he said. On Tuesday, Romania's generating plants had to produce 300 extra megawatts of power to meet demand, he said. Under Ceausescu's rule, heating and electricity were strictly limited in public buildings and hundreds of thousands of state-owned apartments to conserve energy so that Romania could export oil. One of the first steps taken by new government was to increase heating and release to the public food in state warehouses. Since then, emergency supplies of both food and fuel have had to be imported. Romanian media said the patriarch of the Orthodox church, Teoctist Arapasu, officially resigned Thursday for reasons of age and health. His age was not given. There had been a clamor for his dismissal since the revolution. Under Ceausescu, the church advised its flock to be loyal to the regime despite repeated government interference in church matters, such as the the jailing of priests that displeased the regime and banning of some services. The denomination is the nation's larges, claiming a membership of 16 million out of Romania's population of 23 million. About 200 of the 500 students in Bucharest's architecture school went on strike Friday, many pinning small triangular signs on their shirts that said simply ``greva,'' or ``strike.'' Student Dumitru Iulian, 21, said he and his colleagues said students would refuse to attend classes until 26 incompetent professors were removed. ``This is the way the regime worked. These professors scaled the professional ladder through their politics,'' Iulian said.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS-Infected Doctor Told She Has Less Than a Year to Live
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with today's proceedings, picks up 5th graf ``It's impossible...'
DOC.TEXT: A young doctor suing the hospital where she says she contracted AIDS was dimissed from the witness stand today because she was still devastated by her physician's testimony that she might die within a year. ``I'm having trouble talking. I don't think I can go on today. I apologize,'' Dr. Veronica Prego, told the trial judge, Justice Aaron D. Bernstein, after five minutes of testimony. ``That's OK, don't apologize,'' said Bernstein, who postponed the proceedings until Monday. One of Prego's lawyers, Susan M. Karten, said her client had complained of a headache and did not sleep Thursday night. ``Hearing that she's going to die within a year'' had caused Prego's restlessness, Karten said. ``She didn't know that. She's just terribly devastated.'' Prego, who was among the first health professionals to contract AIDS at the workplace through a needle stick, cried Thursday when she first heard her physician estimate how long she could live. The blunt assessment came in response to a lawyer's question. Before asking it, Stanley D. Friedman, the lawyer for the city Health and Hospitals Corp., offered to allow Prego, 32, to leave the courtroom. She declined. ``It's impossible to predict, but it's possible her life expectancy will be a year, or perhaps shorter,'' Dr. Gerald H. Friedland said when Friedman asked how long Prego would live. Friedland, Prego's physican for more than three years, said he had never specifically discussed with Prego how long he believed she had to live. Friedman said the answer was something the jury had to know if it ruled for Prego and awarded damages for future suffering and lost earnings. Prego's 67-year-old mother, who testified early in the trial and has sat in the front row of the spectators' section daily, looked on, but did not understand the prognosis because she speaks only Spanish. Prego moved to the United States in 1982 from Argentina, where her family still lives. She maintains she contracted AIDS on Jan. 12, 1983, while working at Kings County Hospital, when she accidentally pricked her finger on a contaminated needle carelessly left amid a pile of soiled gauze and bed linen by another physician, Dr. Joyce Fogel. She is suing the hospital; its parent agency, the Health and Hospitals Corp.; Fogel and another physican, Sheldon Landesman, for $175 million, charging negligence. The defendants say Prego, who was an unpaid medical-school graduate in training at the time, was injured through her own carelessness. Landesman, a researcher with the State University of New York and a physician at Kings County Hospital, conducted a 1984 study that revealed Prego to be what is believed the first health-care worker in the country to get AIDS through a needle stick. Prego charges Landesman with breaching a pledge of confidentiality and revealing to other doctors that Prego had been infected with the fatal disease.Landesman has denied the claim. Prego conceded under questioning Thursday that the information she received from Landesman's study may have helped save her life in November 1987, when she developed acquired immune deficiency syndrome and nearly died of pneumonia. The Centers for Disease Control has 19 confirmed cases of U.S. health workers contracting AIDS in the workplace, but officials say the real figure probably is much higher.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Who Covered Russian Revolution Dead at 96
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In last graf, F.H.H. King is cq
DOC.TEXT: Frank H. King, whose 38 years with The Associated Press included a 7,000-mile odyssey across Siberia while covering the Russian Revolution, died Friday. He was 96. King died at an Oakland convalescent and senior home. He was the first American reporter to describe, in eyewitness accounts, life in revolutionary Russia. His exclusive reports were widely read in America and Europe. After his epic journey, King covered Washington, then was assigned to London for 17 years, where he was chief of bureau. He was Dallas bureau chief and general executive for the Southwest before retiring on Dec. 31, 1958. King, a native of Excelsior Springs, Mo., and a graduate of the University of Missouri School of Journalism, was hired as an AP stringer in Columbia, Mo. He joined the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, but his $17.50 weekly pay was not enough to hold him when he got a chance to join the English-language Japan Advertiser in Tokyo. With Russia in revolution, the United States, Britain, France and Japan sent expeditionary forces to Vladivostok in 1918. The AP and the Japan Advertiser together hired King to cover the turmoil.
