At one point, he was commended by the American command for helping to rescue women and children besieged by revolutionaries in the Vladivostok railway station. Finally, Admiral Alexander Kolchak, the White Russian leader, was seized and executed by the Bolsheviks and resistance collapsed. In the spring of 1920, the Allies pulled out. As Japanese soldiers took to shooting at almost anything that moved, King decided it was healthier to return to Tokyo other than by the direct route. Instead, he made his way down the coast to China and Peking. The situation changed. King's instinct told him to go west. He put a small kit together and headed across Mongolia, Siberia and Russia, where no one in the Western World had any idea what was going on. King was strictly on his own, traveling on anything available. He walked, rode in a pony cart, a river steamer and on the Trans-Siberian Railway. Always on the move, he went through the Great Wall and across the Gobi desert. He filed stories, never knowing until long after whether the copy arrived. Moscow authorities finally interned him in an old expropriated Czarist mansion while they debated what to do with him. King was rescued by John Reed, an American radical and darling of the Leninists. The authorities decided the best solution was to send King across the border into Finland. From there, he made his way to London. He is survived by his wife, Olga, and son, F.H.H. King, a college professor in New Mexico. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: 6-Year-Old with AIDS Writes Book about Disease
DOC.TEXT: A 6-year-old boy who got AIDS from a blood transfusion when he was a baby has co-written a book about his fight against the deadly disease and his struggle to lead a normal life. The book, ``My Name is Jonathan (and I have AIDS),'' tells people in simple terms how to take precautions around AIDS patients without being fearful of getting the disease. ``Children with AIDS need help from other children too,'' writes Jonathan, who will turn 7 in two months. His last name is not used to protect his family from harassment. ``Being able to play with my brother and my friends is important to me. It hurts a lot when someone won't come to our house because I have AIDS.'' The other author of the paperback is Sharon Schilling, a health education teacher and friend of Jonathan's family. It was published by Denver-based Prickly Pair Publishing and Consulting Co. and is being sold by mail order and at a Denver bookstore, The Bookies. Schilling said she came up with the idea for the book 18 months ago, hoping to market it to schools and parents. She said she wanted people to understand the importance of a child infected with AIDS staying in school. Jonathan's medical condition became public more than two years ago when his mother battled the local school district for the right to enroll him in public school. I told the other kids in my class on my first day about AIDS,'' Jonathan writes in his book. ``It's so good to have friends. That's why I wanted to go to school.'' Jonathan has been in good health recently and is taking DDI, an experimental AIDS drug. Although AIDS is fatal, Jonathan already has lived years longer than doctors predicted. ``I got a disease in my blood. I got it from a blood transfusion when I was a baby. It is called AIDS and it can kill you. If I fall down and hurt myself so that I bleed, you have to run and get help ... stay away from my blood. `But you don't have to worry about getting my disease just from being around me, even if I'm bleeding. Just remember to get an adult to help me.'' Jonathan's book says it is all right to touch him. ``It's OK for my mom to hug me. When she does, I feel safe and loved. It would be awful not to feel loved.'' The boy also talks about death. ``I like to watch the baby fish and frogs hatch in my aquarium. It makes me sad when one of them dies. My mom says that everything dies. I guess I know that, but sometimes I worry about dying. ``Many people who have had AIDS died. I hope that doctors will find a cure.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DC Mayor Barry in court on Misdemeanor Drug Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines previous; edits throughout
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry appeared before a federal magistrate today on a misdemeanor narcotics charge stemming from a federal sting operation that law enforcement officials said caught him on videotape buying and smoking crack cocaine. A federal magistrate ordered Barry to appear for a status hearing Feb. 5, and required him to submit to drug testing every Monday. Court papers filed by federal prosecutors said tests conducted on blood and urine samples taken from the mayor following his arrest Thursday night ``showed evidence of cocaine ingestion.'' Barry, who has repeatedly denied drug use, was in court for 10 minutes and spoke only his name and swore to appear at the hearing. He was not asked to enter a plea to the charge of possessing a controlled substance _ crack cocaine in this case. The charge carries a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a fine of $5,000. His attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, told the magistrate that Barry wanted a jury trial and waived his right to a preliminary hearing. He said the mayor would plead innocent. ``I am going to leave here and go about the business of government,'' Barry told reporters outside the courthouse after the hearing. He declined to discuss his legal or political future. Top city officials said Barry's plans to launch his campaign for a fourth term on Sunday were being postponed indefinitely. Four current or former city officials already were lined up to run against the embattled mayor and Jesse Jackson also was understood to be considering entering the race. Magistrate Deborah Robinson said Barry would remain free until the hearing but she ordered him to telephone court ``pre-trial services'' once a week. After the hearing, Barry was taken to a cellblock in the federal courthouse to be booked. Barry seemed at ease and smiled before and after the hearing and greeted well-wishers in the courtroom. While he waited for the magistrate to appear, he sat with his wife, Effie, and talked with her and his press secretary. ``The purpose of this hearing is to advise you of the charge,'' the magistrate told Barry. She then read the charge and told Barry ``you are not required to make any statement.'' Barry swore to tell the truth and stated his name. Judith Retchin, an assistant U.S. attorney, said the government did not oppose Barry's release on a personal bond and asked ``only standard conditions'' for his release. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens said after the hearing that the undercover operation, which focused on allegations involving Barry, was ``scrupulously fair'' and that the mayor was not entrapped. ``Where there is predisposition there is not entrapment,'' he said. According to court papers filed by federal prosecutors, the mayor was observed by an FBI agent through a surveillance camera giving ``a quantity of currency'' to a cooperating witness in return for a quantity of the illegal drug. ``Mr. Barry put some of the crack cocaine in a smoking apparatus, lit the crack cocaine and smoked it,'' FBI Agent Ronald D. Stern said in an affidavit. The hotel room where Barry was arrested was rented for the occasion by the FBI, according to the affidavit filed in U.S. District Court. The affidavit filed in court said tests conducted on blood and urine samples taken from the mayor following his arrest ``showed evidence of cocaine ingestion.'' The cocaine base was obtained from the Drug Enforcement Administration ``in anticipation of an undercover operation,'' the FBI affidavit stated. After his arrest at the hotel, Barry was released on his own recognizance and spent the night at his home where he conferred with city officials and lawyers. The FBI used a woman to get Barry to the hotel room but would provide no further details, said a law enforcment source who spoke on condition of anonymity. The woman was described by another source familiar with the case as a low-level employee of the District of Columbia government. Asked early today about the amount of drugs involved, Mundy pinched his forefinger and thumb closely together and grinned. At the Justice Department, chief spokesman David Runkel said Attorney General Dick Thornburgh had been told in advance of the undercover operation. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Justice Department officials notified Bush of Barry's arrest. Bush said he had no comment about the incident. Barry's arrest resulted from a joint undercover ``public corruption probe'' by the FBI and the internal affairs division of the Washington Metropolitan Police Department, U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens said in a statement. The arrest occurred a day before today's scheduled sentencing of Charles Lewis, a former friend of the mayor and now a government informant, for conspiracy to distribute cocaine. When Lewis pleaded guilty to the charge last year, he told the judge he had given cocaine to the mayor. Barry's troubles, coupled with the city's soaring homicide rate that police attribute to drug-trafficking, have attracted nationwide attention. Jackson, a two-time presidential candidate who has campaigned against drugs across the country, fueled speculation he would run for mayor when he moved to Washington last year. But Jackson said he would not challenge Barry. He said today that he was ``stunned'' by the arrrest. Councilwoman Charlene Drew Jarvis, who has announced her candidacy for mayor, said Barry's arrest ``changes the political landscape of the city.'' David Clarke, City Council chairman and a mayoral candidate, called the arrest ``a tragic moment in our city's history.'' Top city officials met into the early hours today to assess the impact of the mayor's arrest on the operation of the District of Columbia's government. WUSA-TV reported that Barry was lured to the hotel to visit a longtime woman friend from California. The station said the FBI asked the woman to come to Washington a week ago to set up a meeting with Barry. Barry made several previous trips to see her during her stay, the station said. FBI agents babysat the woman's children during her visit, according to the report. An earlier federal investigation into allegations of cocaine use by Barry was thwarted by the refusal of a woman, with whom the mayor admitted having a ``personal relationship,'' to testify before a grand jury. Karen Johnson, a former city worker who was convicted of drug charges in 1984, was imprisoned for several months following her refusal to testify about selling cocaine to Barry.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers will have a new excuse to ask their parents for money for school _ a department store is opening a branch at West Virginia's newest high school. Stone & Thomas, a Wheeling-based retailer, plans to open its Capital High School store Feb. 5. School officials say they believe it might be the only such shop in the country. Students working at the store will earn credit toward the school's business curriculum, but they won't be paid, school officials said. Company executive Scott Williams says the store won't carry the expensive designer brands of clothing, shoes, cosmetics and jewelry that other Stone & Thomas stores carry. ``Do we want to put $170 Polo jackets there? No. Do we want to put college logo sweatshirts there? Yes,'' Williams said. He said the store also will carry greeting cards and school supplies. Stone & Thomas will receive a percentage of the gross sales from the shop at Capital High, which opened this school year. Students will work on advertising and displays under the direction of an adult manager, Williams said.

Metro-Dade police are giving out more tickets these days _ but they're citing motorists for good driving and the tickets are worth something. Perpetrators of considerate motoring habits on Dade County roads will be pulled over and issued a citation _ redeemable at concerts, sporting events and movie theaters. ``The first impression will be, `What did I do now?''' said program coordinator John Jones, who admits the flashing lights and sirens may confuse some drivers. The first good driver rewarded, Juanita Moore Murray of Hollywood, said her first reaction was to check her speedometer, then begin to worry. ``I was just thinking, all I need is a ticket,'' she said Thursday. Jones gave her two _ to a Janet Jackson concert. The officer had spotted Murray, who drives a minibus for the Jewish Community Center Senior Ride Service, letting another driver pull onto the street from a parking lot. ``After all, we say we practice courtesy and safe driving,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Twin Brothers Celebrate 80th Birthday, More Than 60 Years of Work
DOC.TEXT: Roy and Ralph Reisenberg each got a bottle of gin and a golf umbrella Friday at an office party celebrating the twin brothers' 80th birthday and a lifetime of working together. ``We've been in business together for more than 60 years,'' Roy Reisenberg said. ``We're the oldest twin bank employees in the United States.'' For about 17 years, Roy Reisenberg has been a mail clerk and his brother has verified account signatures in the operations center of Marine Bank of Erie. Before that, they owned a tavern for about 16 years and ran a wholesale food business for 30 years. Ralph Reisenberg said he tried retirement before joining the bank. ``We went to Florida for a few weeks, and I came home and sat around for a few days and said, `Hey, this is no fun,' so I went out and got a job.'' Ralph Reisenberg's wife, Martha, died in May, after 53 years of marriage. He lives in an apartment near his brother and sister-in-law's Erie home. Working 20 hours a week keeps the two brothers going. ``It gets you out,'' Ralph Reisenberg said. ``You don't sit in a saloon all day. There must be about 90 girls around here. There's about six men. You can't beat that.'' Roy Reisenberg said the men, avid golfers, have no plans to retire. ``As long as my legs hold out, I'll be here,'' he said. When the brothers arrived Friday morning _ early, as usual _ they were greeted with a sign blinking birthday greetings outside the building. Co-workers had rented it for the occasion. Bank President Dave Zuern congratulated the Reisenbergs as they walked in, and the two found their offices decorated with balloons and streamers. About 150 co-workers showed up for the birthday party, where the men received $50 apiece and other gifts. Bank spokeswoman Ann Speice said the brothers are conscientious workers. ``They are at work early every day. They never call in sick.'' Ralph Reisenberg said many of his friends have moved or died, and he is grateful for his brother. ``We're different, but we get along _ for 80 years now,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Appeal Arguments Given in Deportation Case of IRA Member
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for an imprisoned Irish Republican Army member argued Friday that the Justice Department overstepped the law in its efforts to deport the man to Northern Ireland. The hearing before the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals was the latest proceeding in Joe Doherty's highly publicized, 6{-year legal battle to fight extradition and deportation. If he loses, Doherty could be returned to face life in prison for the 1980 killing of a British army captain and a later prison escape. Doherty, 34, has been imprisoned since his arrest at a Manhattan bar in June 1983. The British government maintains Doherty is a common criminal who should be extradited to face trial. He and his supporters maintain he committed a political act not subject to extradition and that he deserves political asylum; the IRA says it is fighting to oust the British from Northern Ireland. Doherty has won decisions before two federal judges, a federal appeals court, an immigration judge and three immigration appeals boards. But in June 1988, Attorney General Edwin Meese III intervened and ordered his deportation. Later, Attorney General Richard Thornburgh overturned an immigration appeals board decision to reopen Doherty's deportation case. The hearing Thursday stemmed from Doherty's appeal of the rulings by Meese and Thornburgh. If his appeal is successful, Doherty will be granted another round in immigration courts, this time to apply for political asylum. As throughout his legal battle, emotions ran high at the hearing. Doherty was not present, but the courtroom was filled with his supporters. His attorney, Mary Pike, asserted that the attorneys general improperly intervened in Doherty's case. ``What we see in this case is the naked manipulation of an administrative proceeding,'' Pike told the three judges hearing the appeal. She said the central issue was that ``the attorney general is not above the law and that no individual, including my client, is outside the law.'' Pike also noted that 46 members of Congress had signed a brief supporting Doherty's position. Special Assistant U.S. Attorney Noel Anne Ferris argued that the appeal should be denied because Doherty had earlier conceded that he is deportable and had waived his right to apply for political asylum. Ferris also said Meese was correct in ruling that it was in the interest of the U.S. government to deport Doherty. ``It was in our interest as a country fighting terrorism to return'' Doherty, she said. The three judges _ Wilfred Feinberg, George Pratt and Edward Lumbard _ reserved decision and will issue a written opinion at a later date.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Miners Tour Beckley
DOC.TEXT: Soviet miners visiting the United States said Friday they didn't believe last year's coal strikes in their homeland were very successful. Nine miners who belong to a new Soviet coal miners union are touring Appalachian coal fields this month, comparing techniques and labor organizations, and said their own battle had a long way to go. ``It turns out we're not fighting against an owner but a government system,'' miner Gennady Sharov said during a stop in southern West Virginia. ``To win, we have to change laws. As it turns out, it isn't just a strike for coal miners but for the nation.'' The group of Russian, Ukranian and Kazakh miners all were prominent players in last summer's coal strike which ended after Soviet leaders agreed to recognize their union and negotiate better salaries and work and safety rules. Miner Oleg Kul said the coal strike was the first critical move by Soviet workers in 70 years. ``It's an important step to solidify perestroika and democratization that has been going on for five years,'' Kul said. Perestroika is the Soviet government's relaxation of hard-line restrictions. Kul and Sharov each believe miners have the backing of the Soviet Politburo but that they are fighting a middle-level of Soviet administration. ``They worry about what will happen if our demands are met. They don't want to make changes. They're passive about it,'' Kul said. ``They say, `What can I do? I have no rights, just as you don't.''' Kul said Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev seems ready to declare war on the middle administration to ensure changes filter down to the working class. ``As far as the strike and negotiations went, the government supported the right of the miners to go on strike,'' he said. The group arrived in the United States two weeks ago and visited leaders of United Mine Workers of America and the AFL-CIO in New York and Washington, D.C. before traveling to West Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Police Attack Anti-Apartheid Protest of Cricket Team
LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: Riot police with attack dogs beat and tear gassed anti-apartheid demonstrators Friday protesting the visit of an English cricket team defying a ban on sports contacts with South Africa. Squads of police armed with batons and pump-action shotguns tore into a crowd of about 100 peaceful protesters at Jan Smuts Airport as police handlers unleashed German shepherd attack dogs that bit protesters and knocked them to the ground. Fleeing demonstrators fell on each other and were trapped as they scrambled to escape the dogs. Police beat protesters with long batons as they lay on the ground, trying to ward off the blows. Police hauled off several protesters with blood pouring from head cuts and other wounds. Police said 10 protesters were arrested. The cricket team, called ``rebels'' because of their defiance of the ban on sport ties with South Africa's white-minority government, arrived three hours late after a bomb threat delayed the departure of their South African Airways flight from London. Police dispersed the protesters before the team arrived. Team captain Mike Gatting expressed unhappiness when told about the protest, but said the team would go ahead with the six-week tour. Team members reportedly are receiving $160,000 each for the tour, with Gatting receiving $320,000. ``We're unhappy that if it was a peaceful demonstration, that it was disrupted,'' Gatting said at an airport news conference. Anti-government protesters vowed to disrupt the tour despite a police warning that no demonstrations would be allowed. ``Our message to Gatting and his gang ... (is) we are definitely going to make his life miserable here. Our objective is to stop the tour,'' said Benny Alexander, general-secretary of the Pan Africanist Movement. Demonstrators in six buses arrived at the airport, where police at first prevented them from leaving the buses. ``Ban racist tours,'' said signs carried by protesters along with the green, black and yellow flag of the outlawed African National Congress, the main black political organization. ``Viva ANC!'' protesters chanted. About 100 protesters later were allowed to march to the terminal, where they gathered in a crowd, peacefully singing and dancing. After a few minutes, riot police moved into the crowd after it was ordered to disperse. A senior police officer said the demonstration was illegal because the protesters failed to obtain a magistrate's permit. He said violence used by police was not excessive. Police seized film from Associated Press photographers and others. Geoff Dakin, head of the South African Cricket Union, which organized the tour, said the airport incident was an everyday event of a kind that happens all over the world. Winnie Mandela, wife of jailed black leader Nelson Mandela, and several other black leaders at the airport protested against the police tactics. Mrs. Mandela said the police tactics undermined President F. W. DeKlerk's claim he wants to dismantle apartheid. ``We saw unlimited violence unleashed towards our people here,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Sword, Rare Violins Among Stolen Antiques Found
DOC.TEXT: Investigators say they have recovered more than $500,000 in stolen antiques _ including two centuries-old violins and a sword reportedly used by Civil War General William T. Sherman. The merchandise, which also included books, coin collections, toy cars and guns, was found Thursday in a storage locker. ``We're saying half-a-million dollars right now, but that's probably a very conservative estimate,'' said Dennis Palmentera, an investigator with the Ohio Organized Crime Investigation Commission. Police have arrested 29 people since a grand jury in Columbus, Ohio, returned secret indictments Jan. 2 in connection with an Ohio-based burglary ring, but no arrests have been made involving the Savannah cache. Investigators say the ring has operated for 20 years and is blamed for more than $1.8 million in thefts over five years. ``The ring had fingered out from Ohio,'' said Harold Crabtree, also an investigator with the Ohio task force. ``It spread from Ohio to Florida and was in every state in between.'' The Sherman-related items, which included a portrait of the Union general, were stolen from Sherman's birthplace museum in Lancaster, Ohio, investigators said. The violins were believed made by Antonio Stradivari, the famous Italian craftsman. Palmentera said investigators believe the antiques stashed in Savannah were destined for a major antiques show in Norcross. ``They store it for six months or a year until it cools off, then they'd sell it,'' Palmentera said. ``They sell it in the major shows because this stuff is hard to track.''

DOC.HEAD: Acquitted Defendant in Molestation Case Discusses Lawsuit, Threats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with news conference, lawsuit filed. Picks up 11th graf, `The anger...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA1,2,3, VNY1
DOC.TEXT: Peggy McMartin Buckey, acquitted in the McMartin Pre-School molestation case, said today she would pursue a federal civil lawsuit alleging malicious prosecution despite death threats to her family. Mrs. Buckey, addressing a packed news conference, said she at first hesitated to become involved in further litigation. ``I said to (my lawyer) `Is it worth going to court about? I'm tired of going to court. I'm tired of enduring what I've had to endure.''' But she said she felt those responsible for ruining her life should have to account for it. Mrs. Buckey and her son Raymond won acquittal of 52 felony child molestation charges. Jurors in the nation's longest and costliest criminal trial Thursday deadlocked on 12 other sex abuse counts against Buckey and a single conspiracy count against him and his 63-year-old mother. Superior Court Judge William Pounders declared a mistrial on the 12 counts and dismissed the deadlocked conspiracy charge against Mrs. Buckey. He set a Jan. 31 hearing to determine whether the 13 unresolved counts will be dismissed against Buckey. Buckey, 31, who spent nearly five years in jail before making bail, and his mother, who was jailed for almost two years, cried as they heard the verdicts. ``If it can happen to seven innocent people it can happen to you, too. If it had not been in my faith in God, I wouldn't be here today,'' Mrs. Buckey said. Buckey avoided reporters after the verdict. Initially, five other teachers, including Mrs. Buckey's mother and daughter, were charged. The trial cost about $15 million and lasted nearly three years. The lawsuit filed today names as defendants Los Angeles County, the city of Manhattan Beach, former District Attorney Robert Philibosian, Children's Institute International and therapist Kee McFarlane, as well as Capital Cities-ABC Inc. and its former reporter Wayne Satz. It contended that all defendants joined in a conspiracy to have the McMartin defendants indicted. The lawsuit sought general damages of $1 million and unspecified special damages. Mrs. Buckey said that after verdicts were announced Thursday, a parent of a McMartin school child approached Mrs. Buckey's husband, Charles, and threatened to kill him. She did not elaborate. She also said that children who attended the once prestigious, but now defunct, school trailed her to her car and screamed epithets at her. Some of the children's parents gasped when the verdicts were announced. ``The anger is beginning to rise,'' said Mary Mae Cioffi. ``We have programs all over the country that tell children to run and tell when somebody hurts them, and our children told. Some of them spent 35 days on the stand and they get a `not guilty.' It shows that our justice system needs a revamp for kids.'' Although they did not testify, she added: ``I know my children were molested. I had my daughter sleep between my husband and I for a whole year because she was so afraid somebody would come and get her, that they would kill her, because she told.'' The investigation of alleged mass molestation at the family-run school in suburban Manhattan Beach ignited a nationwide wave of worry about child abuse when it came to light in 1983. It produced widespread fear among working parents that their children might be at risk at school. Jurors who cleared the pair Thursday said children may have been molested. But they said prosecutors in the trial failed to link sexual abuse to the defendants. ``I tried to believe the children,'' said juror Daryl Hutchins. But he said the youngsters had been so ``contaminated'' by parents' suggestions and therapists who interviewed them that he could not accept their testimony. The most important evidence, jurors said, were videotapes of interviews conducted with alleged victims at Children's Institute International, a private child abuse center. The jurors said interviewers used leading questions and coached the children on how they should answer. ``I believe that the children believed what they were saying was true in the courtroom,'' said juror Brenda Williams. ``I could not tell from watching the tape that the children were telling what actually happened to them or if they were repeating what their parents told them.'' Some parents said the judicial system failed. ``I fear that because of this verdict, no child will be seen as a credible witness from now on,'' said Alan Lagunoff. His son, now 10, attended the school for 1{ years but wasn't a witness at the trial. Prosecutor Lael Rubin, who devoted six years to the case, said: ``We ultimately must respect the jury's decision even though I personally disagree with it.'' The case began in August 1983 with a complaint from Judy Johnson, a mother who reported her 2-year-old child had been molested at the suburban school by a man called Ray. Police sent letters to McMartin parents warning of possible molestation. Soon, dozens of parents reported their children had been victimized. Mrs. Johnson, suffering from alcohol and mental problems, died at age 44 a few months before the trial began in April 1987. Defense attorneys contended the case was largely the result of her increasingly bizarre allegations. Children gave accounts of satanic rites and animals tortured to frighten youngsters into silence. Testimony at an 18-month preliminary hearing featured tales of molestations at a church, a car wash and a market as well as ``naked games'' at the school. Juror Julie Peters said she felt the case had destroyed many lives. ``I think everybody was a victim,'' she said. ``I don't think anybody came out of this case a winner.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Keep INS away from Witnesses for Noriega Co-Defendant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with today's hearing; picks up 9th graf, `On Tuesday...'
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today refused to order government investigators to stay away from defense witnesses in the case of a co-defendant of Manuel Noriega. But U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler urged both sides to avoid intimidation. An attorney for Luis del Cid, alleged to be a top aide to Noriega _ complained to the court that investigators from the Immigration and Naturalization Service visited the defendants's wife and two friends soon after the three testified at a bond hearing this week. ``These witnesses declined to go back to court today _ they are terrified,'' said attorney Samuel Burstyn. ``They are worried about their immigration status.'' Del Cid's wife is Panamanian and the other two women are Nicaraguan refugees. But Hoeveler noted the women _ Tilsa del Cid and Norma and Eglantina Alvarez _ had offered to take custody of del Cid if he is freed on bond. ``It is important for me to get the full picture of what their status is,'' Hoeveler said. INS agents had demanded that three women who testified for del Cid on Tuesday turn over all their immigration papers and give information about how they gained entry into the United States, Burstyn wrote in a request for the emergency hearing. ``The timing reflects vividly that this is a retaliatory measure aimed at intimidating these and other defense witnesses,'' said Burstyn. On Tuesday, the Alvarez sisters testified that del Cid helped them flee into Panama to avoid persecution by the Sandinistas. In his motion Thursday, Burstyn said that immigration agents had asked the sisters whether they once worked for Nicaragua's Sandinista government and ``implied that there was something improper about their escape into Panama.'' Earlier Thursday, Burstyn and other defense attorneys accused the government of balking at court orders to turn over both secret and non-secret documents to aid the defense. ``There is a desire to stonewall information ... to hermetically seal off the guts and gore of the early investigation,'' said Burstyn, adding that he hoped the tentative March 5 trial date for Noriega would force the government to stop dragging his feet. Prosecutors last week threatened to try Michael O'Kane, lawyer for the accused drug pilot Daniel Miranda, for mentioning the existence of a National Security Agency listening post in Panama City _ despite the fact the office is shown on a map in the Panama City telephone book. Also, a lawyer for convicted drug kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas strongly denied his client will cooperate with prosecutors to convict the deposed Panamanian leader, despite a taped interview the imprisoned trafficker gave implicating Noriega. ``He will be no witness against Noriega, there is no deal,'' Lehder's attorney Jose Quinon said Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Waite Marks Third Anniversary As Hostage
DOC.TEXT: Anglican envoy Terry Waite begins his fourth year as a hostage of pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants on Saturday with his fate, and those of other captives, apparently hinging on a power struggle in Tehran. A reliable Shiite source, who is familiar with the thinking of the hostage-holding factions, said the issue of the 18 Westerners missing in Lebanon is ``on the back burner'' until Iran's political infighting is settled. ``Any settlement to the hostage issue must await the outcome of the power struggle in Iran,'' the source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Waite, 50, disappeared in Moslem west Beirut Jan. 20, 1987. He was last seen leaving his seaside hotel to keep a rendezvous with kidnappers holding two Americans _ journalist Terry Anderson and Scottish-born educator Thomas Sutherland _ to negotiate their release. No group has claimed it holds Waite and there has been no word on his fate. But Western and Lebanese intelligence officials are convinced he is held by Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, the group holding Anderson and Sutherland. British intelligence sources said they believe he is still alive. Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie said he is confident his envoy will be released. ``There are others who have been unheard of for longer and I remain optimistic that Terry is there and that one day he will return to us,'' the Anglican leader said in an interview televised Friday in London. David Waite said on the program he believed his brother was alive. ``Although there seems to be nothing visible happening, I'm just very hopeful that some time, and please let it be soon, we will see this situation start to turn around. Logically it's got to come to an end some time,'' he said. Waite is one of 18 Westerners, including eight Americans, missing in Lebanon. Most are believed held by factions of the Iranian-backed Shiite fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God. The longest held is Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Their ordeal has been complicated by a split in Hezbollah between the political wing aligned with Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani and radicals allied with former interior minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi. Rafsanjani, who dumped Mohtashemi from his Cabinet in August, has sought to rebuild ties with the West to attract foreign investment badly needed for economic reconstruction following the 1988 cease-fire in the war with Iraq. This is anathema to the fundamentalist radicals, who fear it will undermine revolutionary fervor and the hard-line legacy of revolutionary leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died June 3. Rafsanjani appears to be willing to use Tehran's influence to free the hostages, and improve Iran's image, provided the United States releases Iranian assets worth billions of dollars frozen in 1979. The virulently anti-Western Mohtashemi, on the other hand, has close links with Hezbollah. He was a key figure in forming the movement in the early 1980s and masterminding suicide bomber attacks on U.S., French and Israeli forces that killed hundreds of people. ``The kidnappers are radicals who owe allegiance to Mohtashemi,'' the source said. An anonymous telephone caller, purporting to represent the pro-Iranian Organization of the Oppressed on Earth, another Shiite faction, threatened to kill Waite in August unless Israel freed a kidnapped Shiite leader, Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid. The Hezbollah cleric was seized by Israeli commandoes in a pre-dawn raid in July on his village in south Lebanon. Obeid was not released, but there was no further call claiming Waite had been slain.

DOC.HEAD: Sondheim Beings Teaching at Oxford
DOC.TEXT: Broadway composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim began his new role Friday as professor, addressing an overflow crowd of 250 at Oxford University. ``I've always had an enormous, passionate feeling about teaching and teachers,'' he said in the inaugural lecture of his term at Oxford's St. Catherine's College. Sondheim, who wrote the music and lyrics for such shows as ``Company,'' ``A Little Night Music,'' ``Follies'' and ``Into the Woods,'' is the first visiting professor of drama and musical theater at Oxford University in a post that has been endowed by British producer Cameron Mackintosh. Sondheim is in intermittent residence in Oxford, where he is guiding 13 students through a term that will focus on their own compositions as well as on the London production of ``Sunday in the Park with George,'' Sondheim's Pulitzer Prize-winning musical. ``All the people in this course have a feeling for the theater,'' Sondheim said of his students, who were selected from among 92 applicants. Eleven of the students are British, one is Canadian and one Australian. After a week working with their professor, the students are giving Sondheim rave reviews. ``The guy's a tremendous human being. It's a great surprise. Not what you'd expect of a great maestro,'' said Edward Hardy, 23. ``He has a tremendous relaxing manner and a fantastic sense of humor. ``Stephen Sondheim is exactly the sort of person whom you feel you can approach,'' Hardy said.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Raids in Lebanon Kill 5
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes Friday rocketed a PLO radio station and guerrilla bases of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah in their first two air strikes on south Lebanon this year. Police said five people were killed and 12 wounded. The attacks targeted Radio Al-Quds, or Radio Jerusalem, in the Palestinian refugee camp of Mieh Mieh near the port of Sidon and Hezbollah bases in four villages further south. Two other people were missing after the 77-minute raid on Mieh Mieh, which destroyed the two transmission aerials of the radio, a police spokesman said. He said six Phantom F-4 fighter-bombers fired 34 rockets in seven runs in Mieh Mieh, killing at least three people and wounding eight others. Palestinian guerrillas fired ground-to-air missiles that were deflected by scarlet heat balloons released by the pilots of the raiding jets. The police spokesman said Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization was readying the station to transmit programs to the uprising in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza strip. The station had been in the process of test broadcasts and was to be inaugurated Feb. 1, said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing rules. Guerrillas from Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction ringed the vicinity of the stricken station and stopped reporters and photographers from approaching, pending a security check of the area for possible time bombs. In Jerusalem, the Israeli military command confirmed the two raids, adding that all the jets returned safely to base. It said the radio station ``was intended to broadcast orders to guerrillas in Lebanon and hostile groups'' in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israeli jets last year also destroyed a Fatah radio station in south Lebanon. Israeli army officials said the station had been used to transmit orders to the uprising. Smoke billowed from several parts of the stricken shantytown on the southeastern fringe of Sidon, provincial capital of south Lebanon, 25 miles from Beirut. The spokesman said several delayed-fuse rockets were fired in an attempt to blast the underground structure of the station, but no word on the damage was immediately available. A formation of four Israeli jets earlier rocketed outposts of Hezbollah, Iran's main Shiite Moslem ally in Lebanon, in the embattled Apple Province, six miles southeast of sidon. Police said at least two guerrillas were killed and four wounded in the two rocketing sorties of the overnight raid. The targeted bases were in the villages of Ein Bouswar, Lwaize, Mlikh and Jabal Safi. The Israeli command said its warplanes raided Hezbollah bases north of the market town of Nabatiyeh that were used to mount guerrilla attacks against Israel's northern border. The raid followed two Katyusha rocket attacks on northern Israel Sunday and on the zone Israel has controlled in south Lebanon since 1982. The zone is patrolled by an estimated 1,500 Israeli troops and the 3,000-member South Lebanon Army, a predominantly Christian militia sponsored by Israel. Hezbollah sources in Beirut acknowledged the Israeli raid on their bases in the Apple Province, but refused to discuss damage or casualties. ``They fired devastating rockets on our bases,'' said one Hezbollah source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The fundamentalist Hezbollah and the secular Syrian-backed Amal militia have been engaged in a new round of fighting in the region since Dec. 23. At least 97 people have been killed and 277 wounded in that confrontation, by police count. The two factions have been vying for more than two years for mastery of the 1.2 million Shiites who make up Lebanon's largest single sect. The raids were Israel's first and second on Lebanon this year. At least 28 people were killed and 137 wounded in Israel's 18 air strikes against Palestinian and Lebanese guerrilla bases in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Launch of Space Telescope Delayed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT name of orbiter to Discovery. SUBS 5th graf to correct name of shuttle to Atlantis.
DOC.TEXT: The long-awaited launch of the Hubble Space Telescope will be delayed from March to April because of a problem with one of space shuttle Discovery's solid fuel booster rockets, NASA said today. The $1.7 billion spacecraft is scheduled to become astronomy's most significant tool in expanding knowledge of the universe into the 21st century. The space agency said shuttle managers decided to exchange one of the motor segments on the right booster rocket because there was a question whether a check was done properly. Assembly operations have advanced to the point where the test cannot be repeated, NASA said. The launch was scheduled for March 26. Estimates of the delay range from 10 days to two weeks. The next shuttle mission, that of Atlantis on a military mission, also faces a delay of a few days in its planned Feb. 16 launch. The move of the spaceship to an assembly building was held up two days by a problem with the left main landing gear. There also reportedly were some minor problems with the Pentagon payload. Scientists have eagerly awaited the Hubble launch since well before its original liftoff date in 1985. Early technical problems and the 1986 space shuttle Challenger explosion resulted in the long delay. Orbiting 370 miles high, the telescope will look seven times more deeply into space and detect objects 50 times fainter than the best ground-based observatory.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia Warns Pro-Reform Demonstrators
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's Communist Party daily newspaper on Friday warned a pro-reform group not to push too far in the first official criticism of the remote Asian nation's fledgling reform movement. A foreign source in the capital of Ulan Bator said the comments in the daily Unen came after a street rally Jan. 13 that attracted up to 5,000 people and several incidents of vandalism this week, including the theft of a small statue of Stalin. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said one article in the paper pinpointed several leaders of the newly formed Mongolian Democratic Union, and said they were going ``too far'' in pushing for democratic reform. It also named several journalists and a teaching assistant at the state university as being leaders of the union, and urged them to ``stop and think'' before proceeding with their campaign. A milder article written by the head of the party ideology department called on reformists to work together with the party, and said the party shared such objectives as speeding up the pace of ``perestroika'' and carrying out electoral reform. The MDU, thought to be comprised mainly of intellectuals and artists, staged two rallies in December that drew crowds in the hundreds, and then held the larger Jan. 13 demonstration. During the latest demonstration, speakers for the first time criticized government leaders by name and demanded that Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal, Mongolia's autocratic ruler for more than three decades before he was purged in 1984, be put on trial. The demonstrators were given permission for all three rallies and police made no attempt to interfere. The source said that in the past week a small statue of Stalin in front of an officers' club was stolen, while paint was thrown on the pedestal of a larger Stalin statue in front of the Stalin Museum. A statue of Horloogiyn Choybalsan, the Stalinist leader who carried out bloody purges of opponents and Mongolian Buddhists during the 1930s, was also smeared with paint. It was not known who was responsible for the acts. Mongolia, a nation of only 2 million people scattered across a nation nearly the size of West Europe, has been a client state of the Soviet Union since the Communists took power in 1921. It has cautiously taken up the economic and political reforms advanced by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, although little progress has been made in introducing market principles and there has been no serious challenge, like in East Europe, to Communist Party rule. ``No one is looking for a great confrontation such as happened in East Europe,'' the source said. ``It's a very different cultural mileau here.'' The source said the MDU plans to hold another rally this Sunday. He said it was difficult to predict whether the authorities, now that they have criticized the movement, will try to stop it. ``All of this is so new,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Search for Parents of Abandoned Children
DOC.TEXT: A couple apparently left six children in an apartment without food, heat or electricity, police said. Acting on a tip from an elementary school teacher, police discovered the children, ages 6 to 17, Thursday. They would not release the children's names and have not been able to locate the parents. The children said they have not seen their mother since December, and had not seen their father since Tuesday, Nashua Police Sgt. John McDermott said. McDermott said there was little food in the apartment except bread and potato chips. The children had been attending school, and were taken to stay with a grandfather in Lowell, Mass. The state Division for Children and Youth Services has been asked to investigate, McDermott said. If the parents are found they could be charged with endangering the welfare of a child, a misdemeanor punishable by one year in jail, he said.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Disputes `Concrete Wall' Along Border
LaserPhoto SEL4
DOC.TEXT: The brigadier general stood on a wind-swept observation post overlooking the Demilitarized Zone and challenged observers Friday to find a barrier like the Berlin Wall on the bleak plain below. ``Kim Il Sung is a liar. Can you see any concrete wall as claimed by him?'' asked Brig. Gen. Kang Jong-pil. Kim, North Korea's Communist leader, had said South Korea built such a wall on the 2{-mile-wide DMZ to block free travel between the nations, and he called on South Korea to tear it down. Kang, a deputy army division commander, was briefing about 100 foreign reporters allowed for the first time to visit two front-line units on the 155-mile border as part of Seoul's effort to disprove the North Korean claim. The identity of Kang's unit was withheld as a military secret. The Korean DMZ is one of the most heavily fortified borders in the world and sealed off by more than 1.5 million troops on both sides. The nations are still technically at war since no peace treaty was signed at the end of the Korean War in 1953. There were no concrete walls as claimed by Kim in the two South Korean units visited by foreign reporters on Thursday. At Kang's unit, a 1.6-mile-long anti-tank obstacle was shown to the press. ``I am not sure but I think this is the very concrete wall that Kim Il Sung mentioned in his New Year's address,'' the general said through an interpreter. ``If we remove these tank traps, it is just like giving them guarantee for free passage of tanks,'' he said. The general said Kim, apparently embarrassed by sweeping changes in East Europe, is believed to have mentioned the non-existent concrete wall. ``It's nothing but false propaganda aimed at shifing responsibility for national division to the South,'' he said. The general said anti-tank barriers are set up along only 12 percent of the 12-mile frontline in his unit's sector. No tank traps were seen at the other adjacent unit visited by the reporters. The anti-tank obstacle shown at Kim's unit, 16{ feet high and 21 feet wide at its bottom, is made of rocks, cement and dirt. It lies just outside the DMZ across a vast open field that formed one of the bloodiest battlefields during the Korean War. About 19,000 troops on both sides were killed or wounded in battles in the plain and a nearby ridge during the three-year war, Kang said. At the start of the Korean War, North Korea threw in nearly a third of its 250 tanks to occupy the area and they rolled to Seoul, 50 miles away, in three days, he said. According to the general, North Korea, has also fortified its own sector of the DMZ with multiple electric fences and two lines of anti-tank barriers. Kang said all South Korean barriers have been built outside the DMZ but one of North Korea's anti-tank obstacles is located inside the DMZ, a clear violation of the 1953 Korean Armistice Agreement. Reporters could not verify Kang's claim through binoculars because of hazy weather. At a nearby unit 25 miles away, reporters were takne to a guard post inside the southern sector of the DMZ, where they heared North Korea's broadcasts blaring propaganda criticizing the United States as well as South Korea. ``If Yankees go home, the Korean peninsula will become a paradise,'' the barely audible broadcasts said.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Calls for Reform of Warsaw Pact
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's top military officer Friday called for a ``remarkable reform'' of the Warsaw Pact but said the military alliance was needed to maintain stability in Europe. Winding up the first week of unprecedented East-West talks, Gen. Laszlo Borsits said Hungary would stay in the Soviet-led alliance ``for the time being.'' His remarks generally reflected those of other East European officers who have stressed their national interests over those of the Warsaw Pact. They have not, however, talked about leaving the alliance. ``One of the lessons after this week is the Warsaw Pact is still there,'' said John Maresca, who heads the U.S. delegation to the talks. Gunter Joetze, West Germany's ambassador to the meeting, noted the tendency of the East European countries to discuss their national policies. ``There is no more bloc discipline. Everybody talks about what he (wants),'' said Joetze. Maresca described the initial days of the three-week conference as ``a mixed experience.'' The meeting opened Tuesday with Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, and his Soviet counterpart, Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, discussing the superpowers' policies. Western analysts had been eager to hear the East bloc views following the tremendous political upheavals there. Maresca said the first week of the closed-door discussions had been marked by formality, with senior military officers not engaging in the hoped-for give-and-take. ``That has been the disappointment of this week _ the discussion session,'' he said. ``There hasn't been a lot.'' Poland's ambassador, Wlodzimierz Konarski, expressed relief the generals' talks had been ``quiet and constructive without any tensions.'' Maresca said a key result of the gathering had been the informal contacts that set ``excellent groundwork'' for later discussions. Powell met privately with Moiseyev and had lunch with chiefs of other Warsaw Pact nations. Joetze believed there was ``much more dialogue'' among the nations than he had expected. ``We were afraid that the Soviets would stonewall and would make only general political declarations,'' he said. But, he said, ``they did not. They talked in military substance.'' Maresca contended, though, the Soviets' formal remarks were ``about what one would have expected at this time.'' Moiseyev offered a wide range of criticisms about U.S. and NATO policies and urged the West to follow Moscow's lead in cutting troops, arms and spending. The Soviets' allies appeared more open. ``There's something of a contrast ... between the behavior of the Eastern Europeans and the behavior of the Soviets,'' Maresca said. Poland released a detailed paper on its defense forces that gave not only budget and manpower figures but also naval insignia. Borsits, reflecting the new Eastern approach, said in his speech that Hungary ``no longer gives priority to military power.'' ``The role of the military factor should be gradually but considerably reduced,'' he said. But, he said the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ``are nowadays a stabilizing factor.'' ``Their loosening would upset the balance and would lead to incalculable consequences,'' he said. But, he said, ``we consider necessary and urge a remarkable reform of the (Warsaw Pact) alliance, above all the democratization and modernization of inner relationships and decision-making mechanisms.'' Hungary planned to cut its army by a third, he said. Battle tanks, field artillery and combat planes would be slashed even more. Defense spending also would come down, he said. The meeting was held under the auspices of the negotiations on Confidence- and Security-Building Measures, bargaining among NATO, Warsaw Pact and neutral nations aimed at easing military tensions in Europe. The agenda for the next two weeks will include discussion of the structures of East-West armed forces, military training and budgets.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Sues Exxon over Arthur Kill Spill
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth sued Exxon Friday, charging the recent oil spill into the Arthur Kill ravaged its waterfront and polluted the Elizabeth River. ``This represents a terrible, terrible setback'' in a 17-year effort to clean up the waterfront, said city health director John Surmay. The Superior Court lawsuit seeks unspecified compensatory and punitive damages. New Jersey also has sued Exxon. Surmay said damages to city property has been estimated at $500,000 to $4.5 million. Elizabeth has 2 miles of waterfront on the Arthur Kill, the waterway separating New Jersey from the New York City borough of Staten Island. About 567,000 gallons of heating oil spilled into the channel Jan. 1-2 when a pipeline ruptured. The pipeline linked Exxon's Bayway refinery in Linden and its distribution terminal in Bayonne. Exxon was still seeking to determine the rupture's cause. Surmay said the city's 50-boat marina was damaged by the oil, which also spread into the Elizabeth River. The river empties into the kill. Wildlife on the shoreline and city-owned land on Shooter's Island also suffered, Surmay said. Exxon was ``disappointed'' with Elizabeth's lawsuit, said company spokesman Bill Young, because the company had already started settlement negotiations. Young said Friday that crews were completing the clean-up. The ruptured section of pipeline will be removed next week for examination.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Details Major Defense Cuts
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Citing declining tension in southern Africa, the government announced major defense cuts Friday, including the disbanding of air force and navy units and big cuts in weapons production. The cuts mainly affect the navy and air force with naval personel being cut by almost 25 percent, including disbanding the country's marine corps. The air force will lose six squadrons and retire five classes of aircraft. President F.W. de Klerk announced recently that South Africa would reduce its defense forces because of declining tension in southern African and a need to redirect government spending to social welfare projects. The defense budget is about $4 billion annually. There were no figures on how much money would be saved by the cuts. South Africa last year ended its involvement in a 23-year bush war against nationalist guerrillas in Namibia by agreeing to end its rule of the territory. Namibia is scheduled to become indpendent soon, probably in March. South Africa also withdrew its forces in 1988 from Angola, where it fought alongside rebels battling the Marxist government. Lt. Gen. Kat Liebenberg, acting chief of the Defense Force, said the cuts would make the military smaller and more economical, but would not seriosuly reduce South Africa's ability to defend itself. ``The Defense Forces will justifiably remain true to its reputation as a formidable fighting force that would compel any military force in Southern Africa to think twice before embarking on military adventures against our country,'' Liebenberg said. The army, the strongest arm of the defense forces with 75,000 troops, is least affected by the cuts and will remain the strongest military force in Africa. Neighboring black African states have much smaller, weaker armies. Liebenberg said South Africa still needed strong defense forces despite the reduction in tension in the region. ``The threat to South Africa has not totally disappeared,'' he said. The big cut involving the army was the cancellation of 11 major weapons systems under development, the statement said. Another 49 projects were reduced or delayed, he said. Army operating costs will be drastically curtailed, the statement said. The navy, the smallest arm of the military, was hardest hit by the cuts, with the closing of five naval bases, disbanding of the 900-man marine corps and dismantling of the main regional naval commands. Liebenberg said 2,000 naval personnel out of a force of about 9,000 would be dismissed or retired. The South African navy is mainly a coastal defense force, except for three submarines and two older frigates. Defense cuts will mean the elimination of six air force squadrons and the phasing out of five classes of aircraft, including the relatively old Canberra bomber and the Westland Wasp helicopter. The air force has about 13,000 troops and 366 combat aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Supreme Court Upholds Fetal Homicide Statutes
DOC.TEXT: It is not necessary to define when human life begins to impose criminal penalties for killing a fetus, the Minnesota Supreme Court ruled Friday. The court, in upholding Minnesota's 1986 fetal homicide statutes, said the laws ``do not raise the issue of when life as a human person begins or ends. The state must prove only that the implanted embryo or the fetus in the mother's womb was living, that it had life, and that it has life no longer.'' The justices, in a 4-3 decision, held that the fetal homicide statutes are constitutional even though they don't distinguish between viable and non-viable fetuses. ``The defendant who assaults a pregnant woman causing the death of the fetus she is carrying destroys the fetus without the consent of the woman,'' the court said. ``This is not the same as the woman who elects to have her pregnancy terminated by one legally authorized to perform the act.'' The U.S. Supreme Court's landmark 1973 ruling that legalized abortion ``protects the woman's right of choice; it does not protect, much less confer on an assailant, a third-party unilateral right to destroy the fetus,'' the Minnesota justices said. The opinion was issued in the case of Sean Patrick Merrill of Rochester, who has been charged with two counts each of first- and second-degree murder in the November 1988 shooting deaths of 22-year-old Gail Anderson and her 4-week-old embryo. Rochester attorney Kevin Lund, Merrill's lawyer, said a decision on whether to appeal further is expected within about a week. Olmsted County District Judge O. Russell Olson had denied Merrill's motion to dismiss the charges relating to the embryo, but asked for a ruling on the constitutionality of the 1986 fetal homicide statutes. Olson said Minnesota's statutes ``represent the most sweeping legislative attempt in the country to criminalize actions of third parties which harm fetuses and embryos.'' In rejecting Merrill's claim that the statutes were ``fatally vague'' because they don't define the phrase ``causes the death of an unborn child,'' the court split 4-3, with Associate Justice Glenn Kelley breaking from the majority. Justices Rosalie Wahl and A.M. ``Sandy'' Keith dissented from the entire majority opinion. Writing for the dissent, Kelley said that, without a statutory definition, the phrase ``causes the death of an unborn child'' is ``burdened with ambiguity which ... invites arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement.'' Lund said he found it a ``a moral victory'' that three of the seven justices found the ``death of unborn child'' phrasing ambiguous. ``Unfortunately ... moral victories don't count in a court of law,'' he said. Olmsted County Attorney Ray Schmitz, who defended the statutes before the Supreme Court, said the justices were careful to separate the fetal homicide issue from abortion. ``Our argument was that the constitutionally protected relationship between mother and fetus is entirely different than actions of a third party, and that is essentially what the court said,'' he said. The challenged statutes impose criminal penalties for ``murder of an unborn child'' in the first and second degrees. The penalties of life imprisonment for conviction on a first-degree charge and up to 40 years on a second-degree charge are the same as for murder. The statutes define ``unborn child'' as the ``offspring of a human being conceived, but not yet born.'' The court said it appeared Merrill was claiming that, because the statutes do not distinguish between viable and non-viable fetuses, he was exposed to conviction as a murderer of an unborn child during the first trimester of pregnancy. On the other hand, a woman who obtains a legal abortion under Roe vs. Wade and the doctor who performs it are not murderers. The justices said, however, that the focus of the Roe vs. Wade decision was on protecting a pregnant woman from governmental interference or compulsion.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Calls for International Program to Salvage Environment
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev Friday called for an international program to save the environment. Speaking to the Global Forum on the Environment and Development for Survival, attended by more than 1,000 political and religious leaders from around the world, Gorbachev also backed suggestions for the formation of an international relief agency to respond to ecological disasters. He dubbed it ``the Green Cross,'' in an obvious reference to the Red Cross. Noting that his own country's environment has suffered greatly from thoughtless decisions, Gorbachev suggested international technical cooperation in preventing and repairing ecological damage. He added that he is prepared to allow inspections on Soviet territory to avoid any suspicion that high technology is being diverted to other uses. The Soviet Union has only begun to recognize its own environmental problems in recent years, since Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness, permitted public criticism of bureaucratic decisions. The Soviet environmental movement expanded dramatically after the Chernobyl nuclear power plant explosion, which devastated a large area of the Ukraine and Byelorussia. Gorbachev drew sustained applause from his audience in the Grand Kremlin Palace when he repeated the Soviet Union's long-standing offer to end nuclear weapons testing if the United States agrees to follow suit. He said the Soviet Union expects to sign an agreement soon providing for the destruction of tons of chemical weapons, and he promised that Soviet military maneuvers would be restructured to reduce environmental damage. In the speech, which ended the five-day conference in Moscow, he called for international environmental monitoring and control. That is another item of considerable use to the Soviet Union, which has only recently begun to calculate its pollution levels. The water in many cities is too fouled to drink and toxic waste dumps are often open pools of deadly chemicals. Gorbachev suggested the development of international standards to protect areas of particular concern for the entire world, such as the Antarctic. He mentioned tropical forests, coral reefs and Lake Baikal in the Soviet Union. Focusing on the Soviet Union, he promised to triple the number of preserves of pristine wilderness in the next decade. He also suggested that an environmental conference planned for Brazil in 1992 be held at ``the highest level'' to approve a code of ecological ethics.

DOC.HEAD: Alberto Semprini, Popular Pianist, Dead at 81
DOC.TEXT: Alberto Semprini, a household name in Britain for 30 years as pianist and host of the ``Semprini's Serenade'' radio program, died Friday at the age of 81. Semprini, who died at his home in Brixham, in Devon, suffered from Alzheimer's disease. Semprini, who had an English mother and Italian father, entertained World War I troops on the piano when he was 8 before going to Milan to study. He had a distinguished career as a concert pianist and conductor and was artistic director of the Italian record company, Fonit, for more than 25 years. He was known for his catchphrase, ``Old ones, new ones, loved ones, neglected ones,'' on his radio show, which ran through the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: Woman at Center of Euthanasia Debate Dies After 15 Years in Coma
DOC.TEXT: Ineke Stinissen, who was at the center of a debate on mercy killing in the Netherlands, died Friday after more than 15 years in a coma. She was 47. The cause of death could not immediately be established, Dutch television reported, but the nursing home in the eastern Netherlands where she had been fed intravenously since a botched Caesarean operation in March 1974 had stopped feeding her 11 days ago. Her death marked the end of a more than a decade of campaigning by her husband, Gerard, for her life to be ended because her coma apparently was irreversible. Earlier this month, the nursing home yielded to a court ruling allowing the medical staff to end Ms. Stinissen's life. It previously had refused to do so on ethical grounds. Attempts by a fundamentalist Dutch pro-life group to obtain a court order to keep feeding her had failed earlier this week. One of the key questions in the Stinissen case was whether such a euthanasia decision can be made on behalf of a comatose patient, since Dutch euthanasia policy and practice is predicated on the patient's request. So-called ``active'' euthanasia has obtained quasi-legal status in the Netherlands after gradual acceptance of a set of ethical guidelines. It is estimated that 5,000 Dutch patients die from mercy killing each year. Ms. Stinissen's death came one day after the government appointed a committee of jurists to draw up recommendations for definitive legislation on the issue, which has been debated for nearly a decade.

DOC.HEAD: United States Lauds Soviet Military Reductions in Vietnam
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs new to UPDATE with Cheney trip to Far East, picks up 4th graf pvs, At the ...
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration spokesmen on Friday applauded the withdrawal of some Soviet warplanes from Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam and said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney will discuss possible responses when he visits U.S. allies in the Far East next month. Cheney plans to travel Feb. 10-23 to Japan, Korea and the Philippines, three nations where the United States has major bases, administration officials said. The Soviet announcement was not expected to lead to an immediate cut in U.S. troops in the Far East, according to administration spokesmen, and they said no decision was likely before April when the Pentagon is to to complete a study on the issue for Congress. U.S. ``force levels in the region are based on the longterm threat and our force levels are based on a rational analysis of that threat in the region,'' said a Pentagon spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Edward Lundquist. ``We continually review our force posture and do so in full consultation with our allies so that we can determine the appropriate levels of deployment,'' he said. The cut in the number of Soviet Mig-23 ``Flogger'' fighters and Tu-16 ``Badger'' bombers at Cam Ranh Bay, announced in Moscow on Thursday, will enhance ``regional stability'' and was part of a reduction in Soviet operations abroad over the past two years, said Lundquist. ``We welcome that announcement,'' said Lundquist. ``This is part of their overall reduction of overseas operations,'' and had been spotted by the Pentagon before the Soviet statement, he said. At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said U.S. officials ``anticipate that less Soviet military involvement in Southeast Asia would contribute to regional stability and to efforts to achieve a comprehensive political settlement to the Cambodian conflict.'' Last year, the Soviet-backed government of Vietnam withdrew its occupation force from Cambodia, and an international conference met in Paris last week seeking a political solution to the Cambodian civil war. The partial withdrawal from Cam Ranh Bay was part of a general reduction in Soviet forces in Asia and around the globe, announced at the United Nations in December 1988 by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Gorbachev said the Soviet Armed Forces would be cut overall by 10 percent, pulling troops and tanks from Eastern Europe and withdrawing 50,000 of its 60,000 troops from neighboring Mongolia, along the Chinese border. Beijing has demanded such a cut as a condition for improved ties with Moscow. Neither the Pentagon nor the Soviet Foreign Ministry disclosed the number of aircraft withdrawn from Cam Ranh, which was an American military base before the fall of the U.S.-backed South Vietnamese government in April 1975. ``The number of aircraft they have deployed, and the tempo of operations at Cam Ranh was less in 1989 than it was in 1988, and that was less than in 1987,'' said Lundquist. In Moscow on Thursday, the Foreign Ministry deputy spokesman Vadim Perfiliyev said up to 10 aircraft remained at Cam Ranh Bay. ``Acting within the framework of the earlier announced measures to reduce the numerical strength of the Soviet Armed Forces in the country's eastern section and convert them to a purely defensive structure in the Asia-Pacific region, the Soviet Union has started reducing its presence in Cam Ranh Port by arrangement with the Vietnamese side,'' Perfiliyev said. ``Mig-23 and Tu-16 planes were withdrawn from there at the end of 1989,'' he said. ``A squadron with a varying number of aircraft (six to 10) remains at the Cam Ranh airfield,'' he said. ``The Soviet side hopes that these actions will help to defuse military-political tension and strengthen the climate of mutual trust in the Asia-Pacific region,'' he said. On Wednesday, Tass quoted Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze as saying that ``the day when there will be no Soviet military presence in Asia beyond Soviet borders is near.'' He urged the United States ``correct its policy in that region.'' As of 1989, Soviet forces at Cam Ranh Bay consisted of 2,800 personnel, six Tu-95 bombers, 16 Tu-16 bombers, one squadron of Mig-23 fighters and a fleet of surveillance and electronic warfare aircraft, according to the ``Military Balance 1989-90,'' published by the International Institute for Strategic Studies, based in London. The Soviets also operate one or two submarines and an unspecified number of surface vessels out of the Vietnamese port, according to the institute. U.S. forces in the Philippines consist of 600 Army, 9,200 Air Force and 5,500 Navy personnel, according to the institute. Additionally, the United States keeps 31,600 Army and 11,600 Air Force personnel in South Korea and 2,000 Army, 16,500 Air Force and 8,300 Navy personnel in Japan, with smaller deployments in Australia and Guam.

DOC.HEAD: Rightists Wage Campaign for Japanese `Political Purity'
With AM-Japan-Mayor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After rightists read in the newspaper that Masaaki Nakajima was active in a group working for the rights of foreigners, they drove a military-style truck to his quiet neighborhood in suburban Tokyo. For two days, Nakajima says, men in khaki uniforms harangued his family and neighbors with the truck's powerful public-address system, bellowing ``Get out of our motherland. Why don't you respect our country?'' Many of Japan's estimated 820 ultra-rightist groups spend their time driving along city streets in dark-painted trucks blaring martial music or in harassing perceived opponents like Nakajima, who also heads the United Church of Christ, Japan's largest Protestant denomination. But some rightist groups, in their quest to protect their vision of Japanese spiritual and political purity, have been implicated in violent attacks such as the shooting Thursday of Nagasaki Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima. Motoshima, who was seriously wounded, received death threats after saying that the late Emperor Hirohito shared responsibility for Japan's involvement in World War II. The leader of a rightist group, Kazumi Tajiri, has confessed to the shooting, police said. Although the number of ultra-right organizations has grown in recent years, police estimate the membership to be about 120,000 _ the same as a decade ago. Their ideas are much the same, too: reverence for the emperor and a ``pure'' Japan, anti-communism, opposition to leftist unions and liberal opinion, and a willingness to use violence that recalls the early 20th century when assassination was a political tool in Japan. The groups have little public support, and often instill more fear than respect. But their high-profile activities have made their impact considerable. Fear of rightist reprisals, along with respect for the imperial family, has kept the question of Hirohito's wartime responsibility a largely taboo subject. Attacks on newspaper offices attributed to rightists, such as the murder of a reporter for the liberal Asahi Shimbun in 1987, have had a chilling psychological effect on news reporting. ``There should be many opinions allowed about the emperor's war responsibility,'' said former Nagasaki Vice Mayor Soichi Urabe. ``Although many people are criticizing the violence of the attack on Mayor Motoshima, most people still aren't considering the more basic issue.'' Police say they monitor the rightist groups, but in most cases have no reason to take action because of the constitutional guarantee of freedom of expression. However, some rightists have been arrested for violating an anti-noise law imposed in 1988 to protect Parliament and foreign embassies. The National Police Agency also has recommended tighter security for public figures following Motoshima's shooting, a police official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. A man who answered the telephone Friday at the office of Tajiri's group, Seikijuku, or The Sane Thinkers' School, asked that questions about the organization be referred to national police ``because they know all about us. Their information is generally correct.'' A local police official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the group has about 30 members in Nagasaki and a record of violence and arrests. The group was active in the intimidation campaign against Motoshima that began after the mayor said in December 1988 that Hirohito, then dying of cancer, ``shares responsibility for the war, as well as all of us who lived in that period.'' A year earlier, Tajiri said in a TV interview that he was willing to kill for his beliefs ``because after all, right-wingers are terrorists.'' The rightists also have targeted conservative politicians and groups. Last year, a rightist group reportedly sent a severed finger to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to protest government debate over funding for imperial ascension ceremonies scheduled later this year. In 1988 a rightist group claimed responsibility for a shotgun attack on the home of the founder of the Recruit Co., a conglomerate at the center of a stock-trading scandal that rocked the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Rightist groups around the country are thought to have links through which they coordinate policy and activities _ for example, their decision to halt most public activities during Hirohito's long illness as a sign of respect, and the gathering of dozens of sound trucks from around the country in Nagasaki to protest Motoshima's remarks. Rightist groups also are generally thought to be funded by underworld ``yakuza'' gangs and to receive guns from them, but the connections remain murky. Many rightists advocate a return to the prewar imperial system, in which the emperor was considered the nation's divine spiritual leader and power was highly centralized. They also want to revise the postwar constitution, especially Article 9, which renounces war and the use of force to settle international disputes. Despite their use of the emperor as a symbol, many rightist groups are not enthusiastic about current Emperor Akihito, whom they see as too unimperial and a product of modern democratic society, observers say. In a shock for the rightists, Akihito also pledged when he became emperor to uphold the Constitution. In contrast, the imperial system has been a focus of attacks by Japan's leftist extremists. Officials say they plan to mobilize about 32,000 police to guard the imperial ascension ceremonies from possible leftist attack this fall.

DOC.HEAD: Danny Thomas' TV Son Dies at Age 42
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 4th, `He apparently...,' to UPDATE with reax from Thomas. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `John Hamer...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: Rusty Hamer, the child actor in Danny Thomas' popular 1950s and '60s television series ``Make Room for Daddy,'' has died of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 42. ``He hasn't really been happy since his early 20s,'' said Hamer's brother, John. ``But he didn't show any signs of this happening. It was just all of a sudden.'' Hamer said his brother suffered debilitating back pain but refused to see a doctor. He apparently shot himself in the head Wednesday with a .357-caliber revolver, said Chief Detective Robert McCullough of the Beauregard Parish Sheriff's Office. Thomas, reached by telephone Friday at his home in Los Angeles, said he and Hamer had ``a marvelous association.'' ``I raised him. I got him when he was about 5{ years old on the TV show. His real father passed away not too long after that. I remember him saying to me, crying, `You're the only daddy I have left now.' ``There is no question in my mind he was the best boy actor in comedy I ever met in my life.''
