Thomas said they kept in touch for a while after the show ended but lost touch after he moved to Louisiana. John Hamer found his brother's body Thursday night in the trailer where he lived near DeRidder, about 40 miles north of Lake Charles in southwestern Louisiana. On the TV series, which ran from 1953 to 1964, Rusty Hamer played the precocious child Rusty. Danny Thomas played his father, a nightclub singer and comedian. Marjorie Lord played Thomas' second wife, Kathy, and Angela Cartwright played her daughter, Linda. It was one of television's most durable and popular situation comedies. Most of the cast, including Hamer, returned in 1970-71 with a sequel sitcom, ``Make Room For Granddaddy,'' in which Rusty was a married medical student. It lasted one season. Rusty Hamer got his first film role at the age of 5, appeared in several Abbot and Costello films, and has a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame, his brother said. At age 20 Hamer was working for a Los Angeles messenger service and was bitter and depressed, his brother said. After moving to southwest Louisiana, his jobs included delivering a newspaper, working offshore for Exxon, and occasional work at his brother's restaurant. John Hamer, 47, said he began acting before Rusty but left Hollywood when he was 17. ``I did not enjoy the industry. I felt the people in it _ the majority were confused in their own lives,'' he said. John Hamer said he had moved to DeRidder to open a cafe and Rusty moved there in 1976 to be near their mother, who had moved in with John. He said he thought their mother's ill health took a toll on his brother. The only survivors are his brother and their mother, Dorothy Hamer, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease and is in a nursing home. He will be cremated without services, according to Colonial Funeral Home in DeRidder.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Muffled Conclusions of WIC Report, GAO Says
DOC.TEXT: A revision of an Agriculture Department study unjustifiably played down the benefits of a popular $1.93 billion nutrition program designed to help poor women and children, according to a report to Congress released Friday. The General Accounting Office, the investigating arm of Congress, said department reviewers who evaluated research on the so-called WIC program ``deleted the original chapter and executive summaries'' because those reviewers believed the deleted material portrayed the program ``more favorably than justified by the data.'' WIC, which stands for Women, Infants and Children, provides food to pregnant women and new mothers. A congressional committee plans to hold hearings on the GAO report next week. Results of the six-year $5.9 million analysis were released in 1986 and ``almost immediately'' raised questions, the GAO report said. According to the GA0, the department's compendium of results from the study, substituted for the original summaries, ``contains errors and misleading statements about some of the data and deletes the study team's overall conclusions regarding the WIC program's impact on participants.'' It added: ``In contrast, the original executive summary used appropriate methodology, was accurately presented, and reported the study's main conclusions: that WIC improves the diet of pregnant women and children, adds to maternal weight gain, increases the use of prenatal care, and reduces preterm deliveries.'' In comments included in the GAO report, the department said it ``agrees with GAO's technical criticism'' of the compendium of results, and agrees with criticisms of the delays in publishing the report. ``However, the intent of this document was not to understate the results nor to mislead the reader in any way,'' said Ann Chadwick, acting assistant secretary for food and consumer services. ``It was written out of a genuine concern that the summary submitted by the contractor did not accurately characterize the results of (the study).'' The WIC program began in 1972 and provides food supplements and nutrition education to low-income pregnant and breast-feeding mothers and children up to five years old. An average of about 3.4 million people were enrolled in the program in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30. Food packages contain such items as infant formula, milk or milk products, iron-fortified cereal, juice, eggs and dried beans or peanut butter. The packages are supposed to supplement other food sources like food stamps or welfare programs. According to GAO, the objective of the evaluation that began in 1979 was to ``provide a reliable estimate of the effects of participation in the WIC program on nutrition and health during pregnancy and early childhood.'' The report said that a 1987 Agriculture Department study showed about 10 million people could be eligible for WIC benefits, based on income. And that study used 1984 data, it said. Thus, some members of Congress, including those who would like to see the WIC program expanded, were interested in the evaluation report to help make further decisions on the future of the program. The GAO report has top billing at a joint hearing on Jan. 24 of the House Select Committee on Hunger, headed by Rep. Tony P. Hall, D-Ohio, and the Senate Agriculture Committee, headed by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. In a terse statement issued Friday, Leahy said, ``The allegations made in the GAO report are very troubling. I plan to get to the bottom of this at the hearing next week.''

DOC.HEAD: Agency Upgrades Probe of Escort-Lynx Restraint Systems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Federal engineers are stepping up their probe of possible automatic torso belt failures in the Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx that consumers have blamed for five deaths and 76 injuries, the government said Friday. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it was upgrading its investigation from a preliminary evaluation, involving mostly paperwork, to an engineering analysis in which engineers will study the components involved. ``We've received numerous reports which allege malfunction or failure of the passive restraint system,'' agency spokesman Tim Hurd said. ``Additional reports allege the passive restraint system failed to restrain or adequately protect the occupant during an accident.'' The investigation involves the 1987, 1988 and 1989 Escort and the 1987 Lynx, Ford Motor Co. spokeswoman Linda Becker said. An estimated 1,029,312 are on the road. The Lynx, a clone of Escort sold under the Mercury name, was discontinued after 1987. The agency and Ford have received 316 complaints between them, blaming the belts for five deaths and 76 injuries resulting from accidents, Hurd said. Ford is cooperating with the investigation and company engineers are inspecting the models in question, Ms. Becker said. ``We have found no evidence that any systematic defect is involved,'' she said. ``It appears the passive belt systems have performed as designed.'' The cars have manual lap belts in addition to the automatic torso belts being investigated, she said. The agency also announced new preliminary evaluations of: _Cruise controls that fail to disengage in the 1983 and 1984 Toyota Camry, the subject of four complaints in the United States and three in Canada. _Reports of malfunctioning warning lights in the 1987-90 Camry designed to notify passengers when the passive safety belt system has been disengaged. There have been three complaints blaming the problem for three accidents and five injuries. _Fires and smoke in 1983-88 Ford light pickup trucks caused by dried leaves and debris entering the heating and air conditioning systems. Three fires and six instances of smoke have been reported, and 1.7 million of the trucks are on the road. _Six reports of gasoline leaks in the Volkswagen Vanagon models with supplementary gasoline heaters. _Thirteen reports of cruise control problems in 1984-88 GMC Suburban vans. _Eight complaints of power steering loss in the 1987-88 Chevrolet Astro and Safari minivans. The agency said it had discontinued three preliminary evaluations after finding no widespread defects. The investigations were of safety belt retractor failures in Chrysler Corp.'s 1988 Jeep Cherokee, Wrangler and Wagoneer; under-dashboard fires in the 1987 Porsche 924 and 944 and transmission oil line fires in the 1988-89 Ford Probe. An investigation of transmission oil line fires in the 1988-89 Mazda MX6 was halted after engineers found the problem posed no unreasonable risk.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Activist Myles Horton Dead at 84
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to CORRECT to Knoxville, Tenn., sted Ky., and 12th graf to the school's charter, sted state charter.
DOC.TEXT: Myles F. Horton, a major influence on a generation of civil rights leaders who founded a school that led the movement to franchise blacks, died Friday of cancer. He was 84. Horton, a self-described ``radical hillbilly,'' saw literacy as a key to breaking racial barriers and envisioned a new South long before others thought it possible. In 1932, Horton helped found the Highlander Folk School near Chattanooga. Often called the backbone of the civil rights movement, the school educated impoverished southern workers, labor union leaders and civil rights activists. Martin Luther King Jr., Ralph Abernathy, Eleanor Roosevelt, Rosa Parks, John L. Lewis and Andrew Young were influenced by Horton and supported his endeavors. ``Myles Horton was one of those suffering servants who had a vision of justice in the South long before it was deemed possible,'' Young said earlier this week. John Gaventa, director of the Highlander Research and Education Center, as the school is now called, said Horton died surrounded by friends and family at his home on the school's campus, 20 miles east of Knoxville, Tenn. Horton had been fighting cancer for 2{ years and last month was diagnosed with an inoperable brain tumor. He slipped into a deep coma Jan. 13. A group of Highlander associates started the first Citizenship School in the Sea Islands off South Carolina, the forerunner of other schools that taught poor blacks to read so they could pass literacy tests and vote. In the 1930s, Highlander was a training school for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, or the CIO, and supported coal miners, farmers and textile workers organize unions in the Depression Era. Highlander was one of the few places in the South where blacks and whites could meet and discuss social change. It was closely allied with the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and Martin Luther King. Mrs. Roosevelt defended Highlander when McCarthyites attacked the school in the 1950s as a training center and safe haven for Communists. The state of Tennessee shut down Highlander in 1959, saying interracial gatherings and alleged liquor sales at the school violated the school's charter. Highlander was auctioned in 1961, but started again a decade later. Horton received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Civil Liberties Union of Tennessee in 1989; the Martin Luther King Jr. Award from the Fellowship of Reconciliation, a religious group; the Rothko Chapel Award for Commitment to Truth and Freedom in 1986; and the Literacy Education Award from the International Council of Adult Education in Paris in 1982, among other honors. The son of a sharecropper, Horton was born July 9, 1905 in Savannah, Tenn. He attended Cumberland University in Tennessee, Union Theological Seminary in New York, and then the University of Chicago. Horton married Zilphia Johnson Horton in 1935 and both directed programs at the school. After her death, in 1961 he married Aimee Isgrig, but the couple later separated. He is survived by Charis Horton, 44, a Los Angeles filmmaker, and Thorsten Horton, 46, a Wisconsin college professor.

DOC.HEAD: New Pacific Fleet Commander Named
DOC.TEXT: Vice Adm. Charles R. Larson has been nominated by President Bush for promotion to admiral and assignment as commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet, the Pentagon said Friday. Larson, 53, is the senior Navy member of the U.N. military staff committee and deputy chief of naval operations for plans, policy and operations. He will be replaced in those posts by Rear Adm. Robert J. Kelly. Kelly, 51, is being nominated for promotion to vice admiral. He currently is assigned to the Strategic Studies Institute at the National Defense University.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Who Survived 40 Minutes Underwater Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old boy who survived after being under water for 40 minutes earlier this week died Friday at Fairfax Hospital, a hospital spokeswoman said. George Sader was playing with a cousin and a friend Monday when the ice cracked on a partially fenced drainage pond in Centreville, Va. The two girls were not seriously injured. Dr. Craig Futterman, who had been treating the boy, had said the youth had a 2 percent to 10 percent chance of surviving, and a 2 percent chance of surviving without neurological damage. Most of the boy's major organs had been damaged, Futterman said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls for Lower Interest Rates, Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf pvs `Bush also ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Bush touring the Everglades. Picks up 18th graf pvs `In Atlanta ...' Note 2 grafs are embargoed for 7:15 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday issued an election-year call for lower taxes and interest rates, saying he's not satisfied with home mortgage rates hovering around 10 percent. ``We cannot allow the high costs of housing to suffocate the financial life of America's young people. And when it comes to housing, this must not become a society of `haves' and `have nots,''' the president said on the eve of the first anniversary of his inauguration. ``The 1990s must be another decade of lower taxes and lower interest rates.'' Bush spoke at the National Association of Home Builders convention in Atlanta before flying to Miami to campaign for the re-election of Republican Gov. Bob Martinez. The homebuilders are experiencing hard times, with housing construction slumping last year to its lowest level since the 1982 recession. Bush said mortgage rates have fallen from 18 percent in the early 1980s to less than 10 percent. ``I want to see them come down even more. ... I am not satisfied at 10 percent,'' Bush said, winning cheers from the audience of thousands of people in Atlanta's cavernous Omni Coliseum. His remarks added direct pressure to a White House call a day earlier for the Federal Reserve to ease credit further. Bush also prodded Congress to adopt fiscal policies ``as sound as those of the average American household.'' He said any money saved from lower Pentagon spending should be used to reduce the deficit instead of for new spending. In Washington, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Friday that he hasn't decided whether to endorse Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to roll back Social Security taxes, but criticized Bush for rejecting it out of hand. Mitchell credited Moynihan, a New York Democrat, with stating ``in very stark terms the administration's tax policy, which is, `Let's cut taxes for the wealthy, but not the working people.''' Bush on Thursday called the Moynihan proposal a ``charade'' and Vice President Dan Quayle said it was ``a political trap'' and ``a subterfuge for a general tax increase.'' Riding into Atlanta from the airport, Bush's armored Cadillac limousine billowed white smoke from under the hood because of an unexplained mechanical failure. One aide said there had been a drop in oil pressure. The motorcade stopped on Interstate 75 for about two minutes while Bush switched into a backup car.
DOC.HEAD: Following grafs embargoed for 7:15 p.m. EST:
DOC.TEXT: Later, in remarks prepared for a Martinez fund-raiser in Miami, Bush noted changes around the world with democratic reforms in Eastern Europe and the removal of Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in Panama. ``In fact,'' Bush said, ``there are only two holdouts preventing a totally democratic hemisphere. So let Daniel Ortega (president of Nicaragua) and Fidel Castro (president of Cuba) take note: Like the dinosaur, the day of the dictator is over.'' End embargoed material

Bush toured a section of Everglades National Park not far from Miami, walking along wooden pathways and bridges, watching alligators and discussing wildlife and the environment with youngsters from Sunset Elementary School who accompanied him. As a crow cawed loudly, the president sat on a stone wall, alligators swimming in the swampy waters behind him, and listened to a 20-minute lecture on the fragile Everglades ecosystem from a national park ranger. ``As the world gets smaller, we have to preserve our environment and protect it,'' Bush said. But ``you can't stop everything from growing so you need sound management.'' In Atlanta, Bush spoke at the same coliseum where Democrats held their 1988 convention and nominated Michael Dukakis to run against him. Bush told the homebuilders that low and stable interest rates are vital for home-builders and home-buyers alike. ``A 1 percent increase in the interest rate knocks millions of families out of the market,'' he said, adding that the best housing policy is ``a healthy, growing economy with low, long-term interest rates.'' The Bush White House has been reluctant to criticize the Federal Reserve, but began expressing concern Thursday amid signs the central bank would not support a further easing of credit. After driving rates higher since early 1987, the Fed reversed course in June. Since then, the federal funds rate, controlled directly by the Fed, has fallen about 1.5 percentage points, to about 8.25 percent. The federal funds rate is the rate banks charge one another for overnight loans. Bush used his appearances to make another pitch for congressional approval of a cut in capital gains taxes. He said he wanted an up-or-down vote on the issue soon after the Congress reconvenes Jan. 23. The president also noted a planned march by white supremacist Richard Barrett on Saturday near Atlanta's Martin Luther King center. ``Atlanta is a great and cheerful city. It has proudly risen from the ashes of a distant past,'' Bush said. ``And for those who plan to revel in a rally of hate here tomorrow, let them know this: Atlantans, like all Americans, turn their backs on bigots.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan to Reopen Talks on Aid to China
DOC.TEXT: Japan and China agreed Friday to resume talks on a major Japanese loan package that were suspended after China's military crackdown on pro-democracy dissent. Koichi Matsuura, director general of the Japanese Foreign Ministry's Economic Cooperation Bureau, said a final decision on the loan package will be reached after the two sides exchange data on the contents of the economic assistance, Japanese sources said. Matsuura met Thursday and Friday with Foreign Economic Relations and Trade Vice Minister Shen Jueren. He also held talks Zhu Lilan, vice minister of the State Science and Technology Commission. Matsuura's visit follows the lifting of martial law in Beijing last week, a move aimed at easing tensions with the United States and other countries and persuading the West to end sanctions on badly needed soft loans for development projects. The United State responded to the lifting of martial law by saying it would support new World Bank loans for humanitarian purposes. Japan also welcomed the end of martial law, but said it wanted to see further efforts by China before it revives its economic aid programs. The sources said no specific time has been set for further talks on the $5.6 billion loan package Japan has pledged to provide for some 40 development projects in the 1991-95 period. They said Matsuura told the Chinese that the lifting of martial law was a positive step and that Japan hopes to see China continue its policies of economic reform and opening to the outside world. He said there has been no change in Japan's intention to help China's modernization process through grants, government loans and technical cooperation. The Chinese side expressed its appreciation for Japan's fulfilling its loan commitment of $3.2 billion for the five-year period ending in March. Japan, like other Western nations, after the military crackdown on the democracy movement in June 1989 suspended negotiations on new loans while going ahead with credit already pledged. A Japanese Embassy official said Matsuura's visit was for ``preliminary discussions'' on a variety of credit and grant programs Japan has with China and would not mean an immediate resumption of talks on the five-year package. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has said he hopes a final agreement on the loans can be reached by April as originally scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: Guru Still Evokes Strong Emotion in Oregon
LaserPhoto PD3
DOC.TEXT: The Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh said his showcase of communal living in Oregon would set an example for the world, but at his death Friday his commune was vacant and unwanted, his followers scattered, his memory reviled. Rajneesh came to Oregon in 1981. By the time he was thrown out of the country in 1985, authorities were calling him the most notorious figure in Oregon history. ``He was both a charlatan and a very evil person,'' said Vic Atiyeh, the governor during the guru's years in Oregon. ``Evil in the sense of the kind of people he gathered around him and what he allowed them to do, and his own personal arrogance. He was above everything.'' U.S. Attorney Charles Turner, who prosecuted the guru on immigration fraud charges, said the 400 sham marriages among Rajneesh's disciples that led to the immigration charges, the poisoning of 750 people at restaurant salad bars and the commune's vast electronic eavesdropping network were the largest cases of their kind in American history. ``The legacy of crime that this man left here is unparalleled in American jurisprudence,'' Turner said. The bejeweled guru brought his gospel of meditation and free love to the United States on the pretense of obtaining treatment for a bad back. He never underwent that surgery, but moved to a 64,000-acre ranch his followers had purchased in the remote high desert of central Oregon. Their stated intent was to farm the land on Rancho Rajneesh, but they built homes, a hotel, restaurants, shops, an airport and a meditation hall, and then incorporated as the town of Rajneeshpuram. After it all fell apart, an insurance company foreclosed on Rancho Rajneesh, but has been unable to find a buyer. At its height, some 4,000 red-clad disciples lived at the commune. The gathering swelled to 15,000 when followers from around the world came for summer festivals. Between morning and evening meditation sessions with Rajneesh, disciples toiled 12 hours a day. In the early afternoon, they would stop work and line the dusty roads for the guru's daily ``drive-by'' in one of his more than 90 Rolls-Royces. Singing and swaying, the disciples tossed roses onto the car's hood while armed guards hovered overhead in a helicopter. Sect members won political control of the nearby community of Antelope, renaming it City of Rajneesh, and attempted to control voting in Wasco County by busing thousands of homeless people to the commune in 1984. After state officials ordered eligibility hearings for all new voter registration applicants in the county, the Rajneeshees and their transient guests boycotted the election. ``At the time we were going through it, we didn't realize how extraordinary it was,'' said Norma Paulus, who was secretary of state at the time. ``I can't think of any comparable incidents in American history.'' Rajneesh's acid-tongued secretary, Ma Anand Sheela, was a fixture in the state's media as she accused anyone who opposed the commune of bigotry. Lawsuits were filed by and against the Rajneeshees on issues ranging from slander to the constitutionality of Rajneeshpuram's incorporation. Rajneeshee-loathing spread throughout the state. Caps bearing the guru's likeness inside a rifle target were hot items. In September 1985, Sheela and about a dozen disciples left the commune abruptly. Rajneesh made accusations against her that triggered federal, state and local criminal investigations. Rajneesh was arrested the next month during a stopover at Charlotte, N.C., on a flight to Bermuda. He pleaded guilty to two counts of immigration fraud and returned to India under an agreement with federal officials. Sheela, now 39, was arrested in West Germany and returned to Oregon, where she pleaded guilty to charges that included the attempted murder of the guru's physician with a poison-filled syringe. She also admitted poisoning several county officials and masterminding the salad poisonings at restaurants in The Dalles, the county seat. She pleaded guilty to creating an electronic eavesdropping system at the commune and to setting fire to the county planning office. A guilty plea to immigration fraud stemmed from charges that she helped arrange sham marriages to allow Rajneesh's foreign disciples to remain in the United States. Sheela, a native of India, was deported in December 1988 after serving 2{ years in federal prison. Rajneeshees say about 200 of the guru's followers remain in Oregon, but keep a low profile. Attorney General Frohnmayer says the Rajneeshee episode resulted in the clarification of state laws in several areas. ``We learned from it,'' he said. ``It would be harder for a group bent on breaking the laws of civil government to move in to Oregon now.''

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Complains Of Congressional Meddling
DOC.TEXT: Aid to Panama is being delayed up to 45 days in some cases because of ``inappropriate intrusions'' by Congress into administration affairs, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Friday. Thornburgh, addressing an annual meeting of the Federalist Society, said the lawmakers are ``increasingly attempting to micromanage the executive branch on matters such as foreign affairs, routine executive branch operations and even internal deliberations.'' ``Even today, the president's flexibility to act with dispatch to help our friends in Panama is hampered and delayed by ... congressional caveats,'' the attorney general said. ``They were impetuously passed to stop any foreign aid, or military support, or tariff relief from ever going to General Manuel Noriega. Now Noriega is in a Miami jail _ because of prompt executive action _ but these `regs' are still on the books, blocking help to Panama, in some cases, for 45 days.'' ``Such provisions constitute clearly inappropriate intrusions by Congress into executive branch management,'' Thornburgh said. ``I have grave doubts ... that the power of the purse was ever intended to include the power to define our foreign relations .... and to require that Congress be notified of all covert activities within 48 hours, even if doing so could threaten American lives,'' said the attorney general. He also expressed concern about ``Congress' growing penchant for delegating executive power to persons not controlled by the president, and cited the Independent Counsel act as an example. ``I broach this subject briefly not to impugn any past or present independent counsel, but to point out, forthrightly, present difficulties and potential dangers that arise, even from the best of intentions, when the separation of powers is ignored, or, as in this case, is legislatively `gotten round','' he said. ``Today's overstepping by the legislative branch does not yet threaten individual liberty,'' Thornburgh said. ``But it does unnecessarily challenge this administration's commitment to a less adversarial relationship between the co-equal branches of government.'' The Federalist Society is named after the Federalist Papers, in which Alexander Hamilton, James Madison and John Jay urged adoption of the Constitution. It was founded in 1981 by three Yale and University of Chicago law students to counter what they saw as a liberal bias on law school campuses.

DOC.HEAD: Cranston Blames Federal Regulator for Uninsured S&L Losses
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Cranston, fighting low approval ratings because of his involvement with Lincoln Savings and Loan, said Friday a former banking regulator was to blame for the sale of worthless bonds at the failed thrift's offices. Continuing an offensive he began early this week, the Senate majority whip renewed his attack on former chief S&L regulator Edwin J. Gray as the main culprit in the failure of Lincoln _ and the losses sustained by bondholders, many of them elderly Californians who lost their life savings. Cranston, D-Calif., released documents in Washington and held news conferences in California to paint what he called ``a picture of negligence by Gray and his staff'' when Gray headed the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. One of five senators under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for intervening with regulators on Lincoln's behalf, Cranston has gone on the offensive this week with five news conferences in his home state. Three separate polls in recent weeks show his popularity with California voters has plunged to its lowest level ever since he came to the Senate in 1969. The chief document was a chronology by federal regulators. It showed the bank board permitted Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp., to sell its junk bonds at the bank's offices _ even though regulators questioned the firm's ability to repay bondholders. The bonds, unlike bank accounts at Lincoln, were not insured and became worthless when American Continental filed for bankruptcy. ``It is unforgivable that Gray was permitting the bond sales at a time when his regulators were raising questions about the financial state of Lincoln and American Continental,'' Cranston said in a statement. Gray, president of Chase Federal Bank in Miami, was on vacation and not available for comment, his office said. He headed the bank board, the former name of the thrift regulation agency, from 1983 to June 1987. State and federal officials have said previously that some 22,000 people, mostly Los Angeles-area retirees, were targeted by Lincoln to switch nearly $200 million of federally insured deposits into the uninsured junk bonds after federal examiners first recommended closing the Irvine, Calif. thrift in May 1987. Cranston and four Senate colleagues received a combined $1.3 million for their campaigns and causes from Charles H. Keating Jr., who was Lincoln's owner until the federal government seized the thrift last April. The $2 billion-plus cost for protecting depositors with insured accounts _ not the bondholders _ is likely to be the most expensive thrift takeover in history. The other senators are Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., John McCain, R-Ariz., John Glenn, D-Ohio and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. By focusing on the bondholders, Cranston tried to disarm one of the most personally damaging allegations against him _ bondholders' testimony that his intervention for Keating made him partly responsible for their losses. Donations of $974,000 went to Cranston's campaign or to voter registration projects and other political causes headed by members of Cranston's family. Speaking in California, Cranston said, ``I'm taking this step by step,'' saying that ``One way (to help the bondholders) is to enact legislation to waive immunity and allow them to sue the federal government as they can the state.'' The key document released by Cranston was a chronology by the Office of Thrift Supervision of events surrounding the bond sales. The document showed that early in 1987, Gray's regulators raised serious questions about American Continental's financial condition and its ability to pay bondholders. An internal bank board memo of Feb. 13, 1987, for instance, ``concludes that ACC may not have the ability to service the debt in the long term,'' the chronology said. The regulators did not force the end of the bond sales until Dec. 30, 1988, according to the chronology.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Buy More U.S. Wheat
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 498,500 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in March under a long-term grain supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Friday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat was sold by five companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Dickerson said only 12,950 tons of wheat remain in the Soviet Union's current EEP allocation of 2 million tons announced Dec. 19. Only wheat has been approved for sale to the Soviets under the price-subsidy program. Although no new allocation has been made, the depletion of existing EEP authority raises the possibility that a new one may be in the works, depending on Soviet needs. The seventh year of the U.S.-Soviet grain agreement began Oct. 1. With the latest sales, the Soviet Union has bought more than 2.7 million tons of wheat for 1989-90 delivery and more than 11 million tons of corn, plus some soybeans and soybean meal. All of the wheat was sold under EEP arrangements. In 1988-89, the sixth year of the agreement, the Soviet Union bought about 5.4 million tons of wheat and more than 16.3 million tons of corn, plus soybeans, soybean meal and grain sorghums. All but about 700,000 tons of the wheat was bought under EEP. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The 498,500 tons are equal to 18.3 million bushels worth around $69 million at recent U.S. farm prices. Dickerson reported the subsidies at an average of $17.58 per ton, or about 48 cents per bushel. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices to meet foreign competition.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle to Hold Talks at Honduran Inauguration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Quayle to discuss possibility of U.S. aid to Panama. Picks up 4th graf pvs `If the ...' SUBS 9th graf pvs `In Panama ...' with 5 grafs to ADD quotes, no figures announced on how much aid the U.S. may provide. Picks up 10th graf pvs `Endara should ...'
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, meeting resistance in his bid to visit some Latin American countries, will hold bilateral talks with six heads of state when he goes to Honduras later this month for the inauguration of that country's president, his office said Friday. On a stop in Panama, the vice president Quayle will discuss the possibility of U.S. aid to repair the invasion-torn nation, said Quayle press secretary David Beckwith. In Tegucigalpa, Quayle has scheduled meeting with the presidents of Venezuela, El Salvador, Belize, Costa Rica and Guatemala, as well as with the new president of Honduras, Rafael Callejas. Those discussions most likely will accomplish what President Bush had in mind when he assigned Quayle to visit the region to soothe Latin objections to the U.S. military invasion of Panama, Beckwith said. ``If the consultations are accomplished, it reduces the urgency'' of visiting those countries personally, Beckwith said. ``It will fulfill the mission.'' The talks give the leaders of the Latin nations an opportunity to meet with Quayle without receiving him in their own countries. Many Latin leaders have voiced objections to receiving Quayle so soon after the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama, particularly with U.S. invasion troops still in the country. Administration officials acknowledge that they were troubled by the reaction from the Latin American nations. Officials said that while none of the leaders refused to speak to Quayle, they let it be known that this was not the best time for an American vice president to visit. Quayle's trip to the Jan. 27 inauguration includes a subsequent stop in Jamaica, as well as Panama. No figures have been announced on how much money the United States can provide from its already strapped budget to help Panama rebuild, but Quayle ``will be talking to them about what's needed,'' Beckwith said. ``I'm sure he'll be able to give them an indication of what might be feasible.'' Beckwith quoted Quayle as saying that ``the topic of helping democracy take root and rebuilding Panama is at the top of the immediate foreign policy agenda.'' Other administration officials have said an aid package might include assistance to businesses, building or permanent housing for the displaced. Quayle also will lend moral support to the U.S.-installed government of Guillermo Endara, one of the very points that rankles many Latins. Endara should have to face elections or be appointed by the congress instead of holding power by installation of the U.S. military, they say. Endara, by the account of independent observer groups, won the May election that was invalidated by dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Quayle says one objective of his trip will be to urge recognition of Endara by the Latin countries. In Jamaica, he will consult with President Michael Manley. Although Jamaica voted with the overwhelming majority in the Organization of American States to deplore the invasion of Panama, the Caribbean nation has other matters to discuss with Quayle, said one official. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Jamaica bucked the regional trend and welcomed Quayle because Kingston feels ``the United States should not be held hostage to the action the United States took'' in Panama. Bush announced Jan. 5 that he would send Quayle to Latin America to make explanations about the invasion, which deeply offended even countries friendly to the United States. They saw it as a heavy-handed invasion of Panamanian sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Officials Say Employees May Leave Chad Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed officials said Friday that three employees being detained in Chad in a dispute over a company technical manual they destroyed are expected to leave Sunday. Chad officials told the Marietta-based aircraft company Friday morning that it could make plans for the three technicians to return home, said Dick Martin, a spokesman at Lockheed's Marietta plant. ``The company is confident the three employees and two wives will be on a commercial flight to Paris Sunday,'' Martin said. The detention was ``due to a misunderstanding'' concerning a highly technical maintenance instruction manual that the men believed was not to be handed over to the Chadians at the end of their one-year maintenance contract, said Len R. Webb, Lockheed's director for the Middle East and Africa. When the men destroyed the multivolume document, they were taken into custody. The technicians, identified as Marvin Gambill, Ernest Ruse and Irving Thrash, were confined for 10 days in an N'Djamena police barracks and since Jan. 15 have been kept inside the compound of the Hotel Tchadienne, the African country's top hotel. ``I feel a little as though I were in a cage,'' Ruse said Friday. ``And the worst of it is that I'm afraid no one will ever trust us again.'' Webb said the three men had not been ill-treated or harassed in any way. The three were in Chad because a purchase contract for two Lockheed C-130 military transport planes called for the three-man technical team from the Lockheed Aeronautical Systems-Georgia subsidiary to spend a year there teaching local technicians how to maintain the planes. The contract ended in December. The three men were pledged to silence about the affair by Lockheed officials while they remained in Chad and authorities continued to hold their passports. Webb said he believed he has resolved the problem by obtaining an export license for the manual from the U.S. State Department and getting a new copy of it into the hands of Chadian officials. Webb said the three men _ two of them accompanied by their wives _ would fly from Paris directly to Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Will Appeal Latest Rejection of Marijuana for Medical Uses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf: ``But the,'' to note THC is the active ingredient; INSERTS grafs 15-16: ``The government,'' to note marijuana on rare occasions made available by FDA for medical uses; minor editing throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Groups trying to make marijuana available for medical uses such as controlling nausea in cancer patients on Friday appealed the Drug Enforcement Administration's decision rejecting the move. The DEA acknowledges that marijuana has been used as a drug for centuries and its therapeutic potential has been noted by doctors for 150 years. But the drug has been illegal in the United States since 1937 _ with only a synthetic tetrahydrocannabinol, THC, the active ingredient in marijuana, available for medical use. DEA administrators for 15 years have rejected bids to make marijuana itself available to patients, most recently last month. On Friday, the Drug Policy Foundation, acting as attorney for the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws and the Alliance for Cannabis Therapeutics, took the case again to the U.S. Court of Appeals. ``This will be the fifth time,'' said Kevin Zeese, counsel and co-founder of the Drug Policy Foundation who was with NORML from 1980 to 1986. The Drug Policy Foundation advocates treating drug abuse as a health problem, not a criminal problem. ``Each time we've won,'' Zeese said. ``But this is the first time (the case) is on the issue of whether marijuana has medical value.'' Advocates of allowing medical uses of marijuana want the DEA to change marijuana's status as a Schedule I drug, which is available only for research, to a Schedule II drug, which would make it available for patient use. Previous court cases have been more on procedural matters, such as whether the DEA held appropriate hearings before rejecting applications. On Dec. 29, DEA Administrator John C. Lawn rejected a longstanding petition to reclassify marijuana to Schedule II, overturning a recommendation by DEA's chief administrative law judge, Francis L. Young. Young called marijuana ``one of the safest therapeutically active substances known to man'' and ``accepted as capable of relieving the distress of great numbers of very ill people.'' Young wrote that ``It would be unreasonable, arbitrary and capricious'' for DEA to maintain the old classification. Lawn wrote that Young had ``failed to act as an impartial judge in this matter. He appears to have ignored the scientific evidence, ignored the testimony of highly credible and recognized medical experts and, instead, relied on the testimony of psychiatrists and individuals who used marijuana.'' In addition, Lawn said, Young had ``ignored any evidence presented by the government.'' Synthetic THC is available on Schedule II for use as a cancer chemotherapy antinauseant. Marijuana also has been touted as useful in the treatment of glaucoma. The government provides marijuana for free in some cases in which the Food and Drug Administration has approved use of the drug for ``compassionate'' medical purposes. However, medical marijuana advocates say the process is time-consuming and discourages physicians from applying for the right to prescribe the drug. The FDA said at least two dozen compassionate applications have been approved since the first in 1976, some covering more than one patient. Robert Randall of the Alliance for Cannabis Therapeutics, who suffers from glaucoma and was the first to get the FDA's nod, said he and four others are the only patients who currently have government approval to use the drug. Dr. C. Stratton Hill of the University of Texas' M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, said, ``The people I know who have used (THC) say it's not better than other anti-emetics,'' or antinausea, antivomiting drugs. ``To be effective, you usually have to give it in the dose that will cause the mind alterations,'' Hill said. ``Most patients who have cancer don't particularly like that because they're older folks ... and that's disturbing to them.'' Hill said the use of marijuana ``is more an emotional issue than anything else. ... It's so tied up with the psychological makeup of the person who wants to use it that it's difficult to ferret out what its use actually is.'' But Zeese said studies by a half-dozen states comparing marijuana and the synthetic THC for their antinausea properties have found ``marijuana's much more effective and much safer as well.'' ``With THC, you're taking the pure drug, a much more mind-altering substance. You see God on that stuff. It's like tripping,'' Zeese said. ``Marijuana is something the patient can control. A cancer patient will take two smokes off a marijuana cigarette and that's all he needs.'' Zeese said the biggest problem medical marijuana advocates are likely to face is ``a general rule of law where the Court of Appeals will usually defer to the head of an agency, considering the agency is an expert.'' ``One thing we're going to show is the agency's long-term bias,'' Zeese said. ``We're also going to have to demonstrate Lawn's bias as well _ his own, all sorts of political pressures, pressures from field efforts, his law enforcement background.'' DEA spokesman Cornelius Dougherty said Lawn's personal background _ including promises to the wife of slain DEA Agent Enrique Camarena that Camarena's efforts against Mexican marijuana traffickers would mean something _ is not important. ``The point here is that no one has proven ... that marijuana does have an accepted medical use, unlike morphine and cocaine,'' which are Schedule II drugs, said Dougherty said.

DOC.HEAD: Remorse Upstairs, a Silent Mayor Downstairs
With AM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of the District of Columbia and a drug dealer who said he sold him cocaine both made appearances in the same federal courthouse Friday. For Mayor Marion Barry, the legal process was just beginning. For Charles Lewis, it was at an end. ``The purpose of this hearing is to advise you of the charge,'' Magistrate Deborah Robinson told Barry. ``You are not required to make any statement.'' The usually loquacious politician remained silent. Until his trial on a single misdemeanor count of possessing cocaine, he must undergo drug testing once a week. The mayor was seized in a hotel Thursday night; the authorities said they had pictures of him buying crack cocaine from a woman and smoking it. Two floors up, Lewis was urged by Judge Stanley Sporkin to speak out. ``It is often hard for others to understand ... how low one can sink,'' said Lewis. ``How one can be bought by drugs is shown by my willingness to lie, and not only to lie but to lie to protect the mayor.'' Lewis lied, by his own admission, when he denied selling drugs to Barry in 1988 during at least six visits by the mayor to his hotel room. Barry said it wasn't so. The government placed 16 perjury, conspiracy and cocaine possession charges against Lewis and he became cooperative. In a plea bargaining appearance last November, he told Sporkin he bought crack for Barry three times, either on a street corner or at a friend's house, and said he then gave the crack to the mayor during the hotel visits. ``I'm not worried at all about this,'' Barry said at the time. He said a ``convicted felon'' like Lewis ``will say anything in court ... trying to save his own hide.'' If that was what Lewis was trying to do, he succeeded. In court Friday, the government stood up for him. ``He has shown himself to be extremely remorseful, '' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin. She said the prosecution would not object if the judge sentenced Lewis on the low end of the 15-to-21 month prison span available under federal guidelines. Lewis described ``the contempt I feel for my own actions'' and promised to rededicate his life to public service. ``I will never again fool with the laws of society,'' he said. Sporkin said young men with their whole lives ahead of them had stood before him where Lewis stood and were given sentences of 10 to 15 years. He gave Lewis the minimum, 15 months. Subtracting time served, he is to be released in May. ``I was going to give you 18 months, but the government has impressed me with the extent of your cooperation,'' said the judge. ``You are getting the best break I know.'' ``I want the word to go out that cooperation is extremely important,'' he said. ``The only way we are really going to attack the drug problem is to have people like yourself come forward.'' When he is released, the judge told him, ``I would like you to out ... and tell youngsters why they shouldn't do drugs.'' That is the message that Barry has been delivering when he speaks to young people.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Lauds Social Security Idea, But Declines To Endorse It
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 13th graf pvs, bgng, On Friday... with 3 new grafs to include Dole comments
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said Friday a proposal to roll back Social Security payroll taxes dramatizes ``the inequity and regressive nature'' of the tax system, but he declined to endorse it. Mitchell said he was concerned about the impact that Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan's proposal would have on the federal budget deficit and said he would await two staff studies on this question before making up his mind. But he criticized President Bush for immediately resisting Moynihan's proposal, saying, ``I regret the manner in which the president and the White House has treated it.'' Bush on Thursday called the proposal a ``charade'' and Vice President Dan Quayle said it was ``a political trap'' and ``a subterfuge for a general tax increase.'' ``I call on the Democrat leaders of Congress to give the American people a break and to let the House and Senate work their will by having an up-and-down vote on the capital gains tax cut,'' Bush said. Discussing issues facing lawmakers with the reconvening of the second session of the 101st Congress next week, Mitchell used the Social Security payroll tax issue to attack Bush's tax policies, particularly the president's quest for a cut in capital gains taxes. The Maine Democrat credited Moynihan, a New York Democrat, with stating ``in very stark terms the administration's tax policy, which is, `Let's cut taxes for the wealthy, but not the working people. ... Let the little people pay, cut taxes for the very wealthy.''' ``I think that is a tax policy that is unfair and wrong from a policy standpoint,'' he said, ``and Senator Moynihan has expressed it dramatically,'' he said. Moynihan, whom Mitchell labeled as ``perhaps the leading expert in Congress on Social Security,'' wants to roll back the Social Security payroll tax increase that began Jan. 1. Moynihan's proposal would save workers $7 billion in Social Security taxes this year and $55 billion in fiscal 1991. The payroll tax, paid by both employers and employees, rose to 7.65 percent Jan. 1 from 7.51 percent, and it is levied on wages up to $51,300 instead of $48,000. That means a wage-earner could pay as much as $3,924 in Social Security taxes this year, an increase of about $319 from 1989. Moynihan argues that the payroll tax should be reduced because mounting surpluses in the Social Security trust funds are being used to help offset large budget deficits instead of being put away for future retirement benefits. In a separate session with reporters, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., predicted that Moynihan's plan would ``self-destruct.'' Dole said the White House will soon offer a proposal of its own that would force the government to stop using the Social Security surpluses to reduce the budget deficit. Also Friday, a Republican member of the House, Rep. John Porter of Illinois, introduced his own proposal for preventing use of surplus Social Security taxes to reduce the federal deficit. He said that unlike Moynihan's proposal, it would protect retirees without ``playing tax-cut politics with the Social Security system.'' Porter's plan, which is being promoted by House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia, would return the surplus proportionately to workers whose taxes created it. They would not receive tax cuts or refunds, however; instead, the money would go into a kind of Individual Retirement Account and each worker's claim on future Social Security benefits would drop as the individual account builds. Over a period of 50 years or so, Porter estimated, Social Security gradually would become a private retirement system. That would prevent Congress from spending Social Security surpluses, boost national savings and give workers the potential for higher retirement benefits than are available under the present system, Porter said. The White House jumped on Moynihan's proposal and the re-emergence of Sen. Ernest F. Hollings' longtime proposal for a 5 percent value-added tax _ a national sales levy _ as evidence that Democrats plan to seek a tax increase. Hollings, D-S.C., aims to replace revenues lost by the Social Security tax cut and Bush's own proposal to lower the tax on capital gains. Mitchell said Friday he's against Hollings' tax proposal, saying ``that would add to the regressivity of the tax system.'' But at the same time, he voiced qualms about the impact that Moynihan's proposal would have on the budget deficit. ``The concern which has been expressed about it by responsible economists ... is a concern which I share,'' he said. ``I will await those studies and the opportunity to discuss the matter personally with Senator Moynihan.'' ``I must say that his suggestion ... has dramatized and focused attention on the increasing inequity and regressive nature of the American tax system,'' Mitchell said. He said it demostratees that taxes on the wealthiest people ``have been systematically and dramatically reduced'' in the past decade while taxes for the middle-class ``have actually risen in the aggregate.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Speak to Abortion Phones Via Telephone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 2nd graf pvs `Bush will ...' to UPDATE with presidential proclamation designating Sunday as National Sanctity of Human Life Day. Picks up 3rd graf pvs `Nationwide activism ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Republicans-Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will address a rally of abortion foes via telephone Monday, the 17th anniversary of the Supreme Court legalization of abortion, his press secretary said Friday. Bush will use the same method he did in addressing the Washington rally last year, speaking over a loudspeaker by telephone, Marlin Fitzwater said before leaving with the president on a trip to Atlanta. On Friday, Bush issued a proclamation designating Sunday as ``National Sanctity of Human Life Day.'' ``The prevalence of abortion in America today is a tragedy not only in terms of human lives lost, but also in terms of the values we hold dear as a nation,'' Bush said. ``We ask all levels of government and all sectors of society to promote policies to encourage alternatives such as adoption, and to extend policies that make adopting easier for families who want children and can provide a loving, supportive home for them, particularly for children with special needs.'' Nationwide activism for abortion rights has escalated. Bush has said in recent remarks on the subject that there is room in the Republican Party for pro-choice supporters as well as abortion foes, even though he still opposes abortion except in the cases of rape, incest or threat to the mother's life. That posture has become the GOP answer to growing sentiment, even among its own ranks, against further restrictions on abortion. The Supreme Court last year gave states greater discretion in restricting abortion, touching off a wave of activism by the pro-choice supporters to protect abortion rights. Fitzwater said he didn't know whether Bush would make a point of using the inclusion language when he addresses the annual ``March for Life'' rally, which will be held on the Ellipse behind the White House. Leaders of the anti-abortion movement will meet with Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu, and other administration officials, but there are no plans for the president to see them, Fitzwater said. Bush told tens of thousands of demonstrators last year that abortion on demand is an ``American tragedy.'' He said the landmark Roe vs. Wade decision ``was wrong and should be overturned.'' While abortion foes march down Pennsylvania Avenue and hold their rally, pro-choice groups also will hold activities commemorating the anniversary.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Times Publishes Extra After Mayor's Arrest
With AM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: If only for a day, the nation's capital had an afternoon newspaper Friday. ``BUSTED'' blared the 2{-inch headline above the lead stories in a special edition of The Washington Times that chronicled the arrest of District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry on drug charges. Most of the 24-page edition was devoted to Barry's arrest at a downtown hotel Thursday night by federal agents and city police officers. Not since The Washington Star folded in 1981 had residents of the Washington area seen a local, afternoon newspaper. The ``EXTRA!'' was sold by hawkers outside the rival Washington Post; the District Building, Washington's city hall; the Vista International Hotel, where Barry was arrested, and at downtown subway stations, said Linda Clark, a spokeswoman for the Times, a morning paper published Monday through Friday. The lead stories outlined how Barry was apprehended as part of an FBI sting operation, contained information concerning Barry's arraignment at midday on misdemeanor cocaine-possession charges and had comments from a news conference held by U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens. The special edition also contained comments from elementary school students and other residents of the city along with an editorial and a column on Barry's arrest. Occupying more than one-fourth of the front page was a color photo of Barry and his wife, Effi, leaving their house from his arraignment. The newspaper called its afternoon edition ``Special Report: The Barry Crackup.''

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Orders Government to Give Noriega Documents to Defense
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with magistrate ordering government to protect evidence, turn it over to defense, details. Picks up 8th graf pvs, ```It is...'
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. magistrate ordered the government Friday not to destroy any documents confiscated from Manuel Noriega's homes or offices during the Panama invasion and told prosecutors to turn over an inventory of the evidence to the defense. In an earlier hearing Friday, a federal judge refused to order government investigators away from defense witnesses in the case of a Noriega co-defendant, but cautioned both sides to avoid intimidation. The magistrate's ruling came after an emergency motion by Noriega defense attorney Steven Kollin, who said Assistant U.S. Attorney Myles Malman had traveled to Panama City to inspect material seized by U.S. troops. The U.S. Attorney's office did not object to the order, but warned it was uncertain how long a full inventory would take. Kollin told U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff that Noriega's case was peculiar in the annals of criminal justice. ``This case is so different. ... It's utterly different,'' Kollin said. ``When in the past has an invasion occurred and everything in the country was taken?'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan called the defense request unrealistic, saying it was almost impossible to determine which of the documents would affect Noriega's case directly. But Kollin responded that the defense wanted everything. ``When you're a general in an army, everything is under your dominion and control,'' he said. The magistrate ordered the protection and inventory of the documents, but cautioned that the defense must give more specific information on the addresses of Noriega's home in Panama City and Rio Hato and disclose which offices he occupied in the Panama defense Forces headquarters and Fort Amador. At the request of the defense, the magistrate excused Noriega from attending the session. After the hearing, Sullivan refused to comment on Malman's reported visit to Panama City. The magistrate said the inventory of documents from the house must be available by Thursday, the day before Noriega's bond hearing, because the defense contended some evidence from the homes may bear on that hearing. Earlier in U.S. District Court, Judge William Hoeveler refused to order government investigators away from defense witnesses in the case of Noriega co-defendant Luis del Cid, alleged to be one of the former dictator's right-hand men. An attorney for del Cid complained to the court that investigators from the Immigration and Naturalization Service visited the defendant's wife and two friends soon after the three testified at a bond hearing Tuesday. ``These witnesses declined to go back to court today _ they are terrified,'' said attorney Samuel Burstyn. ``They are worried about their immigration status.'' Del Cid's wife is Panamanian and the other two women are Nicaraguan refugees. According to Burstyn, the agents demanded that the women turn over all their immigration papers and give information about how they entered the United States. Hoeveler noted that the women _ Tilsa del Cid and Norma and Eglantina Alvarez _ had offered to take custody of del Cid if he is freed on bond. ``It is important for me to get the full picture of what their status is,'' Hoeveler said. But he added: ``No investigator for either side can intimidate witnesses.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan was unapologetic about the visit to the three women, saying it was part of a wider investigation. But he denied an allegation by Burstyn that the INS agents accused the women of involvement in money-laundering to frighten them into silence. ``The INS did have an ongoing investigation about alien smuggling which touched on del Cid,'' the prosecutor said. ``We were seeking information about this family.'' And even if no such investigation existed, Sullivan said, ``The government has an absolute right to question witnesses.'' The acting director of the local Immigration and Naturalization Services, Richard Smith, said he could not comment on the case without authorization from Washington. After the hearing, Burstyn said he was satisfied with the judge's action. Del Cid, a lieutenant colonel in the Panamanian Defense Force at the time of his arrest just after the U.S. invasion of Panama, faces a maximum 70 years imprisonment and $550,000 in fines if convicted of being a liaison and courier between Noriega and drug traffickers. At the bond hearing, Burstyn read a statement from Noriega denying del Cid headed Panama's intelligence agency or was a close aide, as the government had charged. Prosecutors later acknowledged he did not head the ``G-2'' intelligence division. But they responded with a photo that showed Noriega and del Cid with Cuban leader Fidel Castro at a 1984 meeting. The government said that meeting was to smooth out problems between Noriega and the Medellin drug cartel following a raid on facilities in Panama they were paying Noriega to protect.

DOC.HEAD: `Old Friend' Of Mayor Barry Sentenced in Cocaine Case
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS cycle designator to AMs and INSERTS new penultimate graf saying that sentence includes time already served
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A convicted drug dealer who testified under oath that he supplied Mayor Marion Barry with crack cocaine was sentenced to 15 months in prison Friday after prosecutors praised his cooperation. Charles Lewis, 49, who Barry has described as ``an old friend,'' told U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin ``drugs have ruined my life'' and said he was the perfect example of ``how one can be bought by drugs.'' The investigation of Lewis, who pleaded guilty to two cocaine conspiracy charges in November, touched off a political firestorm for the mayor. Coincidentally, Barry appeared in the same courthouse an hour earlier to face a magistrate on a misdemeanor charge of possessing drugs. Barry was arrested Thursday in a downtown hotel by the FBI, which charged that he possessed an unspecified quantity of crack cocaine. Lewis has twice testified before the grand jury probing possible drug activities by the mayor. During a plea bargain session in December, Lewis testified that he had supplied the mayor with crack cocaine and that an unnamed city official had given Lewis money with which to buy drugs for the mayor. Sporkin said he had come to court prepared to sentence Lewis to 18 months in prison _ halfway in the 15-21 month range of sentences in federal guidelines. ``But the government has impressed me with the extent of your cooperation,'' Sporkin said. ``You are getting the best break I know.'' The judge also said the 15-month sentence would include time already served, meaning Lewis would be released in May. Lewis had originally faced 16 perjury, conspiracy and cocaine possession charges. In exchange for prosecutors dropping all but two of those counts, Lewis agreed to cooperate fully with the government's continuing investigation of his ties to Barry.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Won't Sign Clean Air Bill If It Too Costly
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called on Congress to approve clean air legislation Friday, but cautioned he will veto any bill that is substantially more expensive than the proposal he sent to Capitol Hill last summer. ``I will only sign legislation that balances environmental and economic progress,'' said the president in a letter to Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the Senate minority leader. Bush, noting that the Senate is planning next week to begin floor action on a tough air pollution control bill, said the proposal is twice as costly as the administration proposal and the one under consideration in the House. The cost to industry of toughening the nation's air pollution controls is expected to be a major subject of debate as the legislation moves forward in Congress in the coming months. Senate Democrats have said in recent days that their bill is not substantially higher in cost from the Bush proposal, but the president in his letter to Dole said administration estimates put its price tag at more than $40 billion a year, compared to $19 billion for the administration proposal. At the same time, maintained the president, the Senate bill ``provides little incremental environmental benefit'' over House and administration versions. Environmentalists have maintained the Senate bill is much stronger and should be enacted. The president's letter was made public by Dole several hours after Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called for quick Senate action on clean air legislation, calling it ``a high priority for me and for the president.'' Mitchell made no reference to Bush's letter. He said he anticipated ``a vigorous'' floor debate on the legislation over the next few weeks. Mitchell said that if clean air legislation is not enacted this year the country's leadership in environmental issues will be ``called into question'' worldwide. Clean air bills in both the Senate and House call for a 10 million ton reduction in acid rain pollutants, tighter auto emission standards, and a requirement that a broad range of industrial plants and businesses install ``best available technology'' to capture toxic chemical releases. The Senate bill, passed by the Environment and Public Works Committee last November, however, includes several ``second stage'' provisions that the administration and most of industry oppose as being too costly. One provision would require automakers to meet a second round of emission curbs beginning in the year 2003, while another would require industry to comply with a health-based standard on toxic chemical releases not related to what emission control equipment might be available. Supporters of the legislation have argued that the tougher bill would not be sustantially more expensive and that industry and administration cost estimates are exaggerated. In his letter to Dole, the president outlined some provisions a bill must have for him to sign it into law. These include that it contain no national electricity tax to help pay for acid rain curbs at the dirtiest electric utilities; that a bill achieve overall pollution reduction levels he outlined in his proposal, and that the controls not exceed his administration bill cost estimates by more than 10 percent. In a related development, the American Lung Association said Friday that the tougher Senate clean air bill with its stronger auto emissions curbs are needed to reduce air pollution to healthy levels. The group, releasing two studies on the effects of dirty air on health costs, said current health costs stemming from air pollution is estimated to be $40 billion to $50 billion a year with about half of that coming from auto emissions. ``Five years ago the high-range estimate ....was $40 billion a year. Today $40 billion has become the best estimate for mid-range of the health costs,'' said Fran DuMelle, director of government relations for the association.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Ask EPA To Block Love Canal Resettlement
DOC.TEXT: Environmental advocates asked the Environmental Protection Agency to turn Love Canal into a research center rather than permit New York state officials to permit resettlement of the old neighborhood whose name symbolized toxic chemical waste. A meeting with EPA Administrator William Reilly and other agency officials took place at the request of Lois Marie Gibbs, head of the Love Canal Neighborhood Association and executive director of the Citizen's Clearinghouse for Hazardous Wastes in Arlington, Va. The agency and the Bush administration ``would look really terrible if they agreed to resettle Love Canal,'' Gibbs said after the meeting. Gibbs and the other environmentalists object to a 1988 habitability study which some officials are using to justify plans to move people back into the neighborhood in Niagara Falls, N.Y. ``The concern that we have is that the people are going to come back, they are going to be told it's habitable with a careful point being made not to say that it's safe ... which is sort of playing with words,'' said Jacqueline Warren, an attorney with the Natural Resources Defense Council who also attended Friday's meeting. ``Love Canal's not cleaned up at all,'' Gibbs said. ``It's contained, and even that's in question.'' But Peter Slocum, a spokesman for the New York State Health Department, said the state believes the about two-thirds of the area is no more contaminated than nearby residential neighborhoods. He said the environmentalists object to resettling Love Canal ``because they don't want to lose the symbol of Love Canal and feel that somehow if people are allowed to live there again, the symbolic value of that tragic mistake will be lost.'' The canal was used by the Hooker Chemical Co. to dump tons of chemical wastes in the 1940s. In the 1950s, the canal was covered and homes and an elementary school were built on top. In the 1970s that residents began to notice foul smells in their basements and oily puddles in their yards. Eventually, the federal government declared the neighborhood a disaster area and evacuated the residents of 728 houses in a 50-block area. Lew Crampton, associate EPA administrator, said the agency would take the next three weeks to study Gibbs' proposal to establish a research and development center in the neighborhood.

DOC.HEAD: No Sign of Security Crackdown in Albania, Italian Senator Says
DOC.TEXT: An Italian senator who was in Albania for three days this week said Friday he saw no sign of a security crackdown in that hard-line Communist country. Sen. Giulio Orlando's comments contradict reports from the media in Yugoslavia, which shares a border with the closed country, that there has been widespread unrest this month in several Albanian cities. Orlando said he spent a day in the capital Tirana, a day in Shkodra, a city near Yugoslavia's border that according to a Yugoslav newspaper report on Jan. 11 was wracked with protests, and a half-day in Berati. Albania keeps its borders sealed to most foreign travelers so assessments by the few who do get in helps evaluate the internal situation in one of the last countries to follow strict Stalinist-style Communism. ``There was no sign of barricades, no (heavy presence) of soldiers, no tanks,'' the senator told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. ``There was the normal presence of soldiers. Nothing to astonish me. No sign of a state of emergency,'' he said. Albania has denounced the reports of unrest and security crackdowns as ``slanders'' that it blamed on Serbian nationalists in Yugoslavia. Orlando, a Christian Democrat who specializes in foreign affairs, said the visit was his third to Albania since 1988. ``In the southern part, the Greek part, there have been some, it seems, I won't say revolt, but requests on the part of Greek Orthodox officials for religious liberty,'' Orlando said. In an interview that appeared Friday in Rome's La Repubblica newspaper, Orlando said the Albanians in Berati were restoring ``three beautiful orthodox churches. Everything was calm there.'' In the telephone interview, the senator said it was his impression in talks with foreign ministry and other officials that the present ``leadership is continuing'' Albania's policy of political isolation. However, he said, ``there's a strong push to modernize the country technologically'' in a direction that requires a certain openness. Orlando said he urged Albanian authorities to sign the Helsinki accords on human rights and told them a meeting of Balkan nation foreign ministers set for October in Tirana would be an opportunity to discuss increasing freedom. ``For the moment, their answer was negative _ to a certain point. ... I had the impression that (becoming a signatory to Helsinki) was under consideration ... that the matter was under reflection.'' Orlando said he thought the Albanian authorities were open to the idea of establishing some kind of institution among Balkan nations to monitor rights of minorities. The senator said it appeared that Albanian authorities seemed to be realizing that the national policy of ``isolation didn't pay.'' Albanian authorities, he said, expressed resolve to work with Italy, Greece and Yugoslavia in tackling pollution problems in the Adriatic Sea.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Asks Greater Freedom in Distributing Money
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, faced with eliminating foreign aid this year to more than a dozen friendly nations, sought congressional support Friday to disregard some legal restrictions on how aid money is distributed. Baker met with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., to see whether lawmakers might permit some flexibility in the so-called ``earmarks'' Congress imposed on fiscal 1990 foreign aid money. Dole said Baker complained that the administration has a list of some 30 countries to which it wants to give a total of $1.6 billion, but has only $950 million in unearmarked money to hand out, leaving a $650 million shortfall. State Department officials have come up with a series of scenarios under which some of the earmarked money _ roughly from $150 million to $250 million _ could be pared from its mandated recipients and given instead to have-nots such as Bolivia, Jamaica, Argentina, Peru and countries in the Eastern Caribbean. ``Some of these countries, small countries, important countries, are going to be zeroed out,'' Dole told reporters. ``He asked us if there's any chance leaders in the House and Senate might go along with it.'' State Department officials have been agonizing over the allocations for this year's foreign aid for weeks. The allocations were suppose to have been decided last month, but remain up in the air because of the shortfall. Dole said Baker did not want to leave out countries that have been cooperating with the United States in various foreign policy areas. ``They feel it's going to send a very bad signal to a lot of countries if we can't scrape up some dough,'' he said. President Bush has the authority under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to rechannel up to $250 million without regard to congressional instructions to meet U.S. ``security interests,'' but the authority is seldom used other than to meet small emergencies. It has never been used to broadly rewrite the foreign aid bill's priorities. An aide to Mitchell said he had taken the matter under advisement and planned to consult with Democratic lawmakers who deal with foreign affairs issues. Baker indicated that easing the earmarks would not only soften this year's money crunch but also set the tone for consideration of the fiscal 1991 foreign aid budget, when the administration hopes to further its perennial goal of minimizing congressional directives in the bill, said a Senate source familiar with the presentation. The idea is similar to a proposal Dole advanced earlier this week for the 1991 budget, to cut foreign aid 5 percent across the board to the largest recipients to provide enough money to aid emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Rolls-Royce Guru Who Set Up Commune in Oregon Dead at 58
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to CORRECT that Opray is former Antelope mayor, minor editing. Picks up 8th, `Rajneesh also...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY17, PD2
DOC.TEXT: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the Rolls-Royce guru who turned a central Oregon town into a tumultuous commune of free love, hedonism, and murder plots before being deported, died Friday at age 58. Rajneesh, who claimed 500,000 followers worldwide, suffered heart failure, according to a spokesman at Rajneesh's commune in Poona. Disciples celebrated his spirit's release with songs and dance, then carted the body to a riverside funeral pyre where it was cremated in the traditional Hindu manner. Since December 1988, Rajneesh had used the name Osho Rajneesh, but in the United States he was known as Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh. He used the Hindu honorific of ``Bhagwan'' meaning ``god'' that Rajneesh adopted after he began lecturing on meditation in India in the 1960s. ``Osho'' is a Buddhist term that means ``on whom the heavens shower flowers.'' In 1981, Rajneesh brought his teachings of free sex and materialism to the scrubby hills near Antelope, Ore., drawing thousands of slavish disciples whose reward was the guru's daily ``drive-by'' in one of his 93 Rolls-Royces _ many painted psychedelic colors, and some decorated with peacocks and lacy curtains. To nearby residents, the commune known as Rajneeshpuram was a monstrous intrusion. ``I don't think I ever wish anybody dead, but I wished many times that he would go back where he belongs,'' said Jean Opray, the former mayor of Antelope. Rajneesh also enraged people in Poona, where he settled after being expelled from the United States in 1985 as part of a plea bargain agreement on immigration fraud charges. A militant young Hindu tried to stab Rajneesh with a long knife in Poona in 1980, but the case was dropped when Rajneesh refused to testify in court. ``Thank God he is dead. He was a living nuisance,'' said Hrushikesh Mulganokar, a retired air force chief who lives near Rajneesh's commune in Koregaon Park, a fashionable residential district of the city. ``We are extremely relieved that our problems have passed away,'' said Buchan Das, a secretary of the Koregaon Park Residents' Association. ``We had no personal antipathy towards Rajneesh. We hated what his presence did to us,'' she said, referring to the open shows of public affection by commune couples. With his long gray beard and hypnotic brown eyes, Rajneesh peddled enlightenment and preached that sex is fun, materialism is good, and Jesus was a madman.
