He claimed to be the world's greatest lover. Rajneesh's mission was to create a new man, ``Zorba the Buddha,'' who would be a synthesis of Eastern mysticism and Western pop culture. ``Explode! Go totally mad ... Jump up and down shouting the mantra `Hoo! Hoo! Hoo! ... Each time you land, on the flats of your feet, let the sound hammer deep into the sex center,'' Rajneesh said in ``The Orange Book,'' his cult's bible. In 1984, he changed his views on free sex and told his disciples to become celebate or stay with one sexual partner. He proclaimed that AIDS would kill two-thirds of the world's population. ``He was both a charlatan and a very evil person,'' said Vic Atiyeh, who was Oregon's governor during the years the guru was there. ``Evil in the sense of the kind of people he gathered around him and what he allowed them to do, and his own personal arrogance. He was above everything.'' U.S. Attorney Charles Turner, who prosecuted Rajneesh on immigration fraud charges, said: ``The legacy of crime that this man left here is unparalleled in American jurisprudence.'' Rajneesh, the eldest of a cloth merchant's 13 children, established his first commune in Poona in 1974. In 1981, he flew to the United States where he was to undergo back surgery. The operation was never performed, and later that year Rajneesh bought the Big Muddy Ranch about 120 miles east of Portland. The commune covered 64,000 acres and was home to 4,000 red-clad followers who toiled 12-hour days to feed Rajneesh's dream of a model community and his penchant for expensive cars and jewels. The crowd swelled to 15,000 during summer festivals. Rajneeshpuram was incorporated as a city on part of the commune in 1982. Disciples also moved into Antelope, a town of 40 people, eventually holding all its elected offices and changing its name to City of Rajneesh. The name was changed back to Antelope in 1985 at Rajneesh's suggestion, as a way to make peace with the angry Oregonians. Rajneesh allowed his gun-wielding personal secretary, Ma Anand Sheela, to wield dictatorial control over the commune, but Sheela and several of her top aides fled Rajneeshpuram suddenly in 1985, accusing Rajneesh of caring more about his wealth than his disciples. Rajneesh responded with allegations that led to a federal investigation and charges the commune had planned to take over the county. He and Sheela were arrested in 1985, Rajneesh as he allegedly tried to flee to Bermuda. He pleaded guilty to two counts of immigration fraud, stemming from charges he arranged sham marriages to keep his foreign disciples in the United States illegally. As part of a plea bargain, Rajneesh was deported from the United States. Several countries refused to let him enter, and he eventually returned to India in November 1985, denouncing the United States as a ``monster'' that should be ``hushed up forever.'' The Oregon commune, which included orchards, a vineyard, a 65-acre vegetable farm, two lakes stocked with fish, and an airport with a 4,500-foot paved runway, is now deserted. An insurance company foreclosed on the property but never found a buyer. Nearly all the Rolls-Royces were sold, many to a car dealer in Texas. Most were repainted. Sheela pleaded guilty to a variety of charges, including plotting to kill Rajneesh's physician with a poison-filled syringe, and orchestrating a food-poisoning outbreak that sickened more than 750 people in The Dalles, the county seat, as part of a plot to take control of the county. Several other of the guru's followers were found guilty of various crimes, including the man who served as Rajneeshpuram's mayor, David Berry Knapp, known as Swami Krishna Deva. A spokesman, Swami Chaitanya Kirti, said Rajneesh had greeted followers at his commune Wednesday but did not appear Thursday because of ``pain on the left side of his chest.'' Followers greeted his demise Friday as a liberation of the soul, and celebrations began as soon as the news of his death was conveyed. Another spokesman, Swami Prabhod, said there were about 10,000 followers, mostly Western, at the commune when Rajneesh died. Music could be heard in the background as he spoke over the telephone from Poona, about 750 miles southwest of New Delhi. His body was kept in the Buddha Hall, covered by roses, for about one hour before disciples carried it to the banks of the River Mulamuthu, a half-mile away, for cremation.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Challenge To Emission Control Standards
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Friday rejected a lawsuit contending the government's fuel economy standards for new cars endanger motorists by encouraging automakers to build less crashworthy vehicles. A three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration regulations were reasonable. The standards were challenged by the Competitive Enterprise Institute, an organization supported by foundations and industries that favor ``a non-government approach to regulatory issues,'' said Sam Kazman, the group's general counsel. Also supporting the suit was Consumer Alert, a 6,000-member group that wants ``expanded consumer choice in the marketplace,'' Kazman said. The suit charged that the government's Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards for the 1987 through 1989 model years increased the number of highway deaths as manufacturers ``downsized'' cars to reduce their weight and boost gasoline mileage. The standards required that each automaker's fleet of cars average 26 miles per gallon for vehicles sold in the 1987 and 1988 model years and 26.5 mpg for 1989. If some models fall short of the standard, others must exceed it so the overall fleet average meets the standard. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner boosted the 1990 standard to 27.5 mpg, prompting a separate Competitive Enterprise Institute suit that is still pending, Kazman said. Even tougher standards would be required under bills before Congress to renew the Clean Air Act. A Senate environmental panel last fall voted to require an average fuel economy standard of 33 mpg by 1996 and 40 mpg by 2000. Automakers are fighting the proposal, which they say would force them to discontinue all but their smallest models while consumers are demanding bigger, more powerful cars. At least six other bills to boost the fuel economy standards are pending. The suit accused the government of ignoring the threat to safety posed by fuel economy standards, but the court ruled that the agency met its legal obligation to consider the issue, Kazman said. He voiced disappointment with the ruling but said it cleared the way for action on the second suit. ``Here we have a safety agency refusing to admit that one of its major programs kills people,'' he said. ``In our view, the evidence is pretty clear that NHTSA not only ignored the safety issue, but in fact lied about it. ... Given the even more disastrous effects of the 1990 standard on auto safety, we're hopeful of a more favorable outcome in that litigation.'' Tim Hurd, spokesman for the agency, said, ``We're pleased that the court found in our favor. We're waiting for their judgment on the other half of the suit.'' He said he was referring to another challenge of the fuel economy standards on environmental grounds.

DOC.HEAD: Snowstorm Blows From Rockies Onto Plains
DOC.TEXT: Heavy snow and threats of heavy snow reached from the Rockies to the upper Great Lakes on Friday from a storm that dumped up to 3 feet of snow on the mountains of New Mexico. In the afternoon, in southeastern Texas, a tornado overturned a mobile home and downed power lines near the community of Hudson, but no injuries were reported. At midday, snow fell from western Kansas across the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles, northern and central New Mexico, Colorado, southeastern Wyoming and western Nebraska. Freezing rain reached from central and northern Missouri across eastern and southern Kansas, northwestern Oklahoma and into southwestern Nebraska. Winter storm watches were in effect into Saturday for parts of Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, and Michigan, the National Weather Service said. Snowfall in New Mexico included 36 inches at Gascon, 34 inches at Chacon, 26 inches at the Sandia ski area, 19 inches at Las Vegas, 16 inches at Angel Fire, 14 inches at Raton and Los Alamos, and 13 inches at Springer. In Colorado, new snow cover included 14 inches at Springfield, 12 inches at Durango, 11 inches south of Rye, and 10 inches at Walsenburg. The snow was welcomed in parched southern Colorado. ``It's a beautiful snow,'' Baca County sheriff's spokeswoman Nettie Blount said. ``It's the first major snow we've had all winter. It's really going to be good for the farmers.'' But there were numerous accident across the state on slippery roads, and in Denver the storm caused delays of at least an hour at Stapleton International Airport. Several schools in the Denver area either closed Friday or sent students home early, and the city ordered a staggered release of employees to ease afternoon commuter traffic. The Colorado State Patrol closed U.S. 287 from Springfield in southern Colorado to Oklahoma due to blowing snow and poor visibility. Snowfall across the Texas Panhandle ranged from 6 to 9 inches, including 9 inches at Dalhart, 8 inches at Borger, Lefors and Vega, and near 8 inches at Amarillo. Snow drifts of 3 to 4 feet were common in the Panhandle and the state highway department ``strongly discouraged'' travel in the area Friday, closing U.S. 287 north of Dumas. U.S. 87 northwest of Dalhart also was closed. Schools were closed Friday in most of the northern Panhandle. In the Panhandle, cars had to wait for roads to be opened, said Kenneth Dillard, foreman for the Texas Highway Department in Dalhart. ``There was buses and vans and cars, with skis on all of them,'' he said. ``There was some happy faces when we let them by.'' In Kansas, new snow cover included 11 inches at Hugoton, 6 to 11 inches across the southwest portion of the state, 10 inches near Syracuse, and about 9 inches at Cimarron and Garden City as well as from Dodge City to Liberal. In addition to the snow, showers and thunderstorms extended from northern and eastern Texas across the northwestern two-thirds of Louisiana, Arkansas, the southeast two-thirds of Oklahoma, southern Missouri, Tennessee, southern Illinois and Kentucky. Wind gusts from morning thunderstorms in Texas tore a roof off a restaurant and damaged buildings and houses in three Dallas-area suburbs. No one was injured. In Maine, wind gusted to 67 mph at Augusta, 47 mph at Greenville and 43 mph at Limestone. The heaviest rainfall during the 6 hours up to noon was 1.57 inches at Tulsa, Okla. 1.36 inches at Ponca City, Okla., 1.26 inches at Fayetteville, Ark., and 1.07 inches at Joplin, Mo. The heaviest snowfall during the 6 hours up to noon was 10 inches at Pueblo, Colo. Macon, Ga., warmed to a record high of 79. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 17 below zero at West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 9 at both Caribou and Limestone, Maine, to 89 at McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Deny Entrapment
With AM-Barry, Bjt,
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors dismissed suggestions Friday that Mayor Marion Barry was the victim of entrapment when he was videotaped by FBI agents buying and smoking crack cocaine. But legal experts and federal law enforcement officials say Barry may have no choice, in the face of overwhelming evidence he used drugs, to claim the government improperly lured him to a hotel room where bought and smoked crack. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said that the ``carefully planned, carefully reviewed and carefully executed'' undercover operation was ``scrupulously fair to the defendant, Mr. Barry.'' ``There was no entrapment there,'' Stephens told reporters on the steps of the U.S. Courthouse after Barry appeared before a federal magistrate on a misdemeanor charge of possessing crack cocaine. Prosecutors examined evidence gathered in the year-long investigation of allegations that Barry used drugs and decided an undercover operation would comply with the law, Stephens said. While not commenting specifically on the evidence against Barry, Stephens indicated that his office had gathered evidence that the mayor was predisposed toward drug use. ``Where there is predisposition there is no entrapment,'' the city's chief prosecutor said, citing the Supreme Court's test on the issue. The entrapment defense _ that law enforcement authorities led a defendant to commit a crime he otherwise wouldn't have committed _ must be raised by the accused at trial. The high court has ruled that a defendant is the victim of entrapment if not predisposed to commit the crime that undercover police induced him to commit. Stephens cited evidence that Barry went to the Vista Hotel ``on his own volition.'' ``He went to the seventh floor on his own free will. He put himself in that situation,'' the prosecutor said. As further indication of the government's confidence in the case, Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said Attorney General Dick Thornburgh followed the progress of the undercover investigation up through Barry's arrest Thursday evening at a downtown hotel. As a defense, entrapment is difficult to raise but it has been successful, notably in automaker John Z. DeLorean's 1984 acquittal of federal drug conspiracy charges. De Lorean's lawyers were able to persuade jurors the automaker was entrapped by federal agents despite videotapes showing the defendant standing next to open suitcase filled with cocaine and saying: ``It's good as gold.'' But given the strength of the government's evidence, Barry's defense ``would have to be entrapment'' even though it ``will be impossible to sell to a jury,'' said Peter Tague, a law professor at Georgetown University. An entrapment defense would open the door for government prosecutors to present evidence of his predisposition to use illegal drugs, Tague said. Tague said prosecutors would be free to present testimony by convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis that he sold cocaine to the mayor and used it with him at a downtown hotel in 1988. Even though Barry was never charged as a result of that incident, prosecutors could use Lewis' statements as evidence the mayor was predisposed to using illegal drugs, Tague said. Stephens' statements indicated that prosecutors were ready for such a defense with evidence aplenty of the mayor's ``predisposition'' toward illegal drug use. Before launching the undercover sting, ``we reviewed all the evidence we developed to date,'' Stephens said. But if Barry can evoke enough sympathy among jurors, he could persuade them he was the victim of government zeal to catch him, experts said. ``The jury can always say this guy was not willing to commit a crime and the government went way too far in importuning him,'' Tague said. Unlike De Lorean, Barry would be accountable to more than just 12 jurors _ he must answer to voters of the nation's capital, where he had been expected to announce plans to run for a fourth term.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Security Officer Comes in from the Cold
DOC.TEXT: An intelligence major in the State Security Service said Friday he let the political opposition know the SSS was spying on it in the campaigning leading to Hungary's first free elections. Maj. Jozsef Vegvari told a news conference he was making his revelations in Hungary's ``Danubegate Scandal'' because of a heavy conscience. He said that besides feeding information to the opposition, he arranged it so a video crew could film intelligence documents that were headed for the shredder, despite a ban on their disposal from the chief prosecutor's office. The office has ordered an investigation into political espionage. Vegvari said the SSS was acting on instructions of the ruling Socialist Party. The party last year changed its name from the Hungarian Socialists Workers' Party in an attempt by the former Communists to maintain their grip on power in the face of the reformist tide sweeping the East bloc. The newly emerging opposition groups, still weak and divided, contend that the information obtained by the government's SSS on their tactics and candidates could give the Socialists a decisive advantage in the March 25 elections. Draft legislation is expected next month in Parliament to curtail security service operations. The latest allegations drew the response, ``Old habits die hard,'' from Premier Miklos Nemeth. In an interview to be published in Saturday's edition of the daily Magyar Hirlap, Nemeth said he regretted not ordering a total overhaul of the Interior Ministry, which oversees the SSS, last year. Brig. Gen. Jozsef Horvath, head of the SSS's Internal Security Service, resigned on Wednesday. Nemeth said ``the remnants of the party-state need to be swept away urgently,'' and promised that ``the internal security department will be liquidated.'' The Interior Ministry issued a statement confirming Vegvari's status and said it initiated criminal proceedings against him for revealing state secrets. The ministry rejected all charges of wrongdoing and said Vegvari was part of an opposition political campaign aimed at undermining the state apparatus. Vegvari told reporters he had a crisis of conscience during funeral services in June 1989 for a rehabilitated Imre Nagy, the reformist premier who was executed in 1958 following the 1956 Hungarian uprising against the nation's Stalinist regime. Soviet troops and tanks crushed that revolution. He said ``events in Romania were the last straw,'' referring to the shooting of demonstrators by Romania's secret police during the December revolution. ``Black Box,''an independent video newsreel group, filmed Vegvari's account of the surveillance on opposition groups, as well as dozens of burnbags in the halls of an Interior Ministry building, which allegedly contained compromising documents. ``The materials included reports on surveillance of opposition political organizations, personalities, religious groups, youth organizations, writers, artists and `irredentists,' '' Vegvari said, referring to activists involved with Hungarian minorities in Romania, Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union. ``I am not a traitor to my country, but I do wish to expose the illegal activities of this organization,'' Vegvari said, adding that the ``KGB is active in Hungary for sure.'' From a notebook, he read to the news conference a list of people who were watched, mentioning opposition figures, a member of Parliament, writers, religious figures and human rights activists.

DOC.HEAD: At Barry's City Hall, a Quest for Normalcy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with descriptions of meetings in top 9 grafs; two grafs transition; picks up 7th graf: ``Top political,'' CORRECTS spelling Gildenhorn in 10th graf: ``Campaign finance,'' and subsequently
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, preparing to fight a drug charge, broke down in tears as he turned over some of his powers to an aide after stormy meetings in City Hall on Friday. As the mayor was making up his mind on what to do about his job, other officials were trying to calm nerves of agitated city employees. Three members of the mayor's cabinet who sought to minimize the mayor's problems were ``shouted down'' by others in a cabinet meeting who said they ``too long had been part of a conspiracy of silence,'' said one cabinet member who spoke on condition that he not be identified. Other officials said some members threatened to resign if Barry tried to carry on as usual. The cabinet has about 50 members, and nearly all were present. After first saying he would ``go about the business of government'' despite the cocaine-possession charge, Barry turned the daily routine of the D.C. government over to the city administrator, Carol Thompson, announcing his action in a tearful five-minute speech, said a cabinet member speaking on condition of anonymity. Barry retains power to veto legislation and sign contracts, which he cannot delegate. A statement from the mayor's office said he based his decision to step aside for Thompson ``on the need for time to handle his legal affairs, his concern for his family, and because it is in the best interests of the citizens of Washington, D.C.'' Earlier, in a meeting of political advisers, long-time Barry aide Herbert O. Reid Sr., now the city's chief attorney, argued vehemently against Barry's yielding of any power, and also against entering a drug treatment program, while others urged the mayor to seek treatment. A source familiar with decisions taken at the advisers' meeting said a decision on entering a drug treatment program was held in abeyance pending further discussions over the weekend. Campaign finance co-chairman Jeffrey Gildenhorn likened the situation to the Richard Nixon White House during the depths of Watergate, and officials said they were scrambling to ``calm a lot of nerves.'' ``It is very important that we retain some sense of normalcy,'' said city council member Betty Ann Kane after a closed meeting to discuss the crisis. ``It was very somber in there, (with) people still in a state of shock. Everyone is concerned about being able to reassure people that the city is not going to fall apart.'' Top political supporters of the mayor, who postponed plans to declare his candidacy Sunday for a fourth term, were clearly stunned by his arrest Thursday night. U.S. Magistrate Deborah Robinson allowed Barry to remain free but ordered him to submit to weekly drug tests and set another hearing for Feb. 5. Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, said the mayor would plead innocent to the charge of possession of cocaine and would demand a jury trial. While the council members were meeting, members of Barry's staff held a series of small meetings which one aide said were ``really to calm a lot of nerves.'' ``There was no undercurrent of something about the mayor being maligned or run down,'' said the staff member, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used. ``We were told to relax, go about our work, and keep a stiff upper lip.'' Council member John Ray said city employees he had seen ``had expressions of concern, shock and dismay on their faces.'' ``I think that's only natural,'' said Ray, who is one of four candidates competing against Barry for the Democratic mayoral nomination. Former Police Chief Maurice Turner, an unofficial candidate for the Republican mayoral nomination, said ``the eyes of the nation and the world'' were focused on the district. ``Our city will overcome this incident, and my prayers are that the mayor and his family will overcome this incident,'' he said. Even some of the mayor's biggest supporters were taking a wait-and-see approach to his latest woes. ``Whatever he does I think should be governed by his desire to help the city,'' said council member Wilhelmina Rolark, a longtime Barry backer. When asked whether she thought the mayor should resign, Rolark paused for a moment and said, ``His compassion for the city ... should govern his actions. We don't know what the circumstances are yet, but if the charges are true, well. ...'' her voice trailing off. At Barry's reelection headquarters, Gildenhorn said the arrest reminded him of ``the Watergate situation. I feel at this point a similar despair.'' Gildenhorn's co-chairman, Stuart Long, said the mayor had not decided whether he would run for reelection. However, Reid discounted the possiblity that the mayor would step down. ``He'll be able to run the city alright,'' Reid said.

DOC.HEAD: Slain Miner's Funeral Attended by Hundreds
DOC.TEXT: More than 700 United Mine Workers members garbed in camouflage green to symbolize union solidarity attended a funeral Friday for a coal miner shot on a picket line. The miners, who came from five states, packed a funeral home chapel to pay their respects to John McCoy, 42, a union miner from Premier who was shot Tuesday morning. ``What meaning is there in the death of a young husband and father?'' the Rev. Ted Osgood said. McCoy had a son, 10, and a daughter, 9. At least 25 bouquets surrounded McCoy's gold casket, which was topped with another floral spread and a folded American flag. A yellow bed of flowers with UMWA spelled out in red stood next to the casket. Many of the mourners, who arrived from Kentucky, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia, wore camouflage green, which became a symbol of union militancy and solidarity during last year's 9-month strike against Pittston Coal Group in three states. McCoy's death came during a union dispute with Regency Industries Inc. and a handful of other companies that work in southern West Virginia. McCoy was employed by a subsidiary for A.T. Massey Coal., the target of a bitter UMW strike in 1984 and 1985. The union sent pickets to southern West Virginia to protest what it said was a back-pay issue. Mine workers claimed Regency owed them $357,000 in wages and benefits. McCoy and two other miners were shot as they approached a picket site, and the assailants are still unknown, state police said. McCoy was hit twice, in the chest and neck. The other two victims were still in the hospital Friday, union officials said. McCoy's body was taken to a remote cemetery seven miles outside of Welch for a formal UMW burial. Fellow members placed sprigs of evergreen on the casket. ``In the union, we've always had the motto, `An injury to one is an injury to all,''' said John Banovic, the union's international secretary. ``There is no greater injury than death.'' The last picket-related fatality in the Appalachian coal fields came during the Massey dispute when a non-union truck driver was killed in eastern Kentucky in May 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria's Zhivkov Accused as Wartime Nazi Agent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Romania to Bulgaria in overline and in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's leaders on Friday faced a wave of labor unrest as the ruling Communists headed toward an extraordinary party congress likely to approve introduction of multiparty democracy and other major reforms. The state news agency BTA said Friday more than 100 labor conflicts were registered by newly formed, independent trade unions from Dec. 25 to Jan. 10. The labor unrest surged into the open after Bulgaria's iron-fisted Communist leader, Todor Zhivkov, was deposed on Nov. 10 in the reforms that swept Eastern Europe. The Jan. 30 party congress will be the first since his ouster. Zhivkov, who has aready been charged with malfeasance in office, abuse of power and other crimes, was accused in a newspaper article Friday of having been a Nazi intelligence agent in wartime Bulgaria. The allegations came in an article in the newspaper Otechestven Front, which said Zhivov worked out of a Sofia villa in 1941. No further details were available on Zhivkov's purported intelligence role. Bulgarian King Boris III sided with Adolf Hitler's Nazi Germany in 1941, and Bulgarian troops occupied parts of Yugoslavia and Greece. Zhivkov himself had leveled charges of Nazi collaboration against the family of his chief critic, reformist Chudomir Alexandrov, when he kicked Alexandrov off the Politburo in 1988. BTA reported Friday that the main strike demands included disclosure of company financial and technical status, a cutback in bureaucracy, dismissal of discredited managers, better supply of raw materials and equipment, and improved working conditions and safety. The Communists have conceded it will take years to overcome the nation's deep economic crisis. In a separate draft declaration to be presented at the party congress this month, the party calls for a market-oriented economy. It says the party favors ``development of a whole variety of forms of social ownership,'' but does not spell out private enterprise. Documents asserting party willingness to adopt far-reaching reforms were seen as an attempt by the Communists, now under pressure from opposition groups and radical changes elsewhere in the bloc, to cling to power. The party congress is set to adopt a statute that drops the Marxist-Leninist label and the principle of ``democratic centralism'' in favor of political pluralism. This week the Communist-dominated Parliament abolished the party's guaranteed monopoly on political power, thus officially ending more than four decades of authoritarian, one-party rule. Talks with the opposition on power-sharing and democratization were suspended Thursday because of the Communist leadership's apparent unwillingness to provide the opposition with a voice in the nation's radio and television. The Union of Democratic Forces, the umbrella organization of all major opposition groups, reaffirmed its right to criticize the Communists in a statement read by spokesman Ruben Vodenicharov on state TV Friday night. ``The exercise of power by a single party means that this one party must be taken to account,'' Vodenicharov said. A draft declaration to be advanced at the party congress, carried by BTA, said, ``The Bulgarian Communist Party must be de-Stalinized and established as a new type of contemporary Marxist party.'' It stresses the need for a radical restructuring of party governing bodies _ the ruling Politburo and the policy-setting Central Committee. ``The political system of democratic socialism implies a multiparty system, parliamentary democracy ... separation of legislative, executive and judiciary powers ... guaranteed freedoms, (and) autonomy of science and education,'' it said. The draft proposes that all party officers be elected by secret ballot and serve only two terms, but did not specify their duration. It calls for a Supreme Party Council to replace the Central Committee; a Central Control and Auditing Commission, and a Central Commission on Party Ethics. It also sets out a format for a chairmanship that would be the apparent successor to the Politburo. According to the declaration text quoted by BTA, the Communist Party is willing to recognize religious and some ethnic rights of the minority Turks and other Bulgarian Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Work Under Way on Arrangements for U.N. Chief to Visit Albania
DOC.TEXT: U.N. and Albanian officials are working on arrangements for Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to visit the isolated East European country, a spokeswoman for the U.N. chief said Friday. It would be the first visit by a U.N. secretary-general to Albania, the last bastion of Stalinism in Eastern Europe. Albanian Foreign Minister Reis Malile invited Perez de Cuellar to travel to his country when he visited the U.N. General Assembly last October. Nadia Younes, spokeswoman for Perez de Cuellar, said no date has been set for the secretary-general to visit Albania, but she added, ``It is only a matter of scheduling.'' Albania's invitation to the secretary-general stems from a ``higher estimation'' of the world body's activities and ``the more influential role the United Nations is assuming in the world community,'' said Sazan Bejo, press secretary at the Albanian Mission to the United Nations. Bejo said he had no information on dates being discussed for a visit but U.N. officials say the U.N. chief is expected to be in Eastern Europe in May for visits to Czechoslovakia and Hungary. A visit to Albania, a nation accused of serious human rights abuses, would make Perez de Cuellar one of the most senior international officials to visit the hard-line Communist state in recent years. Albania, lying between Greece and Yugoslavia on the Adriatic Sea, is one of the most isolated countries in the world. Albanian authorities strictly limit foreign visitors and tightly control access to foreign broadcasts and books. Despite the restrictions, there have been indications of moves toward opening to the outside world since the death in 1985 of Albanian hard-line leader Enver Hoxha. Hoxha broke relations with the Soviet Union in 1961 because of Nikita Krushchev's dismantling of Stalinism.

DOC.HEAD: President's Limo Gives Out
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, on a two-state trip in the South, was forced to switch limousines because of mechanical problems Friday and then switched planes for convenience. Bush was riding into downtown Atlanta to deliver a speech when smoke began pouring from the hood of his armored Cadillac limousine as a result of an oil pressure problem. His motorcade pulled off to the side of Interstate 75 while Bush transferred to a backup car that always is part of his entourage. Within minutes, he was on his way again. The disabled limousine was left at the side of the road with a police guard, police spokesman Michael Powell said. Later, Bush flew to Miami for another speech-making appearance. On the flight from Washington to Atlanta and Miami, Bush rode on the large Boeing 707 that traditionally is regarded as Air Force One. However, for the flight back, Bush chose a 12-seat Air Force C-20, the military equivalent of a Gulfstream jet. White House officials said Bush chose the smaller plane to shave about 25 minutes in the flight time to Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. By using the smaller plane, Bush was able to land at the Washington County Regional Airport at Hagerstown, Md., and then catch a helicopter for a 10-minute hop to Camp David. If he had flown the larger 707, Bush would have had to land at Andrews Air Force Base outside of Washington, and then take a 30-to 35-minute helicopter flight to Camp David, officials said. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the use of two planes would not increase the cost of Bush's travel, since the smaller plane always accompanies him as a backup aircraft. However, Bush's plane switch drew protests from the White House press corps because he excluded reporters on the return flight. Traditionally, a press pool of at least 11 people accompanies the president on all travels. In this instance, however, the White House refused to let any reporters accompany the president on the grounds there was not enough space.

DOC.HEAD: RJR Cancels Test Marketing In Philadelphia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Sullivan said...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with reax from Sullivan, American Cancer Society. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `The Rev....'
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) _ R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. announced Friday it will cancel its Philadelphia test marketing of a cigarette aimed at blacks, saying the company's efforts have been misrepresented by smoking opponents. The move came a day after the country's top health official blasted Reynolds' ``slick and sinister'' cigarette ad campaign, and said tobacco companies were putting profits above the health of the poor and minorities. Peter Hoult, RJR executive vice president of marketing, said, ``We regret that a small coalition of anti-smoking zealots apparently believes that black smokers are somehow different from others who choose to smoke and must not be allowed to exercise the same freedom of choice available to all other smokers. ``This represents a loss of choice for black smokers and a further erosion of the free-enterprise system,'' he said. ``Our sole purpose, plainly and simply, was to test market a cigarette among smokers who currently buy competitive products.'' Uptown, a new menthol brand of cigarette, had been scheduled for test marketing beginning Feb. 5 in Philadelphia. The company had said the ads would target blacks, who, as a group, prefer menthol cigarettes. R.J. Reynolds also said Philadelphia was chosen because its population is 40 percent black. In a speech in Philadelphia on Thursday, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan accused R.J. Reynolds of trying to create a ``culture of cancer'' with Uptown. ``We must resist the unworthy efforts of the tobacco merchants to earn profits at the expense of the health and well-being of our poor and minority citizens,'' he said. ``This trade-off between profits and good health must stop.'' Sullivan said Friday he was ``elated'' by R.J. Reynold's decision. ``This is a victory for the citizens of Philadelphia, for miniority citizens and indeed for all Americans _ a victory for health,'' he said. In Philadelphia, leaders of about 30 organizations that had banded together to fight Uptown expressed joy that the company decided to heed their opposition. ``Fantastic! Super! Wow!'' responded Dr. Carl Mansfield, president of the Philadelphia division of the American Cancer Society. ``That's a really responsible act by R.J. Reynolds, and I commend them on it,'' Mansfield said. ``We didn't know if it (the opposition) would work, but we thought we should try to get them to look at the social and ethical consequences'' of their marketing plan. The Rev. Jesse Brown, president of the Committee to Prevent Cancer Among Blacks, called the decision ``magnificent.'' ``We are glad that R.J. Reynolds decided to hear us,'' he said. ``We don't want this cigarette to be marketed in any city. This sends a signal to R.J. Reynolds that community groups can rise up and deal with them.'' He said that Sullivan's public condemnation of the marketing plan was ``the icing on the cake'' to the local opposition. ``But I think it was really the grass-roots coalition coming together and taking the initiative'' that caused R.J. Reynolds to shelve its marketing plan. Black men have a 58 percent higher incidence of lung cancer than white men, and blacks lose twice as many years of life as do whites because of smoking-related diseases, according to the U.S. Public Health Service. The company's promotional blitz included attempts to associate use of Uptown with glamour and high fashion. One ad featured people enjoying urban night life underlined with the slogan: ``Uptown. The place. The taste.'' ``We have made no plans for the product at this point in time,'' said company spokesman David Fishel. ``We'll just have to evaluate the situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson `Stunned' by Barry Arrest But Silent on Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 7-9: ``Later, Jackson,'' with later Jackson remarks
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's arrest on a cocaine charge threw the capital city's political scene into turmoil Friday and raised new speculation concerning Jesse Jackson. Jackson, in Chicago, said he was ``stunned'' by Barry's arrest Thursday night, but brushed aside as ``inappropriate at this time'' questions about whether he would enter the Washington mayoral race. The two-time presidential candidate established residence in the nation's capital last year amid wide speculation he would enter the 1990 mayoral race, though he said he would not be a candidate if Barry _ a friend from the civil rights movement _ decided to seek an unprecedented fourth term. Barry's arrest, which followed years of rumor and investigations of his activities, drew reactions ranging from sadness to joking from political figures. ``It raises the Gary Hart question: How can one person be so stupid?'' said Democratic pollster Mark Mellman, referring to the former presidential candidate whose hopes died when his secret relationship with a woman other than his wife was revealed. Jackson said he had spoken by phone with Barry's wife, Effi. ``I am concerned with her capacity to maintain her strength through that crisis,'' he said. Later, Jackson was asked in an interview from Ann Arbor, Mich with Detroit television station WDIV what the arrest of Barry said to young black men in the city. ``Crisis is any public official's life sends shock waves to all children. I don't think you should just reduce it to a black-white situation,'' Jackson replied. ``Somehow people who care must reach out with some sense of mercy and some plan for helping the mayor, while at the same time providing adequate and fast services for all the people of the city,'' he said. Jackson has held a wide lead in opinion polls over all other potential and announced mayoral candidates, but in recent weeks friends have said he was moving away from a potential mayoral bid. Four other Democrats have entered the race, and Barry had scheduled an announcement of his re-election campaign for Sunday. He postponed that re-election announcement following his arrest. Barry, 53, was arraigned in federal court Friday on a misdemeanor charge of possession of crack cocaine. He was released on his own recognizance. ``I'm going to leave here and go about the business of government,'' he said leaving the courtroom. But later, he turned over day-to-day charge of the city government to city administrator Carol Thompson, retaining only the powers of signing contracts and signing or vetoing legislation that he cannot delegate. U.S. attorney Jay Stephens said Barry's arrest at a downtown hotel was ``part of the ongoing investigation of a broad range of allegations'' against Barry. Federal authorities said they had a videotape of Barry smoking crack cocaine at a downtown hotel. Barry has repeatedly denied allegations he has used drugs, including the allegations by a former friend who has been convicted on drug charges and was cooperating with authorities. Those denials were cited by members of both parties after Barry's arrest. ``He has been representing to the young people of the district that, drugs are bad, don't use them ... and now apparently all of that has been hypocrisy,'' said Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., a frequent Barry critic and who is the ranking Republican on the House Committee on the District of Columbia. Del. Walter Fauntroy, Washington's elected non-voting member of Congress, said he was in shock. ``I've asked the mayor what you have all asked him,'' Fauntroy told reporters, referring to past allegations of drug use. ``The man has been consistent. He's said no.'' Rep. Lawrence Coughlin, R-Pa., ranking Republican on the House Select Committee on Narcotics, said: ``With almost an incredible arrogance, Mayor Barry has looked the public in the eye and denied ever having had drug usage and said he was telling the truth. The example he has set ... is a horrendous one.'' Democratic National Chairman Ron Brown said: ``I am saddened by this troubling news. Mayor Barry is entitled to his day in court and I believe that a discussion of the political options for the District of Columbia should not interfere with the legal process, which must go forward.'' Sen. Brock Adams, R-Wash., chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee's panel on the District of Columbia, said he had been assured by Deputy Mayor Carol Thompson that there would be no ``interruption in the processes of government.'' Barry's arrest came after his comments in a Los Angeles Times interview had created a new round of controversy. In a lengthy story published Jan. 7, Barry was quoted as telling a reporter ``Isn't anybody in this town can beat me. I'm invincible.'' He also was quoted as saying, ``Hah, Jesse don't wanna be no mayor. Jesse don't wanna run nothing but his mouth.'' In that story, the writer described a scene with Barry in a late-night bar, in which the mayor was quoted as saying: ``Co-caaaane? How folks use that stuff, anyhow? You put it up your nooose? No! Oooooooeeeeeee!''

DOC.HEAD: Cincinnati Wiretapping Case Goes to Jury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with jury quitting deliberations for weekend; picks up 3rd graf, `The jury ...'.
DOC.TEXT: A jury began deliberating Friday on whether two former Cincinnati Bell Telephone Co. installers defamed the company and two of its managers by accusing them of engaging in illegal telephone wiretapping. The Hamilton County Common Pleas Court jury deliberated less than three hours before Judge Fred J. Cartolano sent them home for the weekend, with instructions not to discuss the case with anyone. Cartolano earlier had directed the eight jurors in the civil trial to focus on whether statements by former employees Leonard Gates and Robert Draise harmed the company, its parent Cincinnati Bell Inc. and phone company managers Peter Gabor and James West. The jury must also decide whether Gates and Draise were negligent or demonstrated malice in making the statements, as Cincinnati Bell, Gabor and West allege. ``We want your common sense,'' Cartolano told the jurors. The jury, which has been hearing the case since Nov. 20, began deliberating Friday afternoon. Since it is a civil case, only six of the eight jurors need agree on any issue for a ruling. Cartolano on Wednesday dismissed the defamation lawsuit that Gates and Draise filed against Cincinnati Bell, leaving the jury to decide only the original lawsuit the company filed against the two former installers. The plaintiffs sued, demanding $2 million each from Gates and Draise. But Cartolano instructed the jurors that they must determine amounts to be awarded. The exception is punitive damages, which Cartolano said he would determine if the jury decided to award them. Gates and Draise accused their former employer of illegal wiretapping of customers, including business leaders and federal judges. Cincinnati Bell and its managers say the accusations are lies and that the company never knew of or authorized illegal wiretaps. Only federal judges may authorize installation of electronic listening devices. Cincinnati Bell says Gates and Draise were out to get the company because it fired Draise in 1979 and Gates in 1986. But Gates and Draise say the company is trying to cover up its alleged involvement. ``You have the ability to send Bell and other companies a message: we're not going to stand for it,'' Draise told the jury. He and Gates are serving as their own lawyers. Cincinnati Bell attorney Arnold Morelli told the jury that Gates and Draise should not be believed because they changed their stories, contended they could not remember dates and other details of wiretaps, and would not take polygraph tests. Morelli noted that Gabor and West voluntarily submitted to polygraph tests. Gates and Draise say they installed at least 1,200 illegal phone wiretaps from 1972 to 1984 at the direction of Gabor and West or Cincinnati police intelligence squad members. Morelli said Gates changed his story about whether Gabor or West ordered Gates to install a wiretap on then-President Ford's phone during Ford's 1975 visit to Cincinnati. Draise contended that Gabor ordered him to tap the phone of then-Cincinnati financier Charles Keating in 1974 or 1975. But he backed off that story when Cincinnati Bell lawyers showed that Gabor was working in New York for American Telephone & Telegraph Co. at that time. ``Wild rumors, changed stories, bumping into facts, and refusal to take polygraph tests _ what does that say about their case?'' Morelli said.

DOC.HEAD: Senator, Congressman Nominate `White Hope' Candidate for Poet Laureate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with aide saying Thurmond never forwarded request, aide says. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Rollinson is...'
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. senator and a congressman helped arrange for a fringe presidential candidate whose slogan is ``Keep White Hope Alive in America'' to be considered for appointment as the nation's poet laureate. Aides to U.S. Sens. Connie Mack, R-Fla., and U.S. Rep. Earl Hutto, D-Fla., said they were unaware of Ray Rollinson's racial slogan when they forwarded his request to be nominated to President Bush's office and the Library of Congress. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., also received the request from Rollinson, and wrote a letter back to him, according to Thurmond aide Bill Outlaw. But Thurmond did not forward the request to Bush, Outlaw told The Associated Press in Washington Friday. The aid to Rollinson, 69, of Mexico Beach was disclosed in Friday's editions of the Florida Freedom Newspapers in Fort Pierce, Panama City and Fort Walton Beach. Rollinson is a self-published poet who says he also is running for the Democratic presidential nomination ``to help counter the racist movement of Jesse Jackson, (Democratic National Chairman) Ron Brown and the rest of the white-is-ugly racists of the NAACP.'' The post of poet laureate, which is appointed by the librarian of Congress, was last held by the late Robert Penn Warren. ``We handled it like any other constituency service,'' said Mark Berry, Mack's press secretary. ``There was nothing in what he sent us that could be construed as being racist. Had we known about his campaign, I think that would have made a difference.'' Rollinson denies he is racist and says he did not purposely hide his political philosophies. ``I am a major candidate, so I don't see how I can hide anything,'' Rollinson said. ``My campaign is anything but racist. There isn't a racist drop of blood in my body.'' Rollinson was in the public eye last year when Vice President Dan Quayle invited him to a barbecue in Washington, D.C., as a member of the Republican Senatorial Inner Circle. After news reports about the invitation, the GOP canceled it and beefed up security at the vice presidential mansion in case Rollinson showed up. In a press release for his 1992 presidential campaign, Rollinson wrote that Mack and Hutto had nominated him for the poet laureate position. ``Nomination is not the word I would use,'' Berry said. He said Mack's office sent Rollinson's request to be nominated and samples of his poetry to Bush's office which forwarded the material to the librarian of Congress. Thurmond and Hutto took similar action. ``The stuff we got was pretty harmless, talking about walking on the beach and stuff like that,'' said Brian Keeter, Hutto's press secretary. ``Certainly the congressman does not condone racial overtones, but Mr. Rollinson is a resident of the congressman's district and we always respond to letters from our constituents.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Shoving Match Spreads to Fans, Bands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, bgn `Later in...,' with 4 grafs to CORRECT that officials now say five players, sted seven, placed on probation, UPDATE with quotes from coach. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The free-for-all...' A version moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: A shoving match between players escalated into a brawl involving more players, hundreds of fans and even the band at a basketball game between longtime rivals North Carolina Central and North Carolina A&T. ``There was general rioting throughout the gymnasium between Central fans and A&T fans,'' N.C. Central sports information director Wallace Dooley said in a telephone interview from the school in Durham. Officials for the two colleges discussed Friday what to do about the last eight minutes of Thursday night's game at the Corbett Center gymnasium in Greensboro, the home of North Carolina A&T State University. Later in the day, five members of the N.C. A&T team were placed on probation, and the schools agreed that the game would not be replayed. N.C. Central officials announced the game would be declared a no-contest and would not count against either team. N.C A&T coach Don Corbett said at a news conference Friday that he would review videotape of the game and would determine if further action is necessary. No action has been taken against N.C. Central players. ``I don't think that anybody flagrantly did anything other than defend themselves or react to a situation,'' a visibly upset Corbett said. ``Whatever I've done in 12 years I've been here all went down the drain with 45 seconds of TV work last night,'' Corbett said. ``It went all over the universe, all over the world. We've had calls from everywhere.'' The free-for-all was triggered when N.C. Central forward Derrick Leak was fouled by N.C. A&T center Jimmy Humphries. ``Even people from the A&T pep band were fighting,'' Dooley said. ``They were hitting people with their instruments.'' The 15-minute brawl put an end to the game with N.C. A&T leading 39-38. Two city police officers, one campus security officer and four students were treated for cuts and bruises and released, said Candy Colglazier, a spokeswoman for Moses Cone Memorial Hospital in Greensboro. There was conflicting information about the number of people arrested in the melee, with a sheiff's official reporting three and city and campus police reporting no arrests. City police reported seven arrests later because of a fight at a fraternity party, but desk sergeant Gary Wilson said he was unsure if the fighting was related to the game brawl. Both coaches said none of their players was hurt in the brawl, although N.C. Central Coach Mike Bernard's glasses were broken. Security police, many of them in the far reaches of the 7,500-seat complex attending to a fight which earlier broke out between two fans, arrived on the floor about two minutes after the brawl began. Coaches from both teams worked to restrain their players. At least two chairs from the N.C. Central bench were removed and used as weapons, witnesses said. N.C. A&T Athletic Director Orby Moss pleaded with spectators on the public address system to remain in their seats. But several other fights, apparently involving fans from the two schools, continued in the stands filled to near capacity. Moss then suspended the game and the coaches removed their players. The fighting continued outside among several hundred spectators while players tried to board buses. Chris Fisher, athletic director for N.C. Central, said the two teams have been arch rivals since they were both members of the Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association. ``It's a natural rivalry, even though we're not in the same conference any more,'' said Fisher. N.C. Central and A&T have played 121 basketball games dating back to 1930, with A&T holding a 66-55 series lead. Bernard was disappointed the game ended the way it did. ``It was a hotly contested game between two rivals and it's a shame that the game couldn't be decided tonight,'' he said. ``It's a shame their fans didn't get the opportunity to see the whole ball game. It would have been very exciting the last eight minutes.''

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Chapter Criticizes Austin Schools For Holiday Selection
DOC.TEXT: School officials here are under fire from black leaders for giving students Confederate Heroes Day off while not making Martin Luther King Jr. Day a holiday. ``Why Austin refuses and, whether wittingly or unwittingly, encourages the celebration of Confederate Heroes Day is insulting,'' said Victor Goode, a member of the NAACP. ``Houston, Dallas, San Antonio and Fort Worth schools closed to recognize Martin Luther King Jr. Day,'' Goode said Thursday during a news conference in front of the Capitol grounds statue honoring Texans who fought for the Confederacy during the Civil War. The holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader and the one honoring Confederate leaders Robert E. Lee and Jefferson Davis are optional state holidays. But there is a difference. Workers taking off the King holiday must make up that time by working one of several state holidays. State employees taking off Confederate Heroes Day do not have to make up the time and those that do work get extra compensation. A handful of bills last year in the Legislature would have combined the two holidays, but the proposals died in various committees. Austin school officials responded to the criticism by saying that students were given Thursday and Friday, Confederate Heroes Day, off because it is the end of the semester. Teachers use the time to compile grades and prepare for the spring semester. School trustee Bernice Hart, the only black on the seven-member board, said the two days off at the end of the semester are given to students each year. One of the days just happened to fall on Confederate Heroes Day this year, she said. ``I had no idea it was Confederate Heroes Day,'' Ms. Hart said. ``It's simply on the calendar as the end of the semester.''

DOC.HEAD: Delay of Elderly Man's Trial Held Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: A civil trial involving an elderly man with cancer can't be indefinitely delayed as a cost-saving move, the North Dakota Supreme Court ruled Thursday. The court declared unconstitutional a budget-inspired moratorium on civil jury trials in one of the state's court districts. The ruling came on a request by attorneys for Bernhard Odden, 80, who has prostate cancer. Odden, of rural Berwick, is suing a motorist and the motorist's employer for $650,000 in connection with a November 1986 car accident that injured Odden and killed his wife. The case was scheduled for trial Jan. 29, but was put on hold along with all other civil jury trials in the district by a District Court judge responding to a statewide effort to cut court spending. ``We'll have to live with it,'' Judge James O'Keefe, who issued the order, said of the state Supreme Court ruling. ``We may have to lay off somebody because of it,'' O'Keefe said in a telephone interview from his chambers in Grafton. ``We'll have to make cuts someplace else.'' O'Keefe's order was part of a statewide effort by North Dakota's district court system to cut $1.55 million from its budget. O'Keefe is presiding judge in the Northeast District, which includes 11 counties in the state's northeastern and north-central section. The order didn't apply to criminal trials. O'Keefe's order putting trials on hold drew protests from Odden's attorneys, who argued that a lengthy delay could mean Odden would never get his day in court. Attorneys Michael Geiermann and Casey Chapman had maintained the judge's order could have delayed their client's trial until after July 1, 1991, when the state begins a new two-year budget period. The North Dakota Trial Lawyers Association weighed in on the attorneys' side. The Supreme Court's five justices said Thursday it was unnecessary for them to order a trial in Odden's case. But they said an 18-month delay in bringing the case to trial would be unconstitutional. Chapman said he is satisfied with the ruling. ``I think we'll get our result, which is to get a trial in the case sooner than we otherwise would have,'' he said. District Judge William Neumann, who is to preside over the Odden case, said it would be scheduled for trial soon. Neumann said he, O'Keefe and the district's other judge would confer soon to decide new ways to cut the district's budget. ``I'm afraid the Supreme Court has asked us to pull a rabbit out of the hat,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Small Planes Crash in Ohio, Massachusetts; 4 Dead
DOC.TEXT: Light airplane crashes in Massachusetts and Ohio claimed at least four lives Thursday, and the FBI was investigating the Ohio wreck to see if the executive jet was downed by a bomb. In the Ohio crash, a rented Learjet crashed in flames north of Greenville, near the state's eastern edge, about 5:15 a.m., scattering debris over a wide area and killing both men aboard, officials said. In the other crash, at least two people were killed and four injured when a single-engine plane carrying a group on a ski trip in Massachusetts' Berkshire Hills crashed in the front yard of a home in Great Barrington, officials said. One of the injured was in critical condition. The plane, a Piper Lance, was taking off from the Great Barrington Airport about 7 p.m. when it apparently veered away from the runway, clipped the tops off of several trees and crashed into a yard about 500 yards from a home, said police Officer Paul Montgomery. Montgomery said the pilot and a passenger in the front seat of the privately owned plane were killed. Four others were injured and taken to Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington, he said. The injured included three men and one woman, believed to be from Long Island, New York, said Sharon Ebel, a spokeswoman for the hospital. The woman, 25, was in critical condition and was transferred to the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Ebel said. Names were withheld until relatives could be notified. In Ohio, the Learjet was flying empty to Louisville, Ky., suggesting the men intended to pick up cargo, said Mort Edelstein, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, one of several agencies investigating the crash. ``It was a streak of fire going through the air,'' said Wilbur Baker, who saw the crash about a half-mile from his home. ``When it hit the ground, it was a big ball of fire.'' The FBI sent agents to investigate because the widely scattered debris suggested the plane exploded in flight, said Ed Boldt, and agent in the bureau's Cincinnati office. ``At this point we're going to determine if the crash was caused by a bomb,'' Boldt said. The only evidence suggesting a bomb is the scattering of debris, he said. The victims were identified by the Darke County Sheriff's Department as Richard D. Hovarter, 53, of Mt. Clemens, Mich., and Octavio ``Julio'' Mendez Jr., 42, of Ypsilanti, Mich. Hovarter was believed to be the pilot, said Deputy David Anderson.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0816 to make it 1st Ld-Writethru
Thousands of Soviet Moslem Stream to Border with Iran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Soviet fighting in Baku, details. No pickup. ^With AM-Soviet-Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Moslems by the thousands converged on the Iranian border Friday in defiance of martial law imposed in many parts of the Caucasus republics to control ethnic violence, Tehran radio reported. A report by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency appeared to indicate the Soviets, many of them women, children and elderly, were refugees fleeing the violence, which has killed more than 70 people. Both IRNA and the radio were monitored in Nicosia. The broadcast said Soviet Moslems from the border town of Dzhulfa gathered on the bank of the Aras River that forms a natural boundary with Iran, chanted Islamic slogans, and threw messages in bottles to their kin gathered on the other side. Many parts of the border with Iran and Turkey have reportedly been sealed off following the outbreak of violence Saturday between the predominantly Shiite Moslem Azerbaijanis and Christian Armenians. IRNA said thousands of Soviet Azerbaijanis have crossed the border into Iran since Thursday, indicating parts of the border were still open. It said officials in Iran's east Azarbaijan province were making arrangements for tempory housing for the Soviets. Some were staying with relatives while others were being put up in mosques, the agency reported. In an editorial, IRNA accused the Soviet government and the Western press of trying to suppress the rights of Soviet Moslems by depicting the clashes as ethnic rather than political. ``It seems that ways to suppress Moslems are being paved in the Soviet Union also,'' IRNA said. The news came as Moscow appealed for an end to clashes in Azerbaijan and Armenia, where Red Army units and KGB troops were deployed Monday to control the ethnic violence. Soviet soldiers and ethnic extremists were reported to be fighting in the streets early Saturday in Baku, capital of Soviet Azerbaijan. IRNA said the Soviet Shiites crossed by land into Bilehsavar, Iran, 125 miles southwest of Baku. Iranian news media have previously reported that dozens of Soviet Azerbaijanis swam the Aras to visit Iran. Those reports indicated the Soviets later returned. IRNA did not specify how many Soviet Moslems crossed the border into Iran on Friday, but said 5,000 Soviet Azerbaijanis arrived in Bilehsavar on Thursday. The Soviet Azerbaijanis share a common language, culture and religion with Iranian Azerbaijanis, who make up about a third of Iran's 55 million people. There are about 6 million Soviet Azerbaijanis. Soviet Azerbaijani protesters have been demanding an open border between the countries and tighter links with their Iranian brethren. Nationalists in Soviet Azerbaijan are agitating for the establishment of a ``Greater Azerbaijan,'' an independent, oil-rich homeland for some 20 million Azerbaijanis on both sides of the border Azerbaijan, once wholly under Iranian rule, was ceded to Czarist Russia following a war in 1828. Soviet dictator Josef Stalin sealed the border in 1921, separating families and the ethnically homogeneous peoples.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes In Storm, 7 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Gary McDonald...O'Neal' to CORRECT to Eastman sted Eastern.
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine corporate jet crashed short of a Little Rock municipal airport runway in a storm Friday, killing all seven people aboard, authorities said. The 21-seat Gulfstream II jet, carrying employees of an Eastman Kodak Co. subsidiary, apparently was attempting a landing shortly after 5 p.m., witnesses said. Seven bodies were recovered from the wreckage, said Coroner Steve Nawojczyk, adding there were no survivors. ``The airplane broke apart on impact,'' Nawojczyk said. The plane hit guidance lights short of the airport, hit a street near an airport intersection, struck railroad tracks and a fence, losing a wing and wheel, and plowed 200 feet into airport property without reaching the runway, said Bill Booker, who was at the scene. Heavy rain and lightning swept through the area about the time of the crash. Craig Martin, a witness, said, ``First I heard like a rumbling of thunder and as I looked out I saw streaking fire going across the runway. It didn't look like there was anything left of the plane.'' Airport officials hadn't considered closing the runways because of the weather, and decisions on landing in bad weather are up to the pilot, said airport Manager James Rodgers. The plane left Longview, Texas, earlier Friday and was headed to Batesville, Ark., said Bill Edwards, a spokesman for Eastman Kodak subsidiary Tennessee Eastman Co. in Kingsport, Tenn. The passengers were employees of Arkansas Eastman in Batesville, which makes chemicals and aspirin. The plane was diverted to Little Rock because of bad weather, Edwards said. Gary McDonald, manager of community relations for Arkansas Eastman, identified the dead as: M.L. ``Bud'' Gernert, retired Arkansas Eastman president, and his wife, Marian, and company employees William Schirmer, Randy Wood, Nathan Casteel, and company pilots Don Mason and Ed O'Neal. Charley Rogers, a passer-by, said he was driving on Interstate 440, which passes the airport, when he saw the plane ``hit some guy wires or something _ I saw sparks. It looked sort of red and blue. ``When the plane hit the ground, it just exploded,'' Rogers said. ``All I saw was the explosion,'' he said. ``There were sparks up in the air, so it did hit something in the air.'' State Rep. Jim Keet, D-Little Rock, who arrived at the airport on a commercial flight, said, ``It looks like a major crash scene out here.'' Keet said that at the time of the incident, ``the weather was atrocious,'' and he was surprised that aircraft were coming in for landings at the time.

DOC.HEAD: Plane, Airliner Collide at Atlanta Airport; 1 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-9, bgn ```The Eastern...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with FAA saying it was not known how much time had elapsed between landings, clarification of landing roll, airport spokesman responding to investigation.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX10
DOC.TEXT: An Eastern Airlines jet landing here sheared off the top of a twin-engine aircraft that touched down just before it Thursday evening, killing one person and injuring another aboard the smaller plane, officials said. The 7:10 p.m. collision between the Eastern Boeing 727 and a Beechcraft King Air 100 occurred on a runway at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport, officials said. No one was injured aboard the jetliner, said airport spokesman John Braden. The two male victims were taken to South Fulton Medical Center; one was dead on arrival and the other was listed in stable condition, hospital officials said. There were no reports of other injuries. The collision involved Eastern Flight 111, which originated in Montreal, and a twin-propeller plane flying from DeKalb Peachtree Airport on the edge of Atlanta to Hartsfield, about 15 miles south, said officials with the Federal Aviation Administration. ``Passengers on the Eastern flight are OK. No injuries,'' said Eastern spokesman Robin Matell in Miami. ``The extent of damage on our plane is wing damage. How extensive, I don't know.'' The jet carried 141 passengers and a crew of eight, he said. Roger Myers, an FAA spokesman in Atlanta, said the Eastern plane was completing its landing as the Beechcraft was still taxiing on the runway. ``The Eastern airliner landed behind him, and they collided on the runway. ... He (the Eastern pilot) was on his landing roll,'' meaning the jet was still rolling to a stop, Myers said. Jack Barker, another FAA spokesman, said both planes had been given permission to land. When asked if that indicated a problem in the control tower, he replied, ``That's under investigation.'' Airport spokesman Braden, asked to comment, said, ``I don't know. I haven't talked to them (the control tower).'' Officials did not know yet how much time had lapsed between the two landings, Barker said, although ``it was very close between the two.'' Myers said no fire was reported and he did not know whether either plane might have landed improperly, causing the collision. Matell said an earlier report that the smaller plane had crossed the 727's path was incorrect. ``Both planes were cleared to land,'' Matell said. ``It happened so fast. It was like the plane hit something and sort of scooted to the side,'' said Eastern passenger Mike Whittaker. ``We thought at first either he hit something or he blew a tire. A friend of mine was looking out and he said, `I believe we hit something, it looked like a little airplane.''' ``I seen this debris flying everywhere, terrible, just like it flipped over and it was way up in the air _ terrible,'' said Rodney Johnson, an airport ground worker who witnessed the collision. Braden said the twin-engine aircraft, which carried no other passengers, belonged to Epps Air Service and was based at DeKalb-Peachtree Airport. He said both men aboard the plane were Epps employees. ``The top half of the (twin-engine) plane was pretty well sheared off. ... The engines are intact,'' Braden said. The tail section also was missing. The dead man was identified as Eric Thomas, 30, of Ackworth, hospital officials said. Injured was Daniel Olthoff, 26, of Norcross, who was described as ``conscious, alert and talking,'' but doctors were still examining the extent of his injuries. FAA officials were on the scene. Matell said the Eastern flight originated in Montreal, stopped in La Guardia, and Atlanta was its final destination. The captain is a 23-year Eastern veteran, said Matell, who would not release his name. There was initial confusion about reports of a hydraulic problem aboard the smaller aircraft. Matell, however, said a pilot flying another Eastern plane, landing about the same time as Flight 111, declared an emergency while the pilot was lowering the plane's landing gear because he thought its hydraulic system had failed. He said the problem on Eastern Flight 56, a Boeing 727 flying from Miami to Orlando to Atlanta, turned out to be a faulty indicator gauge that mistakenly signaled hydraulic failure.

The former operators of a preschool wept when jurors acquitted them of 52 child molestation charges, but outraged parents of children who attended the school expressed fears for youngsters nationwide. Jurors in the nation's longest and costliest criminal trial Thursday deadlocked on 12 other sex abuse counts against Raymond Buckey and a single conspiracy count against him and his 63-year-old mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey. Superior Court Judge William Pounders declared a mistrial on the 12 counts and dismissed the deadlocked conspiracy charge against Mrs. Buckey. He set a Jan. 31 hearing to determine whether the 13 unresolved counts will be dismissed against Buckey. Buckey, 31, who spent nearly five years in jail before making bail, and his mother, who was jailed for almost two years, cried as they heard the verdicts.

The country's top health official blasted a ``slick and sinister'' cigarette ad campaign that targets blacks, saying tobacco companies were putting profits above the health of the poor and minorities. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan accused R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. Thursday of trying to create a ``culture of cancer'' with Uptown, a menthol cigarette the company plans to test in Philadelphia starting Feb. 5. The company has said the ads will target blacks, who, as a group, prefer menthol cigarettes. R.J. Reynolds also said Philadelphia was chosen because its population is 40 percent black. Sullivan, who has made minority health a top priority, said he was ``alarmed and angry'' and called on the company to cancel its plans.

As Congress moves toward enacting tougher air pollution controls, one of the biggest mysteries is how much it will cost. Figures range from $14 billion a year to more than $100 billion, and some argue that doing nothing may be most expensive of all. The nation's largest corporations unveiled a study Thursday suggesting that if some of the most stringent proposals for cleaning up the air are enacted, the cost of compliance could soar as high as $104 billion a year. The actual costs likely will be less, conceded Philip Masciantonio, a vice president at U.S. Steel, a subsidiary of USX Corp., but he added even the study's $54 billion ``best estimate'' could be devastating to some industries. The steel industry's coke ovens could be shut down by toxic chemical emission controls envisioned by a Senate clean air bill, he argued.

Frustrated by Ulysses S. Grant's refusal to pose for a portrait, a Swiss artist commissioned to glorify the Union triumph in the Civil War decided instead to paint Grant's old nemesis, Robert E. Lee, in a daring gesture of spite. The long-forgotten oil painting by flamboyant artist Frank Buchser spent the next 120 years gathering dust in a museum in his native Switzerland _ until it was found by Swiss Ambassador Edouard Brunner and brought back to the United States last year. Tonight, on the 184th anniversary of Lee's birth, Brunner will unveil the newly restored portrait of the Confederate general at an embassy reception attended by alumni of Washington and Lee University in Lexington, Va. Lee was president of Washington College in Lexington for five years after his April 9, 1865, surrender to Grant at Appomattox ended the Civil War. The institution was renamed in Lee's honor after his death in 1870.
