DOC.HEAD: Clowns and Circus Glasnost
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The sleek horse gallops around the circus ring with a dashing acrobat and juggler standing solidly on its back. Suddenly, the rider unfurls a colorful banner of Soviet and U.S. flags and the audience wildly cheers. American-Soviet friendship steals the show at the Moscow Circus, now on its second North American tour since ending a 10-year hiatus in 1989. Bomb threats and rallies had greeted the circus in the late 1970s in anger over Moscow's human rights policies. Today, the return of American and Soviet co-ringmasters is the big news. Also co-starring this year is capitalism. Part of the touring circus is operating as an independent cooperative for the first time in 70 years. ``It's been a sensational success _ financially, socially, economically, politically,'' says U.S. producer Steven Leber. ``I'm not just saying this because it's my show: There's a love affair going on between these countries. They don't relate like that to the Japanese or Germans.'' Performers in the circus _ actually a compilation of top-quality acts from scores of Soviet circuses _ say glasnost also has unleashed creativity and brought innovations to one of the most popular art forms in the Soviet Union. ``This is a new generation of circus,'' says Svetlana Nugrazov, a star of the circus. ``The government says it wants avant-garde. There are no barriers now.'' One such enterprising act is the 10-minute finale called ``The Legend'' in which Tamerlan Nugrazov's daring horsemen fling themselves and their horses around a darkened stage in a mock battle scene, crashing swords and shields that flash sparks. In the end, a beautiful woman intervenes by dropping a white handkerchief. The fighters drop their swords, delivering yet another message of friendship and peace. ``Art plays a very important role,'' said Mrs. Nugrazov, the peacemaking woman in her husband's act. ``When people come to the circus, they see that we're just normal people. We don't carry guns.'' Circus glasnost even extends to the clowns, who once had to submit their scripts to censors watching for uncomplimentary jokes, Mrs. Nugrazov said before a recent New York opening at Radio City Music Hall. ``But now, they're saying things that we're all so happy to hear, things they would've been shot for by Stalin.'' The Gibaduliin jugglers dazzle the audience in pitch black by juggling 16 flourescent juggling pins. Ruslan and Zina Gugkaev, husband and wife, perform acrobatics while balanced on either end of a plank some 30 feet in the air. Sarwat Begbudi spins glasses of water in the air while standing on the back of A horse galloping around the circus' single center ring. The single ring is a major difference from U.S. circuses, which often have three going simultaneously. American circuses _ more then 70 are active today _ tend to feature more color and pageantry, while Soviet circuses are more intimate, with the audience sitting right at the edge of the circus ring. Soviet clowns also act more as ringmasters, by helping to introduce acts as well as entertaining between them. Ironically, most circus performers in the United States are natives of Europe, Asia and South America, where circus traditions are older and generally more popular. More than half of U.S. circus performers are imported. ``Some people believe it's a matter of the willingness of the average American to subject himself to the rigors of training without income,'' said Robert Parkinson, a circus historian at the Circus World Museum in Baraboo, Wis. ``The thinking is that people who would have gone into acrobatics years ago are now going into athletics.'' Most major Soviet cities have a permanent circus facility, either for a local troupe or for traveling companies. An entire government department, Soyuzgoscirk, oversees hundreds of circus units, circus colleges and performances across the Soviet Union. The circus will tour the United States and Canada for six months. Another circus, called the ``Crane unit'' because of its feature act with the exotic birds, is also criss-crossing the country. Most acts in both units are new this year, meaning most performers are seeing the United States _ and American audiences _ for the first time. ``People not only like the circus as an art form, but they like the (Soviet) performers,'' Mrs. Nugrazov, one of a few return performers, said in her dressing room while sewing more sequins to her already bespeckled dress. ``What can we think of the American public when they have given such a warm reception to us,'' she said, noting the demonstrations during the circus' detente-era tours in 1978 and 1979. With economic and political uncertainty at home, most Soviet performers also can bank on financial and professional success from the U.S. tour. The prestige, pay and personal experience from a U.S. tour will sustain most performers for the rest of their lives, said co-ringmaster Alexander Makhtiser, an actor who emigrated from Moscow to New York about 12 years ago. And performers in the so-called ``Crane unit'' will make even more than those in the main circus unit, thanks to perestroika, Leber said. The main unit of the Moscow Circus once again is produced jointly by the official circus agency Soyuzgoscirk and by Leber, a longtime producer with such credits as the ``Jesus Christ Superstar'' tour and ``Beatlemania.'' But during negotiations for this year's tour, the Soviet Ministry of Culture, which oversees Soyuzgoscirk, objected to Leber's contract, he said. That led a group from last year's Moscow Circus to form a circus cooperative under a different government department, allowing them relative freedom to sign their own contract with Leber. That cooperative unit is this year's ``Crane unit,'' which Leber hopes to take on a worldwide tour in coming years. His contract with Soyuzgoscirk for the main unit, finally signed after he agreed to cut the optional length of his contract, gives him rights only to U.S. tours, he said. The problems haven't affected this year's success, he said. While declining to give figures, he said this year's two-unit tour has done quadruple the business of last year. And planning already has begun for next year. But for Soviet performers who must audition again for next year, the tour literally may be a once-in-a-lifetime experience. ``They'll go home, it'll take about a week and they'll miss America,'' Makhtiser said before the New York opening on Jan. 12. ``Who doesn't want to come back to such a comfortable life, to see so much, so many colors?'' After New York, the main unit is scheduled to appear in: Rosemont, Ill.; St. Louis; San Diego; Inglewood, Calif.; Sacramento, Calif.; San Francisco; Salt Lake City; Phoenix; Denver; Kansas City; Indianapolis; and Richfield, Ohio. The ``Crane unit'' is scheduled to hit Reno, Nevada; Ames, Iowa; New Orleans; St. Peteresburg, Fla.; Atlanta; Las Vegas; Birmingham, Ala.; Greensboro, N.C.; Charlotte, N.C.; Nashville, Tenn.; and Atlantic City, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: General Motors: Where Humans and Technology Don't Mesh
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp., the world's largest automaker, may suffer from a developmental warp, a systemic imbalance between high-tech manufacturing processes and human capacity to use them well. The problem is correctable, says a professor who had spent three decades analyzing corporate structures, but it will require a specialist, ``a five-year project-type CEO with years of experience'' to replace Roger Smith. Smith, who will retire this year as chief executive officer, initiated a $40 billion-program to modernize production facilities in an effort to bring down costs and raise efficiency. But GM efficiency remains low. The reason, says Eugene Jennings, professor emeritus at Michigan State University and a confidential adviser to corporate chairmen, is that GM failed to develop the human organization to work with the technology. Specifically, ``The new manufacturing processes were ahead of the available experience and knowledge of how to achieve optimal efficiency with compatible, synchronized human organizations.'' In short, technology was developed beyond immediate human usefulness, a familiar problem to anyone who owns a telephone that can do a dozen tricks, if only they were needed, or a personal computer that defies understanding. Says Jennings: ``GM has too many staff personnel compared to line, too many overseeing plant people compared to hands-on types, at least three too many reporting levels, too many committees, too many parts divisions with uncompetitive costs. ``GM fixed costs are too high relative to variable costs, and its general and administrative costs average several times higher per revenue dollar than the leanest competitition.'' The statistical evidence is devastatingly clear, he says, observing that GM's market share has dropped from 48 percent in 1980 to 35 percent in 1989 and seems to be headed lower. Harbour & Associates of Ann Arbor, Mich., estimates that 15 of the 16 least efficient plants in North America are GM, and among the company's least efficient plants are several of their newest. Although estimates vary, average profit per vehicle assembled in North America recently has been about $50 for GM, more than $600 for Ford Motor Co. and more than $1,000 for some of the transplants, or foreign factories on U.S. soil. In Jennings' view, Roger Smith deserves credit for having tremendous vision in devising his plan to push technology far beyond its then-existing level early in the 1980s. ``It was a dream elegant in its conceptualization,'' he says, ``but it went so far so fast it surpassed the human capability to implement it.'' Quality improved, but costs didn't fall. ``The human aspect was a failure.'' In retrospect, he believes, Smith carried the program as far as any one person could, and he states that no person is sufficiently skilled to take on such a 10-year stint. Jennings says a second-stage leader should have been named. What is needed now, says Jennings, is a chairman with a clear assignement to develop the human organization that will bring down costs. In his view, the GM cost-reduction program now under way is a good start, but it must be combined with a ``re-sizing'' of the entire company. Re-sizing is a euphemism for shrinking the company to an efficient level. How much shrinkage? Jennings declines to estimate, but John Hammond of J.D. Power and Associates, an automotive industry analyst, has mentioned a decline to 29 percent of market share before stability and full efficiency are achieved. Jennings believes GM, which always has promoted from within, might have to go outside the company to find the individual suited for the challenge. ``This idea may have had merit in an oligopolistic market where GM could dictate its terms,'' says Jennings. ``Good ideas are too rare to be the exclusive province of insiders.'' Whoever is chosen, says Jennings, has an opportunity to make GM the best managed and lowest cost producer, assuming he can mesh human and technological elements. ``Many things are in place for GM to take off,'' he said. ``It has tremendous opportunities.''

DOC.HEAD: Nutty Fat Girls and the Spice of Life
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: While making her first feature film, ``Sweetie,'' Jane Campion was too busy to critique the story. Any message this dark comedy might carry was left to the medium itself. The New Zealand-born director saw herself as a pragmatist, a problem-solver who used intuition rather than ideals to make creative decisions. Only upon viewing the film did she permit herself the luxury of a little instant analysis. ``It was a surprise to me,'' the 34-year-old director said in an interview. ``For me it was a personal experience. When I saw it, I thought, `There are things I wasn't expecting.' ``I was really rewarded by the effort. I felt really high on occasion when some notes hit that were really special. I always want the possibility that there is some surprise for you, that something unique will happen.'' With most of the cast and crew working on its first feature film as well, ``Sweetie'' does seem to unfold at its own, unaffected pace, as gentle as the trees that provided meaning for the film's tortured Australian family, as dark as the lipstick worn by the title character. Based on an original story by Campion and Australian author Gerard Lee, ``Sweetie'' is minimalism from Down Under, days of rage and days of detachment brought to theaters for a mere $1.3 million. The screen for this small, intimate film is filled, literally, by Sweetie, played by first-time actress Genevieve Lemon. Paranoid and desparately insecure, she receives tragically little support from her moody sister, Kay (Karen Colston), and reserved parents (John Darling and Dorothy Barry). Audiences are allowed to steal a glance at a family that would rather be left alone. ``She's not evil, she just frightened,'' the mother observes, but such insights are expressed only when Sweetie is safely out of earshot. Once around, she's at best ignored, and at worst, treated like a dog still in need of a slap behind the ears. ``The main and most difficult dynamic was between the father and the daughter,'' Campion said. ``It was obviously a history of a great deal of love and encouragement between them which never matured. ``He couldn't accept her as the big, fat, adult self. He could never accept that the childhood potential that she showed wasn't there now. He never helped her to accept reality. She was so addicted to the love that he once gave her. She would seek it from anyone she could get it from.'' Campion grew up in Wellington, and originally preferred painting and plays to film. But she learned quickly how to think visually, admiring ``Women in Love,'' ``Performance'' and other films. ``I was aware at an early age how much I loved daydreaming and story-making, how potent that was for me. I think of filmmaking as play. It's work but I think it's play, too. ``I had a fairly gentle, but fairly fast introduction to filmmaking. But I didn't want to make a feature. I wasn't ambitious in that way.'' She obtained a diploma in anthropology before attending the Australian Film and Television School, where she directed three short films: ``Peel,'' ``Passionless Moments'' and ``A Girl's Own Story.'' Her breakthrough came in 1986 at the Cannes Film Festival when ``Peel'' won the Palme D'Or for best short film. That same year, Campion developed the storyline for ``Sweetie.'' ``I approached Gerry (Lee) and said, `Let's do it together.' I was very worried who was going to be `Sweetie.' I felt that `Sweetie' needed to be childlike, believeable. She had to make almost anything sound real.'' On film, the humor is dry, ironic, matching Campion's own tight smile and clipped accent. On the set, the laughter was loud and jolly, reflected by the director's amused, mischievous eyes. ``We needed an atmosphere that was going to support her (Lemon), being such a big character,'' the filmmaker said. ``We had a very jolly, wild atmosphere. She would sing songs at the top of her voice and all of us would just carry on. We all got a bit nutty at times. ``The film isn't about Sweetie. To me, it's about love and delusion and reality. She seemed to be the catalyst for a lot of these frustrations. I'm not interested in nutty fat girls per se. I'm interested in extremes _ in love and friendship.''

DOC.HEAD: Drug Money Breeds Violence in Colombian Prisons
DOC.TEXT: The violence of Colombia's cocaine trade has reached into its prisons, seriously disrupting the intended last stop in the nation's war on the cartels _ the penal system. Wealth generated by the trade has dramatically increased the level of prison violence as inmates, their pockets full of money, bribe guards to get weapons and fight among themselves for control of contraband, according to the system's director, Jaime Camacho. ``As drug trafficking grows, so does the violence in the jails,'' he said in an interview. A private study by a criminal defense lawyer, Pedro Elias Rondon, concluded that at La Modelo, a Bogota jail housing up to 3,000 prisoners, violence claimed the life of one inmate every day. ``The bloodshed is startling,'' Rondon said. Camacho said Rondon's finding was exaggerated but acknowledged that prisoners frequently killed each other. He said that many of the killings were committed by people ``settling scores'' carried over from previous illegal dealings with one another, dealings fueled by drug money. ``They kill you in here if you don't pay your debts,'' said Timothy Crawford, a U.S. citizen held in La Picota, which holds the country's most most hardened criminals and is considered its most dangerous. Crawford, who has been a prisoner in La Picota since his conviction in 1985 of drug trafficking, spoke briefly to a reporter given a tour of the prison in the company of a guard. During the tour, one of the prison's cold, bare hallways echoed with shouts from inmates as the reporter was led by, asking questions when he could. At one point, the prisoners were asked how weapons made their way into the prison. ``We pay off the guards,'' one prisoner shouted back and the guard beckoned the visitor on. Prison director Camacho said later he was convinced that some guards, whose average monthly salary is $156, are easily bribed. ``The prisons are not closed off from the outside world,'' he explained. ``There is a constant flow of money, drugs and weapons across the gates.'' Until recently, prison officials had only to contend with prisoners' knives, razors and clubs. Lately they began finding guns. Some of the prisoners shouting through the bars at La Picota said that they could buy a pistol from guards for a million pesos, the equivalent of $2,300, which is affordable for a prisoner dealing in contraband. On Christmas Day, inmates of Cell Block One, using at least one pistol, took 18 hostages _ 11 guards, two police officers and five visitors. Warden Sandra Urazan Perez called it the worst uprising in the prison's history. The inmates killed a guard and held the other hostages for two days before police freed them in an operation that left six prisoners dead. Camacho said he was certain the convicts got the pistol with ``the complicity of certain guards,'' but he added that authorities had still not officially determined this. The prisoners' plan to flee in the guards' uniforms was spoiled by a special police force that sealed off the cell block shortly after the hostages were taken, Warden Urazan Perez said. The convicts' connections to drug trafficking became apparent during the uprising when they issued a communique protesting Colombia's extradition policy and the slaying by police of a Medellin cartel leader. Police shot and killed the drug trafficker, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, in a shootout Dec. 15 on Colombia's northern coast. His followers killed rivals four days later at La Modelo prison. ``I'm convinced that the prisons will always reflect the world outside,'' Camacho said. ``Drug violence will continue to touch prisoners inside.'' Guards at La Picota have been victims of the prison's violence. ``This a tough, low-paying job that can cause psychological problems,'' said one guard, who refused to give his name. ``Things have been much worse since the uprising. We're all more afraid.''

DOC.HEAD: Hollywood Writers Say Skiddoo to Historical Accuracy
DOC.TEXT: Eddie Murphy may be funny, but when it comes to language, he's a linguistic laughingstock. Forget the four-letter words. Examine instead Murphy's ``Harlem Nights,'' set in 1918 and 1938, and the movie's inaccurate use of very hip phrases such as ``Gimme five,'' ``I'll let you have your space,'' ``Take it easy,'' ``Yo!'' and ``I just need a couple of seconds to get my head together.'' Or put ``Fat Man and Little Boy'' under the semantic stethoscope. The Paul Newman film, set during 1942's Manhattan Project, bombards atomic-age dialogue with the contemporary phrase ``dead meat,'' the hip verb ``obsessing'' and the 1980s greeting, ``It's good to see you, bro.'' Robert L. Chapman, author of ``The New Dictionary of American Slang,'' said of all the expressions mentioned above, only``gimme five'' and ``bro'' were on the fringes of acceptable usage during the years in which their films were set. Everything else, he said, is out. Like, way out. While most production designers, set decorators, costumers, property masters and choreographers seem to have mastered period authenticity, a few scriptwriters are excelling as idiom idiots, littering movies with linguistic anachronisms. Even the most conscientious writers laboring for accuracy occasionally stumble into embarrassing verbal time warps. Phil Alden Robinson, the author-director of ``Field of Dreams'' and the mid-1940s period comedy ``In the Mood,'' plowed through newspapers, magazines and court transcripts to collect realistic dialogue for the latter film. ``And then I have the father say to his son in the movie, `Life's a bitch and then you die,''' Robinson said. ``A few critics referred to it, saying it was a mistake to use an '80s phrase in a '40s film. They may well be right. It just never occurred to me that (the phrase) wasn't something I've always heard.'' William Safire, who writes the language column for The New York Times Magazine, noted that Robinson, Murphy and Roland Joffe, director and co-writer of ``Fat Man and Little Boy'' stand in good company. ``Whatever they did, it wasn't nearly as horrendous as what Shakespeare did by having a clock in `Julius Caesar,' because back in the days of Julius Caesar (100-44 B.C.) there were no clocks,'' Safire said. Syndicated language columnist Jeffrey McQuain said the musical ``Phantom of the Opera,'' ostensibly set in 1911, features the World War II aviator's expression ``point of no return'' 30 years prematurely. Odds for such historical gaffes increase, as young writers and directors raised not on literature but on television and movies work more steadily in the industry. Lacking the proper dictionaries (or professional interest), the greenhorn (circa 1785) may assume ``A-OK'' is ages old, but it's from the Eisenhower years. Has ``hoosegow'' been slang for ``jail'' since the time of Lewis and Clark? Nope _ try 1860. When budgets and time permit, some scripts are submitted to fact-checking firms such as de Forest research in Los Angeles, which charges $3,500 and up to review a period feature for legal and historical problems. A fair number of writers don't know much about inaccurate language, said Peter Sloman, a senior researcher at de Forest. ``But for those who do know, it can be like listening to an operatic aria where all of a sudden a note comes in a third below where it's supposed to be,'' he said. ``It can be that jarring .. . as annoying as the big vaccination scars on Indians in (movies set) in 1865.'' Yet research firms only serve as advisers on language, and can't really order changes. Furthermore, improvisational performers such as Murphy, Robin Williams and Dustin Hoffman are bound to say whatever comes to mind, whether it's in the script or not. And sometimes, too much attention to historical accuracy can backfire. When Paramount Pictures released ``Black Rain,'' an action movie largely set in Japan, the studio's press materials and advertisements featured the movie's title printed in Japanese characters. Too bad they translated as ``Black Nane.''

DOC.TEXT: The pension board of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America has spurned church orders to divest from firms doing business in South Africa. But the denomination's interim policy group, the church council, is examining ``possible options'' for dealing with the board's refusal to comply with an action last August by the denomination's assembly. It had ordered the pension board to get rid of holdings by September 1991, in all companies with direct or indirect business in South Africa as a protest to its apartheid system of racial separation. The pension board in October asked that the assembly action not be implemented, saying it would jeopardize income, break trust with pension members and make the board liable for damages. A report on possible courses of action comes before the church council at its April meeting.

Roman Catholic leaders are to conduct their annual ``national prayer vigil for life'' here Jan. 21-22, marking the anniversary of the 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. At the same time, the Office for Pro-Life Activities of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops distributed materials stressing that opposing abortion was part of a consistent ethic of life. ``The consistent ethic sustains us in our efforts on behalf of the unborn and on behalf of all whose lives are threatend or diminished,'' said ther Rev. John W. Gouldrick, director of the pro-life office.

Two Chinese students told News Network International that since China's brutal crackdown last June on a pro-democracy movement, students have been converting to Christianity virtually ``by the dorm.'' The ``rate at which students turn to Christ is literally a dormitory at a time,'' the students were quoted by the religious rights network. ``Some departments within certain colleges have changed their whole atmosphere because so many have become Christians.''

Several public television stations and the interfaith network, VISN, will be part of a worldwide telecast this Saturday and Sunday of an international conference in Moscow of religious and parliamentary leaders on protecting the environment.

The Lilly Endowment has passed out another batch of grants totalling $791,000 to strengthen governing boards at 40 North American seminaries. Fred Hofheinz, Endowment program director for religion, said: ``We act on the conviction that strong religious leaders and scholars emerge from strong seminaries, and the vitality of seminaries depends in great measure on the performance of the trustees who govern them.'' Similar grants were made earlier to another 75 seminaries.

After meetings with Soviet officials in Moscow, leaders of B'nai B'rith, said it plans to establish nine provisional units of the Jewish service organization in that many cities across the Soviet Union.

A United Methodist bishop says congregations in that big but shrinking denomination are not evangelizing as much as they should, and they should be held accountable for it. Bishop George Bashore of western Pennsylvania told a recent denominational congress on evangelism: `We are developing processes for the evaluation of clergy throughout our denomination, but I believe we are much more cavalier in calling our congregations to accountability for what they are doing.'' The United Methodist Church has 8.9 million members, making it the nation's second largest Protestant denomination, but the membership has declined steadily for 25 years from an all-time high of 11 million in 1965. Bashore said, ``We need to redirect resources from places that aren't taking off to churches that will take off in the name of Jesus Christ.''

DOC.HEAD: Chilean Victims Plan Criminal Complaints Against Military
DOC.TEXT: Victims of human rights abuse are planning ``a giant wave'' of criminal complaints after the military steps aside in March, posing a potentially risky problem for the new civilian government. The military, which has ruled for the last 16 years, has made it clear it will not tolerate prosecutions of its members even though it will be out of office. But the victims and their relatives insist they will not give up their demands for justice. The independent Chilean Human Rights Commission says it has 124,000 cases of human rigts violations ``duly documented, ready to be brought before the courts'' immediately after the inauguration of the new government. Most of them involve military officials. ``It will be a giant wave of trials,'' said Gonzalo Taborga, the commission official in charge of international affairs. ``We will encourage people to bring their cases to the courts, because justice is essential for the stability of our future democracy,'' Taborga said in an interview. Many Chileans fear that pushing the human rights issue too hard could trigger a violent reaction by the military and put the new civilian government in danger. President-elect Patricio Aylwin takes office March 11, replacing the longtime right-wing military ruler, Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Pinochet recently warned, ``If one of my men is touched, the rule of law will be broken.'' Pinochet, who seized power in a bloody 1973 coup, plans to stay on as commander of the powerful 60,000-men army. He is sheltered by a clause in the 1980 constitucion, drawn up by his regime, which prevents Aylwin from naming a new commander. Taborga dismissed the danger of a new coup as a result of the trials. ``It will be the other way around,'' he said. ``The trials will strengthen democracy and the sense of justice.'' Aylwin has vowed ``to find the truth and do justice'' in the human rights violations. But he has also stressed the need for ``extreme prudence.'' He also has promised to seek compensation for many of the victims. After the 1973 coup, thousands of supporters of the toppled leftist government were detained. Many were killed, tortured or confined to secret prisons or detention camps. Tens of thousands were forced into exile abroad. Francisco Cumplido, Aylwin's appointed minister of Justice, said the future government ``will fulfill its promise of finding the truth and doing justice in the human rights abuses.'' ``We will of course act with the political caution required in such a complex problem, combining the interests of the victims with the stability of the government,'' Cumplido said. But he added, ``We are not saying that a reason of state may prevent seeking the truth, doing justice and compensating the victims.'' In an interview earlier with the Santiago daily Las Ultimas Noticias, Cumplido was quoted as saying the armed forces can be assured that the new government is not planning ``a witch hunt'' on the human rights issue. Aylwin and his top aides have said any problems in the human rights area will be dealt with through the regular courts and not, as some have suggested, through special tribunals or commissions. But still it will be a complicated situation for the Aylwin government, caught between the warnings from the military, and the often impassionate pressures for justice from the victims and their relatives and from political groups, many of them his allies. The military government issued an amnesty law in 1978 covering all the abuses occurred since the 1973 coup. Aylwin's platform calls for ``repealing or anulling,'' that law, but recently his aides have suggested such an action, fiercely opposed by the military, may be dropped. Cumplido told Las Ultimas Noticias that there is ``an alternative strategy'' for achieving justice in pre-1978 cases without necessarily repealing the amnesty. He did not elaborate, but the comment, supported by other Aylwin aides, seemed aimed at appeasing the military on an issue that is widely expected to be the most sensitive in the relations between the armed forces and the new civilian government.

DOC.HEAD: Ideas, `Amazing Grace,' and Veterans _ Bill Moyers' New Season
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jessye in 4th graf is cq ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: In Septmber 1986, Bill Moyers, publicly worrying that CBS News was yielding to ``the encroachment of entertainment values,'' left CBS and returned to public TV. He has been very, very busy there ever since. This year will be no different. On Sunday, Jan. 28, PBS' resident philosopher and essayist launches the second season of his ``World of Ideas'' series, this one a once-a-week, 52-week series of half-hour interviews. In March, he'll have a 90-minute special, ``From D-Day to the Rhine'' _ his trip to Europe last summer with a group of World War II infantrymen who fought from the invasion of Normandy in 1944 to Germany and the war's end in 1945. Next fall, he'll have ``Amazing Grace,'' a 90-minute special about John Newton's classic hymn as told by those who've sung it, among them opera's Jessye Norman, pop singer Judy Collins and folk singer Jean Ritchie. Also afoot: ``Kids at Risk,'' a study of high school graduates who can't function in society, and a 1991 special that, as he puts it, examines why college athletes ``can be stars on Saturday and failures in life.'' Moyers' first ``World of Ideas,'' which led off with filmmaker David Puttnam, had five interviews a week for 10 weeks with a varied mix of subjects. The more leisurely second round, for which Moyers says he has a three-year, $2.5 million-a-year funding commitment from General Moters and the MacArthur Foundation, is equally eclectic. It starts with Robert Lucky, chief of communications research at Bell Laboratories. Others on the roster include filmmaker Steven Spielberg, neuro-philosopher Patricia Churchland and playwright-director Peter Sellars. As in his first batch of ``Ideas,'' Moyers doesn't fear the term ``talking heads,'' shots of interviewer and subject talking. For some TV executives of the keep-it-moving MTV generation, talking heads mean many turn-offs. ``Sometimes they are turn-offs,'' he concedes in his soft Texas accent. ``The question is, are the talking heads thinking minds and thinking people? Are they interesting to watch? I think the most fascinating production value is the human face.'' Moyers, press secretary to President Lyndon B. Johnson, then publisher of Newsday newspaper before finding TV a bully pulpit for ideas and essays, is less critical of network TV news now than when, dismayed, he left that arena. However, like former CBS correspondent Ike Pappas, he does worry that some of network news ``is dominated now by producers _ which is not itself a bad thing if they started out as reporters and journalists. ``But if all they know is pictures and editing, then the success of the piece is at the expense of the journalist.'' Still, he says, some network newscasts he has seen _ mostly on weekends _ ``are very good.'' He singles out CBS' Saturday and Sunday night newscast and the ``CBS News Sunday Morning'' that Charles Kuralt anchors. ``I'm a big fan of Kuralt's show,'' he says. ``It's the most visually interesting and literate broadcast on the air.'' On most weeknights, he says, he watches Cable News Network, likening its newscasts to the straight-ahead ``CBS Evening News'' when Walter Cronkite anchored it. ``CNN is doing the basic nuts and bolts of news the way Cronkite used to do it,'' Moyers says, venturing that in time Ted Turner's 24-hour CNN ``will be the staple of most people.'' The primary reason, he says, is that ``our work habits, travel schedules and living habits are such now that it's very hard to create a critical mass of audience at a given time. So you have to be there when people want you.'' Will network evening newscasts eventually go the way of the pterodactyl? Moyers, the former commentator on those of CBS, doesn't know. ``It's hard to fathom the thinking of the people who are in charge'' of the networks now, he says. ``As long as they are making money out of it, I think they will continue what they're doing. ``But I find it hard to believe that all three of them can be making money out of newscasts that are essentially alike.''

Elsewhere in television: ECOLOGY AND THE TUBE _ Salesmen for Ted Turner, cable maestro and environmentalist, are trying to syndicate an ecological cartoon series, ``Captain Planet and the Planeteers.'' With Tom Cruise as the voice of Capt. Planet, the show has episodes on oil drilling, acid rain and toxic waste dumping, and villains named Hoggish Greedly, Looten Plunder and Sly Sludge. CBS, also keen on the global ecosystem, is considering a series pilot called ``The Elite,'' starring Gil Gerard. It's about a team of experts ``fighting to protect an increasingly fragile enviroment.'' And ABC will air a celebrity-filled enviromental show on April 22 called ``The Earth Day Special.'' Some cynics speculate that if all this keeps up, some evil corporation is certain to commission a special called ``Just Say No to Rain Forests.''

DOC.HEAD: AP Series Sparks Re-Examination of Drought Overpayments, Policies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 19th graf, ``We were begging ... Walt Riker., to fix year when Dole was requesting aid to last year sted 1988.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department is re-checking some payments made under the 1988 drought relief program and congressional leaders are urging policy reviews after The Associated Press found widespread misapplication of funds in the $3.9 billion emergency effort. One New Jersey farmer has been asked to repay $100,000 after a federal agent read AP reports that checks went to corporations and farmers ineligible for disaster aid. Entire counties in California and New Mexico are being investigated as well, according to the Agriculture Department. The AP found that the program became a one-time windfall for thousands of farmers outside drought areas whose losses were due to normal quirks of nature. Claims were approved for such common perils as insects, sand, wind, cold and fungus, even ``ineffective herbicide'' _ all of which were outside the bounds of the drought effort. Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., a member of the House Agriculture Committee, called the AP series ``a needed story'' and said Congress must try to establish safeguards to prevent problems in future agriculture disaster programs. ``We have to set up some structures,'' Roberts said. ``That's why I think the AP series and other examples have been very beneficial. They point up the road we should not take.'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said his department's Office of Inspector General probably will investigate the 1988 relief program and likely will study the AP series, which appeared in December. ``The fact is, these kinds of programs are exceedingly difficult to administer, and they have inherent shortcomings,'' said Yeutter, who was interviewed recently at a wheat growers' convention in Texas. ``It's not that people avoided their responsibilities or were cavalier in the implementation; it's simply that it's just not an ideal way to deal with this problem.'' The Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, the arm of the Agriculture Department that administered the program, is already checking specific misdeeds spotted by the AP, deputy administrator Dan Shaw said in Washington, D.C. The ASCS says, however, that it won't check beyond the 22 counties in eight states the AP examined in its investigation. ``Those few that I was concerned with, we are checking to make sure corrections will be made,'' Shaw said. Shaw said other counties won't be studied because ASCS officials don't believe serious problems exist nationwide. ``I think (the AP) did a pretty good job,'' he said. ``I think you came up with the same problems we were having administering the program.'' But Dennis Pryslak, the New Jersey lettuce grower who was ordered to repay the aid he received, said it's unfair to single him out just because he was mentioned in an AP story. ``There's 50,000 other guys out there in the same situation and we got caught,'' said Pryslak. Yeutter said he hoped to avoid future big-buck bailouts, either by improving the federally subsidized crop insurance system or creating a permanent, efficient disaster program. ``We simply cannot afford a combination of the two,'' Yeutter said. ``The combination of mousetraps that we're using to deal with natural disasters in this country is not a very desirable combination.'' If Congress chooses to finance disaster programs rather than subsidize crop insurance, the Agriculture Department will go back and examine the problems the AP found, he said. ``One could put in place permanent disaster legislation that would be a potential substitute to crop insurance,'' Yeutter said. ``Once the administrative system was put in place, we wouldn't have the kinds of problems that were cited in your articles, or at least they'd be dramatically minimized.'' The AP stories appeared amid an intensifying debate in Washington over the value of crop insurance vs. year-to-year disaster relief. Earlier this month, Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kansas, senior member of the Senate Agriculture Committee, renewed his call to strengthen crop insurance and clean up excess in farm disaster programs. ``We were begging for disaster help for Kansas wheat farmers (last year) and there were other senators fighting for the watermelon and pickle growers,'' said Dole spokesman Walt Riker. ``What he's saying is, let's clean up crop insurance and make it attractive for farmers to participate in. Let's not have these whole programs where the country is paying for `ginseng root relief,''' Riker said. Ginseng root was among the many crops eligible for disaster assistance in 1988. Indeed, the AP study, conducted over seven months, found that payments went far beyond the initial intent, supported by almost everyone, to save Midwestern grain growers from bankruptcy. Growers collected on everything from kiwi fruit in California to Christmas trees in Connecticut. Checks were written for rain-bloated tomatoes in New Jersey and washed-out bird seed in Colorado. Rep. Kika de la Garza, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, defended the disaster relief program and contended the benefits to truly drought-stricken areas were ``camouflaged'' by abuses found by the AP. ``Legislation at best is an imperfect endeavor,'' de la Garza said. ``Therefore there are those (mistakes) that for one reason or another fall through the cracks. That always happens when we do legislation in an emergency situation. ``I would have liked to have taken more time. I would have liked to have done more study. But there was no time. Something needed to be done.'' Some problems the AP found, such as farmers ``triple dipping'' by collecting disaster aid, crop insurance and growing a replacement crop all on the same acreage, were corrected in the 1989 relief program, de la Garza said. The House committee, de la Garza said, will look into the reported abuses and ask the Agriculture and Justice departments to see if fraud or other illegal acts were committed. ``Already, from word of mouth, we've been looking,'' de la Garza said. Two weeks ago, the ASCS asked Pryslak to return his $100,000 in assistance within 30 days. The AP had reported that his business exceeded the $2 million revenue limit, disqualifying it from the federal program. Pryslak, who has appealed the decision, said he gave the local ASCS office correct information and asserted he was paid through the agency's misinterpretation of the rules. ``If I knew about the $2 million ceiling, I wouldn't have taken the money,'' he said. Peter DeWilde, the ASCS director for New Jersey, said errors were made on both sides. ``He didn't give us some information and some information we didn't ask for,'' he said. A determination of Pryslak's appeal is expected by the end of February. ``Sometimes the rules are hard to interpret, and then sometimes the rules are changed on us,'' DeWilde said. ``We welcome any chance to make sure these people deserved to be paid.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon AMs, Jan. 22

DOC.HEAD: Journey Along the Iron Curtain _ A 43-Year Faultline Is Gone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: a box is BC-Iron Curtain-Churchill, b0742.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos, LaserGraphic
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: ``An iron curtain has descended across the continent,'' Winston Churchill proclaimed in 1946, popularizing an image for the chain of barbed wire, watchtowers, walls and armed guards that would divide Europe for 43 years. As revolution swept Eastern Europe, Associated Press Correspondent Marcus Eliason and Photographer Diether Endlicher went on a journey that took them from the northern end to the southern end of the continent's ideological faultline.

One crisp evening, as Eastern Europe was becoming free, an old man named Johan Pavtits sat near the Hungarian border fence and remembered a December day in 1948. That was when the barbed wire went up between Lutzmannsburg in Austria and Zsira in Hungary, and soldiers came from the Hungarian hinterland. They knew little of the bonds that had tied the two villages for generations. Innocently they asked a farmer for the loan of his pliers so they could tighten the wires in what would come to be known as the Iron Curtain. ``The world ended here. But it was only half a world. The other half was over there,'' said Pavtits, gesturing with his callused laborer's hand at the lights coming on in Zsira, 300 yards east. ``And now the barbed wire is being taken away, and the world is whole again.'' The world is whole again _ it was a refrain heard constantly by an Associated Press reporter and photographer on a journey from Travemuende, the West German port where the Iron Curtain begins with watchtowers and high fences, to Trieste, the Italian port where it ends in a rusty, shin-high rail. The most vivid image of the Cold War was in collapse: border walls piled in useless slabs; the barbed wire from uprooted Czechoslovak fences coiled by the roadside; deserted, padlocked watchtowers. Countryside once quiet, divided and remote now was alive with traffic jams of East German day-trippers coming west, with tearful villagers surging through fences to meet neighbors for the first time, with a ferry boat making its first crossing of the Elbe River in 44 years, and with East and West German border guards who once glared at each other now chatting as though they always had been friends. It was a time of pure euphoria, when people everywhere welcomed each other with open arms, and the politicians and armies along the Iron Curtain suddenly became mere onlookers. The Iron Curtain, the image popularized by Sir Winston Churchill in a speech March 5, 1946, at Westminster College in Fulton, Mo. (``an iron curtain has descended across the continent''), now would need an epitaph.

ON THE BALTIC: The Iron Curtain begins without preamble _ a string of buoys in the Baltic Sea and then a row of border posts marching ashore at the Priwall Peninsula, at the West German port of Travemuende. Here, just weeks after East Germany opened its borders, is a sense of what the Iron Curtain was: freedom up to the border markers, with strollers braving the icy December wind; then barbed wire and watchtowers looming forbiddingly out of the fog. Then, six miles south, comes the first sign of change: the quiet checkpoint of Schlutup buzzing with Trabants, the smoky little East German cars that have become the most immediate symbol of the new freedoms. New holes were constantly opening in the 871-mile chain of walls, fence and watchtowers of the German-German border.

AT HITZACKER, 50 MILES SOUTH OF LUEBECK: A ferry toots its horn, the last passengers scramble aboard and it chugs off on a six-minute voyage to the East German bank of the Elbe River. Michael Brese, 31, is skippering the first service across the Elbe since April 1945, when his grandfather's ferry was sunk by American artillery. As soon as he had heard the border was opening, he says, he sent leaflets to the East German village across the river: ``Be at the fence on Nov. 18; we're coming to fetch you.'' In the past, such audacity would certainly have gotten him arrested. Now he finds hundreds of East Germans waiting for him, pressing against the fence, shouting, ``Open the gate!'' The East German guards refuse, but they soon cave in. So many cheering, weeping people clamber aboard that the ferry is briefly grounded. ``When we were children we used to fish in the river and we would gaze across, hoping to see maybe a face in a window, or someone walking,'' he says. ``We had a saying: `The Elbe has only one bank.' Well, now it has two banks again.'' Brese has punched his own, personal hole in the Iron Curtain.

ZICHERIE AND BOECKWITZ: Before the Iron Curtain descended between them, the 700 villagers shared a school, dairy and fire brigade. But then, Zicherie became a tourist attraction where Westerners could stand and stare at the lost eastern portion of the Fatherland. Now the wall is open. A man from Zicherie walks through, presents a glossy calendar to the East German guards in Boeckwitz, and returns beaming with pride at his contribution to German brotherhood. ``Everything we teach here has suddenly become history,'' says Birgit Neyhaus, who works at Zicherie's Political Education Center where West Germans can learn about East Germany. One recent day, she says, the unthinkable happened: an East German teacher showed up to ask her whether he could bring in his class to learn about West Germany.

PHILIPPSTHAL, IN HESSEN STATE: As American soldiers patrol, bulldozers open a new crossing. Two GIs walk up, looking for pieces of the Iron Curtain as souvenirs. The East German guards are uncooperative and the GIs leave empty-handed. An American patrol ambles up to the 650-year-old bridge linking Philippsthal to Vacha. The soldiers gaze at the crowds walking over the bridge past an ugly gray watchtower. The Philippsthal people pay no attention, but across the way, the East Germans, never having seen ``the enemy,'' seem fascinated. Things have changed: _Horst Badura, the Philippsthal town councilor, exults: ``We used to be Siberia; now we're the middle of Germany.'' _Christian Schlenczek, a Hessen forester, no longer has to wait six weeks for permission from East Germany to fell a dying tree near the border fence.

SUNDAY IN AUTENHAUSEN IN BAVARIA: At 10:15 a.m., a gate in the old border fence opens and people are reunited with neighboring Lindenau. Hundreds surge through, led by a brass band. An East German border guard, poised to stamp passports, is washed aside in the flow. ``Forget it,'' his commander tells him. ``This is hopeless.'' The two villages look remarkably alike: half-timbered houses, narrow lanes, farm smells. But for 35 years they saw nothing of each other except their respective church steeples, a mile apart.

DOC.HEAD: LUTZMANNSBURG: mile apart.
DOC.TEXT: LINDENAU, EAST GERMANY: Herbert Angermueller, 65, who was born here, is back for the first time since 1944. Each time he starts a sentence, he interrupts himself with a gasp or a cry: the old smithy, his old bedroom window, the fountain whose splashing sang him to sleep as a boy. And there, in a doorway _ could it be? He bursts into tears and falls into the arms of Augusta Beyer, 83, his next-door neighbor all those years ago.

BRATISLAVA, CZECHOSLOVAKIA: This city of 500,000 lies right on the Iron Curtain but now it seems as if it had just experienced a liberating explosion. Posters and political cartoons adorn every wall and shop window. A building displaying a hammer and sickle of communism is festooned with 25 protest banners. ``WE ARE WITH YOU'' _ on an unfinished highway bridge. ``RETURN SMREKOVICU TO THE PEOPLE'' _ in a sporting goods shop, referring to a government ski chalet. Schoolgirls copy slogans into their exercise books and chuckle at a cartoon of ousted Communist Party boss Milos Jakes. In a cultural center, crowds listen to a troupe playing Slovak folk music, while children watch Tom and Jerry cartoons on TV and munch corn on the cob sold by a cheerful street vendor. For the first time in 20 years the newspapers contain real news, and long lines form to buy them. Until a few days earlier, residents of Bratislava's high-rise apartments could only look across the Danube into Austria and into the eyes of freedom. Vienna is just an hour's drive away, but to go there people had to have official permission, fill in reams of forms and leave behind a close relative to guarantee their return. Now they just go off in the car; visa requirements for Austrians and Czechoslovakians were abolished in time for Christmas.

NORTH OF BRATISLAVA: Whole stretches of fence lie uprooted in messy coils by the roadside. A man clambers down to the Morava River, a Danube tributary that was off-limits for 20 years, and casts his line to fish. Michal Stolar and three friends collect Christmas trees on a hillside. Two days earlier they were among 6,000 Austrians and Czechoslovaks who formed a 4{-mile human chain across the border to celebrate the opening of the fence. Stolar, a 30-year-old geologist, knows his Iron Curtain intimately: ``A fence two meters (6 feet, 6 inches) high, then a strip with flares that went off when they were stepped on, then a second fence, 2.80 meters (nine feet) high. ... There were 187 strands of wire in each fence. Altogether enough wire to circle the earth 1{ times.'' But three months earlier, a Czechoslovak doctor had outwitted the Iron Curtain. He escaped over it on a motorized hang-glider. Ten miles to the north, a watchtower stands abandoned next to a German World War II bunker. Across the road, Josef Zapletal, 56, is repairing a fence on the collective farm where he has worked for 25 years since the Communists confiscated his private farm. The windows in the watchtower are broken. Zapletal says they were smashed by the guards, celebrating the death of their patch of the Iron Curtain.

HEGYESHALOM CHECKPOINT ON THE HUNGARIAN BORDER: Guards wave lines of cars through and the duty free shop is doing brisk business. Crossing this border used to take hours, as cars were searched for Bibles, Western magazines and hidden escapees. Along the roads, signs offer tourists rooms for rent, churches and shops are open, a picture of Christ is tacked to a tree, and little is left to suggest that this had once been one of the toughest communist countries in Europe.

LUTZMANNSBURG, AUSTRIA: Heinz Ritter is a 50-year-old schoolteacher and local historian whose scrapbooks and photos now are helping nearby Hungarian scholars fill the blanks created by communist censorship. ``They have the same problem that my generation had after Hitler: to find out what was true, what really happened,'' Ritter says. ``You can't flee history.'' In Ritter's father's diary, the entry for Dec. 14, 1948, records the departure of Lazslo Kobor, Lutzmannsburg's handyman. Kobor returned to his village of Zsira, 300 yards away in Hungary. Then the fence went up, and he didn't come back for 41 years. Now 60, he is back in Lutzmannsburg, mowing lawns and painting window frames.

TRIESTE: In Winston Churchill's description, this Italian port on the Adriatic was the southern end of the Iron Curtain. Trieste became a Cold War flashpoint when Yugoslavia claimed it after World War II. But the dispute was settled in 1954, Yugoslavia left the Soviet bloc, and the frontier at Trieste is largely unfenced. Thousands of Yugoslavs travel to Trieste to work or shop, while Triestinis own summer houses on Yugoslavia's Istrian Peninsula. Europe's ideological divide finishes at Muggia, the Venetian quarter of Trieste. An Italian customs officer is puzzled by visitors coming now looking for the place where the Iron Curtain ends. ``Iron Curtain?'' he says. ``There's no Iron Curtain here.'' And so it is, all the way from the Adriatic to the Baltic.

DOC.HEAD: The Iron Curtain and Winston Churchill
With BC-Iron Curtain Journey, b0740-b0741
DOC.TEXT: ``From Stettin in the Baltic to Trieste in the Adriatic an iron curtain has descended across the continent.'' So declared Winston Churchill on March 5, 1946, in a speech to Westminster College in Fulton, Mo. ``Behind that line lie all the capitals of the ancient states of Central and Eastern Europe,'' he said. The wartime British prime minister had it almost right: as things later turned out, the Iron Curtain started at the West German port of Travemuende on the Baltic Sea, about 150 miles west of the Polish port of Stettin. In 1946, the division of Germany into separate states was not yet envisaged. Stettin, now Szczecin, lies near what is today the eastern border of East Germany. Churchill did not coin the term ``Iron Curtain.'' A British newspaper had used it the year before to define Europe's post-World War II ideological divide. But it was Churchill's speech that popularized it as an image of the Cold War.

DOC.HEAD: Bias Complaints Surround System for Resolving Stock Disputes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto, Graphic planned
DOC.TEXT: M.K. ``Pete'' Peterson trusted his stockbroker. He says that was his mistake. The 70-year-old retired corporate executive claims that in April 1987, on his broker's advice, he entered into a series of complicated transactions that depended on a stock price rising. It didn't. The October '87 market crash left Peterson with $800,000 in losses from speculative trades in sophisticated securities with fancy names like ``naked puts'' and ``margin calls.'' Now the Dallas millionaire wants his money back. Peterson has taken his case to arbitration, the out-of-court forum where Wall Street firms require customers to resolve disputes with brokers. But like many disgruntled investors whose savings are squandered through naivete, bad judgment or broker incompetence, Peterson contends he cannot get a fair hearing because the arbitration system favors the industry. ``My life's about over but I've got one more battle to fight and I'm going to win it,'' said Peterson, who claims the case has cost him about $2 million in trading losses, taxes, legal fees and other expenses _ about half his net worth. Arbitration has come under increased scrutiny since the Supreme Court last May upheld the constitutionality of contracts that require brokerage customers to settle grievances before a hearing panel rather than in court. Opponents claim arbitration is biased because it is run by the nation's stock exchanges and other self-regulatory bodies and because panels contain an industry representative. Proponents say it is quicker and faster than litigation and investors do just as well in recovering losses. The Securities and Exchange Commission last year approved reforms designed to remove secrecy surrounding the process and ease what advocates of arbitration say is an unfounded image of anti-customer bias. ``Arbitrators are deciding the case, not some board of directors of a stock exchange,'' said Theodore A. Krebsbach, director of litigation for the Wall Street firm Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``It's a perception thing, not a reality.'' Unlike litigation, arbitration panels make decisions based on information presented, without complex rules of evidence. Arbitrators do not have to explain decisions and appeals are limited. Panels usually consist of one securities industry representative and two arbitrators representing the public. ``The worst thing is having a cadre of retired brokers and managers _ people who depended on the industry for ideas and money for years _ sitting in judgment on people who have been ripped off by brokers,'' said Robert Dyer, an Orlando, Fla., lawyer who handles securities arbitration cases. Because of the key Supreme Court ruling and the bull market followed by huge investor losses in the crash, arbitration claims have surged. A total of 6,101 cases was filed in 1988, vs. 830 in 1980. Industry figures show investors won 51 percent of the 3,731 cases decided in 1986-88. Of 102 rulings in a three-month period last year, victorious plaintiffs recovered about half of the losses they claimed, according to a study by Securities Arbitration Commentator, a Maplewood, N.J., newsletter. But if pre-arbitration settlements are included, industry officials estimate about 75 percent of grievances result in some monetary award _ high by legal standards. While customers such as Peterson have resources to fight, others are not as fortunate. A divorced New Jersey teacher who lost $100,000 in the crash claimed that trading by her Shearson broker was irresponsible and unsuitable. She sought $357,441.84 in losses and damages. She got nothing. Others do well by the process. A divorced Los Angeles mother recently won $403,000 in a case alleging inappropriate investments by her PaineWebber Inc. broker. In a rare punitive damage award, arbitrators also ordered the firm to pay her $100,000 and the broker to pay $50,000. But because arbitration panels do not have to issue written opinions, it is difficult to determine the basis for decisions. Prior to last May, the self-regulatory groups were not even required to disclose arbitration awards. The New York Stock Exchange and National Association of Securities Dealers handle about 90 percent of the nation's arbitrations, with the rest occurring at smaller exchanges. Brokerages own and control the self-regulatory groups. Partly because of the bias perception, the Securities Industry Conference on Arbitration last year required that customer contracts highlight arbitration clauses, formerly buried in fine print. Exchanges also limited independent arbitrators' ties to Wall Street. But lawyers want more choice in deciding who sits on arbitration panels, a larger pool of arbitrators to choose from, mandatory written opinions and the right to substitute an independent arbitrator for the industry panelist. ``I want someone who is more representative of my client than someone who is more representative of the types of people we're suing,'' said New York lawyer Theodore Eppenstein, who unsuccessfully argued the Supreme Court case involving arbitration contracts. Last week, the self-regulatory bodies agreed to study a proposal by the Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's main trade group, to remove arbitration from industry auspices to an independent forum, such as the American Arbitration Association. Stock exchange officials defend the current system and see no need to replace it, even though arbitration programs are costly. For example, the NASD said it spent $7.09 million on arbitration in 1987-88, recovering just $1.34 million in fees. Arbitration's backers say that adding written opinions and appeals will make arbitration resemble litigation _ more expensive and drawn-out for everyone, defeating the purpose. Lawyers, they say, prefer court because they can make more money. ``It probably gets down to economics,'' said Edward W. Morris Jr., the NYSE's arbitration director. ``Legal fees are less in arbitration.'' Exchange officials maintain that industry panelists are tougher on their counterparts because they are concerned about preserving ethical standards. Having an ``expert'' also helps decipher complex cases, they say. ``The people who serve on these panels ... do so because they feel very strongly about the integrity of the industry,'' said Scott Noah, assistant general counsel for the American Stock Exchange. Pete Peterson would disagree. The investor claims the arbitrators hearing his case laughed and talked during testimony by one witness. Hearing transcripts show one panel member told Peterson he did not like his personality and another asked why he was so foolish to trust his broker. Peterson claims the broker embarked on a too-risky strategy and ignored repeated instructions to bail out and cut his losses. Bruce Collins, an attorney for the brokerage, Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc., said Peterson was a savvy investor who agreed to the transactions and simply took a beating. The firm denies wrongdoing. Collins claimed Peterson _ who has hired a public relations firm, written protests to the NYSE, Congress and the SEC, and paid for an outside study of his case _ is challenging the arbitration panel because he fears he will lose. Merits aside, the Peterson case shows that investors unhappy with arbitration do not have alternatives. Some lawyers say the lack of choice and flaws in the process subvert investor protection intended by Depression-era securities laws. ``Stockbrokers say `Trust us with your money, you're in good hands with us,''' said William F. Davis, a Los Angeles lawyer. ``Then when you lose it they say, `That's the breaks.'''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Jan. 21

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Key Events in Bush's First Year
With BC-Bush's First Year, b0730 of Jan. 16
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of key events in the first 12 months of George Bush's presidency: Jan. 20, 1989: Bush takes the oath of office as the 41st president. Feb. 6, 1989: Bush unveils a proposal to rescue the nation's savings and loan industry from billions in losses. Feb. 9: Bush proposes major revisions in the last Reagan budget, addresses Congress. Feb. 23-27: Bush attends the funeral of Japanese Emperor Hirohito and visits Beijing, China, and Seoul, South Korea, the first of 15 foreign capitals he visits this year. March 9: Senate rejects the nomination of former Texas Sen. John Tower as defense secretary; Bush nominates Dick Cheney to the post the next day. March 24: The catastrophic Exxon oil spill in the Gulf of Valdez; four days later, Bush dispatches Transportation Secretary Sam Skinner to Alaska to survey damage. April 5: Bush sends Congress the ``Educational Excellence Act of 1989,'' boosting federal school funds by $441 million to promote public school choice, magnet schools and other programs. April 14: Bush and congressional leaders agree on a deal to reduce the fiscal 1990 budget deficit. April 18: Bush signs legislation implementing a bipartisan accord with Congress on Central America. May 11: Bush recalls the U.S. ambassador from Panama after Manuel Noriega throws out election results. May 12: Bush, in a speech at Texas A&M University, unveils his vision for a new relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union. May 15: Bush calls for new anti-crime measures, including mandatory sentences for firearms offenses and a major expansion of federal prison capacity. May 26-June 2: Bush unveils surprise plan for major reduction in conventional forces in Europe during NATO summit in Brussels; also visits Italy, Germany and Britain. June 3: Bush ``deeply deplores'' the brutal Chinese crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square; two days later he orders sanctions. A few weeks later he sends National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft on a secret mission to Beijing. June 12: Bush unveils major revisions to the Clean Air Act, pledges drastic reductions in urban smog by the turn of the century. June 13: Bush vetoes a bill raising the minimum wage from $3.35 to $4.55 an hour, 30 cents more than he wanted. June 22: Bush launches a ``Points of Light Initiative'' to encourage all Americans to volunteer for community service. June 27: Bush says he will press for a constitutional amendment to ban flag desecration. June 29: Bush proposes limits on political action committees sponsored by corporations, unions or trade associations. July 7: Bush proposes a 25 percent pay raise for members of Congress, judges and senior government officials, coupled with a ban on speech fees for lawmakers. July 9-18: Bush visits Warsaw and Gdansk, Poland, and Budapest, Hungary, promising help for their shift to democracy; also attends French bicentennial celebrations and the economic summit in Paris and visits the Netherlands. July 20: Bush marks the 20th anniversary of man's landing on the moon by calling for a return to the moon and, in the next century, to Mars and beyond. July 26: Bush signs legislation decontrolling natural gas prices. July 31: Bush cuts short a speaking trip after terrorists allegedly hanged Marine Lt. Col. William R. Higgins, a hostage in Lebanon. Four days later, after a flurry of diplomatic maneuvers, the terrorists lift an execution threat against a second hostage, Joseph J. Cicippio. Aug. 9: Bush signs the savings and loan rescue bill. Aug. 19-Sept. 5: Bush vacations in Kennebunkport, Maine. He goes fishless until the next to last day. Sept. 5: Bush unveils his national drug strategy in televised address to nation. Sept. 21: Bush sends U.S. marshals to the Virgin Islands to help restore order after post-Hurricane Hugo rioting. Sept. 27-28: Bush holds education summit with governors in Charlottesville, Va., agrees to set school performance goals. Sept. 29: Bush visits South Carolina to see the damage from Hurricane Hugo. Oct. 3: Bush authorizes roadblocks and air cover for coup against Noriega that fails. Oct. 20: Bush tours earthquake damage in Oakland and Santa Cruz, Calif. Oct. 26: Bush confers ``most favored nation'' trade status on Hungary. Oct. 27-28: Bush attends the Western Hemisphere summit on democracy in Costa Rica, derides Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega as ``this little man.'' Oct. 31: Bush announces Malta meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Nov. 9: Bush offers low-key reaction to fall of Berlin Wall, saying, ``I am not an emotional kind of guy.'' Nov. 10: Bush unveils proposals to spur home ownership, aid the homeless. Nov. 13: Bush presents the Presidential Medal of Freedom to Solidarity's Lech Walesa. Nov. 22: Bush begins naming daily ``points of light'' to underscore his support of volunteerism. Dec. 1: Bush authorizes U.S. military aid to help Philippine President Corazon Aqunio put down a coup. Dec. 2-3: Bush meets off Malta in a storm-tossed summit with Gorbachev. Dec. 4: Bush draws plaudits from NATO allies in Brussels on the summit. Dec. 8-10: Bush sends Scowcroft on second mission to China. Dec. 20: U.S. troops invade Panama, topple Noriega regime. Dec. 24: Noriega seeks refuge in Vatican Embassy. Jan. 3, 1990: Noriega surrenders to U.S. authorities, is flown to Miami to stand trial on drug-trafficking charges.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Jan. 21

DOC.HEAD: Ancient Industries Found in Vast Complex of Man-made Caves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to correct release date
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Not far from the site where David fought Goliath, archaeologists are peeling the mystery away from a vast industrial complex in a network of artificial caves dating back at least 2,700 years. Maresha, the likely birthplace of King Herod, flourished as a commercial center of about 5,000 people, said archaeologist Amos Kloner. Unique among the ancient cities, Mareshites established their industry underground. They raised pigeons, manufactured olive oil, stabled horses, collected rainwater and buried their dead in underground chambers chiseled from soft chalk limestone. Kloner, who has spent 15 years excavating and mapping the network of more than 1,000 interlocking chambers, said the caves were in continuous use from at least the 8th century B.C. until 40 B.C. when Maresha was overrun by Parthians from ancient Armenia. Why they invested so heavily in underground development is still a puzzle, especially since there are no natural caves in the region. Kloner, of the state Antiquities Authority, suggests the reason may have been simple practicality. The caves were apparently created when the ancients quarried stones to build a hilltop fortress and surrounding houses, he said. ``Maybe it was easier to use such chambers since the walls and roof were already in place.'' The lifestyle, especially during the pagan Hellenistic period when Maresha reached its peak a few centuries B.C., is becoming clearer. Teams have unearthed a fortress tower, ordinary houses, thousands of pottery vessels, figurines, a horde of silver coins and an almost perfectly preserved olive oil factory. ``As far as the Hellenistic period is concerned, there is no site more important,'' Kloner said. Particularly important are silver coins, the newest of which were dated 112 B.C. and found in a house above one of the cave systems. Kloner said the date confirmed Jewish sources about the conquest of the city by John Hyrcanus I, who forced the Edomites to convert to Judaism. Pointing to an inscription found in a series of gabled burial chambers, Kloner translated the Greek: ``The bones of Beretanu and Appolonius, the sons of Antipater.'' A later Antipater was the father of Herod the Great, and the name in Maresha may be further proof of Herod's origins here, he said. Most figurines and other remains in the burial chamber were looted during the 1970s. In addition to the theft problem, the caves are dangerous, and are officially closed to the public. The hilly terrain is punctured with open pits from collapsed chambers, some concealed by overgrowth. The caves have no lights and in recent years, three spelunkers have been killed and a dozen injured. The Jewish National Fund plans to open the site to the public by next year after the government spends about $1 million to make the site safe. The caves, in the Judean foothills 30 miles southwest of Jerusalem, are along a highway built on a Roman road that passes Crusader ruins and the grassy fields of Shephela where David the Israelite defeated the Philistine champion Goliath. That confrontation was about the same time Maresha is first mentioned as an inheritance of the Tribe of Judah in the Bible (Joshua 15:44). The most visually stunning finds are the olive oil works, where giant stone crushers, weights and storage chambers are virtually undamaged. The only things missing are the giant wooden beams used to squeeze the olive mash. The oil was drained along channels cut in the floor to a collection pit that could store 5,000 gallons. There are about 70 such factories in the caves, and Kloner estimated nearly half the oil, used for heating and lamps, was exported. Another cave contains 1,900 holes the size and shape of modern loaves of bread and which housed thousands of pigeons. In fact, some contemporary birds have sneaked in and can be heard cooing. Underneath are 2-yard-high trenches Kloner said were used to collect the droppings for fertilizing crops. ``Even today, pigeon manure is considered by farmers to be the best,'' he said, adding that pigeons were also raised for meat and exported.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Jan. 22
