DOC.HEAD: 55 Percent of Scientists Give Frog Dissection Thumbs Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT that girl was from Los Angeles area sted San Francisco area
DOC.TEXT: Researchers are jumpy about the practice of dissecting frogs in biology class, and would like the practice excised from curriculums. Out of 365 letters to Research and Development magazine in response to an October editorial, 55 percent supported a statement that dissection should not be required in high school biology, 40 percent said it should be required, and 5 percent were undecided, said Robert Cassidy, editor-in-chief. ``The results are surprising in that we expected more scientists and researchers to favor dissection of frogs in biology classes,'' Cassidy said. The poll wasn't scientific because the comments were voluntary, he said. The issue of frog dissection gained national attention in 1987 after a Los Angeles-area girl refused to participate, citing moral beliefs. The case led to a 1989 California law allowing students to refuse to dissect animals. A case also cropped up last year in New Jersey, where a girl cited religious beliefs. The Animal Legal Defense Fund, which estimates that 5.7 million animals are killed each year for dissection in colleges and high schools, also has begun a campaign to inform students about their right to refuse to dissect animals. In the survey, scientists who were against dissection wrote that students don't really learn anything from the practice, that it's inhumane and that it does not foster a good education, Cassidy said. ``The fact that these people took the time to write is telling. I mean, they took office polls and everything. Some told of their own personal experiences ... how humiliating it was.'' One high school graduate who survived worm, grasshopper and frog dissections said she doesn't understand what all the fuss is about. ``When I did it in high school, it wasn't this huge issue like it is now,'' said Cynthia Lu, a student at John Marshall Law School in Chicago. ``You did it and didn't question it. ``I didn't have too many problems with it _ the frog was already dead.'' Research and Development, based in Des Plaines, is a worldwide publication for scientists and decision-makers in the research industry.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Jan. 22

DOC.TEXT: Inflation increased modestly in 1989 to an 8-year high of 4.6 percent, boosted by double-digit price increases for dairy food, eggs, tobacco and fuel oil, the government said. In December, consumer prices climbed a moderate 0.4 percent despite a sharp rise in fuel oil costs during the holiday cold snap, the Labor Department reported Thursday. Economists attributed the relative stability of consumer price increases to the Federal Reserve's tight money policy. Consumer prices rose 4.4 percent in 1988.

The White House broke with its usual practice of not commenting on Federal Reserve policy by suggesting that cuts in interest rates ``are justified'' by current economic conditions. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Thursday that the Jan. 8 reduction in the prime rate by banks, to 10 percent from 10.5 percent, ``hasn't been totally passed through'' and that the administration hoped it would be. Bond prices, meanwhile, tumbled amid increasing fears of inflation, dimmed prospects for lower interest rates and a growing belief that the economy has hit bottom.

Housing starts slumped in 1989 to their lowest level since the 1982 recession, the government said, but many analysts looked for further drops in mortgage rates to improve the situation in 1990. ``The drop in December housing starts is primarily due to severe weather in most of the nation last month,'' John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, said Thursday. The frigid weather pushed December starts to their lowest monthly level since October 1982, which in turn contributed to the year's downturn.

French chemical giant Rhone-Poulenc SA has agreed to merge its pharmaceutical business with Rorer Group Inc. in the latest drug industry deal that seeks to lower research costs and gain global market reach. The two companies announced Thursday that Rhone-Poulenc would contribute nearly all of its worldwide pharmaceutical operations to Rorer in exchange for 68 percent of the new company's stock. The remaining stock would be offered to shareholders in Rorer, best known for its Maalox antacid. The deal, estimated to be worth about $3 billion, would produce one of the world's 10 biggest pharmaceutical companies in terms of sales and the second biggest in Europe, the companies said.

Some suppliers for Campeau Corp.'s U.S. retailers said they are sending out new merchandise, clearing the first obstacle analysts said the stores face under bankruptcy court protection. But many suppliers said Thursday that before shipping, they want to see a court-approved financial plan expected this week from Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. ``I am planning and hoping to ship to them. I'm waiting to hear some more news,'' said Howard Bloom, president of Chetta B, a New York clothing maker.

In another sign of the unsettled conditions in the book business, Nancy Evans resigned after three years as president and publisher of Doubleday, a leading publisher of general interest books. Ms. Evans, a former editor in chief of Book-of-the-Month Club for what now is Time Warner Inc., was credited with revitalizing Doubleday in the wake of its acquisition in late 1986 by Bertelsmann AG of West Germany. She is being succeeded by Stephen Rubin, the publisher and editor in chief of adult fiction and nonfiction at Bantam Books, a sister division to Doubleday, it was announced Thursday.

Most of the benefits from cutting capital-gains taxes would go to people who report gains year after year, not those whose incomes are boosted once in a lifetime by the sale of a family farm or business, congressional analysts said. The report released Thursday by the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation rebuts a key Bush administration argument for the reduction and provides new evidence for Democrats who view a capital-gains cut as a windfall for the rich. The analysis found that 58.9 percent of the gains recorded in a 5-year period were reported by people who had gains every year.

Health Secretary Louis Sullivan condemned R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co.'s plans to test-market a cigarette aimed primarily at blacks and said the company is promoting ``a culture of cancer.'' The nation's top health official called on the company Thursday to cancel its plans to market the new ``Uptown'' cigarette on a trial basis in Philadelphia beginning Feb. 5. Sullivan described the company's marketing plan as ``slick and sinister.''

A major consumer group asked the Federal Communications Commission to investigate this week's outage on the AT&T long-distance network as the company said it intends to offer customers nine hours of discount calling to make amends. American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said Thursday it asked the FCC for permission to charge cheaper, holiday rates from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Feb. 14 _ Valentine's Day. But the Consumer Federation of America said that wasn't good enough. It asked the FCC to probe whether Monday's problems were caused by AT&T cutting corners to maximize profits under a new incentive-based regulatory plan.

Stock prices were widely mixed Thursday amid uneasiness over weak corporate earnings and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 7.25 points to 2,666.38. The dollar rose sharply against key foreign currencies. Gold prices declined after gaining overseas. Bond prices tumbled. Wheat futures prices dropped and cattle futures climbed; orange juice futures fell sharply; most oil futures rose; and precious metals retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Freezes Broker Accounts of Four Accused of Insider Trading
DOC.TEXT: The brokerage accounts of three foreign companies and a Swiss investor accused of insider trading of Rorer Group Inc. stock have been frozen, federal securities regulators say. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Thursday that it had obtained a court order in New York on Wednesday to freeze the accounts pending a hearing later this month. The defendants named in the SEC complaint were: Fondation Hai, of Monte Carlo, Monaco; Holding Protection Ltd., Athens, Greece; Unifund SAL, located in Kasslik, Lebanon; and Robert Rossi of Geneva, Switzerland. The SEC charged the four with trading on inside information about merger talks between Rorer, a Fort Washington, Pa., pharmaceutical company, and an unidentified company. Later Thursday, Rorer Group said it had agreed in principle to sell 68 percent of its stock to France's Rhone-Poulenc SA for a package of cash and securities anticipated to be worth about $73 a share. The SEC said it had evidence that the defendants allegedly bought Rorer common stock and call option contracts ``while in possession of material non-public information concerning negotiations for the acquisition of a controlling interest in Rorer by a European company at a substantial premium over the market price.'' The SEC claimed the defendants stood to make $6 million from those trades. Neither Rorer nor the European suitor was accused of any wrongdoing. Gary Sundick, an SEC attorney in Washington, would not disclose how the defendants allegedly obtained the inside information, saying it was not part of the public record. The SEC complaint claimed the alleged insider trading took place between Jan. 4 and Monday, when Rorer disclosed negotiations were under way. The SEC also alleged that ``certain unknown purchasers'' bought Rorer option contracts and common stock through financial institutions in Zurich, Geneva and Lausanne in Switzerland. The banks and brokerage houses also were not accused of wrongdoing. The court order, signed by U.S. District Judge Robert J. Ward, freezes the brokerage accounts of the named defendants and the Rorer-related assets of the unidentified defendants pending a hearing Jan. 30. At that hearing, before Judge Shirley Wohl Kram, the SEC will seek a preliminary injunction. The SEC also wants the defendants to disgorge $6 million in alleged illegal profits and pay fines totaling three times that amount. Sundick said he did not know who was representing the defendants in this country. Ward's order Wednesday was a move sought unilaterally by the SEC, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Study of Stock Trading To Be Reviewed Next Week
DOC.TEXT: New York Stock Exchange President Richard Grasso plans to comment on a study of stock trading by the Office of Technology Assessment when the congressional think tank meets next week. Grasso is part of a blue ribbon panel convened by OTA to review its study of information technology in the securities markets. The panel is slated to meet Monday to review a draft report. Published reports in The Wall Street Journal and USA Today this week have indicated the study, in the works for the last 18 months, is critical of the NYSE's specialist system of trading, in which stock can only be traded through certain designated exchange members who are charged with maintaining an orderly market in that security _ even if it means buying or selling the stock because no other takers can be found. Spokesmen for various organizations in New York and Washington declined to comment on the reports or said they had not seen the study. A spokeswoman for the NYSE, Sharon Gamsin, said the study is not complete yet. ``We will comment on the final study study when their report is issued,'' she said. Jean McDonald, a spokeswoman for OTA, an arm of Congress that analyzes science and technology and its potential impact, said the study was requested in June 1988 by the House Energy and Commerce Committee, headed by Rep. John D. Dingell, D-Mich. A spokesman for the committee said he hadn't seen a final copy of the draft and couldn't comment on what action, if any, Congress might take. The study was an outgrowth of the 1987 stock market crash. Critics claimed the selloff was worsened by computer-driven program trading. A draft of the OTA study is to be reviewed Monday in Washington by a panel that includes market professionals, regulators, academics, bankers and others. The final report will be submitted to a 12-member congressional board _ equally divided between Democrats and Republicans, House and Senate members _ which oversees the OTA. If approved by the board, the study will be released to the public, said Ms. McDonald. ``We do not make any recommendations,'' she said. ``We lay out the various policy options.''

DOC.HEAD: Unique Middlemen Pass Judgment on Retailers' Risks
DOC.TEXT: As Campeau Corp. gradually lost its footing last year, a unique group of financial middlemen that helps keep department store shelves stocked demonstrated the powerful role it plays in retailing. These middlemen, known as factors, told several apparel manufacturers they wouldn't step in to accept the credit risk of Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc., Campeau's American retailing arms. The snub didn't push Allied and Federated over the brink and into bankruptcy court. But by raising the prospect of bare shelves, the move by factors may have nudged the Campeau divisions in that direction. Without the faith of the factoring and credit community, the nine Allied and Federated chains from New York-based Bloomingdale's to The Bon Marche in Seattle were in danger of losing face in the industry. Factoring companies have significant power in the apparel industry, which supplies merchandise that accounts for the bulk of sales at many department stores. Their relationship with manufacturers is closer than that between traditional credit rating agencies or bill collectors and clients. Like credit agencies, factors advise clothing makers whether it's wise to deal with a particular retailer. But in addition, factors assume the credit risk of retailers for manufacturers and advance loans to apparel makers, as well as performing much of their bookkeepping work. ``To a certain extent, we're a special breed,'' said Francis X. Basile, chairman and chief executive officer of the country's largest factoring company, CIT Group-Factoring Inc., a subsidiary of Manufacturers Hanover Corp. and Japan's Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. Factoring is a long established but little understood occupation. The practice probably goes back to antiquity but its modern evolution in this country began in colonial times when agents known as ``factors'' were hired to service mills in England and Europe. It started as a service at the wholesale end of the distribution chain, involving fabrics sold by textile mills to manufacturers, and evolved to include goods sold by manufacturers to retailers. A factor buys a manufacturer's accounts receivables and assumes the risks that those bills will be paid. If a retailer doesn't come through with the money for an order of women's dresses, for instance, a factor still has to pay its client, the dress maker. The factoring fee averages about 1 percent of the volume of the receivables. Factors play a key role in the garment trade because the industry is dominated by small to medium-sized companies that can't afford to assume credit risks themselves. Because they're putting their money on the line, factors don't want their clients to accept orders from shaky retailers. But factors can't be too conservative. Their clients need to sell and could find others more eager for their business. Basile said he tells his staff: ``Be liberal but don't get stuck.'' Factors also will allow clients to draw advances against the receivables, giving them cash to manufacture pending orders. Factors charge interest on advances outstanding. ``The well-run, the intelligent factor is going to tailor-make an arrangement for its clients or potential clients,'' Basile said. ``The uniqueness of what we do allows us some latitude in structuring deals and helping clients.'' Factoring companies also perform all the bookkeeping tasks for some of their clients, essentially becoming a client's credit department. Factoring has had an image problem, and some outsiders confuse them with lenders who charge excessive interest. Basile, who has been in factoring and commercial finance for more than 30 years, said when he was new to the business he was told that companies that used factors were a step away from bankruptcy _ a notion he rejects. ``The fact of the matter is we have among our clients ... companies that are the Rock of Gibralter financially,'' he said. Still, some companies prefer not to disclose that they use factors, making it impossible to gauge how much merchandise in stores is factored. Industry estimates range as high as 70 percent. The volume of receivables factored in the apparel industry was nearly $45 billion in 1988, according to figures compiled by the textile and apparel trade publication Daily News Record. Although largely confined to the textile and apparel trades, factors are active in footwear and home furnishings. The Trust Company Bank in Atlanta also handles factoring in seafood and trucking. ``We have tried to spread our tentacles. There's no reason why many businesses can't be factored,'' Basile said. ``I think that we have trouble getting into certain businesses because we have an undeserved reputation.'' Factors once were small independent outfits until banks started acquiring them. Basile said a factor doing $2.5 billion in annual volume was a giant in 1980. CIT's volume last year was about $7.5 billion. Some banks in recent years have withdrawn from factoring and sold out to others. In the past 10 years the number of factors has been halved, with about 15 to 18 left.

DOC.HEAD: Confident Suppliers Resume Shipments to Campeau Stores
DOC.TEXT: Some suppliers for Campeau Corp.'s U.S. department stores say they've resumed shipping merchandise despite being unable to cash checks the retailers issued shortly before seeking bankruptcy court protection. Analysts had called the resumption of normal shipments the most pressing issue for the stores under Chapter 11 protection, especially for stores in the South, where the spring selling season opens soon. ``Right now, we're not asking anything from them except to honor the normal conditions of business,'' said David Pergola, senior vice president for sales at the Greif Cos., which began shipping clothing Thursday to Campeau's stores. ``We are confident that by the weekend, fresh spring merchandise will be going out to all of Campeau's stores,'' said Bernard Chaus, whose Bernard Chaus Inc. sold the stores $40 million in clothing last year. Chaus said his company hadn't been able to cash some checks Federated issued before Monday because the bankruptcy court had frozen the retailer's bank account. Many suppliers, however, said they want to see a court-approved financial plan expected this week from Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. before shipping goods. ``I am planning and hoping to ship to them. I'm waiting to hear some more news,'' said Howard Bloom, president of Chetta B, a New York clothing maker. ``I'd hate to ship now and not get paid. I'd look like a fool.'' Meanwhile Thursday, Campeau spokeswoman Carol Sanger said the company doesn't plan to sell assets to satisfy the debts of Federated or Allied. ``The company has no intent to conduct a fire sale,'' she said. ``We are not talking about a liquidation, we are talking about restructuring a corporation.'' Federated and Allied, which own such department store chains as Bloomingdale's, Lazarus and Rich's, filed for protection from their creditors Monday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The chains, with 258 stores and 100,000 employees in 43 states, listed debts of $7.7 billion and assets of $9.1 billion. Department stores risk losing customers if they can't offer fresh merchandise or if their shelves begin to show gaps from lack of inventory. ``The question is, are all vendors going to go along with that, be comfortable doing that, and that is a hard call,'' Jack Seibald, a retail analyst for Salomon Bros. in New York, said of the prospect for renewed shipments. ``My guess is the bigger ones will go ahead.'' Parfums Stern Inc., a cosmetics maker, Movado Watch Corp. and Lenox China said they haven't decided when to resume shipments. Fred Kalmar, vice president for finance at Bugle Boy Industries, said the clothing company has been promised a report on Campeau's financing this week. ``We do plan to support the Campeau stores,'' Kalmar said. Liz Claiborne spokeswoman Sarah Patterson said the company has clothing shipments prepared but is waiting for a financial plan Campeau promised to provide by Friday. Liz Claiborne tops the lists of unsecured creditors for many of the Federated and Allied stores, with the bankruptcy filing listing millions of dollars in debts. Ms. Patterson said the company didn't know how much the stores owe. Leslie Fay, a sportswear maker, began shipping orders to Campeau's stores Thursday, said senior vice president Herman Gordon. He estimated the stores' outstanding account with Leslie Fay at ``a couple of million dollars,'' but said he was confident of repayment. ``We are going to be shipping to them on the regular terms we have always dealt with,'' Gordon said.

DOC.HEAD: Some Former Executives to Lose Big Pensions
With PM-Campeau, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Chapter 11 filing by Campeau Corp.'s retailing divisions could cost some former top executives retirement benefits totaling as much as $10 million. About 525 former executives of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. are in that group. They account for less than 2 percent of Federated's 25,000 retirees nationwide, but their claims are the largest and the least likely to be fully paid. ``We're talking about executives with six- or seven-figure incomes, not widows and orphans,'' Campeau spokeswoman Carol Sanger said. Campeau, the real estate company owned by Canadian Robert Campeau that acquired Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988, put its U.S. retail operations under bankruptcy protection Monday as a way to keep the 258 affected department stores operating. The stores are profitable, but Campeau owes about $7.7 billion largely because of the high cost of financing the acquisitions. ``It seems somehow wrong that people who worked hard for many years are now victims of Mr. Campeau's takeover,'' said James Selonick, a former Federated vice president. ``Our money, which is a good many million dollars, is being used to bail out Federated, and I think that's unreasonable.'' Selonick and other former executives are listed among Federated's creditors in 6,000 pages of bankruptcy documents the company filed. Most of those losing their pensions will be senior executives who took part in senior employee retirement plans and deferred compensation plans or who had signed individual employment agreements. Others are executives who worked for Federated before 1953, when its current pension plans were established. The former employees' pre-1953 benefits are not protected from the bankruptcy. All other pensions, life insurance, and medical benefits paid by Federated are protected under bankruptcy proceedings, Ms. Sanger said. The bankruptcy filings listed 25 Federated executives who will lose an undetermined amount of benefits from individual employment agreements they had signed. Retirees who signed such agreements typically earned $100,000 to $1 million a year. ``Those things are not protected in a trust because they were individually negotiated and the payments stop in a Chapter 11,'' Ms. Sanger said.

DOC.HEAD: American Expands European Service, But Cuts Some Cities
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines said it was boosting its European service overall but delaying some new services and cutting certain existing routes because it doesn't have enough airplanes. In addition to London routes gained in recent deals with TWA and Texas Air Corp., American said Thursday it would add nonstop flights from Chicago to Glasgow, Scotland, and to Munich and Dusseldorf in West Germany. The expansion gives the Fort Worth-based carrier 145 flights a week to Europe, a 22 percent increase. ``We believe the restructuring will make us a stronger, more vibrant competitor in the European market place,'' said Mike Buckman, vice president of sales. ``We're determined to make American the leading U.S. carrier in the European market.'' Analyst Mark Daugherty with Dean Witter Reynolds said the move ``just underscores their aggressive ambitions to secure and implement U.S.-European service prior to 1992,'' when Europe hopes to abolish most internal trade barriers. American also announced it has applied to the U.S. Department of Transportation for six routes between the United States and Japan. The routes are: Chicago-Tokyo, Chicago-Nagoya, Los Angeles-Tokyo, Los Angeles-Nagoya, San Jose-Tokyo and San Jose-Nagoya. With the European expansion, Buckman said international operations will amount to about 15 percent of the carrier's business. In separate deals last month, American, the nation's biggest domestic carrier, bought the Chicago-to-London route authority of Trans World Airlines Inc. and the Miami-to-London route flown by Texas Air's Continental Airlines. The Continental route was a small part of an overall $471 million deal with Texas Air to buy the Latin American routes and some other assets of Eastern Airlines. Federal authorities still must approve those deals. Pan American World Airways has challenged the Eastern deal. While boosting European service overall, American will drop current non-stop service to Frankfurt and Lyon, France, from New York, and cease one-stop flights to Stuttgart and Hamburg, West Germany, and Geneva, Switzerland. American also is delaying previously announced plans to fly from Chicago to Helsinki, Finland, and Warsaw, Poland, and from Dallas-Fort Worth to Barcelona, Spain. ``We're anxious to service those cities,'' Buckman said, but ``we don't have the long-range, `over water' aircraft required.''

DOC.HEAD: FBI Conducts Raids in 15 States
DOC.TEXT: FBI raids in 15 states targeted producers of counterfeit automotive parts, which automakers say cost them millions of dollars and may pose safety threats. No indictments have been issued and no arrests have been made, FBI spokesman John Anthony said Thursday. He said agents were tallying the number and value of the confiscated parts, expected to be in the millions of dollars. The raids came after 2{ years of undercover investigation into counterfeit parts. General Motors Corp. said that according to a Federal Trade Commission study, consumers spend about $3 billion yearly on fake auto parts. Richard Sherman, general director for U.S. sales and marketing in GM's Service Parts Operations, said the company had found dangerous parts carrying the GM label, including brake linings made of cardboard and oil filters made of rags and a perforated food can. ``We have no problem with legitimate manufacturers of quality auto parts,'' said Kenneth Myers, marketing manager for Ford Motor Co.'s Parts and Service Division. ``We have a big problem, however, with manufacturers and distributors of poor quality, unsafe and defective parts who wrongfully try to market their products as genuine Ford parts,'' he said. The FBI conducted raids in California, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia and Washington, Anthony said.

DOC.HEAD: Corporation Asks Addition of Former FHLBB Chairman as Defendant
DOC.TEXT: The nation's former top thrift regulator joined with his subordinates in a vendetta against Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, the former holding company for the thrift alleges in a U.S. District Court filing. Attorneys for Phoenix-based American Continental Corp. on Thursday asked Judge Richard M. Bilby to add Edwin Gray, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, as a defendant in the holding company's suit against current and former S&L regulators. The case is scheduled to go to trial March 27 in Tucson. Gray, currently an officer of Chase Federal Savings Bank in Miami, could not be reached for comment. Telephones went unanswered at the bank and his home. American Continental sued last spring, claiming that regulators had undercut its efforts to save Lincoln, a $6 billion thrift headquartered in Irvine, Calif. The filing came after American Continental filed for reorganization under federal bankruptcy laws on April 13 and the government seized Lincoln, the holding company's chief asset, on April 14. The government bailout is expected to cost at least $2 billion in taxpayer money. American Continental also is suing in a federal court in Washington to overturn the government's seizure of Lincoln. Investors, meanwhile, are suing Lincoln in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Phoenix alleging the loss of $250 million on junk bonds purchased through the thrift. American Continental spokesman Bradley Boland said the company's motion to include Gray as a defendant alleges that Gray and others engaged in ``a pattern of leaking confidential, inaccurate and misleading information to the press.'' The pattern was systematic and done in retaliation for American Continental's criticism of re-regulation of the S&L industry, which Gray was promoting, Boland said in a news release. The release of information sullied the reputations of Lincoln and American Continental and damaged their business relationships, he said. Michael Gallagher, an attorney for American Continental, said the decision to include Gray as a defendant was based partially on testimony by Rosemary Stewart, a regulator for the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, before the House Banking Committee last year. Ms. Stewart, who worked for the now-defunct FHLBB under Gray, said she sensed a ``hidden agenda on the part of certain agency officials with regard to Lincoln.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Offers $1,000 To Employees Who Buy American Cars
DOC.TEXT: A company chairman grew tired of seeing foreign cars in his firm's parking lot, so he offered a bounty _ $1,000 to any employee who buys an American-made car or light truck. ``All it's got to be is an American label on an American-made car,'' said Peter Rossin, chairman of Dynamet Inc. in southwestern Pennsylvania. ``A Honda car made in Ohio doesn't qualify because the profits derived from that car go back to Japan.'' ``As I drive to work and park in the lot, I see a lot of foreign cars,'' he said. ``There are two products where there really is a major trade imbalance _ petroleum and cars _ and I can't do anything about petroleum.'' The offer is on a first-come, first-served basis, and 70 of the company's 350 employees will be eligible each year, said company spokesman Stephen Reese. An employee can participate in the plan once every five years. Any employee with at least six months experience at Dynamet can qualify for the bounty by providing proof of purchase and a copy of the car's title. ``It will be just like submitting an expense account,'' Reese said. The company manufactures titanium and nickel-based alloys for the aerospace and medical markets at its plants in Washington and nearby McMurray in suburban Pittsburgh. It also has a plant in Clearwater, Fla. Employees were notified late Wednesday of the incentive plan. One shift foreman, Sam Insana, said he planned to shop for a new pickup truck Thursday night. ``I echo the sentiments entirely,'' said Insana, who has worked at the Washington plant for 10 years. ``My wife will be pleased to hear about it.'' Rossin, 66, also sent letters to Chrysler, Ford and General Motors telling them about his offer. The auto companies hadn't received the letters by Thursday, but General Motors spokesman Ralph Kramer said the incentive isn't unprecedented. ``We occasionally hear about something like this,'' he said. ``From our viewpoint, anything that will prompt a customer to buy a domestic car can't help but do some good.'' Frank Joyce, a spokesman for the United Auto Workers, added, ``Most of our members would find that a welcome gesture.'' Rossin, who drives a Cadillac, said he was hoping his plan ``has a snowball effect and that other companies will participate. We get enough companies involved and we might make a dent in the trade imbalance. ``I'm just a big believer in America and I hate to see us take a back seat to anyone.''

DOC.HEAD: Rorer And Rhone-Poulenc Agree To Pursue Merging Pharmaceutical Businesses
DOC.TEXT: French chemical giant Rhone-Poulenc SA has agreed to merge its pharmaceutical business with Rorer Group Inc. in the latest drug industry deal that seeks to lower research costs and gain global market reach. The two companies announced Thursday that Rhone-Poulenc would contribute nearly all of its worldwide pharmaceutical operations to Rorer in exchange for 68 percent of the new company's stock. The remaining stock would be offered to shareholders in Rorer, which is best known for its Maalox antacid. Analysts estimated the deal would be worth about $3 billion. The new company would be one of the world's 10 biggest pharmaceutical companies in terms of sales and rank No. 2 in Europe, the companies said. ``Rorer will promote our aggressive entry into the two top world markets, the U.S. and Japan,'' said Jean-Rene Fourtou, Rhone-Poulenc's chairman and chief executive. ``Second, it moves us into the top 10 pharmaceutical companies and offers us the crtitical mass to achieve our long-term expansion plans.'' Rorer emphasized the companies still need to arrange financing and the proposed merger needs to win approval from their directors and stockholders. About 75 percent of Rhone-Poulenc is owned by the French government, according to Rorer spokesman Jeff Richardson. Samuel Isaly, a partner in Mehta and Isaly, a stock market research firm, described the proposed deal as ``an excellent strategic combination.'' Rhone-Poulenc is in the top 10 in the European pharmaceutical market but has no direct marketing in the United States or Japan, where Rorer has a modest network established. ``So in a single stroke, a new pharmaceutical specialty firm is created with reasonably strong positions in the U.S., Europe and Japan,'' Isaly said. The analyst said, however, that the firms' products are not as complementary as their geographic markets. Rorer's major drugs are cardiovascular, gastroenterology, hypersensitivity, bone metabolism and plasma products. Rhone-Poulenc concentrates on cardiovascular, antibiotic, anti-inflammatory, central nervous system and oncology drugs. Rhone-Poulenc would have a majority of the seats on the new company's board of directors, but Robert E. Cawthorn, Rorer's chairman and chief executuve, would head the new company. Rorer stockholders would get a mix of cash and securities worth about $73 a share, according to a statement from Rorer. Rorer stock closed down 75 cents a share Thursday at $62.87{ in New York Stock Exchange trading. The deal was announced after the market closed Thursday. The announcement was expected. On Monday, Rorer said it was negotiating with an unidentifed firm that would acquire 68 percent of its stock. The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday filed suit in U.S. District Court in New York charging three unidentified foreign firms and a Swiss investor with trading on Rorer stock based on inside information about the negotiations. Rhone-Poulenc, based in Paris, had an estimated $11 billion in 1989 sales, while Rorer, based in the Philadelphia suburb of Fort Washington, had sales of more than $1.1 billion. As the cost of developing new drugs climbs, the pharmaceutical industry has been undergoing a rash of mergers, with companies seeking to gain higher revenues from worldwide markets while cutting research and development costs through consolidation. Last year, Philadelphia-based SmithKline Beckman Corp. merged with Britain's Beecham Group PLC to form SmithKline Beecham, and New York-based Brisol Myers Co. acquired Squibb Corp., of Princeton, N.J., to form Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. Rorer officials compared the proposed deal with the merger that created Marion Merrell Dow last year. Dow Chemical Co. bought a controlling interest in Marion Labs Inc., a Kansas City, Mo., pharmaceutical company, and combined the company with its pharmaceutical subsidiary, Merrell Dow. A minority interest remains in public hands, keeping a stock exchange quote for Marion Merrell Dow.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Fourth Quarter Heading Way Down
DOC.TEXT: The cost of sales incentives and temporary plant closings will cut into automakers' profits for the fourth quarter of 1989 and into this year, analysts predict. Seven automotive analysts checked by The Associated Press forecast dramatic profit drops among the nation's Big Three automakers in the fourth quarter. Chrysler Corp. will earn little or nothing, they said Thursday. Fourth-quarter and year-end 1989 earnings statements for General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler are due within the next four weeks, and will show a significant drop from the record $11.21 billion in earnings the companies reported for 1988. GM's fourth-quarter 1989 earnings should be between 48 percent and 58 percent lower than the year before, the analysts said. Ford's are forecast to be between 40 percent and 44 percent lower and Chrysler's profits are predicted to be nearly non-existent. ``Chrysler could be marginally profitable in the regular automotive earnings,'' said independent analyst David Healy of New York. ``But they have a bunch of write-offs possible ... which could leave the fourth-quarter in the red.'' Healy and other analysts said the No. 3 automaker's early retirement and salaried employee severance plans hooked to its $1.5 billion cost-reduction program will cut into earnings. GM is likely to report a one-time gain on the sale of some of its stock in Isuzu Motors Ltd. of Japan, boosting its non-operating income, the analysts said. Overall, production cuts and the cost of buyer incentives to sell cars and trucks will depress earnings in the quarter, they said. ``I think that the combination of higher incentives and lower production has basically reduced the industry to the break-even level,'' Healy said. In past quarters, GM and Ford have reported profits buoyed by earnings overseas, especially in Europe. Chrysler has little presence outside North America. The trend of overseas profits outpacing North American earnings is likely to continue, the analysts said. ``I don't think anybody is going to make money in North America,'' said Kathleen Heaney of Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. of New York. In addition to incentive and lost-production costs, Big Three earnings have been dented by increasing popularity of cars made by Japanese companies in the United States and overseas. Last year, for example, the Honda Accord was the best-selling car in the United States. Nearly 60 percent of those cars were made at Honda's plant in Marysville, Ohio, and the rest were imported. ``The automotive recession in North America is much deeper than it looks,'' said Scott Merlis of Morgan, Stanley & Co. in New York. ``It has been artificially levitated by rebates.'' Automakers are reluctant to talk about the cost of rebates but acknowledge that it can average in the hundreds of dollars for every vehicle sold. Some dealers have complained that new cars are priced artificially high to make up for the incentives. The companies sometimes charge incentive costs to the quarter in which the vehicle was built and sometimes to the quarter in which it was sold. That makes it tough to tell just how much a company is spending on the consumer lures. But no matter when automakers account for the incentives, they come straight from profits.

DOC.NOTE: $adv18
For Release PMs Thursday, Jan. 18
DOC.HEAD: Out On A Limb Where It Is Comfortable
DOC.TEXT: While many fellow economists are contemplating a soft landing if not a recession for the economy in 1990, Russell Redenbaugh, an experienced forecaster, is preparing for a soft takeoff. A soft takeoff is a safe one, although perhaps undramatic. It is not a sudden ascent; its characteristics are moderation, sustainability, steadiness. It is a positive, reassuring economy. In more specific economic terms it means growth of between 2 percent and 3 percent, accompanied by moderation of the extremes and negatives that marred the 1980s. It means lower inflation, lower interest rates, a lower federal budget deficit. It means more exports and a reduction in the trade imbalance. It is one accompanied by lower capital gains taxes and rising returns on capital. It is an economic situation that, Redenbaugh says, professional economists with a negative outlook have ``grossly misread.'' Because they have misread events, he says, they have come to ``patently wrong conclusions.'' That is, they are talking about economic deterioration, obsessed with ``a handful of gloomy statistics for specific sectors of the U.S. economy,'' unable to measure an historic event that he calls the key indicator. To him, the key to the immediate economic future is the freeing of the Eastern European economies from 40 years of deindustrialization, a discontinuity that ``the economics profession ... cannot comprehend.'' Redenbaugh knows that his forecast puts him way out on a limb, especially in the conservative business in which he operates, but he claims to like it there, saying ``I feel comfortable; it's never crowded.'' Most economists and investment advisers run in a herd, he says, adding: ``In this business you must have an aversion to crowds. Crowds are comfortable, but they never produce good results.'' Redenbaugh needs results, is measured by them, and expects to get them as chief strategist for Cooke & Bieler, Inc., a Philadelphia-based asset management firm for Fortune 500 pension funds and profit-sharing accounts. He believes that recent economic events will produce a real peace dividend, an immediate expansion of commerce, and a lengthening investment horizon that, as a consequence, will means higher price-earnings ratios for stocks. He isn't entirely alone in his optimism. Edward Yardeni of Prudential-Bache is probably as far out on a limb. And the Conference Board said today that the U.S. economy is rebounding rather than eroding, with exports leading the way. But if you attended a convention of economists almost anywhere this month you might not be pleased with what you heard. Based on their published reports, almost any uplifting news would be balanced off with depressing reminders. Redenbaugh believes many professional economists are unable to deal with changes in Europe because it doesn't fit their ``orthodoxy of using statistical models to explain everything.'' He contends they want to say something to the effect that ``Three out of the last four times when the Iron Curtain collapsed the following happened,'' which is, of course, absurd. While the suddenness of the collapse of managed economies in Europe amazed Redenbaugh, he had suggested it might happen, although more slowly, in a paper one year ago. At that time he said economic considerations were dismantling the Iron Curtain and undermining Communist ideology, and that if the Soviet Union was to survive it would have to abandon Marxist economic systems. What has since occurred, he says, is now the key factor in economic forecasting, whether or not it fits the conventional forecasting models. As the 1990s begin, he states, ``it is not the health of the economy that is questionable, for it is healthy; it is the health of the economics profession that is questionable.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thursday, Jan. 18.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Foreign Investments Down, But Value Up In 1988
DOC.TEXT: Foreigners spent $58.4 billion on direct investments in the United States in 1988, up $300 million from 1987, according to government figures. The Commerce Department's International Trade Administration said Thursday it recorded 1,084 foreign direct investments in 1988, down 18 percent from 1,328 in 1987. The agency reported that the values of the 516 transactions it could identify rose 0.5 percent to $58.4 billion from $58.1 billion in 1987. It said transaction values for many investments were not publicly available. Foreign direct investment means the direct or indirect ownership of 10 percent or more of the voting securities of an incorporated business, an equivalent interest in an unincorporated business or 10 percent or more interest in real property. Calling 1988 ``the year of the big deal,'' the Commerce Department said the transactions included nine valued at more than $1 billion, with a combined value of $22.1 billion, or 38 percent of the total. Twenty-two other transactions were valued at $500 million or more each and had a combined total of $32.2 billion, or 55 percent of the overall total. The department said a record 110 investments were worth $100 million or more. ``As in the past four years, Japan was the source country for the largest number of transactions,'' the report said. ``More than 46 percent, or 419 transactions, originated in Japan, with 201 identified values totaling $15.1 billion.'' British investors were second, with 213 transactions including 116 with identified values totaling $15 billion. Noting that the major industrialized nations traditionally have been the source of most direct investment activity, the agency said Canada, France, West Germany, the Netherlands and Switzerland joined Japan and Britain to make 906 transactions, or 84 percent of the total. That was down from 87 percent of the 1987 total. Still, ``the identified aggregate value of the transactions by the seven countries _ $51.2 billion _ represented 88 percent of the total identified value,'' it said. The Commerce Department said nearly 53 percent of the investment transactions were in manufacturing, primarily in non-electrical machinery, electric and electronic equipment, chemicals, printing and publishing and transportation equipment. ``The services and the real estate sectors also attracted large numbers of foreign investors,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group Seeking Investigation of AT&T Outage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group is asking federal regulators to make sure this week's major outage in AT&T long distance service wasn't the result of profit motives getting in the way of quality. The Consumer Federation of America said Thursday it would ask the Federal Communications Commission today to investigate what happened on Monday, why the outage lasted for nine hours and why AT&T wasn't better prepared to handle it. Gene Kimmelman, the federation's legislative director, said he was concerned that AT&T may be cutting corners under new FCC regulations that let the company earn whatever profits it can within a ``price cap'' formula that limits yearly price increases. ``In moving to this new form of relaxed regulation with no limit on profits, AT&T may have reconfigured its network, cutting corners on quality to try to boost its profits,'' Kimmelman said. An American Telephone and Telegraph Co. spokesman labeled Kimmelman's allegations ``utterly ridiculous.'' The federation's announcement came shortly after AT&T said it will give its customers nine hours of discount calling on Feb. 14, Valentine's Day, if the FCC approves. AT&T said it was trying to make amends for Monday's nine-hour outage in which millions of customers got busy signals and failed connections when they tried to use AT&T long distance service. The company blamed a computer software problem that spread from New York to more than 100 switching centers nationwide. AT&T, which has about 80 million customers, also said it would compensate its ``800'' service businesses, and negotiate one-on-one with all its business customers for possible additional concessions. But the consumer group complained that AT&T was offering its discounts _ averaging 33 percent _ on Valentine's Day between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. That mainly would benefit business, the federation said, claiming that most residential customers do their long distance calling during evening and nighttime hours. In a letter being delivered today, Kimmelman asked the FCC to investigate the outage or review the monitoring standards that were adopted when price caps went into effect in July. ``We find it difficult to understand how the network breakdown _ whatever its initial cause _ could have spread so far, and resulted in so much of AT&T's service being disrupted for so long,'' Kimmelman wrote. AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said the consumer group's claims were ridiculous and noted his company's ``longstanding commitment to quality service over more than a century.'' He disputed Kimmelman's statement that residential customers make most long distance calls in the evenings and at night. ``The bulk of all long distance calls are made by residential customers, regardless of time of day ... and therefore lower daytime prices benefit both residential and business customers,'' Linnen said. AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen said his company was offering the Valentine's Day discounts as a ``gesture to underscore how much we value our relationship with our customers, knowing there is no way to make up for the inconvenience they may have experienced.'' If the FCC approves AT&T's request, the company's residential, business and international customers would be charged an average 33 percent less than regular weekday charges on out-of-state, direct-dialed calls placed during the day. AT&T, which carries 70 percent of the nation's long-distance calls, said a 10-minute, direct-dialed, coast-to-coast call between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. on Valentine's Day would cost $1.58, compared with $2.50 on a normal weekday. The discounts also will apply to credit card calls and ``800'' service calls, but not to operator-assisted calls or to calls placed before 8 a.m. or after 5 p.m., which already are discounted, Linnen said. The company said ``800'' service customers will be eligible to receive a credit on their bills up to the monthly service charge.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Sees Taiwan as Biggest Growing Market for American Produce
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The No. 1 export growth market for American farmers over the next few years won't be the Soviet Union, China or even Japan, says the Agriculture Department. It will be Taiwan. A new study by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service puts Taiwan at top of a 10-nation listing of prime opportunities for U.S. agricultural exports. The others, in order, are: South Korea, Japan, Hong Kong, Egypt, Pakistan, Iraq, Singapore, the Soviet Union and Turkey. China was a near-miss, coming in 11th. Mike Dwyer of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service said a number of variable factors were considered in a computer model used to analyze 80 countries as U.S. agricultural customers and project growths over the next three to five years. Some of the factors were related to trade performance, including growth in imports from the United States going back to 1980. Other ``macroeconomic'' variables such as debt-and-service ratios, population trends and per capita incomes were considered. Dwyer, reporting in a forthcoming issue of AgExporter magazine, noted of the 10 top potential markets, nine are developing countries, with Japan the exception. Also, he said, most of the others are in the Middle East and the Far East, with an emphasis on ``newly industrialized countries'' of Asia _ Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong. Looking at U.S. agricultural exports in the 1986-88 period, Dwyer said Taiwan was the sixth largest market, importing an average of $1.36 billion worth of products annually. South Korea was third at $1.8 billion, while Japan was the biggest at $6.1 billion. ``While these are all quite large, our study suggests there is a lot of room for further growth,'' he said. The 12-nation European Economic community as a bloc is one of the biggest markets for American farmers. For example, in the 1989 fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30, when U.S. farm exports totaled $39.7 billion, the EEC accounted for $6.5 billion, topped only by Japan at $8.2 billion. But Dwyer said the EEC didn't show great growth potential in the study. ``Despite the weaker dollar, (EEC) nations have been declining markets for the United States in recent years,'' he said. ``It will probably become more difficult to export bulk commodities there because (the region) already has become or is becoming self-sufficient in many of these products.'' Some of the best-growth markets, including Iraq, Egypt and Pakistan, show up well because of projected population growth, U.S. food aid, credit and subsidized prices, Dwyer said. In the ninth-ranked Soviet Union, growth potential based purely on numbers is ``very good'' over the next few years, he said. ``Add to that the changes taking place in the political environment there, and that market could really expand for the United States,'' Dwyer said. ``The agricultural sector is unable to keep pace with demand, and consumers are dissatisfied with the lack of food on grocery shelves.'' Dwyer added the Kremlin is aware of the problems and is interested in restructuring the Soviet food system. The move toward free-market practices ``could create opportunities for diversities in Soviet imports.'' China, with more than one billion people and its political turmoil, is difficult to gauge but stacks up as a favorable growth market for the United States, he said. ``Prior to 1981, China was a hot import market,'' Dwyer said. ``Then, the realization hit that it couldn't continue to import at the rate it was without incurring massive foreign debt. So China pulled back and imports fell 13 percent a year during 1981-87.'' As a result, China's imports of U.S. products dropped an average of 28 percent a year during the 1980-88 period, he said. ``There has a been a comeback in U.S. exports (to China) this past year, but the market is considered volatile,'' Dwyer said.

After buying wheat recently, the Soviet Union is adding soybean meal to its U.S. shopping list. The Agriculture Department said Thursday that private exporters sold 100,000 metric tons of meal to the Soviets for delivery by Sept. 30 under a long-term grain agreement between the two countries. The current pact began its seventh year on Oct. 1 and will expire on Dec. 31. Negotiations on a new agreement are scheduled to resume March 21-22 in Vienna. Most sales have been grain, including about 11 million tons of corn and more than 2.2 million tons of wheat for delivery during the seventh year. Sales of soybean meal now total 895,000 tons for 1989-90 delivery; soybeans, 217,900 tons; and barley, 7,300 tons. All of the wheat, including 525,000 tons announced earlier in the week, has been sold at prices subsidized under the department's Export Enhancement Program. Only wheat is approved for sale to Moscow under the subsidy program. The new sales were made by unidentified private exporting companies, which are required to report large sales to the department. No selling prices or further details were released. Meal prices at processors have been around $180 per ton of 2,000 pounds each, according to USDA market reports. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds, indicating a value of about $198 per metric ton, or a total estimate of around $19.8 million.

DOC.HEAD: Cigna To Acquire Nashville Insurer for $777 Million
DOC.TEXT: Cigna Corp. has signed a definitive agreement to acquire Equicor-Equitable HCA Corp. in a $777 million deal that would make Cigna the nation's largest health insurer for employers. Cigna on Thursday said it would purchase the Nashville-based company, which sells health insurance, in a cash transaction. Once the deal is completed, Cigna would serve more than 12 million people with traditional health insurance operations and nearly 2 million more through health maintenance organizations. Equicor is a joint venture owned by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and Hospital Corporation of America. It is the sixth-largest group health insurer, based on $5.5 billion in premiums and fees for administering employers' own health insurance plans in 1988. Wilson H. Taylor, Cigna chairman and chief executive officer, said the aquisition would result in the elimination of some jobs because of duplication of effort, but the company hasn't determined yet how many or which jobs would be lost. Taylor said Cigna is buying Equicor because ``Cigna is committed to establishing a leading position in the managed health care business.'' Managed care refers to health maintenance organizations and other networks of health care providers aimed at restraining the soaring costs of care. ``The timing for growth couldn't be any better'' because of employers' increasing desire to limit rising costs of employee health care,'' he said. Analysts said the plan was a good one for Cigna. ``I think it is a brilliant strategic move because size and critical mass have become the key strategic variable in the group health business,'' said G. Alan Zimmerman, a vice president at Smith, Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``You have to get bigger in order to negotiate effectively with employers.'' Cigna already has the largest for-profit chain of HMOs in the nation, bringing in $1.5 billion of revenues in 1988, compared with Equicor's $300 million in revenue. The acquisition will increase Cigna's HMO membership by about 30 percent. Cigna has 1.5 million HMO members in 31 sites across the nation, and Equicor has 450,000 in 19 sites. Cigna has yet to report financial results for 1989, but Taylor said its HMO operations lost money. They are expected to post a profit this year, he said. Equicor's HMO operaton, with some HMOs relatively new, are incurring ``modest losses'' overall, Taylor said. Equicor has 7,300 employees in about 80 offices nationwide. The acquisition, which is subject to regulatory approval, should be completed in six months, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Denies Plans to File For Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Heavily indebted publisher Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. denied rumors it plans to file for bankruptcy after the company's stock plummeted to an all-time low. HBJ stock, which changed hands at nearly $10 a share just three months ago, traded as low as $2 Thursday before closing at $2.875, down 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange. HBJ ``is not a candidate for Chapter 11'' bankruptcy protection, William Jovanovich, the company's reclusive chairman, said in a statement released after the market closed. Jovanovich said the rumors were sparked by the highly publicized problems of other indebted companies, an apparent reference to bankruptcy filings Monday by Campeau Corp.'s Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. Jovanovich made his statement to the Dow Jones Professional Investor Report after the Orlando-based company tried to calm market jitters with another statement early in the afternoon. Huge sales of HBJ stock early in the day fueled speculation surrounding the publisher. Volume totaled 4.8 million shares, making it the most active issue on the Big Board. After the stock hit its low point, the company issued its first statement saying that operating income and cash flow in 1990 would be ``significantly higher'' than what HBJ will post for 1989. HBJ is not due to release 1989 earnings until February or March. In 1988, the company posted a loss of $126.5 million because of high interest payments associated with its debt. HBJ has about $1.6 billion in junk bonds outstanding. The company borrowed nearly $3 billion as part of a frantic recapitalization 2{ years ago to repel a hostile takeover bid by British publisher Robert Maxwell. Last year, HBJ sold its six theme parks to Anheuser-Busch Cos. for $1.1 billion in an effort to pare its debt.

DOC.HEAD: British Inflation Rate Holds Steady at 7.7 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Britain's inflation rate rose 0.3 percent in December and was up 7.7 percent for the year, the government said Friday. The Central Statistical Office attributed the December rise in the Retail Price Index to sharp increases in food prices, particularly for fresh fruit and vegetables. The index also reflected higher housing costs, the government said. The rate was better than the 7.8 percent increase the financial markets had been expecting and was good news for the government, which has been fighting resurgent inflation with 15 percent interest rates. The index, which uses a January 1987 base of 100, stood at 118.8 in December, compared with 118.5 in November and 110.3 in December 1988. Excluding mortgage interest payments, retail prices rose 6.1 percent in December from the previous year. This is the same rate of increase as November's and October's year-over-year rises.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Sue Farley Over Pepperell Deal
DOC.TEXT: A group of West Point-Pepperell Inc. stockholders has filed a federal lawsuit charging that Farley Inc. misrepresented its takeover of their Georgia textile company. The lawsuit, filed Thursday on behalf of a group said to own 46,800 Pepperell common shares, followed reports that Chicago-based Farley Inc. was having trouble securing financing for the buyout. Farley agreed last year to acquire sheet-and-towel maker Pepperell for $3 billion. In a brief statement, Farley denied than any of its ``tender offer materials or other disclosures were not complete or accurate disclosures at the time they were made.'' Farley said the suit, which names its founder, industrialist William Farley and unidentified Pepperell officials as defendants, is ``without merit'' and it plans to ``vigorously contest the plantiffs in court.'' Farley's acquisition of Pepperell, based in West Point, Ga., was said to create the world's largest textile and apparel group, with more than $4 billion in sales and about 70,000 employees. Farley's best-known holding is Fruit of the Loom underwear.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Trade Surplus Narrows for Eighth Consecutive Month
DOC.TEXT: Increasing consumption and growing imports pushed Japan's trade surplus lower in December for the eighth consecutive monthly decline from year-earlier levels, the Finance Ministry said Friday. The trade surplus, calculated on a customs-clearance basis, shrank 36.3 percent to $6.19 billion from a year earlier, when it registered $9.72 billion, the ministry said. The trade account for all of 1989 was in surplus by $64.43 billion, compared with $77.56 billion in 1988. A breakdown by nations or regions was not available. Ministry officials attributed the paring of the trade surplus to increasing personal consumption and high import growth. In December, they said, high oil prices also pushed up the value of imports. In December, exports totaled $24.59 billion, off 6 percent from a year earlier, while imports were up 11.8 percent at $18.40 billion. Monthly trade surplus with the United States dropped 24 percent to $3.83 billion, the report said. Japan's trade surplus has been a target of sharp criticism from the United States and other trading partners throughout the 1980s.

DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press on Jan. 18 erroneously identified the late husband of Barbara Piasecka-Johnson, who offered $100 million to buy the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, as a former head of the pharmaceutical company Johnson & Johnson. Mrs. Johnson's husband, J. Seward Johnson, was a member of the family that founded the company. He had served on the company's board of directors but was never chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Evans Resigns, Rubin Selected Doubleday President, Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Evans has resigned after three years as president and publisher of Doubleday, and will be replaced by Stephen Rubin, publisher and editor in chief for adult fiction and non-fiction at Bantam Books. Ms. Evans, a former editor in chief of Book-of-the-Month Club for what now is Time Warner Inc., was credited with revitalizing Doubleday, a leading publisher of general interest books, in the wake of its acquisition in late 1986 by Bertelsmann AG of West Germany. The announcements of the changes were made Thursday. Doubleday and Bantam Books are operated along with Dell as separate divisions within Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group Inc., which itself is second in size only to Random House among the nation's general interest book publishers. Ms. Evans was unavailable to comment on her resignation. Her departure comes two months after Alberto Vitale left as president and chief executive of Bantam Doubleday Dell to replace Robert L. Bernstein as head of Random House. Bernstein resigned unexpectedly in early November after 23 years as head of Random House. Industry analysts said they suspected Vitale's selection at Random House reflected concern with improving profitability. Industrywide sales have slumped in recent months and competition has grown keener. The changes at Bantam Doubleday Dell were announced by Berhard von Minckwitz, interim chief executive officer and co-chairman of the group, and Jack Hoeft, president and chief operating officer. ``During her three years as president, Doubleday regained its stature as a leading hardcover house, focused upon the publication of books whose editorial integrity is matched by the quality of their physical production,'' they said. But they said that with this phase of Doubleday's rebuilding in hand, they and Ms. Evans decided it was an opportune time for Ms. Evans to move on ``to pursue the many possibilities that await her in the communications field.'' ``She will announce her plans shortly,'' the statement read. Ms. Evans had been editor in chief and vice president of Book-of-the-Month Club from January 1985 to January 1987 and previously hosted an author interview television program. Among recent Doubleday titles have been ``Drive'' by basketball star Larry Bird and ``Confessions of an S.O.B.'' by former Gannett Co. Inc. chairman Al Neuharth. The trade newsletter BP Report, based in Wilton, Conn., estimated that Bantam Doubleday Dell had revenue of $550 million in 1988, second only to Random House's estimated $800 million, among general interest publishers. Rubin, 48, joined Bantam in May 1984 as executive editor. He became editorial director for adult fiction and non-fiction in February 1985, was elected vice president six months later and editor in chief in January 1987. He became publisher and a Bantam senior vice president in July 1988. Von Minckwitz and Hoeft said in a memo to the staff that Rubin ``is unwaveringly committed, as are we, to an editorially independent Doubleday offering a full-range publishing program of hardcover and trade paperback fiction and non-fiction for adults and young readers.'' At Bantam Books, Jeff Stone was named to the newly-created position of vice president and publisher, adult hardcover and trade paperback books. He had been vice president and associate publisher of Alfred A. Knopf Inc. and vice president of Vintage Books, a trade paperback imprint of Random House Inc. Last November, Lou Aronica was appointed vice president and publisher, mass market books, for Bantam's mass market paperbacks. Both Stone and Aronica report to Bantam's president and publisher, Linda Grey.

For release Monday Jan. 22
DOC.HEAD: In the Pits, a Year of Scandal And Scrutiny
Graphic in AP Access under COMMODITIES
DOC.TEXT: On Karsten Mahlmann's calendar, the new year began Jan. 1 but it took a little longer for the Chicago Board of Trade chairman to put 1989 behind him. Not until this past Wednesday, when he won a close election to a fourth consecutive one-year term, was Mahlmann certain of majority support among the 3,500 members of the world's oldest and largest commodity futures exchange. It was a vote of confidence after a year of scandal that began Jan. 19, 1989, when federal authorities revealed a sweeping investigation of trading fraud at the Board of the Trade and the smaller Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which together account for about 75 percent of U.S. futures trading volume. ``I can't remember a tougher year in the seven years I've served on the board,'' Mahlmann said in an interview. The probe has resulted in criminal charges against 48 people. Fourteen have pleaded guilty to swindling customers. A parallel investigation at New York's four major futures exchanges was revealed in May but has yielded no indictments yet. The Board of Trade's troubles multiplied in July when exchange directors exercised their seldom-used authority to order traders to sell soybean futures, forcing prices lower. The board claimed it was necessary to prevent one grain company from cornering the market. The trading-fraud scandal brought cries for reform of the rapidly growing futures industry and has delayed congressional reauthorization of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the federal agency that regulates the futures pits. Futures contracts are agreements to buy or sell commodities ranging from agricultural products to financial instruments on some future date at a price agreed upon in advance. People trade futures to hedge losses or speculate on future prices. Amid the intense public scrutiny of the futures markets and their trading practices in the past year, the Chicago exchanges have strengthened policing efforts, stiffened penalties for cheating and proposed reforms that address some concerns raised by the FBI investigation. But the toughest measures, such as restrictions on dual trading and stricter regulation of broker associations, are yet to come. Dual trading is the practice among floor brokers of trading for their own accounts as well as customer accounts. Broker associations are groups of independent futures traders who share revenues and pool expenses. Critics say both practices provide opportunities for traders to defraud customers. ``A lot needs to be done,'' said Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla. ``If you review what's actually been done, we've had a good deal more in terms of intentions expressed rather than real action.'' English sponsored a CFTC reauthorization bill passed last year by the House. The measure would sharply curtail dual trading until an exchange demonstrates an ability to better detect wrongdoing. Senate action on a similar bill is pending. The CFTC, meanwhile, is seeking public comment on a proposed rule that would limit dual trading but it's not as tough as the bills in Congress. The Chicago exchanges defend dual trading as a means of keeping markets liquid when the customer order flow is light, thus reducing price volatility. They bristled when curbs on dual trading were first suggested, but have since indicated acceptance of restrictions that would be lifted when highly accurate trade-auditing systems are in place. The Board of Trade and Merc are involved in a rare joint effort to develop a hand-held electronic trade-recording device. The machine would replace the traditional paper cards on which commodity traders pencil in their trades. The electronic trading cards and would zap the information to exchange computers, theoretically creating a complete, instantaneous record of all trades. The exchanges have invited proposals for companies to design an electronic trading card and hope to begin testing prototypes on their trading floors this fall. ``It will make detection of abuses a certainty,'' said Merc spokesman Andrew Yemma. But some critics contend commodities fraud will remain difficult to detect until the exchanges do away with open-outcry trading, a 140-year-old tradition in which traders crowd pits and strike deals through a seemingly chaotic combination of hand signals and shouted bids and offers. ``Verbal orders, executed by shakes, winks, hand gestures, spit and God-knows what, that's the window of opportunity for fraud,'' said former Sen. Thomas Eagleton, who quit the Chicago Merc's board of governors in November. He accused the exchange of trying to protect a former chairman accused of failing to stop two of his employees from defrauding investors. The Board of Trade and the Merc are working on electronic trading systems to supplement open-outcry trading, but neither exchange plans to phase out the practice, saying it creates the world's most efficient markets. The futures industry has enjoyed remarkable growth since the early 1970s, when financial futures were introduced. Volume has soared from 13.8 million contracts traded in 1970 to 267.4 million last year. Last year's industry-wide volume increase of 8.8 percent marked the 21st consecutive annual rise. The Board of Trade's trading volume fell 3.3 percent last year, though. Exchange officials blamed it on quieter agricultural markets than in 1988, a drought year. But John Damgard, president of the Futures Industry Association trade group, said industry-wide volume probably would have been higher if it weren't for the fraud scandal. ``There's clearly been a price to pay for this,'' he said, ``and the Chicago exchanges are right at the focal point.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday Jan. 22

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices headed higher today in what analysts described as a technical rally after the market's recent declines. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 5.12 to 2,671.50 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 637 up, 298 down and 478 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 25.57 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Stock prices began to stabilize late in Thursday's session, when buying of blue chips enabled the market to finish mixed after a broad early retreat. Analysts said traders' spirits brightened this morning as interest rates dropped back a bit after their steady rise of the past few weeks in the bond market. But considerable skepticism lingered on the Street about the staying power of any rally attempt. Corporate earnings reports issued to date for the fourth quarter of 1989 have contained some even bigger disappointments than traders were expecting. In addition, rising interest rates in Japan, West Germany and other industrialized countries have intensified speculation about the possibility of an international business slump in the months ahead. Digital Equipment dropped 1 to 81 on top of a 5~-point loss Thursday, when the company posted a quarterly earnings decline that was sharper than many observers had expected. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .41 to 187.48. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .05 at 366.22. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.25 to 2,666.38. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2 on the NYSE, with 587 up, 879 down and 501 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 178.59 million shares, against 170.47 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Windham Hill Records Reportedly for Sale
DOC.TEXT: Windham Hill Records, founding distributor of New Age music, is listening to buyout offers while hoping for a reported $50 million sale price. Anne Robinson, Windham Hill's president and chief executive, said her company discussed deals with several potential buyers in recent weeks, but would not elaborate, the Los Angeles Times reported Friday. ``Our distribution agreement with A&M Records expires at the end of March,'' Ms. Robinson said. ``We have been approached by a number of parties interested in either distribution (of our records) or acquisition of our company. I can't say more than that.'' Capitol Records is among those talking with the Palo Alto-based record company, the newspaper said, citing unnamed music industry sources who said the asking price was about $50 million. Capitol officials declined formal comment on the report. Windham Hill's possible sale follows a recent wave of record company buyouts by larger media companies. Polygram last fall acquired Windham Hill's distributor, A&M Records, for about $500 million. Windham Hill pioneered the recording of New Age music 14 years ago, with unorthodox marketing methods like mail-order sales and distribution through bookstores. The New Age music is mostly instrumental and has been described as a mix of classical piano, jazz and natural sounds such as wind and running water. Billboard magazine in 1988 formally recognized New Age music by ranking releases in a separate category. There are now about a half dozen major New Age record companies.
