For Release Monday, Jan. 22
DOC.HEAD: Fate of Campeau Corp. Bonds Unknown, But Few Small Investors Hurt
DOC.TEXT: The bankruptcy filing of Campeau Corp.'s U.S. department store divisions last week came as no surprise to the bond market, and few small investors should be hurt by the damage done to the Campeau divisions' bonds. Not many individual investors are believed to own bonds issued by Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., except indirectly through mutual funds. ``Most of it was sophisticated investors, big investors,'' said Pam Stubing, an analyst for Moody's Investors Service Inc. Even investors in junk-bond mutual funds that hold Allied and Federated bonds should not see the value of these funds hurt by the Chapter 11 filing of the department stores. That's because the funds typically have less than 1 percent of their assets in any single bond issue. For example, far less than 1 percent of T. Rowe Price's high-income, or junk-bond, fund consists of bonds from Allied and Federated, said Jane Nelson, a spokeswoman for the big Baltimore-based mutual fund operator. Neither Price nor Fidelity Investments, another major mutual fund sponsor, reported much concern from investors in their junk-bond funds over the bankruptcy filing. ``People sort of knew what was going to happen. It's not as though it was a surprise out of the blue,'' said Tracy Gordon, a spokeswoman for Boston-based Fidelity. The impact of the filing was muted further by the fact that these bonds have been trading far below their issue price for months due to concern over Campeau's troubled finances. In fact, many of the bonds have been trading at one-tenth of the price they sold for originally. Because of that and the assumption by many that a bankruptcy reorganization was a foregone conclusion, the price of the bonds was little affected by the actual filing. However, the bonds began trading on a ``flat'' basis after the filing. When bonds trade flat, a seller does not receive any of the accumulated interest from the buyer. Bonds typically pay interest only twice a year. Because of this, if a bond is purchased, for example, three months after its last interest payment, the purchaser would have to pay the seller prorated interest. When a bond trades flat it indicates investors don't expect to see any interest payments. It appears the biggest losers from the Allied and Federated filings could be the institutional investors and investment houses that bought large blocks of the bonds. Among the major creditors listed in the bankruptcy papers were First Boston Corp., State Street Bank, Manufacturers Hanover bank and PaineWebber Inc. The par, or face, value of Allied's publicly traded debt securities totals about $1.2 billion, while the figure for Federated is about $2 billion, said Ms. Stubing, the Moody's analyst. However, the actual worth of these issues is far less because they are trading below their issue price. Ms. Stubing said she believes the Allied and Federated bondholders will see some return for their investment despite the fact the divisions are nearly $8 billion in debt. ``I'm reasonably optimistic that they will get something for their pain and effort,'' she said. ``After all, the stores are not to blame in this thing, the debt is to blame.'' But things won't be smooth during the reorganization, which could take more than a year, she said. ``It's going to be a very complex thing. There're a lot of entities involved and a lot of cross-ownership between Allied and Federated.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Jan. 22

DOC.HEAD: Three Charged with Breaking into Classified Military Computer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Three men have been accused of breaking into a government computer and obtaining a classified military secret, an act a federal prosecutor says shows the nation's defense computers are vulnerable. The three Silicon Valley computer workers, Kevin L. Poulsen, 24, Mark K. Lottor, 25, and Robert E. Gilligan, 31, are accused of using personal computers, stolen Pacific Bell Telephone Co. equipment and stolen access codes to tap into government and telephone computer computers and obtain classified military documents and FBI information on associates of the late Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos. Peter G. Neumann, a computer security expert at SRI International, a computer consulting company, said this was the first case he knew of in which classified information was allegedly obtained by computer break-ins. The federal indictment, unsealed Wednesday in U.S. District Court in San Jose, is one of the first in the nation to use federal criminal statutes directed at computer crime, assistant U.S. Attorney Robert K. Crowe said on Thursday. U.S. Attorney Joseph Russoniello said at a news conference in San Francisco Thursday that the military secret, which concerned a military exercise at Fort Bragg, N.C., was classified at the time it was stolen in 1987 or 1988 but has since been declassified. The act ``does signal a vulnerability'' in the defense system computers, he said. All three men are current or former employees of Sun Microsystems in Mountain View or of SRI International in Menlo Park. According to the indictment, Poulsen used common burglary tools, including surgical gloves, powdered graphite and lock picks, and forged a Pacific Bell employee card to steal the telecommunications equipment and access codes from offices in San Francisco and San Ramon, in Contra Costa County. Poulsen and Lottor ran part of the alleged conspiracy from the Menlo Park apartment they once shared, Crowe said. Gilligan and Poulsen are accused of trafficking in codes that allow access to U.S. government computers through electronic mail, the 15-page indictment said. The charges said the computer entered by two of the men was the Army MASNET Computer Network, used exclusively by the government. The charges do not indicate the uses of the computer. Poulsen also is charged with burglarizing Pacific Bell sites to steal the access codes, and with manufacturing fake identification badges to gain private computer information. The indictment also accuses Poulsen of using his computer knowledge to obstruct the investigation into his alleged activities. Gilligan, who reportedly still works for Sun, and Lottor, who works for SRI, are expected to surrender voluntarily. Poulsen, a former employee of both companies, remained at large. If convicted, Lottor and Gilligan face up to 20 years in prison and fines of $30,000. Poulsen could be sentenced to 37 years in prison and a $50,000 fine. The indictment does not indicate when authorities began investigating the three, or what the men intended to do with the military secrets.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Slide Further In Storm Reaction
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices fell moderately in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, steepening a decline linked to heavy precipitation in the nation's winter wheat region. Wheat futures fell to 3{-month lows Thursday as an intense winter storm dumped snow and rain across a large portion of the Southern Plains, where moisture was badly needed for the winter wheat crop. The storm system responsible for the moisture was moving from the Southwest into the central United States today and should help replenish soil moisture in corn and soybean areas, analysts said. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.95} a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.41} a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $1.39{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 1 cent lower with January at $5.60 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were unchanged to .13 cent lower with February at 78.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent lower to .05 cent higher with January at 83.75 cents a pound; hog futures were .30 cent lower to .20 cent higher with February at 49.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent lower to .18 cent higher with February at 55.27 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Plans To Cut Workforce by About 5,000
DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS new 5th graf to include Martin Marietta cuts; uppicks 5th graf pvw: The job ...; version moved general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Less than two months after settling a strike triggered in part by mandatory overtime for production workers, Boeing Co. said it expects to cut its Seattle-area work force by as many as 5,000 people. The aerospace giant said it needed to shed workers because it had completed start-up work on its newest generation jumbo jet and because warmer East-West ties had cast doubt on the outlook for its defense business. Boeing said it hoped to achieve half the cuts through retirements and resignations, but company officials hinted that further layoffs could be possible. About 1,700 hourly workers are to be laid off through April with another 800 later in the year, the company said Thursday. The Martin Marietta Astronautics Group also announced plans Thursday to cut about 200 jobs by the end of February, but will transfer many workers to other posts within the aerospace giant, a company spokeswoman said in Denver. The job losses come as Boeing enjoys a record backlog of more than 1,700 commercial jets worth about $85 billion, with deliveries scheduled beyond the turn of the century. Last year, the company added 10,000 employees in the Puget Sound area and was so strapped for production workers it borrowed 600 machinists from Lockheed. The company also required workers to put in heavy overtime schedules, which became a major factor in the 48-day strike by machinists that ended in November. The Lockheed workers were needed on the new 747-400 jumbo jet, which fell behind schedule as the company introduced four different versions of the long-range jetliner in 1989. The extra workers are no longer needed because startup and certification work on the new jumbo has been completed, Boeing said. About 1,400 hourly employees are expected to be laid off at the company's Everett plant north of Seattle, where widebody 747s and 767s are built. Most of the other layoffs are expected to be at defense plants, Boeing spokesman Paul Binder said. In interviews last month, Boeing Chairman Frank Shrontz said the company anticipated some layoffs. Boeing recently announced it wants to build a new widebody jet, the 777, but no orders have been announced and production startup is at least two years away. ``Because the new 777 airplane program is still not formally approved and with uncertainties in the defense budget, Boeing will continue to review and revise its work force requirements throughout the year,'' the company said. Binder said Boeing thought last fall it could absorb most of the commercial airplane job reductions by transferring people into defense programs. But with the opening of the Berlin Wall and the fall of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe late in the year, many U.S. defense programs have come under question. ``Some are going to be stretched, some cut, some shortened,'' Binder said. ``The requirements of the defense sector just went away.'' Boeing is a major subcontractor to Northrop on the B-2 stealth bomber, a program already slowed by defense cutbacks. It also holds contracts for the small ICBM mobile launcher, the V-22 helicopter-plane and the space station and is competing for the Air Force's multi-billion dollar Advanced Tactical Fighter contract, all programs under close congressional scrutiny. Overall, Boeing's defense segments have been losing money and were consolidated at the first of the year into Boeing Defense & Aerospace Group. The company trimmed 800 jobs as part of the consolidation but most of those people found jobs elsewhere in the company. The division's president, B. Dan Pinick, has said he wants to cut overhead by $100 million, which could entail the loss of some jobs. Thursday's announcement made no mention of any job losses at Boeing plants outside the Puget Sound region. Binder said he did not have employment projections for company divisions elsewhere in the country. Layoff notices will be issued Friday to about 1,900 employees who might be among the 1,700 workers laid off starting March 20, the company said. It said it will provide counseling and help laid-off workers find new jobs. At the end of 1989, Boeing had just under 106,700 employees in Washington state, an increase of almost 10,000 from the beginning of the year. Nationwide, Boeing employment grew by 10,800 last year to 145,200.

DOC.HEAD: Industry, Environmentalists Dispute Cost of Clean Air Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 7th graf, A study, with 3 grafs to update with study released, quotes; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: As Congress moves toward enacting tougher air pollution controls, one of the biggest mysteries is how much it will cost. Figures range from $14 billion a year to more than $100 billion, and some argue that doing nothing may be most expensive of all. The nation's largest corporations unveiled a study Thursday suggesting that if some of the most stringent proposals for cleaning up the air are enacted, the cost of compliance could soar as high as $104 billion a year. The actual costs likely will be less, conceded Philip Masciantonio, a vice president at U.S. Steel, a subsidiary of USX Corp., but he added even the study's $54 billion ``best estimate'' could be devastating to some industries. The steel industry's coke ovens could be shut down by toxic chemical emission controls envisioned by a Senate clean air bill, he argued. The study by the Business Roundtable, an association of the heads of the 200 largest corporations, was the latest estimate of how much the tighter air pollution controls now before Congress will cost business _ and their customers _ and how they might affect the economy. But supporters of the tough pollution controls argue inaction has a price tag of its own. A study released today by the American Lung Association maintained that current air pollution from automobiles may be costing Americans up to $93 billion a year in added health care expenses. Many of these costs would be eliminated under the pollution curbs being considered in Congress, the report said. At a news conference, the authors of the study said that while the $93 billion represents a ``high range'' they are confident from available data that health costs from breathing today's dirty air is costing society at least $40 billion to $50 billion, about half of that from automobile pollution. ``Five years ago the high-range estimate ....was $40 billion a year. Today $40 billion has become the best estimate for mid-range of the health costs'' associated to air pollution, said Fran DuMelle, director of government relations for the American Lung Association. President Bush has estimated that his proposal _ similar to legislation advancing in the House _ would cost from $14 billion to $19 billion a year. He urged Congress on Thursday to ``preserve the careful balance'' between cleaning up the air and preserving jobs. Democratic sponsors of a Senate clean air bill, expected to be brought to the floor next week, say it is not much more expensive than the president's version. But the Bush administration disagrees and opposes key provisions of it as being too costly. The tougher air pollution controls before Congress would require cuts in acid rain emissions from electric power plants, automobile exhausts and toxic chemical releases from industrial plants. ``Annually the nation spends tens of billions of dollars trying to alleviate the very real human cost of dirty air and the costs of lung disease, cancer and public health dangers associated with air pollution continue to rise,'' says Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chief sponsor of the Senate bill. ``The cost of cleaning up the nation's air is high, but the cost of not cleaning the air is even higher,'' he continued. Environmentalists, responding to the Business Roundtable cost estimates, contended that industry exaggerated the expected impact of the 1970 Clean Air Act when it was debated 20 years ago. ``This is part of an industry ritual on the eve of any pollution control debate in Congress. They release inflated figures,'' said Richard Ayres of the Natural Resources Defense Council, also chairman of the Clean Air Coalition. Likewise, business interests and the Bush administration dispute the Senate Democrats' contention that their bill will be no more expensive than the president's version. A review of the Senate bill by the Environmental Protection Agency, not yet released, will show ``substantially higher'' cost figures, said one administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Provisions in the Senate bill calling for health-based standards on toxic chemical releases from industrial plants and tighter auto emission controls both will be costly, argues William Fay, executive of the Clean Air Working Group, which speaks for industry. His group has said the Senate bill will at least double the $32 billion that industry pays each year to meet current air pollution controls, according to Commerce Department figures. There also is no unanimity on the health-related costs of air pollution. While there are such costs, argues Masciantonio, the USX Corp. executive, the direct relationship between health costs and specific sources of pollution has yet to be clearly shown.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pushes Lower Interest Rates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 graf with praise for Carters, comment on trees and protest after 14th graf, He also; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told the slumping homebuilding industry today that he wants interest rates to drop further and said a federal commission will study ways to make home ownership more affordable. Bush, on the eve of the first anniversary of his inaugurastion, declared, ``The 1990s must be another decade of lower taxes and lower interest rates.'' The president told several thousand members of the National Association of Homebuilders that Congress must adopt ``fiscal policies as sound as those of the average American household.'' Bush's comments added impetus to administration efforts to pressure the Federal Reserve Board into an easier credit policy. ``We cannot allow the high costs of housing to suffocate the financial life of America's young people,'' the president said. ``When it comes to housing, this must not become a society of haves and have-nots.'' Observing that the cost of new homes has been steadily increasing for the past ``decade and a half,'' Bush said more and more young Americans are finding themselves priced out of the home market. He vowed to work with Housing Secretary Jack Kemp to cut federal red tape ``to create decent housing that people can afford.'' He noted that he had asked Kemp to convene a commission that would study burdensome bureaucratic barriers to affordable housing construction ``and make recommendations on how to eliminate them.'' He offered no details. ``But the truth is, there's one housing policy and one sales strategy that's better than all others combined _ a healthy growing economy with low, long-term interest rates,'' Bush declared. ``Vital to homebuyer and homebuilder alike are low and stable rates of interest,'' the president added, claiming that each increase of one percentage point in the interest rate ``knocks millions of families out of the market.'' Bush's comments and those by other administration officials come amid speculation that momentum at the Fed for easing credit policy had ended. As he has done in nearly all of his speeches this year, Bush also called on Congress to act on items that he proposed last year, especially his proposal for a cut in the tax rate on capital gains _ the profit from sales of investments. ``I call on the Democrat leaders of Congress to give the American people a break and to let the House and Senate work their will by having an up-and-down vote on the capital gains tax cut,'' Bush said. He also the homebuilders organization that he stands firm in his opposition to massive new government public housing projects and will press again in the upcoming session of Congress for a plan to give public housing tenants vouchers to make it easier for them to buy their own units. Bush made a special point of praising former President Carter and his wife Rosalynn as a ``point of light'' for working with an organization that helps provide low-cost shelter. The president also departed from his prepared text to tell the homeowners that he was annoyed to see ``so many suburbs denuded of trees'' when builders clear new tracts and subdivisions and asked them to save some, both for the sake of business and for the environment. Several hecklers holding a sign protesting U.S. aid to the government of El Salvador jeered Bush briefly from the back of the hall before being led away by security officers. Bush took note of a planned white supremacist march Saturday near the Martin Luther King center in Atlanta. ``Atlanta is a great, cheerful city that has proudly risen from the ashes of a distant past,'' he said. ``And for those who plan to revel in a rally of hate here tomorrow, let them know this: Atlantans, like all Americans, turn their backs on bigots.'' Following his speech in Atlanta's Omni Coliseum, the president was flying to Florida for a late-afternoon tour and briefing at Everglades National Park and to speak at a fund-raising dinner in Miami for Republican Gov. Bob Martinez's re-election campaign. On Thursday, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater urged lower interest rates, breaking the administration's general policy of not commenting on Fed policy. ``This is not a new message. But it's important occasionally to point out that lower interest rates are normally good for the economy,'' he said. Furthermore, he said Fed members should take a close look at recent economic indicators _ which show moderate inflation and sluggishness in retail sales and housing _ and ``understand these numbers are low and indicate inflation has remained very steady over the last seven or eight years and that lower interest rates are justified.'' The administration's statement on interest rate policy comes amid speculation that momentum for lower rates at the Fed had ended. No one would welcome lower rates more than the homebuilders, who have just finished their worst year since the recession of 1982. The housing industry was sluggish through most of 1989 as the Fed pushed up interest rates as it sought to slow the economy and curtail inflation. As concerns grew that the economy might be slowing too much, the Fed allowed interest rates to gradually fall in recent months _ but not by enough to help the homebuilding industry. David Seiders, chief economist for the organization Bush was addressing, said he is counting on a ``moderate decline in interest rates in the first half of the year'' to sustain his organization's forecast for a better year this year. The Commerce Department on Thursday reported that housing starts _ construction begun on new homes and apartments _ tumbled by 8 percent in December, the worst performance since October 1982. Fitzwater said the plunge was ``not good news,'' although analysts blamed much of the drop on unseasonably cold weather in much of the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Met's Changes Bury Pillsbury's Former Culture
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 6th graf to CORRECT employment figure to 57,000, delete reference to 1988 employment level; uppicks 7th graf pvs: ``My favorite ...
DOC.TEXT: The Pillsbury Dough Boy has undergone a dizzying year of change under new owner Grand Metropolitan PLC as the British conglomerate made painful cuts that many inside the food company say were overdue. ``There had been a strangulation of the organization _ too many layers,'' said former Pillsbury executive David Webber. ``It wasn't like a smooth-running machine that all of a sudden toppled.'' The transformation began Jan. 4, 1989, when London-based Grand Met acquired Pillsbury for $5.8 billion, ending a hostile takeover bid that included expensive court battles in Minnesota and Delaware. The changes have ranged from a revamping of Pillsbury's Burger King fast-food subsidiary to the sale of seafood and restaurant businesses and the closure of unproductive facilities. Another major restructuring was announced Thursday, a $140 million investment to modernize food plants and lay off 1,300 workers over the next 18 months. The job losses could be offset by at least 800 new jobs, the company said. The restructuring will reduce to about 57,000 the number of employees at Pillsbury and at Burger King headquarters and company-owned stores. Pillsbury and Burger King operate separately. ``My favorite analogy is burning our boats in the bay,'' said Ian Martin, Pillsbury's new chief executive officer and a Grand Met veteran. ``I like to stand with my troops on the hillside and say, `There stand the boats. They're burning. We're not going back out by sea. The only way we win is by going over the hill.''' Webber said Martin wasted no time demonstrating the gung-ho approach. The 11-year Pillsbury executive was fired in July _ and received a generous severance package _ after presenting a flat sales projection for the beleaguered frozen pizza division. ``In my terms,'' Martin said, ``that's planning for failure.'' The changes have coincided with a 30 percent increase in operating income at Pillsbury over the first nine months of 1989 compared with the same period a year earlier, Grand Met says. The company does not disclose net profit for Pillsbury. Grand Met, with 1989 sales of $9.5 billion, is staking Pillsbury's future largely on its Green Giant vegetables, the line of baking products represented by the Dough Boy, Haagen-Dazs ice cream, frozen pizza and Burger King. The fast-food unit reported sales of $5.4 billion last year and added $119 million to Grand Met's operating profit for the year ended Sept. 30. Besides beefing up Burger King's advertising campaign, Grand Met has appointed Haagen-Dazs quality control executive Sam Yong to improve quality at the chain _ an area considered one of its faults. ``They are more decisive. They don't hesitate,'' said William Pothitos, a Burger King franchisee in Montreal. ``The last regime used to manage by committee.'' Said Webber of the man who fired him: ``I do think Ian Martin was a very welcome addition. There had been a strangulation of the organization _ too many layers.'' Under former Chairman William Spoor, Pillsbury routinely underwent double-digit growth. But the company grew awkward and after John Stafford took control in 1985, it sputtered. Profits, which hit $208.1 million in fiscal 1986, were headed for a dismal $69.3 million in fiscal 1988 when Spoor returned from retirement to replace Stafford. By then the company was ripe for a takeover and Philip L. Smith, hired from the former General Foods Corp., had been chairman less than a month when Grand Met made its unsolicited tender offer of $60 a share on Oct. 4. Smith ultimately left with a ``golden parachute'' severance payment worth more than $8 million. Martin said Pillsbury had been suffering from inertia. Most of the plans carried out by Grand Met were ``somewhere in the bowels of the organization,'' he said. ``We just went ahead and did it. I don't know, somehow they seemed to have bruised feet in the starting blocks. ``When I move, I move quickly,'' he said. B. Sham Moteelall, 39, the former transportation manager for the industrial foods division and one of the victims of Grand Met's drastic restructuring, thinks Martin moved too quickly. ``I figured I was the guy who was going to survive,'' said Moteelall, who was fired during an office champagne party in April. ``When they start herding people out the doors, how do they know they're herding the right ones? How do they know they're not cutting into the bone?''

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Group Calls for $1 Billion Security Fund
DOC.TEXT: An organization that represents airline passengers on Friday called for a $1 levy on all air tickets to finance a $1 billion program to improve airline security and fight terrorism. Geoffrey Lipman, secretary-general of the International Foundation for Airline Passengers, said such a fund would contribute towards research into more sophisticated security technology and improved training of airline staff, particularly in Third World countries. He cited a survey by the foundation that showed 80 percent of travelers questioned would support such a charge on tickets. The proposed fund would supplement existing security expenditures by governments and airlines, Lipman added. Some U.S. airlines, such as Pan Am and Trans World Airlines, add $5 to the cost of a trans-Atlantic ticket to cover security screening for international flights. ``It is not a question of the money, it's the organization and the motivation,'' he told an American International Club audience in Geneva. ``It's the need to battle against the kind of inertia that sets in 12 months after Lockerbie,'' he said, referring to the bomb that downed Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland on Dec. 21, 1988, killing all 259 people on board and 11 people on the ground. Lipman called for tougher international action, including severing aviation links with countries known to support or protect air terrorists. He said that although many airports had tightened safety procedures, much more needed to be done to implement existing security conventions on issues such as baggage checks. In Washington, the Federal Aviation Administration met Friday with U.S. airline industry representatives on security issues. The agency was expected to appeal to the airlines not to go public when they receive terrorist threats against passenger flights.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Investment In Portugal Jumps 161 percent
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 1st graf to CORRECT percentage to 161 sted 232; uppicks 2nd graf pvs: The figures ...
DOC.TEXT: Foreign investment in Portugal rose 161 percent in 1989 to $2.4 billion, according to government figures cited by Portugese news media Friday. The figures reveal a rising trend: in 1988, direct foreign investment rose 124 percent to over $920 million, and in 1987, foreign investment also showed triple-digit gains. According to figures cited by Trade and Tourism Minister Joaquim Ferreira do Amaral, the main components of foreign investment last year were tourism and real estate with 34 percent, banking and insurance with 21 percent and manufacturing with 20 percent. Without giving figures, Ferreira do Amaral said Britain was the biggest investor in Portugal, followed by France, Spain, the United States and Japan.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Arbitration
Case Study: 65-Year-Old Widow Says She Lost It All, and Then Some
DOC.TEXT: Unsuspecting widows who say they lost it all because of irresponsible brokers entrusted with the nest egg? They don't make this stuff up. Elfy Willdorff, 65, of New York, claims she lost more than $1 million in the October 1987 stock market crash because of risky trading by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Legal papers filed in her arbitration case show Mrs. Willdorff opened a retail account at Shearson in 1983 with her life savings, including money left by her husband, who ran a small dental supply business. The claim accuses broker Walter Kovler, himself around 80 years old, with unsuitable and unsupervised trading in speculative stock options using the conservative stock-and-bond portfolio she brought to the Wall Street firm. Mrs. Willdorff's case typifies disputes resolved out of court in arbitration before a panel usually consisting of two independent arbitrators and one from the securities industry. ``This is the horror that occurred to thousands of unwitting small investors who will never be able to recover from what happened in 1987,'' said attorney Theodore Eppenstein. ``Mrs. Willdorff went from a millionaire to insolvency in a few weeks.'' When Mrs. Willdorff opened her account, she signed a contract requiring her to submit any grievance to arbitration, forfeiting the right to sue. The Supreme Court last year upheld such contracts. Mrs. Willdorff will be bound by the decision of the arbitration panel, with limited rights of appeal. Studies show investors win about half their cases and victorious plaintiffs recover about half their losses. Eppenstein _ who unsuccessfully argued the Supreme Court case on arbitrations contracts _ said that given the size of the claim he would have sued Shearson rather than arbitrate. Theodore A. Krebsbach, Shearson's litigation director, declined to comment because arbitration proceedings are supposed to be private. ``I think any claimant would be upset with us if we went public with the facts of a case that was pending,'' he said. German-born Mrs. Willdorff, separated from her parents in 1939 and taken to England as part of a wartime child rescue mission, had invested in blue-chip securities until she took her account to Shearson, the legal papers state. Her account statements show total equity of $938,164 on Sept. 27, 1987, which turned into a deficit of $400,145 on Oct. 31, 12 days after the crash. The complaint says Shearson engaged in risky options trading that was unsuitable given Mrs. Willdorff's age, financial needs and investing history _ a common claim in customer-broker disputes. Options trading is highly speculative but generates higher broker commissions than routine stock transactions. The complaint states Mrs. Willdorff's income is about $10,000 a year from the dental supply business, Social Security and West German wartime reparations payments. The papers say Shearson knew she relied on her account for living expenses, including a rent-stabilized one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan. The papers also claim Shearson failed to supervise the broker, breached a duty to act in the customer's best interest, reassured Mrs. Willdorff that her investments were safe and failed to tell her when her money evaporated.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Sunday, Jan. 21

DOC.HEAD: Stocks End Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close, details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices put in a mixed performance on London's Stock Exchange Friday after weathering a particularly hectic week. Over the last five sessions, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index lost nearly 2 percent in value. Only on Wednesday did the index post a moderate gain. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 1.9 points, or 0.08 percent, at 2,335.0. Share prices have been unsettled by declines in bond markets around the world that were sparked by rising concern about interest rates. Instability in the Soviet Union and worries over British wage inflation and labor disputes have dampened investors' appetite for shares. But dealers said Friday's session was dull amid confusion over the market's next near-term direction. ``People are going to do little or nothing until they feel that bond and equity markets have settled down,'' one trader said. The Financial Times 30-share index rose 3.6 points to close at 1,868.0 points. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 0.82 point to close at 1,276.46. Volume came to a light 391.0 million shares, compared with 462.2 million shares on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Seaway Set Export Steel Record in '89 as Total Tonnage Fell
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The St. Lawrence Seaway handled a record 1.5 million metric tons of export steel in 1989 but total cargo tonnage declined 3.4 million metric tons due largely to a drop in Canadian grain shipments, according to preliminary year-end statistics. ``The seaway handled 422 percent more export steel this year than it did last year,'' said James L. Emery, administrator of the Saint Lawrence Seaway Development Corp., which operates the U.S. portion of the inland waterway. In 1988, 287,000 metric tons of export steel traversed the waterway, which runs from the Atlantic Ocean through the Great Lakes to Duluth, Minn. The previous record year for export steel through the seaway was 1982, when 1.25 million metric tons were moved. ``Seventy percent of U.S. steel production is in the Great Lakes region and, obviously, the seaway has been increasing its share of that steel,'' Emery said in a statement Thursday. Nationally, U.S. steel exports are estimated to have reached 3.6 million metric tons in 1989, double 1988's total, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The institute attributed the jump in U.S. steel exports to the low value of the dollar, an improvement in steel quality, intense marketing of U.S. steel in Europe and the Far East and improved productivity. Stone and salt were also shipped through the seaway in record amounts. Stone was up 4 percent, from 432,000 metric tons in 1988 to 448,000 metric tons. Salt increased 34 percent, from one million metric tons in 1988 to 1.3 million metric tons. On the downside, Canadian grain shipments through the seaway dropped 4.2 million metric tons last year, according to the seaway corporation. Other declines were seen in fuel oil, which dropped 35 percent; chemicals, down 22 percent; coke, down 13 percent, and scrap iron and steel, 14 percent. As a result, total seaway tonnage dropped to 37.1 million metric tons, a 9 percent decline from 1988's total of 40.5 million metric tons. While all these figures were preliminary, Emery said the final tonnages would vary by a few metric tons if at all when they are released next month. Almost 2,800 commercial vessels traveled through U.S. seaway locks in 1989. On average, they carried cargo weighing 17,292 tons, about 2 percent more than in 1988, the corporation said. The last vessel cleared the seaway on Dec. 23 and the waterway was closed for the winter. Locks are now undergoing improvements and winter maintenance.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Put Off Decision on Neil Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators are putting off a decision on whether to act against Neil Bush, the president's son, after reviewing information from an investigation of Bush's role in the failure of a Colorado thrift association. An internal committee of the Office of Thrift Supervision met into the evening Thursday and said Friday that it would reconvene Tuesday on the matter. Meanwhile, the thrift office, a bureau of the Treasury Department, said in a statement that W. James Metz, majority stockholder of Silverado, became the fourth officer of the thrift to accept a lifetime ban from working for a federally insured financial institution. Bush, 34, was a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, Denver, from 1985 until August 1988, when his father accepted the Republican presidential nonimation. Regulators shut down the thrift in December 1988, blaming the institution's management for heavily investing in Colorado's ailing commercial real estate market. The collapse of Silverado, now operating as part of Columbia Savings, the largest thrift in Colorado, is expected to cost taxpayers up to $1 billion. Regulators are focusing their investigation on what they said was ``an exceptionally large number of problem transactions'' between Silverado insiders and borrowers. Bush, who was a partner in an oil exploration firm, JNB Exploration, had business deals with two of Silverado's major borrowers, developers Bill L. Walters and Ken Good. Bush has said in interviews that he has nothing to hide and is cooperating fully with investigators. He met several times last week with thrift office enforcement officials. Possible civil penalties Bush could receive range from banning him from the industry to ordering him to refrain from violating banking regulations in the future. Such civil penalties would not interfere with any later criminal prosecution if one was indicated. Separately, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is considering whether to file a civil suit against the S&L's officers and director seeking recovery of Silverado's losses. A former federal S&L examiner, James Moroney, has alleged that regulators dragged their feet on Silverado because of Bush's presence on the institution's board and its other political connections. Regulators in Washington have said they investigated Moroney's allegations and found them invalid. Bush has said he never sought to use his political connections and would not have if asked. Metz agreed to the industry ban without admitting or denying wrongdoing. He will be prohibited from working for an S&L, bank or credit union without prior approval from regulators. Previously, former Silverado chairman Michael R. Wise and former vice chairmen Richard K. Vandapool and Robert M. Lewis had agreed to accept a similar penalty.

DOC.HEAD: European Community Foreign Ministers Meet On Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Western European foreign ministers will gather Saturday amid mounting calls to deepen their political union and come up with more money for Eastern Europe. The special session of the 12-nation European Community in Dublin Castle, Ireland, follows a bold call this week from the community's executive body, the European Commission, for accelerated political and economic unity. European Commission President Jacques Delors suggested the community increase its budget by $1.65 billion to aid Eastern Europe and indicated that East Germany could soon join the European Community. France and West Germany, pressing the pace for closer union, backed the suggestion, but Britain immediately signaled caution and opposed new loans to Eastern Europe's six emerging democracies _ Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Bulgaria and Romania. Britain contends the East bloc nations are already deep in debt and says the emphasis should be on training in the running of a free enterprise economy. Ireland, which on Jan. 1 took over the six-month, rotating presidency of the European Community, was anxious to avoid an open dispute. But the Irish Foreign Ministry acknowledged Friday there were ``differences of emphasis between the community countries.'' Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins summoned the Saturday night meeting to review the fast-changing situation in Eastern Europe. But the meeting also is likely to rekindle differences over political and monetary integration. Delors, a French socialist, called for a new ``institutional structure'' for the community, implying wide-ranging new powers for the Brussels-based commission over national governments. In London, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher described his remarks as a ``great pity.'' Delors also envisaged special links between the community and the six Eastern European countries, adding East Germany was a ``special case.'' ``There is a place for East Germany in the community should it so wish,'' he said. The European Community is coordinating aid to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe at the request of last July's summit in Paris of the world's seven most industrialized cuntries, the United States, Japan, Canada, France, West Germany, Britain and Italy. At that time only Poland and Hungary had moved away from communist rule. Aid totalling some $6 billion has been pledged by 24 Western countries to Poland and Hungary. Since then, Western nations have offered similar help to the four other countries. Proposed aid includes a development bank called the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat, Soybean Futures Fall On Moisture, Slack Demand
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and soybean futures prices fell Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade, dropping sharply near the close on selling linked to slack export demand and improved growing conditions for winter wheat and South American soybeans. Corn futures finished narrowly mixed. Wheat futures sank to their lowest levels in almost four months, extending a decline that began Thursday when large amounts of snow and rain began falling on wheat fields from the Texas panhandle to western Kansas. But Friday's pattern of steep losses only in the March and May wheat contracts indicated the selling was inspired more by slack export demand than the beneficial weather, said Jerry Zusel, manager of exchange floor operations for Balfour Maclaine Corp. In the wheat market, the March and May contracts represent stockpiled grain while contracts for later delivery represent the new crop. ``I think today's action, at least for soft red winter wheat, signals that old-crop wheat is very expensive and prospects for any new business is not very great in the near term,'' Zusel said. The soybean market has been trending lower all week on reports of rain in southern Brazil, an important soybean-growing region. At the close, wheat futures were \ cent to 5 cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.92} a bushel; corn was } cent lower to } cent higher with March at $2.41{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent higher with March at $1.38\ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 5\ cents lower with January at $5.57} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: China Reports Record Grain Harvest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: China harvested a record 407.9 million tons of grain last year, the official China Daily reported Friday. Agriculture Minister He Kang, speaking at an agricultural conference Thursday, also said 1 million scientists and teachers will be sent to the countryside this year as part of a drive to further increase grain output. China reached its previous high of 407.3 million tons in 1984, but output fell to 379 million tons in 1985, the first of four straight disappointing harvests. In 1989, grain production was 394 million tons. The poor crops resulted from bad weather and a decrease in land devoted to grain crops. Farmers recently have built houses or small factories on farmland or switching to vegetables and other crops that pay better than grain. The government, concerned the nation was losing its ability to feed itself, has tightened restrictions on the conversion of farmland and urged farmers to meet their quotas for grain. Last year, it also increased subsidies to rural areas after 1988 when local banks ran out of money to pay farmers and were forced to issue IOUs. He said fields planted with grain increased by 4.9 million acres last year, to about 272 million acres. He said the central budget had budgeted $3.9 billion for agricultural production in 1990, an increase of about $42.5 million. Agriculture experts have said China must produce 500 million tons of grain annually by 2000 just to keep up with population growth.

DOC.HEAD: Lufthansa, Interflug in Cooperation Accord
DOC.TEXT: Deutsche Lufthansa AG of West Germany said Friday it has reached agreement with Interflug, the East German national airline, on a broad cooperation plan involving passenger service, cargo and other areas. Lufthansa said it and Interflug have agreed to work together as two independent airlines ``to improve the quality of their services in the interest of our customers and to strengthen the efficiency of their airline operations and the market positions of both companies.'' Based on a ``treaty'' similar to that planned between the East and West German governments, the two airlines will develop joint projects to find new market segments and fields of cooperation, Lufthansa said. The two companies also will attempt to remove the remaining barriers to air traffic between the two German countries and Berlin. Currently, neither Lufthansa nor Interflug are allowed to cross the border between the two countries, and neither airline is permitted to fly to West Berlin. The East Berlin airport, Schoenefeld, is located outside the city limits to circumvent the Allied powers' restrictions on air traffic to East Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: PaineWebber Earnings Up Sharply
DOC.TEXT: PaineWebber Group Inc. said Friday its 1989 fourth-quarter earnings rose sharply despite losses from the Oct. 13 market drop and hard times thoughout the industry. PaineWebber said its earnings for the full year rose 18.5 percent. The firm is expected to be one of the few on Wall Street to report profits for last year, one of the least profitable in the decade. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, PaineWebber reported net income of $10.9 million, or 20 cents per share after deducting preferred stock dividends, compared with $512,000, or a 20-cents-a-share loss, in the same 1988 quarter. Revenue totaled $452 million for the quarter, up slightly from $447 million the year before. But PaineWebber said that accounting for its preferred stock dividend requirements, net income was $4.96 million in the fourth quarter, up from a $5.73 million loss in the year-previous fourth quarter. PaineWebber Chairman Donald B. Marron said the quarterly earnings were reduced because of arbitrage trading losses in United Airlines during the 190-point stock market plunge on Oct. 13. For the full year, the firm reported net income of $51.96 million, or $1.05 a share, compared with earnings of $42.4 million, or 58 cents a share, in the samd 1988 period. Revenue was $1.73 billion, a slight decline from $1.75 billion in 1988. After accounting for preferred stock dividends, the firm's annual earnings rose to $28.2 million from $16.7 million in 1988. PaineWebber attributed the annual increase to improvements in retail sales, institutional sales and trading, investment banking and international businesses. PaineWebber employs about 12,900 people in nearly 300 offices worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Plans to Investigate Federated-Allied Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.TEXT: The House Judiciary Committee will investigate the bankruptcy filings by Campeau Corp.'s U.S. retail divisions and look into the consequences of leveraged buyouts, Chairman Jack Brooks announced Friday. Brooks, D-Texas, said the Judiciary subcommittee on economic and commercial law would hold hearings on the court-supervised reorganization of Federated Stores Inc., the renamed holding company of Campeau's U.S. operations, and the potential for a wave of new bankruptcies resulting from debt-financed takeovers in recent years. ``The gold rush is over now, and the time for reassessment has arrived. I intend to move quickly in the upcoming session of Congress to consider the lessons of the Campeau bankruptcy, and how LBO bankruptcies will affect consumers, suppliers, creditors and the American economy,'' Brooks said. Swamped by debt, Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. divisions filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Act on Monday. The 258 stores run by Federated and Allied will remain open while the court oversees their restructuring. Toronto-based Campeau's acquisition of Federated in 1988 and Allied in 1986 left the two saddled with $7.7 billion in debt. Together Federated and Allied run nine department store chains such as Bloomingdale's, Burdines, Jordan Marsh, Rich's and Lazarus. ``With Campeau's bankruptcy in the first days of the 1990s, our nation has begun to reap the bitter harvest of the leveraged buyout frenzy of the 1980s,'' said Brooks, who is also chairman of the subcommittee, which has jurisdiction over competition policy as well as bankruptcy law. ``I fear that the Campeau Chapter 11 filing in Cincinnati this week is only the beginning, and that we will see the takeover trophies of the 1980s become the bankruptcy case names of the 1990s,'' Brooks said.

DOC.HEAD: Original Kentucky Fried Chicken Site To Be Museum
DOC.TEXT: The first Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant is being restored as a working museum in this southeastern Kentucky town, which hatched a business that now has $5 billion in sales in 58 countries. Officials working on the restoration hope to finish the project in time for the 100th birthday of the restaurant's founder, Col. Harland Sanders. The unveiling of the new museum will coincide with Laurel County's 1990 World Chicken Festival. The restaurant and motel originally were called Sanders Court and Cafe. That's where the colonel developed and perfected his famous recipe and the technique of pressure frying, said Wallace Hebert, marketing director for J.R.N. Inc., owner of the franchise. There are now 7,900 Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants in the United States and 57 foreign countries, including one in Tiananmen Square in Beijing, China, said Richard Detwiler, a spokesman for Kentucky Fried Chicken Corp. Retail sales were $5 billion in 1988, he said. Franchise owner John R. Neal has wanted to restore the original restaurant for many years, said Hebert. It was closed in September 1988 and moved to a temporary location next door. A restoration team is advertising to purchase any artifacts from the original restaurant, which opened in 1940, including furniture, menus and kitchen utensils, he said. Members of the community have donated silverware, old uniforms, tables, chairs and other items from the old restaurant. One of the more unusual features of the old Sanders Court and Cafe was a model motel room that guests had to pass through in order to use the bathroom or the pay telephone, said Hebert. This was Sanders' marketing strategy to show people the quality of the motel rooms and boost his motel business, said Hebert. ``He was a shrewd marketer. He really was,'' he said. An official with the Laurel County Tourism Commission said he hopes the museum and the chicken festival, which will feature cooking contests, two parades and a Col. Sanders look-a-like contest, will boost the region's tourist economy. ``We hope to make this an annual event,'' said Ken Harvey of the World Chicken Festival.

DOC.HEAD: CapCities Buys Five Business Magazines, Milford Publishing
DOC.TEXT: Capital Cities-ABC Inc. said Friday it had acquired five business magazines and other assets from Thomson Information-Publishing Group, an affiliate of Toronto-based media giant International Thomson. Meanwhile, the Milford (Conn.) Citizen reported Friday that Capital Cities has purchased Milford Publishing Co., publisher of the daily Milford Citizen and seven other community newspapers. Terms of the deals were not disclosed. Capital Cities said the purchase of the five business magazines was made through its Fairchild Publications, which publishes about 30 newspapers and magazines including Women's Wear Daily and the fashion magazine W. Fairchild acquired Thomson Information's retail press division which publishes the business magazines Video Business, a weekly with a controlled circulation of 40,000; Cablevision, biweekly, 13,000; Communications Engineering and Design, monthly, 12,000; Autosound & Communications, monthly, 23,700, and Consumer Electronics, monthly, 60,500. The retail press division also includes several trade show dailies and cable directories. Fairchild spokesman Phil Meeks declined to say how much revenue the division generated last year. Milford Publishing, previously owned by Goodson Newspapers of New Jersey, will now join Capital Cities' Shore Line Newspapers Group, which publishes 18 weekly and semiweekly newspapers and shoppers. Capital Cities announced Monday that it had purchased Imprint, a chain of 14 weeklies in Connecticut. Capital Cities owns the ABC television network, a portion of the cable network ESPN, eight independent TV stations, six radio networks and 21 radio stations.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Switch Denied for Home Savings
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Friday denied California's Home Savings of America, the largest and one of the healthiest thrift institutions in the nation, permission to switch to the insurance fund backing commercial bank deposits. Home Savings, whose deposits are insured by the Savings Association Insurance Fund, had applied to merge with its wholly-owned subsidiary, Bowery Savings Bank of New York, which is already insured by the Bank Insurance Fund. Members of the savings fund pay higher deposit insurance premiums than members of the bank fund. The Office of Thrift Supervision said it denied the switch because S&L bailout legislation passed last August bars thrifts from pulling out of the Savings Association Insurance Fund for five years. Home Savings had applied for the switch to the thrift office's predecessor, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, before the law was enacted. The thrift already has filed a federal lawsuit trying to complete the Bowery merger, and spokeswoman Mary Triggs said Home would continue to fight that case in the courts. The Irwindale, Calif., thrift had assets of $44 billion on Dec. 31. Its withdrawal from the savings insurance fund would be a major blow to the fund, which is intended to pay for S&L failures after the money from the bailout bill runs out.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Gain Ground
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices gained ground Friday thanks to foreign buying following a steep sell-off the day before. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond rose 21-32 point, or $6.56 for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which falls when prices advance, slipped to 8.26 percent from 8.33 percent late Thursday. Analysts said much of the improvement came in overseas trading of U.S. government securities in Tokyo and London before the New York market opened. Tokyo traders had been selling U.S. securities to make profits and offset losses in the struggling Japanese stock and bond markets. But on Friday, ``the Bank of Japan bought Japanese government bonds during the Tokyo session,'' said Kathleen Camilli, a money market economist with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ``That helped to support our market as well.'' ``It does look like we've reached (bond price) levels where we're attracting some foreign demand,'' said William V. Sullivan, director of money- market research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Bond prices tumbled 29-32 point, or about $9 per $1,000 face amount, on Thursday in reaction to increased fears of inflation and comments by two Federal Reserve Board governors that they did had no plans to ease monetary policy. The government reported the highest year-end inflation rate in eight years and economists forecast a sharp rise in consumer prices in January, which depressed the bond market. The market had little reaction to a survey released Friday by the Fed's Philadelphia bureau that the economy was increasing slightly in January in the region. It also did not react strongly to President Bush calling for lower interest rates to spur growth. The White House on Thursday directly said the Fed should lower interest rates. Lower interest rates, which encourage businesses and banks to borrow money, increasing demand for bonds, send prices of government securities higher. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term government issues gained 3-32 point to \ point, intermediate maturities rose 5-16 point to 7-16 point and long-term issues advanced 19-32 point, according to figures provided by Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was up 3.67 at 1,171.77. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.98 percent as the discount declined 5 basis points to 7.73 percent. Yields on six-month bills slipped to 7.99 percent as the discount lost 6 basis points to 7.59 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.97 percent as the discount lost 5 basis points to 7.43 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 8[ percent, unchanged from late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 92 5-16, up 1-16 point. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.35 percent from 7.36 percent late Thursday.

DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously Jan. 18 that a restructuring of Pillsbury Inc. had reduced the number of employees at Pillsbury and its Burger King business to about 16,500 from 104,000 in mid-1988. The combined employment at Pillsbury, Burger King headquarters and Burger King restaurants owned by Pillsbury's parent Grand Metropolitan PLC is about 57,000. The story also erroneously reported Grand Met's annual sales as $9.5 billion. Annual sales totaled about $15 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Closes Mostly Lower; Gold Falls

Analysts said trading in the U.S. dollar was quiet. Ronald Holzer, chief dealer with Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said the foreign-exchange markets focused on the Canadian dollar, which has fallen throughout the week in response to the Bank of Canada's decision to ease its monetary policy and allow interest rates to decline. At the close of trading in New York, the U.S. dollar was worth 1.1836 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1713 late Thursday and 1.1573 a week earlier. In European trading, the U.S. dollar closed at 1.1786 Canadian dollars, up from late Thursday's 1.1713. Ken Foxcroft, senior vice president at Toronto-Dominion Bank, said, ``Interest rates in Canada are starting to ease while rates in the rest of the world are continuing to move up, so a lot of the attraction of investing in Canada is disappearing.'' Analysts attributed some of the declines in the U.S. dollar to profit-taking ahead of the weekend. The dollar fell against the British pound. In London, one British pound cost $1.6475 late Friday, more expensive for buyers than Thursday's late $1.6445. In later New York trading, a pound cost $1.6470, compared to late Thursday's $1.6435.
