DOC.HEAD: New Jersey to Consider Rules on Long-Distance Information Systems
DOC.TEXT: State regulators are considering whether long-distance phone companies should be required to provide information about competing services when they suffer outages like the one that crippled AT&T's network on Monday. ``We want to make sure that a customer who wants to make a phone call can get the information to get a carrier to complete the call,'' said George Dawson, a spokesman for the state Board of Public Utilities. AT&T's long-distance service nationwide was out for nine hours on Monday. Company officials traced the problem to a bug in a new software program. Dawson said BPU officals had read news accounts of people who complained that during the outage, AT&T operators refused to give out the access codes of the nation's two other major long-distance carriers, MCI and US Sprint. Dawson said the board itself had received no complaints. ``I don't think anybody is thinking that AT&T has the responsibility to pick another carrier for the caller,'' Dawson said. But he said long-distance companies and the state's two local telephone companies, New Jersey Bell and United Telephone, are required as public utilities to provide any telephone numbers requested, including those of competing-long-distance companies. New Jersey has six long-distance carriers and a seventh company that transmits data long distance, Dawson said. Twenty companies package long-distance service for resale. AT&T spokesman Harry Baumgartner said the company was concerned that whatever rule the BPU proposed ``would equitably apply to all long-distance companies.'' Baumgartner said that more than 400 long-distance companies operated nationally, plus another 300 alternative operator services. ``It's extremely difficult, if not impossible to track all of their access codes,'' he said. Moreover, he said, ``AT&T does not want to be in the position of making preferential decisions'' in telling callers which competitor to call. Monday's outage struck quickly and unexpectedly, and AT&T did not have working procedures in place for its operators, Baumgartner said. AT&T changed procedures to allow operators to provide the access codes at about 6 p.m. New Jersey Bell operators do not give access codes, but will provide telephone numbers for people to call to obtain the codes, said New Jersey Bell spokeswoman Karen Johnson. ``We are really prohibited from giving out carrier-specific information, and we feel the access codes fall into that category,'' Ms. Johnson said. She said many long distance companies did not want other companies giving out their access codes. United Telephone operators may not recommend long distance carriers, said Glenn Lewis, a United spokesman. He said the company did check with its lawyers during the outage to see what information operators could give out.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Slump On Economic Slowdown Fears
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices fell sharply Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting fears of an economic slowdown, which would reduce demand for the metal. On other commodity markets, precious metals were mixed; oil futures rose; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Copper futures finished 1.7 cents to 3.05 cents lower with the contract for delivery in January at $1.01 a pound. The more heavily traded March contract settled at 99.30 cents a pound. The selloff extended Thursday's more moderate decline and resulted from growing perceptions that copper demand is slackening after more than two years of strong consumption, analysts said. ``What really highlighted the fact that demand is likely to weaken is the recent stock market weakness,'' said James Steel, a metals analyst with the futures brokerage Refco Inc. ``With the U.S. stock market going down and the London and Japanese markets going down also, that's a clear indication that as we go into 1990, demand will be soft,'' he said. Thursday's Commerce Department report of an 8 percent drop in housing starts to the lowest level in seven years supported perceptions of an economic slowdown, as did announcements of worker layoffs by several large manufacturers. Copper demand is closely tied to the nation's economic health, especially to the construction industry which accounts for more than 40 percent of copper usage. Analyst Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. noted a lack of buying recently on the physical copper market at a time when copper consumption is normally on the rise. In precious-metals trading on the Comex, gold futures settled unchanged to 30 cents lower with February at $410.90 a troy ounce; silver was 1 cent to 1.2 cents higher with March at $5.25 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures climbed sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, led by the Februry crude oil contract, which expires on Monday. The buying of crude was mainly due to concerns about a possible squeeze in supplies of crude for delivery against the February contract, analysts said. Heating oil rallied and gasoline followed as temperatures fell in the Northeast after several days of springlike conditions. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 25 cents to 91 cents higher with February at $23.67 a barrel; heating oil was .26 cent to 1.82 cents higher with February at 63.66 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .12 cent lower to .91 cent higher with February at 61.62 cents a gallon. Wheat and soybean futures fell on the Chicago Board of Trade, dropping sharply near the close on selling linked to slack export demand and improved growing conditions for winter wheat and South American soybeans. Wheat futures sank to their lowest levels in almost four months, extending a decline that began Thursday when large amounts of snow and rain began falling on wheat fields from the Texas panhandle to southern Kansas. But Friday's pattern of steep losses only in the March and May wheat contracts indicated the selling was inspired more by slack export demand than the beneficial weather. Wheat futures settled 5} cents lower to \ cent higher with March at $3.92 a bushel; corn was unchanged to } cent lower with March at $2.41} a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to } cent higher with March at $1.39 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 6 cents lower with January at $5.58 a bushel. Cattle futures posted strong gains on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid expectations for stronger spot markets next week. Live cattle futures finished .05 cent to .55 cent higher with February at 79.35 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .43 cent higher with January at 83.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .08 cent lower to .18 cent higher with February at 49.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .80 cent lower to .05 cent higher with February at 55.15 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Ralston Purina Net Fell 35 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Ralston Purina Co. said Thursday its net income fell 35 percent in the October-December quarter, largely because profits in the year-earlier period were swelled by a large one-time gain. Profits in the company's fiscal first quarter totalled $130 million or $2.03 a share, down from $202 million or $2.99 a share a year earlier. The year-earlier profit figure was boosted by a $70 million gain on the sale of Van Camp Seafood Co., the maker of Chicken of the Sea tuna fish. If that one-time gain were not included, Ralston's earnings per share would have increased to $2.03 from $1.94. Sales rose 11 percent to $1.88 billion from $1.68 billion. ``When you read everthing in, I think it's a very positive quarter,'' said Roger Spencer, an analyst at PaineWebber in Chicago. Ralston spokesman Pat Farrell said higher advertising and promotion costs for the introduction of several kinds of dog snacks trimmed profits in the quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied Preparing to Explain Operations to Stores
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp.'s Federated and Allied retail divisions sent suppliers figures Friday showing they have more than $335 million to finance shipments of new merchandise for their stores. Figures released by the companies show Federated Department Stores Inc. has a current cash balance of $220 million and Allied Stores Corp. has $117 million in cash. Federated and Allied, which filed Monday for U.S. Bankruptcy Court protection from their creditors, also have arranged credit lines totalling $700 million to finance their reorganizations. ``The company said we had sufficient cash to maintain operations without the (reorganization) financing,'' spokeswoman Carol Sanger said. Allied said it wouldn't need to draw on the reorganization financing until March, and Federated said it wouldn't need to use the new financing until the fall season. Some suppliers, including Liz Claiborne and Leslie Fay, began new shipments to Campeau's stores Thursday, while many others said they were withholding merchandise until they see the retailers' financing. Retail industry analysts had identified renewed merchandise shipments as the most pressing need for the chains' stores, especially those in the South, where the spring selling season begins soon. Meanwhile, Federated and Allied were preparing teams of executives to visit stores to explain operations under bankruptcy court protection, Ms. Sanger said. ``The operation of the stores will continue unchanged. This is just to assure them that they are having all their questions answered,'' she said. Top executives of chains belonging to Federated and Allied visited the Cincinnati headquarters for briefings Wednesday. In their bankruptcy court filing, Federated and Allied listed total assets of $9.1 billion and debts of $7.7 billion. The retailing giants, which own such chains as Bloomingdale's, Lazarus and Burdines, have 260 stores and 100,000 employees in 43 states. Federated says it has a $400 million line of credit for reorganization from a group of banks led by Citibank of New York. Allied says it has a similar agreement for $300 million from Chemical Bank. Both agreements still need bankruptcy court approval. Court approval for the retailers' reorganization credit lines should take four to six weeks, Ms. Sanger said. ``It's not finalized yet, but then we have no need of it yet and we don't anticipate needing it for quite some time,'' she said. The first hearing in the case is scheduled for next Thursday, when U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug will consider a request by the retailers to pay obligations related to employee benefits that were due before the bankruptcy court filing.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Gain
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures ended higher in volatile trading Friday, led by a jump in crude oil. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the February contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude, surged 91 cents to close at $23.67 a barrel. The March contract closed 49 cents higher at $22.08 a barrel while April rose 40 cents to $21.37. Analysts attributed the sharp rise in the February contract to last-minute buying before the contract expires on Monday. Among refined products, No. 2 heating oil for delivery in February advanced 1.82 cents to 63.66 cents a gallon, March gained 1.01 cents to 59.68 cents and April ended 0.76 cent higher at 56.82 cents a gallon. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for February delivery added 0.91 cent to 61.62 cents a gallon, March rose 0.89 cent to 62.69 cents and April gained 0.74 cent to 63.43 cents. Analysts said strong demand for heating oil during an unusual cold spell in December tightened supplies of crude in some parts of the country. ``The expiration of the February crude contract on Monday sparked aggressive short-covering as supplies of sweet crude are tight in Cushing, Oklahoma,'' said Andrew Lebow, senior broker with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. Energy analysts said heating oil continued to stabilize after a 19 cent drop in the last three weeks that followed December's price spurt due to strong demand brought on by frigid weather.

DOC.HEAD: TCI Spinoff To Help Deal With Possible Regulatory Constraints
DOC.TEXT: Tele-Communications Inc.'s plan to spin off a new company to handle its programming interests will help it deal with possible regulatory constraints and to continue to grow, industry analysts said Friday. TCI is the nation's largest cable system operator and also has extensive interests in cable programming, including a 22 percent stake in Turner Broadcasting System Inc. On Thursday, John Malone, TCI's chief executive officer, said the TCI board authorized management to develop a plan to form and distribute to shareholders a new company that would contain its programming interests, its minority interest in some cable systems and other cable service businesses. The spinoff would ``create a new growth vehicle for TCI shareholders, unencumbered of potential regulatory constraints or conflicting objectives,'' he said. The announcement came after the close of trading on Thursday. In national over-the-counter trading, TCI rose $2.37{ a share to $17.37{ on Friday. The cable industry has come under increasing criticism in recent months in Congress because of rate increases over the past three years and because of the perceived influence some major operators have for determining whether new cable programs can be included among serviuces available on certain cable systems. Legislation has been proposed to regulate rates again for the first time since 1986 and to prohibit cable systems from owning interests in the programs they carry. John Reidy, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York, said the move would ``take the steam out of these legislative initiatives.'' ``The segregation of programming interests into a new company will really blunt the regulatory thrust,'' he said. The proposed spinoff would also help stockholders and investors focus on TCI's values, and create a growth vehicle for the giant cable company, said Michael Kupinski, a cable analyst for A.G. Edwards & Sons of St. Louis. TCI, which has about 11 million subscribers, had 1988 sales of $2.2 billion. Malone said the planned spinoff would be similar to earlier spinoffs of WestMarc Communications in 1984 and Republic Pictures in 1985. The company said the TCI that will remain after the divestiture will be devoted to managing the bulk of its present cable systems, which includes about 18 percent of the nation's cable subscribers. TCI said the decision to spin off assets came at a routine board of directors meeting during which TCI executives reportedly expressed dismay at how the company's stock has been faring in Wall Street. The stock, with other cable issues, has been depressed for several months due to regulatory fears. Besides Turner Broadcasting, TCI owns a 50 percent stake in the American Movie Classics cable channel, a 49 percent interest in The Discovery Channel and a 14 percent stake in Black Entertainment Television. TCI also has an interest in Prime Network, a regional sports programming partnership that includes Denver's Prime Sports Network, and recently agreed to acquire a 50 percent interest in the Showtime pay cable service. TCI executives said that in addition to the programming properties, TCI could transfer cable systems with 1 million to 2.5 million subscribers into the new corporation. Other properties reportedly being considered include the Netlink satellite service business, which packages cable programming for home-dish owners.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Throws Out Drug-Testing Rules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lede to CORRECT name of agency and clarify that ruling not limited to random testing; Subs 10th graf pvs bg'ng, The opinion, to fix agency name; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Friday threw out a bid by the Urban Mass Transportation Administration to test local transit system employees for drug use, including random testing. The U.S. District Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said the agency had exceeded its congressionally mandated authority in trying to impose uniform nationwide rules on local transit authorities. ``We believe that Congress intended for such matters to be handled locally with UMTA's guiding hand, not with an iron fist,'' the court said in an opinion filed by Chief Judge Patricia M. Wald. The decison upheld an appeal by transport unions and reversed an earlier decision by the U.S. District Court. The court battle began shortly after the authority issued regulations in December 1988 requiring all local transit systems receiving federal funds to assure a drug-free workforce. The regulations, similar to rules established for transport workers under the jurisdiction of the Department of Transportation, called for urinalysis testing of employees before employment, after an accident, when reasonable suspicion of drug use existed, randomly and before an employee suspended for drug use was allowed to return to work. The Amalgamated Transit Union and the Transport Workers Union of America contended the transport agency had no authority to impose a federal drug-testing program on all recipients of federal mass transit money. Jim La Sala, president of the Amalgamated Transit Union, said Friday that the UMTA's attempt to impose national standards was ``overkill and not sensitive to local concerns or issues.'' ``Local unions and mass transit employers are well-suited to themselves reach decisions on drug testing and employee assistance programs that reflect each local situation,'' La Sala said. ``There is no evidence of widespread drug use nationally in the mass transit industry and the UMTA knows it.'' The opinion said Congress had given local transit authorities, not the federal agency, the power to submit locally designed plans to deal with safety hazards, including drug abuse. A bid by the federal government to mandate ``a uniform national plan that is not in any respect tailored to local needs and circumstances'' cannot be squared with the language or intent of the legislation enacted by Congress, the court said. ``Unless and until Congress chooses to confer such authority to UMTA over safety matters, UMTA's uniform, national anti-drug program regulations do not represent a valid exercise of its statutory authority,'' the court said.

Three former executives were wrongly convicted of murder and other charges in the death of an employee who suffered cyanide poisoning on the job, the Illinois appellate court ruled. The 1985 case, believed to be the first in which corporate officials were convicted of murder in a job-related death, was sent back to Cook County Circuit Court. The appellate court ruling came Friday.

The House Judiciary Committee will investigate the bankruptcy filings by Campeau Corp.'s U.S. retail divisions and look into the consequences of leveraged buyouts, Chairman Jack Brooks announced. The Texas Democrat said Friday the Judiciary subcommittee on economic and commercial law would hold hearings on the court-supervised reorganization of Federated Stores Inc., the renamed holding company of Campeau's U.S. operations. The hearings also will examine the potential for a wave of new bankruptcies resulting from debt-financed takeovers in recent years, Brooks said.

Bank of New England Corp. said it expects to report a $1.05 billion loss for 1989 and said it was ``actively pursuing'' the sale of more than $6 billion in assets. The company, New England's second-largest bank holding company after Bank of Boston Corp., issued a statement Friday that also said it expected to enter a consent order with federal regulators to reshape the company's operations.

Tele-Communications Inc. stock rose in the wake of the announcement that the nation's lagest cable operator is considering spinning off a new company to handle its programming interests. Industry analysts said the proposal will help the company deal with possible regulatory constraints and to continue to grow. In national over-the-counter trading Friday, TCI rose $2.37{ a share to $17.37{.

A federal appeals court threw out a bid by the Urban Mass Transportation Administration to test local transit system employees for drug use, including random testing. The U.S. District Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said Friday the agency had exceeded its congressionally mandated authority in trying to impose uniform nationwide rules on local transit authorities. The decison upheld an appeal by transport unions and reversed an earlier decision by the U.S. District Court.

Federal engineers are stepping up their probe of possible automatic torso belt failures in the Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx that consumers have blamed for five deaths and 76 injuries, the government said. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Friday it was upgrading its investigation from a preliminary evaluation, involving mostly paperwork, to an engineering analysis in which engineers will study the components involved.

Campeau Corp.'s Federated and Allied retail divisions sent suppliers figures showing they have more than $335 million to finance shipments of new merchandise for their stores. Figures released by the companies Friday show Federated Department Stores Inc. has a current cash balance of $220 million and Allied Stores Corp. has $117 million in cash. Federated and Allied filed Monday for U.S. Bankruptcy Court protection from their creditors.

Roughly half of the 3.5 million low-income older Americans covered by Medicaid needlessly spend hundreds of dollars for private medical insurance, according to a private study. Between 1.5 million and 2 million people 65 and older are projected to have private insurance such as ``medigap'' policies even though Medicaid covers their medical expenses, the report said Friday. The study was commissioned and released by the American Association of Retired Persons and was based on interviews with a random sample of 1,500 older people contacted by telephone in January and February 1989.

President Bush issued an election-year call for lower taxes and interest rates, saying he's not satisfied with home mortgage rates hovering around 10 percent. Bush spoke Friday at the National Association of Home Builders convention in Atlanta before flying to Miami to campaign for the re-election of Republican Gov. Bob Martinez.

Stock prices finished higher Friday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 11.52 to 2,677.90, a loss for the week of 11.31 points. Bond prices gained ground. The dollar was mostly lower against other major currencies. Copper futures prices fell sharply; precious metals were mixed; oil futures rose; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: American Company Authorized to Invest in Titanium Dioxide Plant
DOC.TEXT: After a four-year wait, South Korea has authorized E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.'s application to build a $97 million titanium dioxide plant jointly with a local firm, the Finance Ministry said Friday. Officials said the proposed plant will be capable of producing anually 60,000 tons of titanium dioxide, a white crystaline compound used as a paint pigment. The American company will put up $77.6 million and control 80 percent of the venture, with the remaining 20 percent invested by Hanyang Chemical Corp., officials said. Strong opposition by local environmentalists who feared pollution had delayed the approval. Sources said the U.S. government recently intervened to get the project approved. The Ministry officials said the approval was conditioned on du Pont burying waste from production. Du Pont is expected to market the product at home and abroad. There is now one small domestic producer. Officials said the final approval came Thursday when the Foreign Capital Project Review Committee met. Hanyang and Du Pont have yet to pick a site for the plant, according to Hanyang officials who did not say when the plant will begin operation. One press report said it will take about three years to build the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Ban Against Multiple Listings Ends Monday for New Options
DOC.TEXT: After some mixed signals from federal regulators earlier this month, the nation's five options exchanges are set to begin trading on new listings Monday. But most exchanges will be offering new options on far fewer stocks than originally planned because the Securities and Exchange Commission, which regulates options, hasn't changed its rules yet. Options are financial instruments that give holders that right to buy or sell 100 shares of a stock at a designated price for a certain amount of time. Options are traded on stocks listed on exchanges or traded over the counter. Currently, most options on the stocks listed on an exchange can only be traded in one marketplace at a time. The privilege of trading a specific option, assigned by lottery, is not permitted on any other exchange. But thanks to a rule passed by the SEC last May, that exclusivity will end on Jan. 22. The new SEC rule will allow for the multiple listing of all options. But earlier this month, SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden asked the exchanges to voluntarily limit their multiple listings to new options while maintaining the exclusivity of listings for existing options. Breeden asked the exchanges to delay phasing in the existing options until June to allow development of some way to link all the markets so investors can have access to the best deal. ``The allocation plan or lottery is abolished as of Monday for new options,'' said Bonnie Greenberg of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the world's biggest options exchange. On Monday, the American Stock Exchange in New York will list options in the stock of Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc., Racal Telecom PLC and Sotheby's Holdings PLC. Options on Sotheby's also will be offered on the CBOE and the Pacific Stock Exchange. But all of those exchanges had planned to list many more options, expecting new rules that would lower the eligibility requirements for stocks to have options listed. The SEC, however, informed the exchanges earlier this month that the lower requirements hadn't been approved yet and the old standards were still in effect. ``We intended to trade 31 options if certain requirements were met,'' said Roy Berces, a spokesman for the Pacific Stock Exchange. Instead, he said, the Pacific exchange will be listing just three options: Norwest Corp., Sundstrand Corp. and Sotheby's. The other options exchanges in this country are the New York Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: United Technologies Adopts New Ethics Code
DOC.TEXT: United Technologies Corp. on Friday announced that the company is adopting a new ethics code governing the professional conduct of the company and its 185,000 employees. The announcement came a little more than a year after the defense giant came under scrutiny during a Pentagon investigation into military procurement practices, but a company spokesman said the probe had nothing to do with the new ethics policy. In outlining the plan during a meeting Friday with top executives that was telecast to 13 UTC offices around the country, Robert F. Daniell, UTC chairman and chief executive officer, said the code was drafted in response to increased public attention on corporate ethics in recent years. ``UTC top management and its board of directors decided that public expectations should be addressed by issuing a code of ethics which clearly states the corporation's principles and established standards of conduct,'' Daniell said in a statement. The Pentagon's procurement investigation began in the fall of 1988 and focused on allegations that U.S. defense officials were bribed for confidential contract information. UTC spokeswoman Peg Hashem said Daniell was asked by an employee on Friday about whether the new policy was a response to the investigation. Hashem quoting Daniell as responding ``absolutely not.'' ``He said that over the past several years, we have placed a lot of emphasis on defense-related issues in the ethics area, and about mid-year of 1989, top management began discussions about whether we shouldn't broaden our focus and come up with a comprehensive ethics code that we would apply across UTC, both for our commercial and aerospace side,'' said Ms. Hashem. ``It's not that we didn't have an ethics code before. We did,'' she said. ``We had lots of policies addressing ethics, but this was an effort to pull it together in a comprehensive way and we'll be applying it consistently across UTC.'' Pratt & Whitney, the jet engine division of UTC, became a focus of the probe amid allegations that a company official had obtained confidential contract information from General Electric Co., a chief competitor for military jet engine contracts. The probe, dubbed ``Ill Wind'' by federal officials, is ongoing, a congressional source who insisted on anonymity said Friday. In his remarks to employees, Daniell said the new code ``spells out'' what the company can and cannot do in its worldwide operations. ``We can and should take great pride in our reputation, and we must commit ourselves to its continuation as the basis for our future success,'' he said. Daniell also announced the formation of a new business practices unit to oversee the new ethics code. The office will be made up of a network of business practices officers at each of the company's operating units. The officers will be available for employees to obtain information, guidance and interpretation relating to the ethics code. Frank W. McAbee, former vice president-government contracts and compliance, has been named vice president of business practices, and will oversee the new unit and be in charge of enforcing the new code.

DOC.HEAD: Gibson Resigns As President Of American Federal
DOC.TEXT: William E. Gibson, who put together one of the initial Southwest Plan thrift rescues, has resigned as head of American Federal Bank, the steel company that owns the institution said Friday. Lone Star Technologies Inc. gave no reason for Gibson's departure as president, chief executive officer and a director. American Federal officials referred all calls to Lone Star spokeswoman Judith A. Murrell, who declined to elaborate beyond an official statement. Gibson, 45, was not in his office Friday and calls to his home were not returned. Lone Star said American Federal's executive committee will manage the thrift until a successor is named. American Federal was created in August 1988 from 12 insolvent thrifts in one of the first applications of the Southwest Plan, where regulators brought in capital from outside the industry to rescue the institutions. The Gibson Group, which included Gibson and six others, persuaded Lone Star to participate in the plan. Although the deal was the fifth under the Southwest Plan, it was the first to bring in non-traditional investors. Lone Star spent $48 million to acquire the institutions, which together had assets of about $2.4 billion and liabilities of $3 billion. The federal government also provided Lone Star a $499 million note and $1.31 billion in assistance. According to figures from Sheshunoff Information Services Inc. in Austin, Texas, American Federal now is the 11th-largest thrift in the state with $3.04 billion in assets, a third of it in repossessed assets. In the first nine months of 1989, American Federal earned $7.05 million. In all of 1988, earnings were $6.7 million. Since he took over the thrift, Gibson and American Federal have been cited as examples of a successful transaction under the Southwest Plan. Before he went to American Federal, Gibson was executive vice president of Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Co. in Chicago. Previously, he was a senior vice president at RepublicBank Corp. in Dallas and had served in the Nixon administration as senior staff economist on the Council of Economic Advisors. Dallas-based Lone Star is a holding company whose principal subsidiary, Lone Star Steel Co., an oil field pipe and services company, is operating under bankruptcy court supervision. Last year Lone Star pared off all its subsidiaries except American Federal and Lone Star Steel.

DOC.HEAD: Newsletter Publishes Story After Fighting Court Order
DOC.TEXT: A business newsletter, ordered last week to halt publication of an article containing confidential information about a major accounting firm, sent out a special edition Friday with the story. The move came one day after a New York state appellate judge ruled that the information, already published by The New York Times, could not be kept sealed by a lower court and ordered the documents released to the news media. Arthur Bowman, editor of Bowman's Accounting Report, said the four-page special edition contained the article about Ernst & Young he was forced to kill earlier this month. Between the time of the restraining order Jan. 8 and the appeals court action on Thursday, the Times also obtained the information and published a story. ``We have already published,'' Bowman said Friday. ``It's in the mail.'' The special edition of Bowman's also contains an editor's note about the legal battle. ``We deeply regret finding ourselves embroiled in a legal dispute with a respected member of the (accounting) profession,'' the message said. ``However, we also feel strongly that protection of the First Amendment overrides other considerations. ``We are pleased to put this episode behind us.'' The Atlanta newsletter's fight with Ernst & Young drew the interest of many large news organizations, several of whom joined in support of Bowman's. Ernst & Young contended that the information in the articles was proprietary, and the firm's lawyers compared it with Coca-Cola's secret formula. The news organizations, who joined Bowman's in charging that New York Supreme Court Judge Beatrice Shainswit's original order was an unconstitutional abridgement of press freedom, include The Associated Press, the Society of Professsional Journalists, The New York Times, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, The Wall Street Journal, the Newsletter Association, the New York Daily News, Newsday and American Lawyer. Also submitting a friend of the court brief on behalf of Bowman's was the New York Civil Liberties Union. The Bowman's article contained information similar to that which was in the newspaper story about the firm that resulted from the merger of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young. Among other things, the articles said Ernst & Whinney partners take home roughly 65 percent of profits earned jointly with Arthur Young for the next three years, while Arthur Young's partners share the rest. Bowman said the current newsletter was his second special edition, the first one coming last May when he broke the story of the Ernst & Whinney-Arthur Young merger. The regular January edition of Bowman's had a black space with the word ``Censored'' in the area where the Ernst & Young story was to have appeared.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Bank of New England, 2nd Ld-Writethru, f0210,0776
DOC.HEAD: Bank Expects $1.05 Billion Annual Loss; Wants To Sell $6 Billion In Assets
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 10th graf to CORRECT ``of'' to ``or'' in quote, add quotation marks; picks up 11th graf pvs bg'ng, The recent ...
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. said Friday it expects to report a $1.05 billion loss for 1989 and said it was ``actively pursuing'' the sale of more than $6 billion in assets. The company, New England's second-largest bank holding company after Bank of Boston Corp., issued a statement that also said it expected to enter a consent order with federal regulators to reshape the company's operations. Analysts said a mounting pile of bad real estate loans, a reflection of the slump throughout the region, made Bank of New England a growing target for a federal takeover. ``It's like `Do they survive?' time,'' said Virginia Adair, a banking analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in New York. ``The odds are increasingly slim.'' Bank of New England's stock tumbled after the company's announcement, falling $1.37{ to $2.87{ a share in New York Stock trading. It was the day's most active stock, with 6.76 million shares changing hands. The company said it expected to report a loss of approximately $1.2 billion for the fourth quarter _ making its annual loss about $1.05 billion _ after boosting its reserves against possible credit losses to $1.65 billion. The company, which has seen its assets shrink in the last quarter from around $32 billion to $29 billion, said it expected to have $2.25 billion in non-performing assets, mostly troubled real estate loans. Standard & Poor's said Friday it was slightly lowering its credit rating for Bank of New England's senior and subordinated debt, certificates of deposit and debt issues supported by letters of credit. The Wall Street credit rating agency said its action reflected the continuing deterioration of Bank of New England's loan portfolio. S&P said the company's reserves appeared adequate to cover ``currently identified problem assets.'' ``Earnings prospects, however, are poor, given the high level of nonperforming assets and pricing pressure upon the company's financing,'' S&P said in a news release. ``With reduced capital levels, the company has little financial flexibility to address any further deterioration in loan quality or any other problems that may develop.'' The recent real estate slump has hurt many banks, but analysts said Bank of New England was one of the biggest victims because its growth was based largely on an aggressive lending strategy during a construction boom earlier in the 1980s. Analysts say the bank financed some loans that in retrospect look questionable. Now, with the real estate market declining, developers are having trouble making loan payments. The bank has come under increased scrutiny by federal regulators. Last month, Chairman Walter Connolly said he was relinquishing his role as chief executive officer. Bank of New England said Friday it expects to enter consent orders with the Federal Reserve Board and the federal comptroller of the currency. Dean DeBuck, a spokesman for the comptroller's office in Washington, D.C., said the order would be issued soon, although he declined to be specific, and said it would outline steps the bank has to take ``to restore its weakened condition.'' The order should contain directives to raise more capital and improve management controls over lending, he said. But DeBuck said in general terms that by agreeing to sign a consent order, a bank would not necessarily avoid a possible federal takeover. ``It can go either way,'' he said. ``If it can raise capital, then it strengthens the bank. If it can't raise capital, then it doesn't strengthen the bank.'' The bank has been trying to raise money through the sale of assets. Earlier this week, federal regulators reportedly rejected a tentative agreement for Bank of New England to sell some subsidiaries to Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc. in Providence, R.I. Analysts say the bank would have a hard time finding another bank or investor to take over the company, and the federal government would not likely approve the sale of its stronger subsidiaries because that would leave the bank in worse financial shape. Among the assets Bank of New England is selling are $1 billion in leasing assets, $1.3 billion in home equity loans and $3 billion in commercial loans. To cut costs, the bank said it had consolidated many operations, resulting in the elimination of $35 million in annual expenses and 900 staff positions through attrition, sales and cutbacks.
